Similar to her character in Vince Gilliganâ€™s sci-fi series Pluribus, star Rhea Seehorn ventured into the uncanny valley of the Others â€” most of the worldâ€™s population, now a mass collective of humans conjoined mentally via an extraterrestrial signal â€” with […]
content:
Spoiler alert: The following article contains details about the Season 1 finale of Pluribus.

Similar to her character in Vince Gilliganâ€™s sci-fi series Pluribus, star Rhea Seehorn ventured into the uncanny valley of the Others â€” most of the worldâ€™s population, now a mass collective of humans conjoined mentally via an extraterrestrial signal â€” with a distinct lack of information. However, unlike her fictional stand-in, the grouchy romantasy author Carol Sturka, she did so without fear.

Gilligan has been forthright during the press rounds for the popular Apple TV show, now the streamerâ€™s most-watched in history, that he penned the sprawling series with Better Call Saulâ€™s shrewd Kim Wexler in mind. For Seehorn, it was equally a no-brainer.

Watch on Deadline

â€œI think especially as women, we sometimes want to know exactly where youâ€™re going to take the character, because what if weâ€™re not going to really be used? What if the character wonâ€™t be allowed to evolve in any way? I already know heâ€™s not going to do that,â€ she tells Deadline of the role.

Carol is abrasive, challenging and deeply relatable. Despite being â€œextremely impulsive and extremely reactive,â€ her decisions are propelled by a deep sense of loss, righteous anger and, as Seehorn describes it, â€œpassionate rage.â€ What drew the three-time Emmy nominee to the part even further wasnâ€™t just the characterâ€™s â€œchallengingâ€ complexity, but also the content of the show, which makes legible philosophical queries that have plagued our species since inception.

Below, Seehorn chats about Carolâ€™s intractable grief, the joys of creativity and why her characterâ€™s Season 1 finale decision is a â€œcompletely normal response to a breakup.â€

DEADLINE: First off, congratulations on the Golden Globe nomination â€” so well deserved. Creator Vince Gilligan has said he wrote this part for you, but aside from working with him again, what drew you to this character?

RHEA SEEHORN: It literally just was Vince. Even if he didnâ€™t write it for me, Vince just saying, â€˜I have a project for youâ€™ â€” because of his style of collaboration, the sets he creates, the department heads he surrounds himself with, the civility he conducts his sets with and then the writing itself is just the best foundation youâ€™ll ever have to try to build a character. And I didnâ€™t have any fear about it. He didnâ€™t even tell me what it was going to be about. I had no idea. And I said, â€˜Itâ€™s fine, just yes.â€™ And he said, â€˜Well, no, you can wait and read it first.â€™ I said, â€˜I donâ€™t need to.â€™

I think especially as women, we sometimes want to know exactly where youâ€™re going to take the character, because what if weâ€™re not going to really be used? What if the character wonâ€™t be allowed to evolve in any way? I already know heâ€™s not going to do that. Then, once I got the script, I would imagine I had a similar reaction to many people who watched the pilot, which is, â€˜This is bananas. What is happening, and where are we going from here?â€™ His scripts â€¦ have pace and tone in them, so you have that breathless journey as you do when youâ€™re watching them; theyâ€™re really fun reads.

And I also could see all these genres that he was playing with and then turning them on their ear. I could also see these tone shifts that then got even wilder in swings once weâ€™re working on performing them. I was like, â€˜Was that comedy that just happened in the middle of that horribly dark moment?â€™ I was like, â€˜Wow, this is going to be challenging, and so much fun.â€™ And I just got really excited. And my first thought was, â€˜Oh, this would be a show for me as a watcher.â€™ Iâ€™d be so excited about this show, plot-wise and character-wise, but then also the profound questions it brings up about what it means to be human.

Rhea Seehorn as Carol Sturka in â€˜Pluribusâ€™ (Apple TV)

As a creative person, probably the most horrifying idea is that you canâ€™t create something new in this world. In the show, you have to balance the overwhelming loss that is catapulting all of Carolâ€™s decisions, and the tightrope she walks between wanting answers, wanting to fix things, and inadvertently contributing to suffering in a world that is now devoid of it. Were those discussions something that you were exploring as you stepped into this world?

Vince wasnâ€™t writing to a particular theme or a topic. Many people have felt like: Is this commentary on AI? Is this commentary on the pandemic lockdown, divisiveness in our country, zealotry of any kind, community versus the individual? And he wasnâ€™t writing to any of those themes; he was writing about human nature, but he does live in the world weâ€™re living in.

I, too, believe that when Iâ€™m playing the part, Carol is not viewing this as a theoretical debate topic. She does not have the luxury of thinking about this philosophically. Itâ€™s only when it comes up practically as far as wrestling with the debate of, â€˜Am I allowed to believe that these people really care about me? Do I really think these people are a threat? What kind of threat are they?â€™ So I wasnâ€™t really looking at it in an ideological way either, but I certainly had some really fun late-night conversations with my crew on weekends, of just the questions it brings up. Not only what would you do, but how do you redefine the idea of love? Is true love only when itâ€™s unique to you? And is there something wrong with me that I might appraise some art as high art and some art as low art, or real writing versus not real? What is that? As long as it makes one person happy, isnâ€™t it all the same? Is there something wrong with me that I actually love to be competitive with myself, and that I always want to get better at every scene I do? I hope I become a better and better actor, but would I be OK if everybody was brilliant? I donâ€™t know.

And to your point, one of the biggest things for me, is the joy of being surprised by what others have created, whether itâ€™s a book or a song or a play or someone elseâ€™s performance or art, a joke â€” to ever have a real belly gut laugh at something, again, necessitates surprise. But I suppose the others would argue: But they are in awe of everything; everything is beautiful.

I donâ€™t think itâ€™s for me, though.

Manousos is both a parallel and a foil of sorts to Carol. They are driven by similar things, are stubborn and angry â€” very relatably so. But the way Carlos-Manuel Vesga put it was that Carol has everything but no purpose, and he has purpose but has nothing. Iâ€™m curious how you view that, or if you view it similarly.

Was he speaking about Carol before [the Joining]?

No, after.

I deeply disagree then.

How great is Carlos-Manuel though? Weâ€™re all a bunch of complete nerds that sit around talking about deep-dive script analysis of characters. It would bore anybody else to tears but Carlos-Manuel has definitive opinions about what the other characters are or think or are doing that sometimes we do not, and we have a very good time and a good laugh about debating him sometimes. He has not told me that one.

Carol absolutely has purpose. He may have gone through the DariÃ©n Gap because of his purpose, but Carol, thinking that she needs to save the world, lifted a 500-pound gorilla called grief off her chest every single morning, and every glance out that window by the back kitchen sink, and every paver she put down, and no matter how exhausted she was [while] digging the grave for [her] own wife, gets back up; gets back up when she sees a barcode on the bag.

Carlos-Manuel Vesga as Manousos Oviedo in â€˜Pluribusâ€™ (Apple TV)

She is addicted to having a purpose, in my opinion. Sure, itâ€™s a distraction from the overwhelming feeling of being bereft and having lost everything but even her stuff with Zosia, when she capitulates to this relationship â€” someone had asked me earlier: Is the act of beginning to write another novel another distraction of playing house? I said, â€˜No, to me, thatâ€™s the whole other love of her life, was her career and being a writer,â€™ and to have it completely taken away from you â€” thereâ€™s no one to write for anymore. When these people come and say, â€˜Actually, no, youâ€™re the only person in the whole world that could write a new book for us, and we are eagerly awaiting.â€™ And her little ego of, â€˜I could have fans again,â€™ and the part of her thatâ€™s like, â€˜Thereâ€™s a reason for me to get out of bed and put pants on tomorrow?â€™ Even amidst this new love affair, sheâ€™s up and out of that bed. I know that feeling of having the 4:30 a.m. call, and no matter how early it is, youâ€™re so happy to have the call.

Sheâ€™s lacking [in] ways to get to her purpose, and is very, very impulsive and is very, very reactive, but yeah, heâ€™s without purpose, that guy! Come on, youâ€™re just gonna obliterate everybody? Howâ€™s that gonna save mankind?

They do both take the paths of most resistance â€” digging the grave, refusing to take a plane â€” so that does show persistence in going after something.

Theyâ€™ve definitely met each otherâ€™s match in the department of being a stubborn ass.

You said Carolâ€™s impulsive, which she totally is, but I also find that she is somewhat deliberate in that impulsivity. I read in an interview that youâ€™re constantly thinking about why sheâ€™s doing what sheâ€™s doing, like, â€˜Why is she choosing to sleep on the couch when she can sleep on the bed?â€™ Thereâ€™s just so much going on in her brain, and sheâ€™s at war with herself. How do you view that, and how do you bring that to your performance?

The script analysis work Iâ€™m doing as an actor is where the â€˜whyâ€™ comes in, so Iâ€™ve thought about: â€˜Why did she fall asleep on the couch and fall asleep drinking?â€™ But Carol, in the moment, did it instinctively; itâ€™s like hot coals to go up that staircase that early â€” â€˜I couldnâ€™t possibly look at her side of the bed.â€™ So when Iâ€™m playing her, and sheâ€™s very deliberate at times, I find her extremely impulsive and extremely reactive with a lot of passionate rage. And all of these things at times can be her superpower, but at times the biggest thing in our way is this behavior.

So even though I, as the actor, may try to think about whatâ€™s the â€˜whyâ€™ that she did it, if Iâ€™m trying to play somebody who keeps acting impulsively and reactively, you then take out that transition. So even in our lives, when we have an impulsive reaction to something, if you were to go back and go like, â€˜Why did I bark at that family member way too loudly when they commented on my dress?â€™ And then you go home and you realize, like, â€˜Because there was someone else at the table that [is] always remarking on my clothes, and I picked this dress up specifically, and I had already gotten insulted that morning.â€™ And there was a â€˜why,â€™ but you didnâ€™t think about it at that moment; you just screamed at your cousin.

(L-R): Rhea Seehorn and Karolina Wydra in the Season 1 finale of â€˜Pluribusâ€™ Apple TV

One of the things I wanted to wrap up with was, Carol almost goes on this circular journey from pilot to finale, where she comes back to her purpose, as we discussed. And thereâ€™s the atom bomb that she requests, which I loved so much.

[Laughs] Completely normal response to a breakup, donâ€™t you think?

Yeah, I wish I could do that. But if you could expand on or describe whatâ€™s going on in her head at that moment. Is it a bargaining chip? Is it a threat? Is it a sign of despair? Is it all of these things or none of these things?

Iâ€™m not trying to be evasive, I actually think you nailed it. It is all of these things and none of these things. I went and asked Vince, like, â€˜Do you know exactly what her plan is with it?â€™ And he said, â€˜No.â€™ And I think he was being honest; I know theyâ€™re in the writersâ€™ room now writing Season 2.

Normally, I do supply my own reason, just so that my acting will have specificity to it. This was one of the rare cases where I thought: It is an impulsive, highly reactionary, highly angry, highly hurt decision. â€˜Iâ€™m going to ask for the largest, most destructive, horrible thing I could, and Iâ€™ll figure out the rest later.â€™ I think itâ€™s even more rash that she doesnâ€™t have a plan. Thatâ€™s my opinion.

I think itâ€™s just [that] she wanted to make a huge statement. And sheâ€™s so hurt and so angry and doesnâ€™t know what to do and is so overwhelmed by the choices sheâ€™s been left [with]. I mean, for one, sheâ€™s got to go pair up with Machete Dude? I mean, seriously, thatâ€™s my only teammate now? Maybe DiabatÃ© [played by Samba Schutte], if he stops having sex with them; at least I know he doesnâ€™t want to be changed. Sheâ€™s not super happy about the picks for her team for kickball, I could say that, so she gets an atom bomb! I kind of had fun with the delivery of that last line, too. Just kind of like: â€˜I donâ€™t need to explain to you why I got it; itâ€™s an atom bomb, whatever.â€™

This conversation has been edited and condensed for concision and clarity.

content:
Disney Studios continues to show the power of the theatrical window as the Burbank, CA lot is officially crossing the $6 billion worldwide threshold today.

Broken out thatâ€™s $2.3B domestic, the best for any major motion picture studio stateside YTD, and $3.65B in international B.O.

We told you this was coming, but with the $450M+ and counting global success of James Cameronâ€™s Avatar: Fire and Ash, it happened a few days sooner.

Disney is the first and only studio to cross $6B this year, the next best major is Warner Bros with $4.3B. 2025 repped Disneyâ€™s biggest year at the B.O. since 2019 when it an all-time $13.1B ($11.1B from Disney titles alone, the rest being 20th Century Studios and Searchlight). That was the first and only time a major motion picture studio crossed $10B at the worldwide B.O. Note, Warner Bros, crossed $4B first this year before any other motion picture studio.

This is Disneyâ€™s fifth time clicking past $6B, the previous years being 2019, 2018, 2017 and 2016.

Watch on Deadline

Disneyâ€™s flew to $6B this year off the heels of 16 wide releases including two $1 billion-plus grossing titles with Zootopia 2 ($1.3B to date) and Lilo & Stitch ($1.038 billion) â€” the only two MPA titles to cross that mark. There were also three Marvel Studios movies which combined topped $1.3B global: The Fantastic Four: First Steps, Thunderbolts* and Captain America: Brave New World. In addition there was Predator: Badlands which became the highest grossing in the 38-year old sci-fi thriller franchise with a near $184M as well as Freakier Friday ($153.1M). Not faring well, but contributing to the pot were Tron Ares ($142.2M), and Pixarâ€™s Elio ($154.2M).

Avatar: Fire and Ash collected $50.8M worldwide yesterday, $16.5M of that coming from North America. The running total of the Cameron, Amanda Silver, Rick Jaffa, Josh Friedman & Shane Salerno story by threequel is $119M domestic, with $331.1M overseas. China continues to lead all offshore results with $67M.

As we reported previously, Fire and Ash repped the second biggest global opening for a MPA title this year with $347M after Disneyâ€™s own Zootopia 2 ($560.3M). The threequel also repped the second biggest global opening for Cameron after 2022â€™s Avatar: Way of Water at $441.7M (historically reported).

title: Park Chan-Wookâ€™s â€˜No Other Choiceâ€™, â€˜The Testament Of Ann Leeâ€™ & â€˜The Plagueâ€™ Step Into Holiday Frame â€“ Specialty Preview
summary: Marty Supreme goes wide with Song Sung Blue alongside a handful of notable limited releases from comedy thriller No Other Choice, summer camp scare The Plague and Venice Golden Lion-winner Father Mother Sister Brother, to Ralph Fiennes in The Choral and Amanda Seyfried-starring The Testament Of Ann Lee, all of which will all carry indie […]
content:
Marty Supreme goes wide with Song Sung Blue alongside a handful of notable limited releases from comedy thriller No Other Choice, summer camp scare The Plague and Venice Golden Lion-winner Father Mother Sister Brother, to Ralph Fiennes in The Choral and Amanda Seyfried-starring The Testament Of Ann Lee, all of which will all carry indie film into 2026. New openings this week are clustered on Wednesday and Thursday, Dec. 24 and 25, to open the long Christmas holiday weekend.

New limited releases: Independent Film Company debuts The Plague today at New Yorkâ€™s IFC Center and the Laemmle Royal in Los Angeles ahead of a nationwide expansion to about 500 screens on January 2. The film, which premiered at Cannes, sits at 100% on Rotten Tomatoes (off 29 reviews), see Deadlineâ€™s here. In the summer of 2003, at an all-boys summer water polo camp with Lord Of The Flies vibes, socially anxious twelve-year-old Ben (Everett Blunck) struggles to fit in amidst a ruthless social hierarchy. When he befriends Eli (Kenny Rasmussen) â€” a lonely, acne-ridden outcast shunned by the others for carrying a ficticious â€œplagueâ€ â€” Ben becomes entangled in an escalating ritual of scapegoating and fear where cruelty masquerades as a game.

Watch on Deadline

Taken from writer-director Charlie Polingerâ€™s own summer camp experiences, the cast if full of young newcomers including Rasmussen, Blunck and Kayo Martin as ringleader Jake. Joel Edgerton, a producer, plays camp counselor Daddy Wags.

The Plague nabbed three Film Independent Spirit Awards nominations for Best Feature, Best Lead Performance (Blunck) and Best Breakthrough Performance (Martin). Blunk was nominated for a Critics Choice Awards â€“ Best Young Actor. The film took prizes at the Deauville American Film Festival, Sitges, Fantastic Fest and Woodstock Film Festival.

Mubi debuts Jim Jarmuschâ€™s comedy Father Mother Sister Brother Dec. 24 at the Film Forum and Film at Lincoln Center in New York, and Landmark Nuart in Los Angeles. World premiered the Venice Film Festival where it won the top prize, the Golden Lion. See Deadline review. Was the Centerpiece of the New York Film Festival. Tom Waits, Adam Driver, Mayim Bialik, Charlotte Rampling, Cate Blanchett, Vicky Krieps, Indya Moore and Luka Sabbat star in the exploration of the universal intricacies of family dynamics told in the form of a triptych set in New Jersey, Dublin and Paris. Each story concerns the relationships between adult children, their somewhat distant parent (or parents), and each other. Expands nationally Jan. 9.

Neon opens Park Chan-wookâ€™s black comedy No Other Choice on Wednesday at 13 locations in five markets (NY, LA, San Francisco, Chicago, Austin). Based on Donald E. Westlakeâ€™s novel The Ax, the story follows Man-su (Lee Byung-hun) on a desperate hunt for a new job after his abrupt layoff from the paper company where he worked for 25 years. Premiered at Venice, see Deadline review, and went on to open the Busan International Film Festival, win the International Peopleâ€™s Choice Award at TIFF, and earn Park the Best Director Award at the Sitges Film Festival. At 99% Certified Fresh with critics on Rotten Tomatoes, itâ€™s South Koreaâ€™s Oscar-shortlisted entry for International Feature Film and has three Golden Globe nominations, for Motion Picture â€“ Musical or Comedy; Motion Picture â€“ Non-English Language; and Best Actor in a Motion Picture â€“ Musical or Comedy for Lee Byun-hun.

The Choral from Sony Pictures Classics opens Thursday in New York (Angelika, New Plaza Cinema) and LA (Laemmle Royal, AMC Burbank). Directed by BAFTA, Olivier and Tony Award winner Nicholas Hytner and written by BAFTA, Olivier and Tony Award winner Alan Bennett, in their fourth collaboration (after The Lady in the Van, The History Boys and The Madness of King George). The film follows a choral society in Yorkshire in 1916 whose male members enlist in World War I, leaving the demanding Dr. Guthrie, played by Ralph Fiennes, to recruit teenagers. Together, they experience the joy of singing while the young boys grapple with their impending conscription into the army. With Roger Allam, Amara Okereke, Simon Russell Beale, Thomas Howes. World premiered at TIFF.

Searchlight Pictures is out with Mona Fastvoldâ€™s biopic The Testament Of Ann Lee today in NYC (Village East by Angelika, AMC Lincoln Square) and LA. Premiered at Venice, Deadline review here. At 90% RT Certified Fresh. The story of Ann Lee, founder of the devotional sect known as the Shakers, who preached gender and social equality and was revered by her followers. The film captures Leeâ€™s quest to leave England and build a utopia in the New World and has nabbed star Amanda Seyfried a Golden Globe nomination for Best Actress in a Motion Picture â€“ Musical or Comedy. The film features traditional Shaker hymns reimagined as rapturous movements with choreography by Celia Rowlson-Hall and original songs and score by Academy Award winner Daniel Blumberg (The Brutalist). Screenplay by Mona Fastvold and The Brutalist director Brady Corbet.

Wide: Focus Features rolls out Craig Brewerâ€™s Song Sung Blue starring Hugh Jackman and Kate Hudson in 2,400 theaters. The duo play the real-life Mike and Claire Sardina, down-on-their-luck musicians who form a joyous Neil Diamond tribute band. Michael Imperioli, Ella Anderson, King Princess, Mustafa Shakir and Hudson Hensley also star, with Fisher Stevens and Jim Belushi. Song Sung Blue World premiered as the Closing Night Film at AFI Fest, see Deadline review. Hudson has a Golden Globe nomination and will be honored with the Icon Award at this yearâ€™s Palm Springs International Film Festival. She and Jackman were recognized for their performances with the inaugural Musical Tribute Award at the Gotham Film Awards earlier this month.

Josh Safdieâ€™s TimothÃ©e Chalamet-starring Marty Supreme from A24 put up the best limited opening of the year this past weekend at six theaters, setting the table nicely for a big jump to about 2,600 screens on Christmas Day. Chalamet, whose character is based on a brash New York shoe salesman turned ping pong champion, is up for a Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Motion Picture â€“ Musical or Comedy. The film â€“ 95% Rotten Tomatoes Certified Fresh â€” also has Globe noms for Best Motion Picture â€“ Musical or Comedy and Best Screenplay for Safdie and Ronald Bronstein.

As per Deadlineâ€™s Anthony Dâ€™Alessandro, Song Sung Blue, Marty Supreme (already at $1M) and Angel Studioâ€™s David are eyeing $12M-mid-teens apiece over four days. Marty Supreme could overindex.

title: â€˜Pluribusâ€™ Finale: Episode Writers On Carolâ€™s Last-Ditch Effort To â€œGive In,â€ The Hive Mindâ€™s â€œHideous Violationâ€ & The â€œFunâ€ Of Meeting Manousos
summary: Spoiler alert: The following article contains spoilers for the season finale of Pluribus. After traversing approximately 8,000 kilometers â€” some of it tedious, some of it harrowing â€” Carlos-Manuel Vesgaâ€™s obstinate Manousos Oviedo arrives in Albuquerque, on Carol Sturkaâ€™s (Rhea Seehorn) turf, expecting to find the same steadfast leader he glimpsed in her call-to-action home […]
content:
Spoiler alert: The following article contains spoilers for the season finale of Pluribus.

After traversing approximately 8,000 kilometers â€” some of it tedious, some of it harrowing â€” Carlos-Manuel Vesgaâ€™s obstinate Manousos Oviedo arrives in Albuquerque, on Carol Sturkaâ€™s (Rhea Seehorn) turf, expecting to find the same steadfast leader he glimpsed in her call-to-action home video urging remaining survivors to join her in saving the world.

But as the Season 1 finale of Pluribus unfolds, itâ€™s clear heâ€™s caught her unawares â€” in a state of limbo where her burgeoning romance with Zosia (Karolina Wydra) has overshadowed much else. As episode co-writer and executive producer Alison Tatlock tells Deadline, it was inevitable that the duoâ€™s first meeting â€œwould have to start as a disaster.â€

â€œBecause the timing is terrible,â€ she explains. â€œIf it had happened a couple episodes earlier, maybe weâ€™d have a different story, but by the time he gets there, sheâ€™s in a completely different headspace. We, in the script even, had a moment where we, in a stage direction, referred to her kind of vaguely remembering that she made videos where she was calling everyone into action; itâ€™s not where her head is at anymore. And thatâ€™s when he shows up, expecting the Carol Sturka that he saw on the video, and that person is a little bit dormant right now.â€

Watch on Deadline

Fellow co-writer, EP and director of the episode, Gordon Smith, adds, â€œAll those things that give grist to the mill were really fun to sort of tease out, and fun to see them not quite be the people that they even think of themselves. Carol thinks, â€˜No, I am a hero. Oh, wait, this guy just walked 8,000 miles [sic] to be here. Maybe I havenâ€™t done as much as I thought,â€™ and vice versa, I think.â€

Vesga, a prolific Colombian actor who was cast in the role after being up against 710 people, points out the differing stakes between his character and Carol.

â€œAt least when it all starts, they see the enemy in the Joining. I am not sure if their reasons and their motivations are the same,â€ he says. â€œI think they come from very different worlds. You have Carol, who is a first-class citizen of the world, and you have Manousos, whoâ€™s probably a fifth-class citizen of the world, who is a migrant from Colombia to Paraguay, with all that comes with migrating and leaving your life behind and experiencing the trauma of just landing somewhere else new, losing your world. And then the small, little world that heâ€™s managed to build in Paraguay is taken away from him, so his motivation is like, â€˜Hell no, not this time, not again.â€™â€

For Vesga, that means the two of them are approaching the problem of the Others in dichotomous ways.

â€œHereâ€™s a guy who has nothing in the world: no food, almost no clothes and yet he has purpose. And we cut from that guy and we go to Carol, who has, quote unquote, everything that she wants and has no purpose,â€ he says. â€œRheaâ€™s an amazing actor, but that one [scene], when sheâ€™s sitting in front of that firework, and she knows that it might kill her, and yet she stays there â€” that is one of the best performances Iâ€™ve ever seen. And I was thinking, â€˜There is someone who has everything and is without a purpose.â€™ They seem to be trying to [get] to the same place, but they are going [about it] in a different way for different reasons.â€ (Editorâ€™s note: Seehorn vehemently disagrees with this characterization, which you can read about here.)

Seehorn and Vesga in the Season 1 finale of â€˜Pluribusâ€™ ( Apple TV

As Manousos and Carol struggle to communicate â€” because of their mutual unwillingness to cede ground, similar caustic personalities (and certainly a language barrier doesnâ€™t help, though it does add to the scene earned levity) â€” the former crystallizes his concern: â€œDo you want to save the world, or save your girl?â€ The apt distillation of their conundrum (the episode is named â€œLa Chica o El Mundoâ€) is drawn into focus after Carol fires off a warning shot at Manousos as he triggers a seizure in the Others, not unlike she did some episodes ago. After conducting quasi-scientific experiments on representatives of the Hive, he reaches the conclusion that the Joining can be reversed; but as the Others pack up to leave Manousos, Carol goes with them.

As Smith characterizes it, the ensuing idyllic montage is Carolâ€™s last-ditch effort to â€œgive inâ€ to the collective.

â€œThatâ€™s really the essence of what we wanted to make it feel like, and that journey was the most beautiful, placid [thing],â€ he says. â€œCarolâ€™s giving herself this one chance to give in to the real temptation of the Others, which is, â€˜Hey, the worldâ€™s beautiful. Come see it with us.â€™ Essentially, â€˜Give in,â€™ and it needed, I think, for the fall at the end, to hit as hard as it can. Everything else needed to feel like it was just the best vacation, or best series of vacations, that you could possibly hope to take. So we tried to craft that â€” all of the sequence I feel like I was trying to make the transitions feel like they were gentle, and make the shooting feel like it was gentle.â€

Carol and Zosia stroll along sun-soaked beaches, take a bath in a luxurious Shanghai high-rise hotel and unwind with an aprÃ¨s-ski evening in (all shot in Big Sky, Montana; as creator Vince Gilligan jokes, â€œTheyâ€™re dressed for the beach, but theyâ€™re wearing galoshes to get through like a foot of snow and slush right outside the door.â€) Just when this domestic serenity reaches its tipping point, Carol stumbles upon an alarming truth: The Others have located the eggs she had frozen with Helen years ago and are actively working on transforming them into stem cells, a process that can take as little as a month.

Tatlock says of the Othersâ€™ ethical justifications in the matter: â€œWe talked about it a lot, like, â€˜What do they do? What will they not do? What line will they cross? What line would they not cross?â€™ And we agreed that, while they would not force Carol physically to have a procedure that would extract her stem cells, if she had already voluntarily given up her eggs in a previous chapter of her life, which she did, that that would fall under the banner of, not consent, but that would be accessible to them, and that it would not break any ethical rule in their minds. Of course, to her, it feels like a hideous violation. So thatâ€™s where they part ways.â€

Smith recalls there were â€œvarious pitches on the tableâ€ as the creative team discussed how the Others would inevitably acquire Carolâ€™s stem cells, given the collectiveâ€™s â€œspecificâ€ understanding of agency.

Gilligan notes of the dubious governing rules of the Othersâ€™ morality: â€œBut, maybe, if the eggs had already been fertilized, they wouldnâ€™t have been able to, right? Because they canâ€™t [actively interfere]. Boy, that opens up [a whole can of worms]. We talked many, many, many hours about this stuff. Itâ€™s a quagmire.â€

All episodes of Pluribus are streaming on Apple TV. Season 2 is in the works.

title: Mark Hamill on â€˜Star Warsâ€™ AI Deepfakes, Weighing Retirement and Voicing The Flying Dutchman in â€˜The SpongeBob Movieâ€™
summary: Mark Hamill didn’t plan on having such an active year. In January, the actor lost his home in the Palisades fires and was forced to relocate with his family. Just months later, the 74-year-old actor found himself promoting three major studio projects: Mike Flanagan’s life-affirming fantasy drama “The Life of Chuck” (streaming Dec. 26 on […]
content:
Mark Hamill didnâ€™t plan on having such an active year.

In January, the actor lost his home in the Palisades fires and was forced to relocate with his family. Just months later, the 74-year-old actor found himself promoting three major studio projects: Mike Flanaganâ€™s life-affirming fantasy drama â€œThe Life of Chuckâ€ (streaming Dec. 26 on Hulu), the adaptation of Stephen Kingâ€™s â€œThe Long Walkâ€ and now â€œThe SpongeBob Movie: Searching for SquarePants,â€ in which Hamill voices the ghoulish Flying Dutchman.

â€œYou canâ€™t really control it, but this was a really, really active year,â€ Hamill tells Variety. â€œI donâ€™t have anything lined up, so maybe next year wonâ€™t be so active.â€

Popular on Variety

Hamill weighed the idea of retirement after reprising Luke Skywalker in the â€œStar Warsâ€ sequel trilogy, wanting to hang up his cape while the going was still good. â€œAs much as an actor appreciates a good entrance,â€ he says, â€œyou want to find a way to end your career in a way where you can hold your head high.â€



That outlook shifted when Mike Flanagan offered him a part in â€œThe Fall of the House of Usher,â€ which reignited his excitement for the craft. â€œIt was a character part that wouldâ€™ve been routine in voiceover,â€ Hamill said. â€œIn voiceover, they donâ€™t care what you look like, so youâ€™re going to play many roles youâ€™d never get on camera. They cast with their ears, not their eyes.â€



Now firmly in his third act, voice acting has allowed Hamill to keep playing those juicy roles untethered from age or physicality. But as AI reshapes Hollywood, he remains wary of how his legacy â€” especially in future Disneyâ€™s â€œStar Warsâ€ projects â€” will live on. â€œItâ€™s hard to predict the future,â€ Hamill says, â€œbut I may have to ask my family if they want me in a Star Wars movie 30 years from now after Iâ€™m gone.â€



With Variety, Hamill discusses his approach to the Flying Dutchman, moving on from â€œStar Wars,â€ and why he quit Facebook.

Youâ€™ve had quite the year.



Yeah. When it rains, it pours.



How are you reflecting on the year as a whole? The Palisades fire in January, all these big movies â€” itâ€™s been a lot of ups and downs.

Itâ€™s remarkable. Iâ€™m in the business of escapism, and if I can take peopleâ€™s minds off the horrible headlines â€” especially for those affected by the fires â€” then Iâ€™ve done my job. A lot of things are unexpected. I did a show years ago called â€œRegular Show.â€ It has a cult following, but it ran for eight seasons. Iâ€™ve never been on a show that comes back. We did 40 new episodes, and they want to do 40 more.



Before â€œThe SpongeBob Movieâ€ starts, thereâ€™s this five-minute â€œNinja Turtlesâ€ short that plays. Did you see it?



I did.



It pokes fun at societyâ€™s over-reliance on ChatGPT. Has it been unsettling seeing AI-generated videos of you or Luke Skywalker? I saw one the other week of Luke talking to Ben Kenobiâ€™s Force Ghost and couldnâ€™t believe how realistic it looked.

I havenâ€™t seen that. Is it live-action or animated?



Itâ€™s live-action. It plays like a deleted scene from â€œReturn of the Jedi.â€

Gee, I havenâ€™t seen that. Itâ€™s one of those things where thereâ€™s a disconnect between the fan world and myself, in the sense that every actor does the job, and when the job is completed, they move on to the next project. They donâ€™t really hang on to it. And yet, â€œStar Warsâ€ is such a vital ongoing franchise. [Disney] is doing really well, and obviously, theyâ€™ve done more material since I left. But I had my time. Now Iâ€™m just a fan. I love â€œRogue One,â€ â€œMandalorian,â€ â€œAndor.â€ Theyâ€™re doing great without me.



Disney has a new partnership with OpenAI, where fans will now be able to generate short videos using characters from the â€œStar Warsâ€ universe. How does that sit with you?

Itâ€™s fascinating to see it develop, and Iâ€™m also apprehensive about how it will be used. The story of the AI-generated actress that got signed by a major agency is mind-boggling. Is she going to stay 33, or whatever her age is, forever? Itâ€™s obviously hard to predict the future, but I guess Iâ€™m gonna have to talk to my family about if they want me to be in a â€œStar Warsâ€ movie 30 years from now after Iâ€™m gone.



Itâ€™s cool to hear you lend your voice to The Flying Dutchman. How did you approach that iconic laugh, especially given comparisons to the Joker?

When I accepted the offer to be the Flying Dutchman, I thought it was a new character created just for this movie. I start to do my homework, and itâ€™s a character thatâ€™s been done for years by Brian Doyle-Murray. Iâ€™ve been a fan of his since â€œSaturday Night Live.â€ I loved him on Chris Elliottâ€™s show â€œGet a Life.â€ Heâ€™s just terrific. But I was too intimidated to listen to what he had done. I thought Iâ€™d better do my version, and Iâ€™ll listen to his later. With a character like a ghost pirate in the world of â€œSpongeBob,â€ you can go as big as you want. Itâ€™s like childrenâ€™s theater. There is no too big.

In terms of the Joker, when youâ€™re in the head of the character, I didnâ€™t see the parallels. Now that Iâ€™m sort of distanced from it, I can see how people find comparisons between the two. I love both characters in different ways, and theyâ€™re both fun to play.



Certain actors choose the route of retirement, but youâ€™ve stayed incredibly active. Do you think you could retire?

A few years ago, I started thinking, â€œIâ€™ve done a lot, maybe itâ€™s time to make a dignified exit.â€ As much as an actor appreciates a good entrance, you want to find a way to end your career in a way where you can hold your head high. The real turning point for me was meeting Trevor Macy and Mike Flanagan about â€œThe Fall of the House of Usher.â€ That made me excited about performing again because it was a character part that wouldâ€™ve been routine in voiceover. In voiceover, they donâ€™t care what you look like, so youâ€™re going to play many roles youâ€™d never get on camera. They cast with their ears, not their eyes.

You canâ€™t really control it, but this was a really, really active year. I donâ€™t have anything lined up, so maybe next year wonâ€™t be so active. When youâ€™re in your 20s and 30s, itâ€™s hard to think of yourself in your 50s and 60s, but I certainly didnâ€™t think Iâ€™d be on camera as long as Iâ€™ve been.



Are there any dreams you havenâ€™t achieved yet?

I wanted to go to Broadway, I did that. Iâ€™ve wanted to do animation ever since I found out that people did animated voices. In grade school, I saw Clarence Nash do Donald Duck on a Walt Disney show, and I really zeroed in on all my favorite shows. I learned who Mel Blanc was. I loved â€œRocky and Bullwinkle.â€ Iâ€™d go to the record stores to look at the back of the record albums to write down the names of the actors â€” because we didnâ€™t have the internet, you couldnâ€™t Google it. It was something I aspired to.

Itâ€™s a very unique job, and doing the Flying Dutchman is one of the reasons I love being an actor. And the fact that I got to play it in live-action segments. I mean, it was crazy fun. If people have even a fraction of the good time that Iâ€™m having doing this character, theyâ€™re in for the time of their lives.

They say in the movie that SpongeBob has the purest heart of an innocent. Before SpongeBob, that was Luke Skywalker for a lot of people. What gravitates you towards these optimistic characters?

I never forget the fact that we are in the business of escapism. These are troubled times. The movie is therapeutic in that regard. You go to something like â€œThe SpongeBob Movie,â€ you leave all your troubles behind. Itâ€™s healthy in troubling times to have an escape.

George Lucas mastered that escapism, but at its core, â€œStar Warsâ€ is a very anti-authoritarian story.

Well, thatâ€™s the thing. Itâ€™ll work on different levels, depending on your age. And youâ€™re right about George. The original â€œStar Warsâ€ was an allegory commenting on the Vietnam War. So thereâ€™s the resistance, the rebels, the Empire. Itâ€™s surprisingly relevant when you consider whatâ€™s going on in our country today.

Youâ€™re in the business of entertainment, but youâ€™ve also stayed very connected to politics and charities. Why is that important to you?

If youâ€™ve been lucky enough to be able to do what you love and make a living at it, you have a responsibility to pay back as best you can. Thatâ€™s why I love Make-A-Wish, and thatâ€™s what I use social media for. Iâ€™m not really overtly political on talk shows, but more so on Bluesky and Instagram. I left Twitter the day after the election because I didnâ€™t want to support anything that Elon Musk is involved in. I left Facebook in 2016 because I didnâ€™t like the way Zuckerberg handled Hillary. But who cares that I left Facebook? Itâ€™s a real lesson that youâ€™re only one voice in a country of over 300 million. So, get a grip and donâ€™t take yourself too seriously.

title: Pat Finn, a Second City Alum Known for Roles on â€˜The Middleâ€™ and â€˜Ed,â€™ Dies at 60
summary: Pat Finn, a veteran character actor best known for his roles on the TV comedies “The Middle,” “Ed” and “Marvin Marvin,” died Dec. 22 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 60. Finn worked steadily in film and TV from the mid-1990s on. Early in his career, he was a member of the Second […]
content:
Pat Finn, a veteran character actor best known for his roles on the TV comedies â€œThe Middle,â€ â€œEdâ€ and â€œMarvin Marvin,â€ died Dec. 22 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 60.

Finn worked steadily in film and TV from the mid-1990s on. Early in his career, he was a member of the Second City improv troupe, where he worked with Chris Farley.

Finnâ€™s most prominent role in recent years was a recurring character on â€œThe Middle,â€ the domestic comedy that ran on ABC from 2009 to 2018. He played Bill Norwood, a friendly but quirky neighbor of the Heck family at the heart of the series. On the Nickelodeon live-action series â€œMarvin Marvin,â€ Finn played the patriarch of a family who takes in an alien teenage boy from another planet.

Finnâ€™s long list of credits included guest shots on a host of notable TV series, from â€œSeinfeld,â€ â€œFriendsâ€ and â€œCurb Your Enthusiasm,â€ to â€œThe Goldbergs,â€ â€œTwo Broke Girls,â€ â€œYes, Dearâ€ and â€œThe Bernie Mac Show.â€ His film work included â€œDude, Whereâ€™s My Car,â€ â€œFunky Monkey,â€ â€œI Love You, Beth Cooper,â€ â€œItâ€™s Complicatedâ€ and â€œSelfie Dad.â€ He was also featured in commercial spots for H&R Block, DiGiorno Pizza and Toyota and the milk industryâ€™s â€œGot Milkâ€ campaign.

Popular on Variety

Finn grew up in Evanston, Ill. He graduated from Marquette University in 1987 with a degree in speech. Farley, the comic actor who went on to fame in â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ and movies who died in 1997 at age 33, was a classmate and rugby teammate of Finn, according to the Marquette University website.

After college, Finn worked in improv out of Chicago and joined the touring company of Second City. His big boost in TV came with a series regular role on â€œThe George Wendt Show,â€ which lasted only eight episodes on CBS in 1995. Finn and â€œCheersâ€ alum Wendt played bachelor brothers who run an auto repair shop in Madison, Wisconsin. From 1995 to 1997 he had a recurring role on CBSâ€™ â€œMurphy Brown.â€

Other TV roles on his long resume include â€œCaroline in the City,â€ â€œThat 70s Show,â€ â€œThe King of Queens,â€ â€œThird Rock From the Sun,â€ â€œAccording to Jim,â€ â€œLess Than Perfect,â€ â€œThe Drew Carey Show,â€ â€œMy Boys,â€ â€œThe Suite Life of Zack and Codyâ€ and â€œWizards of Waverly Place.â€

Finn is survived by his wife, Donna, and three children.

title: Elizabeth Chan, Famous for Releasing a New Holiday Album Each Year, on Making Her 15th, â€˜Christmas Unhinged,â€™ About Doing the Season After a Divorce
summary: Elizabeth Chan is in her 15th consecutive year of releasing a new Christmas album every year, and going through a divorce and becoming a single mom was not about to put a stop to that personal and professional tradition. She considers all 15 of those records to be reflective of where she was in the […]
content:
Elizabeth Chan is in her 15th consecutive year of releasing a new Christmas album every year, and going through a divorce and becoming a single mom was not about to put a stop to that personal and professional tradition. She considers all 15 of those records to be reflective of where she was in the year leading up to the season, and the fact that home-and-hearth look a little different for her in 2025 is duly reflected in â€œChristmas Unhinged.â€

The title of this yearâ€™s release is a reference to Hinge, which has been Chanâ€™s post-divorce dating app of choice this past year. She could have gone with something a little cornier, because, as she jokes, â€œThis chapter is called â€˜Single Bells, Single All the Way.'â€

In all seriousness, Chan says, â€œI felt like I could really speak to everyone that listens to my Christmas music and Christmas music lovers everywhere to understand what kind of Christmas I was having this year, and why itâ€™s OK to live Christmas not just in, like, a snow globe of time, but as an actual living, lived experience.â€

Popular on Variety

Perhaps youâ€™re familiar with Chan for the legend that has built up around her as the only artist of note to have devoted her recorded output exclusively to Christmas music, which was a hot take a decade ago, let alone 15 years into her unbroken streak. Or perhaps you became aware of her as the artist who put up a challenge to Mariah Carey, and prevailed; Carey attempted to trademark the term â€œQueen of Christmas,â€ and Chan went to court to block it, contending that she had also been using it or had it applied to her going back as many or more years. (Carey eventually stopped further action in the trademark pursuit, leading the judge to dismiss it and leave the slogan in the public domain.) If youâ€™re unfamiliar with any of those parts of Chanâ€™s story, you can retrace the footprints through the snow via previous Variety articles, including this origin story.

But for 2025, we had a very-late-in-the-season catchup with Chan about whether â€œChristmas Unhingedâ€ is officially a divorce album, and what itâ€™s been like to return the dating field and eventually have to explain to all possible suitors just what it is that sheâ€™s known for.

The answer might be evident to anyone who knows you, but the question is: Why put out a Christmas album that reflects your divorce?

This is definitely new emotional territory for me. But if you step back and look at all 15 chapters of my life in Christmas music, what makes my Christmas music so distinctive is that at the end of the year where weâ€™re all taking inventory of where we are in our milestones of living, I curate my albums to capture the snapshot of where I am. And if Iâ€™m getting divorced, there are millions of other people just like me, who are facing the holidays without their spouse or without their family members as they know it, or their traditions have been upended. Iâ€™m not the only one. So itâ€™s a tremendous honor to be able to create the kind of Christmas songs that are lacking if we only hold onto â€œA Holly Jolly Christmas.â€ I can grow with my Christmas canon and share some songs that might inspire others to embrace all of the holiday season â€” the good, the bad and the unknown.

Would you go so far as to call this your Christmas divorce record?

I think that last year was more my Christmas divorce record, with the album I called â€œShatterproof.â€ I actually filed for divorce last year and I was going through so much internal turmoil, but I wasnâ€™t ready to share it all yet. I processed the impending end of my marriage in the last album as safely as I could process it. I only do Christmas music, but this is how I process my emotions as an artist; itâ€™s very cathartic to me. â€œChristmas Unhingedâ€ is what happens once I decided to be divorced and embark on rediscovering myself, not focusing so much on the pain of divorce, but the opportunity of becoming who Iâ€™m meant to be in the second act of my life. As a single mom, itâ€™s a beautiful thing. You know, divorce starts very sad, but thereâ€™s so much opportunity, because once youâ€™ve been so down, the only place you can go is up, and Iâ€™ve never felt more myself in many years than I do right now.

You have talked on your social media about what itâ€™s like to date now as the self-proclaimed Queen of Christmas and how men react to that.

Especially while I was dating people during the beginning of the Christmas season, which is around September, I started to get really nervous, because this is when I cannot hide this aspect of my life. First of all, I have not even dated in 20 years. So when I had to start even contemplating going out on dates again, and then downloading an app, going through hundreds and hundreds of random pictures and trying to decide, â€œHey, do I wanna date you, Random Picture?,â€ itâ€™s the weirdest thing in the whole world, right? And I got very, very frustrated in the process. So I ended up writing a non-Christmas song called â€œLove Me Right or Leave Me Alone,â€ which is sincerely my Hinge-dating mission-status song.

Also, I did a Beatles cover on this record, â€œSomething,â€ because I feel like there wasnâ€™t a proper female version of that song. And as I was meeting new guys and going on all these dates, Iâ€™d be like, â€œOh yeah, thereâ€™s something about him.â€ And then I sang it for myself and I put it on Hinge as my mating call.

You got your Beatles on with this record, doubly, because you also covered John Lennonâ€™s â€œHappy Xmas (War Is Over),â€ which you retitled â€œHappy Ex-mas.â€

I do covers only if they transform in the way that I relate to lyrics. When I got divorced, I started to really think about the lyrics to that song, and the one lyric that really helped me in the studio get through all of my pain of divorce was the lyric â€œWar is over if you want it.â€ Right when youâ€™re in the middle of a divorce, those words are so powerful. And so that is really a message to my ex-husband. Which is not the original intent of the song. But having sung it the way that I did and even retitling it â€œHappy Ex-Masâ€ â€” sorry, Yoko, if youâ€™re not happy about that! â€” the way that it came out was super cathartic.

Going back to your dating experiences this year, what was it like to tell people what you are famous for?

Iâ€™ve dated tons of different types of people from all ethnicities and creeds and cultures, and they get to know me as Elizabeth, and theyâ€™ll connect with me if theyâ€™re also going through divorce or if theyâ€™re single parents. But sometimes the minute that they find out Iâ€™m the queen of Christmas, itâ€™s like a needle drops. Itâ€™s like, â€œWhat does this mean? Do you know Iâ€™m Jewish?â€ or something like that, and Iâ€™m like, yeah, it doesnâ€™t matter. But it can become very challenging to people. Itâ€™s just been pure comedy.

Maybe they imagine itâ€™s like the Tim Allen movie, and they think they will date you and then they suddenly turn into Santa Claus and grow a big beard and belly.

I feel like the only person who wouldâ€™ve really tolerated that wouldâ€™ve been the Mormon potato farmer that I dated. I donâ€™t know how I found this guy in New York. He wouldâ€™ve been OK with turning into Santa, Iâ€™m pretty sure. I went on a coffee date with a Hare Krishnaâ€¦

I was gonna ask if you had run into any Christmas fetishists who might be really turned on by that part of you.

There was a request from somebody who was really convinced that I should expand into Christmas OnlyFans. And I knew very quickly that this guy was not the guy for me. So yes, I encountered that guy. It was a very awkward conversation because I think he was quite serious about it.

You make it sound, though, like youâ€™ve had fun this year, going through that process, as confounding as it is to someone coming back into the dating world in the age of apps.

I have to step back and laugh because the whole ridiculousness of dating in this day and age is so unlike how I remember dating back in the day, where you would go to a bar and then maybe get someoneâ€™s number and start dating, and then it was just that person until it faded out. Now it doesnâ€™t even feel like dating; it feels like a messed-up video game. The worst term we had back then was fading out on somebody. Now weâ€™ve got rostering, weâ€™ve got ghosting, we have submarining, we have breadcrumbing, we have all kinds of stuff. You know how in Alaska they have a thousand names for snow? In dating, thereâ€™s a thousand names for disinterest.

Wait, you are going to have to explain some of these terms, to someone who is not out in the field. â€œGhostingâ€ I get, but what were some of the others you mentioned?

â€œRostersâ€ means when people have more than one person that they date casuallyâ€¦ â€œSubmariningâ€ is not quite ghosting, which is where someone just completely goes like the Ghost of Christmas Past on you and they just disappear and thereâ€™s no explanation. Submarining is when they kind of go down into the depths of the ocean and you have no idea where they are, and then like maybe a week later or two weeks later, they come back up. Itâ€™s like, â€œHey, whatâ€™s up? I was just down in the ocean. Sorry I couldnâ€™t talk to you. I was in the abyss.â€

Times have indeed changedâ€¦

And a lot of these profiles are AI-generated. I might be falling in love with robots.

Back on the music: Do you ever consider taking a year off between Christmas albums? Or would that ruin what youâ€™ve got going?

Never. What, youâ€™re asking me now, 15 years in? You could have asked me this eight years in.

Just wondering if itâ€™s ever been a temptation to skip a year, or like in college, taking a gap year.

I think the closest thing to a gap year that I had was when I broke my spine and I couldnâ€™t sing. I had a meeting with my musicians and my co-producers and managers and I let them know that I physically could not stand because I was paralyzed from the left leg down. and I couldnâ€™t even breathe. I had no stability of my diaphragm because I had broken my L1 to L5. I was crying and my daughter was sitting next to me and she was like, â€œNo, mommy, Iâ€™m gonna help you sing.â€ And then my friend Dave Eggar, when I floated around that maybe that might be the year that I wouldnâ€™t be able to do something, was like, â€œThereâ€™s no way.â€ We always figure it out. So my team around me reminds me, â€œNo, Elizabeth, you have a greater purpose. You must tell your story every Christmas.â€ I really owe it to my friends in this business who remind me that at the end of the day, Iâ€™m an artist, and as an artist, my perspective informs my inspiration, and my inspiration is through my Christmas music. They constantly remind me that what I do is very different, and theyâ€™ll hold that space for me and remind me that youâ€™re not allowed to not celebrate a Christmas.

Itâ€™s like me asking you: Are you gonna skip a Christmas this year? Have you ever skipped a Christmas?

You know, I have not.

No. Right? So why would I? I mean, I know I do a little extra than you do, but Iâ€™m not gonna not celebrate Christmas, and the way that I celebrate Christmas is just the way that I celebrate it, is like, you know, producing new songs and coming up with new albums and presenting them to the world and telling my story one Christmas at a time. Why would I not want to do that?

I got behind in thinking about the season, and I did not put any lights up till the 22nd this year, but I feel like this conversation has helped me round a corner.

See, my magic powers prevail. Iâ€™m sure that you know if you need some Christmas backup, all you have to do is call and ask. I am the Queen of Christmas. Like, I know some people.

title: â€˜Re-Entryâ€™ Filmmaker Ariel Mahler On The Importance Of Trans Visibility And Vulnerability In AFI-Backed Short Film

content:
Itâ€™s OK to let go of the past, but to heal fully, itâ€™s important to remember the lessons that your experience taught you. No theme rings more true than in Ariel Mahlerâ€™s short film Re-Entry, a masterclass character study that artfully weaves the tender and cerebral in a tale of reconciliation with past regrets and the overwhelming power of self-love. The story follows a transgender NASA scientist, Maya (Danielle Squyres), who rediscovers a lost satellite she launched 35 years earlier. Though excited by the potential recovery of the satellite, Maya finds herself still haunted by the memory of her painful, closeted past (younger Maya, played by Tirosh Schneider) and what she perceives to be the humiliating end of her career. Maya must decide whether to inform NASA about recovering the satellite or to let the weight of the past send her spiraling through orbit.

The 15-minute short was an official selection of Out on Film â€“ Atlanta in 2024 and the recipient of the Best LGBTQ+ short award at the Savannah Film Festival.

Watch on Deadline

Below, Mahler opens up to Deadline about the vulnerabilities to crafting cinematic trans narratives, inspirations and the importance of self-reflection.

DEADLINE: Where did the idea of Re-Entry come from?

ARIEL MAHLER: It started with science because my cinematographer, who Iâ€™m really close with, who is also trans, Maryn McGaw, actually sent me a TikTok video about this phenomenon known as a zombie satellite. This is a scientific phenomenon: a satellite launched many decades ago sometimes malfunctions, stops communicating, and then floats aimlessly in outer space. Then, whatâ€™ll happen even more decades later, the satellite will reemerge and essentially come back to life and start communicating again, hence the zombie satellite name. So, when I was looking at this video, it had a real emotional impact on me because it was a language that resonated with me as a trans person. The TikToker was talking about these satellites floating, lost in the wrong orbit, searching for the ability to communicate after theyâ€™ve lost it, and then something happens where theyâ€™re able to reemerge and begin communicating again. They find their orbit and their orientation. And, I was just like, â€œYep, that tracks. Iâ€™ve had all of those experiences in my own personal life.â€

So, when I saw this video, I imagined that it would be like creating a character who lives as a metaphor for the satellite. This trans woman, who has for a long time felt like sheâ€™s lost in the wrong orbit, is floating, searching for her community, when something inspires her to re-engage and re-enter her own life, essentially. Re-Entry is a story about reconciling with your past and making terms with who you once were, as it impacts who you are now. And I think that everybody probably can relate to the experience of thinking about your past and thinking about choices you made or things you did or things you didnâ€™t do that impact who you are today, and that you maybe regret or you have complicated feelings about. And for queer and trans people, we tend to have a very complicated relationship with our past. So, I wanted to use this metaphor as a vehicle to explore our relationship with the past and how we integrate it.

DEADLINE: What were some cinematic influences for your short?

MAHLER: One of my favorite genres is emotional sci-fi films. Some of the biggest reference points for me are Arrival, Contact and Interstellar. They are all films that use science as a vehicle to tell a deep, emotional story about whatever situation the character is facing. So, me and my cinematographer watched those.

DEADLINE: Iâ€™m fascinated by the way you tell the story. You have two different actors playing the same character: one, the younger male presenting version of Maya, and the other, the older version of Maya. Talk a bit more about this concept of both of them being in communication with each other onscreen.

MAHLER: It wasnâ€™t always that way. In the creative writing process, I struggled with [how to convey inner turmoil]. I knew the storyâ€™s foundation was an older trans woman who rediscovers a satellite she helped launch and is now forced to decide, â€œDo I return to NASA as my new self?â€ So, I knew that there had to be another person involved in that because I didnâ€™t want her to just be alone wandering around having this monologue. So, I really struggled with who is the best person to bring into this world and to interrupt the status quo of how she lives her life. There was a version where her coworker, George (Robert Dowdy/Leon A. Walker), came in much earlier, and it was actually him who showed up and said, â€œHey, we found the satellite.â€ And then she had to deal with, â€œDo I out myself to him? How does this go?â€ There was a version where it was a young NASA intern who came over to try to get her to come back to NASA. There were all these different versions of it.

And then I was thinking about, I want this to be the most coherent and specific conflict possible. So, who is Maya actually struggling with? Who is she most at odds with? And I realized, oh, itâ€™s herself. And then I also realized, oh, this is a film, so I can sort of bend reality a little. Not too much, but realistic enough to tell this story. So, the idea of bringing her former self back evolved through that very slow process. It was something I was a little nervous about at first because I think a lot of trans people tend to have complicated relationships with our past, as I said earlier. One of those complexities is that it can be hard to reckon with former versions of ourselves. Trans people sometimes even use the phrase dead name to refer to their former self as if their previous self is literally dead. Iâ€™ve always struggled with that because on one hand, I understand that. Looking at old photos of myself, I found it challenging and struggled to a certain extent.

But on the other hand, I actually have a lot of love and compassion for my younger self, because I think about it as, â€œThey were just trying to do the best they could in a world that was telling them they had to be a very specific type of person.â€ I remember that the idea of putting the characters face-to-face felt scary, but it was also another reason why I was like, that means itâ€™s the right thing to do, because if Iâ€™m afraid of it, Iâ€™m a bit like, this is risky, then that feels like exactly the right place to go.

Re-Entry AFI / Ariel Mahler

DEADLINE: How much of this short film is you?

MAHLER: Iâ€™ll answer this first by going back to the film at hand. When I decided to bring the younger Maya into the world, I struggled. I was really trying to figure out who was going to go back to NASA and who was anti-going back to NASA. Originally, it was flipped from the film version. Older Maya was the one who was like, â€œI found the data, I want to go back,â€ and younger Maya was like, â€œNo, you canâ€™t. You canâ€™t let them see you like this.â€ Then that was the push-and-pull dynamic, but it flipped. The reason that this feels relevant to your question, I think, is part of the challenge and also catharsis of making this movie is that it was a messy process. Itâ€™s messy to think about my past. On one hand, I want to grab the former me and shake them by the shoulders and be like, â€œWhat are you doing? Stop lying to everybody. Stop lying to yourself. Take control of your destiny. Itâ€™s not worth spending all of this time being miserable.â€

Thereâ€™s also some anger that I feel towards my younger self and love, shame, empathy and just the whole rainbow of human emotions. When a film is so deeply personal, it can be really challenging to drill down into the core thing [youâ€™re trying to communicate]. Because itâ€™s a short film, I only have 15 minutes to say one very specific thing, and thereâ€™s so much that I could say on this topic. Trying to nail down one specific thing made it really challenging but energizing.

The other piece that feels relevant to your question is my journey as a filmmaker. This is obviously a very trans story with a trans narrative, but, as a storyteller, itâ€™s also important to me to tell stories that are not â€œjust trans.â€ I never want it to be where the only conflict is coming out, or the only conflict is trans identity. So, for this short film, putting Maya in the realm of this scientific world was meaningful to me because sheâ€™s not just trans, sheâ€™s a scientist. Sheâ€™s a NASA astronomer. She has a whole career that sheâ€™s been working her entire life for.

In the same way that Iâ€™m not just trans, Iâ€™m a filmmaker and an artist, and I have a career Iâ€™m building. So those two things feel deeply connected. But when I think about past me, Iâ€™m thinking about it in relation to my gender. Iâ€™m also thinking about the regrets I have. I knew I wanted to be a filmmaker when I was four years old, stealing my dadâ€™s camcorder and making dumb little movies with my friends, yet I was afraid to embrace it fully. I was like, â€œWell, thatâ€™s not practical,â€ throughout high school and college. I opted to be more traditional. Then it wasnâ€™t until I was almost 30 that I really embraced filmmaking. So, I look at former me and think about where my career would probably be now, if I had started back in high school or whatever.

DEADLINE: How did you find your two leads in younger and older Maya?

MAHLER: It was a very interesting challenge that I set up for myself, because I knew that I, one, had to cast a trans woman as a lead, and two, someone who was at least 50 years old, plus, because authentic casting is really important to me. But, unfortunately, there just arenâ€™t a lot of visible older trans women actresses. And this isnâ€™t because they arenâ€™t out there, but because they just havenâ€™t really been given the opportunity to get work or be seen. So, thankfully, Danielle Squyres was part of an acting group in LA called ActNOW, which is a program for queer and trans people. I have some friends who are also involved in that, and one of them, my friend Sasha Forests, knew Danielle and connected us. So, I brought her in for the audition process, and I knew she was the one. She has a really beautiful subtlety and was also really able to capture that external shell. But then, inside, you can sense the vulnerability and rawness.

For younger Maya, that was a new challenge, because I cast Danielle first, so I needed to find someone who vaguely resembled her. It was still about authenticity casting; I wanted somebody who had at least some personal understanding of queer and trans identity. So, I didnâ€™t just want to necessarily cast a straight cisgender man who has no personal experience with that, but at the same time, I didnâ€™t fully want to cast a trans woman and ask her to completely detransition herself for this student film. So, I was like, â€œHow do I balance this?â€ Thankfully, I met Tirosh [Schneider] through a mutual friend, and they identify as non-binary and gender queer. They were comfortable presenting as a male at the time but are very much in the queer world and know what the experience of feeling othered by your gender is like, so that felt important.

Also, I do think, from a spiritual perspective, once you begin the journey of making a film, thereâ€™s a call in the universe, or God, or whoever you pull your power from, that magic conspires to put all the pieces into place. And the fact that I met Danielle, Tirosh and Robert, who plays George, all these people came into my life at the exact moment when I needed to find them. It was a beautiful experience.

Re-Entry AFI/Ariel Mahler

DEADLINE: Youâ€™ve shown this film on the festival circuit. What has the reception been like so far?

MAHLER: Weâ€™ve been lucky and have had great feedback. Weâ€™ve been going to festivals for a year and a half now, which is awesome and exciting. The most meaningful thing to me is when specifically trans people come up to me and feel really seen by this story, because I do think that anytime youâ€™re putting something out that is vulnerable, thereâ€™s a bit of fear. I didnâ€™t know how trans people were going to respond to this younger self idea of putting a physical form of this womanâ€™s younger [male-presenting] self. And a lot of the trans people that Iâ€™ve spoken to feel really seen and emotionally resonant with that story, so that means a lot. Weâ€™ve also been able to screen it for some students and young people, and having younger trans folks come up to me and say they were touched by and appreciate this story is meaningful to me because I never had that when I was young.

DEADLINE: What would you like people to take away from this short?

MAHLER: For me, Iâ€™ve learned that I would often go back in order to move forward. We have to look backwards and engage with our past. Engaging with the past can be scary, uncomfortable and vulnerable, but thatâ€™s exactly why we have to face that hard truth. Itâ€™s only through actively engaging with our past and making terms with our journey that weâ€™re able to move forward.

[This interview has been edited for length and clarity]

In terms of digital reach, it was the second ranked episode on Peacock, behind the season premiere, and drew 503M social views across YouTube, Facebook, X, Instagram and TikTok, which the network says is â€œoutpacingâ€ last seasonâ€™s Ariana Grande-hosted episode, which was the most viewed social episode of Season 50.

content:
Original Saturday Night Live cast member Chevy Chase admits he was â€œhurtâ€ that he was excluded from on-stage and sketch performances in SNL50: The Anniversary Special.

â€œWell, it was kind of upsetting actually,â€ he revealed in CNN Filmsâ€™ forthcoming documentary Iâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Not. â€œThis is probably the first time Iâ€™m saying it. The special, which featured a mix of recent and classic SNL characters and cast members throughout its 50-year run, was initially going to include more of the actor, according to the docu. In a later referral in the docu to the Weekend Update segment, Chase questionedâ€Why was Bill Murray there and why was I not? I donâ€™t have an answer for that.â€

Chase reveals in the documentary that he brought up his displeasure once â€œin a text to Lorne (Michaels_ and then took it back.â€

â€œI said, â€˜Okay, I take it back, silly.â€™ But itâ€™s not that silly. Somebodyâ€™s made a bad mistake there. I donâ€™t know who it was, but somebody made a mistake. They shouldâ€™ve had me on that stage. It hurt.â€
