title: Bari Weiss Defends â€™60 Minutesâ€™ Decision in Staff Memo: â€˜This May Seem Radicalâ€™ but â€˜No Amount of Outrageâ€™ Will â€˜Derail Usâ€™
summary: What did CBS News management get staffers for Christmas? A memo doubling down on a controversial decision that has roiled the Paramount Skydance news unit and drawn torrents of criticism. In a note to staff sent hours before the start of Christmas Eve, CBS News Editor in Chief Bari Weiss, President Tom Cibrowski and new […]
content:
What did CBS News management get staffers for Christmas? A memo doubling down on a controversial decision that has roiled the Paramount Skydance news unit and drawn torrents of criticism.

In a note to staff sent hours before the start of Christmas Eve, CBS News Editor in Chief Bari Weiss, President Tom Cibrowski and new senior editors Charles Forelle and Adam Rubenstein insisted a move to delay a â€œ60 Minutesâ€ report by correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi was enacted â€œto make sure it is comprehensive and fair.â€ The signatures on the memo mark what is believed to be the first tacit appearance of a new CBS News editorial â€œmastheadâ€ that Weiss expects to get more entrenched in the newsgathering process at the company, according to people familiar with the matter.

â€œRight now, the majority of Americans say they do not trust the press. It isnâ€™t because theyâ€™re crazy,â€ the memo read. â€œTo win back their trust, we have to work hard. Sometimes that means doing more legwork. Sometimes it means telling unexpected stories. Sometimes it means training our attention on topics that have been overlooked or misconstrued. And sometimes it means holding a piece about an important subject to make sure it is comprehensive and fair.â€

Popular on Variety

CBS News revealed over the weekend that a â€œ60 Minutesâ€ segment reported by correspondent Sharyn Alfonsi and centered on the on-screen accounts of Venezuelan men deported by the U.S. to prison in El Salvador had been shelved just hours before Sundayâ€™s broadcast. As disclosed by an email sent to colleagues by Alfonsi, the decision was made by Weiss, who insisted that Trump officials appear in the report to comment on camera, even though Alfonsiâ€™s team had made good faith efforts to secure response ahead of filing the report for legal review. â€œThe public will correctly identify this as corporate censorship,â€ Alfonsi said in her memo.

Weiss has, since her arrival in October, insisted without presenting evidence that mainstream media has lost Americansâ€™ trust. And yet, a September study from Pew Research Center showed that CBS News enjoyed the backing of 51% of U.S. adults who have at least some trust in the information they get from national news organizations. CBS was ranked on par with CNN and PBS, and just a few percentage points behind ABC News and NBC News.



Such decision making â€ may seem radical,â€ the new memo said. â€œSuch editorial decisions can cause a firestorm, particularly on a slow news week. And the standards for fairness we are holding ourselves to, particularly on contentious subjects, will surely feel controversial to those used to doing things one way. But to fulfill our mission, itâ€™s necessary.â€

The â€œ60 Minutesâ€ imbroglio grips CBS News and its parent at an extremely inopportune moment. The news unit is just days away from trying to launch Tony Dokoupil as the new anchor of â€œCBS Evening News,â€ and looks to be doing so without the weeks of pre-launch promotion such a move would normally warrant. Instead, Dokoupil will go on a barnstorming tour of the U.S. and visit many cities and towns during his first days on the air. Whatâ€™s more, Paramount is engaged in a heated battle with Netflix to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery, and a continuing series of gaffes under Weissâ€™ management casts a cloud over Paramount CEO David Ellisonâ€™s ability to manage the coropration.

Many staffers are aghast over Weiss decision, noting that it came at the end of a long vetting process and after CBS News had already promoted the â€œ60 Minutesâ€ segment to the public. Indeed, many people have been able to watch the report on their own because a Canadian media outlet which airs â€œ60 Minutesâ€ made Alfonsiâ€™s report available via digital means. Should a new version of the story surface on the newsmagazine, viewers will be able to see how it was changed under Weissâ€™ supervision. According to people familiar with the report, Alfonsi had already made efforts to seek comment from Trump officials, and had included a video snippet from White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt that offered the administrationâ€™s take on the topic.



More to comeâ€¦.

title: â€˜Pluribusâ€™ May Be Slow, but It Was Never Boring
summary: SPOILER ALERT: The following piece contains plot details from “La Chica o El Mundo,” the Season 1 finale of “Pluribus,” now streaming on Apple TV. I have a confession to make: I love Carol Sturka. In that way, Iâ€™m a lot like the hive mind thatâ€™s absorbed most of humanity in â€œPluribus,â€ the Apple TV […]
content:
SPOILER ALERT: The following piece contains plot details from â€œLa Chica o El Mundo,â€ the Season 1 finale of â€œPluribus,â€ now streaming on Apple TV.

I have a confession to make: I love Carol Sturka.

In that way, Iâ€™m a lot like the hive mind thatâ€™s absorbed most of humanity in â€œPluribus,â€ the Apple TV drama of which Carol is the star. I love Carolâ€™s abrasiveness. I love how she responds to the end of the world not with high-minded heroism, but a self-centered defiance rooted in grief â€” a solipsism encouraged by how the hive mind caters to her every request. I love how Carol is tough enough to spend over a month on her own when the hive mind abandons Albuquerque rather than endure Carolâ€™s efforts to undo their joining, but human enough to relent and give acquiescence a try in the season finale. (Humanity and its attendant flaws are in scarce supply in â€œPluribus.â€) I believe Carol is a truly great TV character, brought to life by a truly great TV actor in Rhea Seehorn.

Not everyone seems to agree. â€œPluribusâ€ is the third series from Vince Gilligan, the showrunner who earned himself a permanent place in his chosen mediumâ€™s Mount Rushmore with the back-to-back triumphs of â€œBreaking Badâ€ and â€œBetter Call Saul.â€ Both those series focused on ascendant figures in New Mexicoâ€™s narcotics trade, an exciting hook that belied Gilliganâ€™s evident fascination with the detailed gruntwork between violent confrontations. I always think of Jonathan Banksâ€™s Mike Ehrmantraut silently disassembling his car, part by individual part, in search of a tracker over several minutes of screentime in an early season of â€œSaul.â€

Popular on Variety

Appleâ€™s largesse allows â€œPluribusâ€ to expand Gilliganâ€™s purview to Las Vegas, South America and other far-flung locales, but also practice his preferred MO with a heightened focus. â€œBreaking Badâ€ and â€œBetter Call Saulâ€ â€” particularly the latter â€” could be rigorous, but they also distributed that rigor across a wide-ranging ensemble. In her Gilligan-verse debut, Seehornâ€™s Kim Wexler was just one of many fastidious obsessives in and around the Albuquerque underworld, joining kindred spirits like Mike and chicken-slash-meth kingpin Gus Fring (Giancarlo Esposito). In â€œPluribus,â€ Carol and the hive mind are pretty much all we have, give or take a few fellow survivors like gleeful hedonist Mr. DiabatÃ© (Samba Schutte) and Manousos Oviedo (Carlos-Manuel Vesga), who spends much of Season 1 holed up in a Paraguayan storage facility.

That puts pressure on both Carol as audience surrogate and the viewer asked to train their attention on a single personâ€™s response to a global cataclysm. Lengthy scenes show Carol doggedly investigating the hiveâ€™s source of nutrition (Human Derived Protein, which is exactly what it sounds like), or Manousos studying radio frequencies and noting his findings by hand. Especially in the hiveâ€™s absence, â€œPluribusâ€ is quiet, deliberate, patient â€” and for some, those qualities cross the line into â€œboring.â€ Writing for The New Republic, critic Philip Maciak pronounced the show â€œa bit of a snooze,â€ echoing many complaints on social media about the hiveâ€™s noisy, chaotic genesis giving way to the placidity of a status quo where almost everyone is quite literally of one mind.

Clearly, I disagree. I can point to certain objective factors in Gilliganâ€™s defense: â€œPluribusâ€ balances out the indulgence of languid scene-to-scene pacing with sub-50 minute runtimes and a nine-episode season; the showâ€™s visual panache works against a sense of monotony, like a dumpster-diving sequence directed by frequent Gilligan collaborator Gordon Smith that gives the grossest of tasks uncanny color and symmetry. (Cinematographers Marshall Adams and Paul Donachie seem to bask in the desert sun.) But mostly, I think how you feel about â€œPluribusâ€ comes down to how you feel about Carol, and your investment in the trajectory she takes from closeted, self-loathing romantasy author to airlifting an atom bomb onto Manousosâ€™s doorstep.

The premise of â€œPluribusâ€ is abstract and allegorical by design, and Gilligan has said in interviews he prefers to leave interpretation to his audience. While the hiveâ€™s parallels to AI are uncanny â€” they even respond to prompts! â€” Iâ€™m partial to the most literal of readings. Millions of people donâ€™t survive the process of assimilation into the hive, and Carolâ€™s wife Helen (Miriam Shor) is one of the casualties. Carol is in mourning, and many of her most extreme, impulsive or just unsavory actions arise from that fact. So does our empathy for her.

In losing Helen, Carol has lost the one person on Earth who saw and accepted her for who she really was: her curmudgeonly qualities, but also the basic fact of her sexuality, which Carol hid from the public by making the romantic lead of her popular Wycaro series a man. Part of what makes the hive mind so eerie is how itâ€™s able to provide a hollow facsimile of such intimacy. The hive absorbed Helenâ€™s memories before she died, and deploys this knowledge in alternately earnest and manipulative ways. (Much of â€œPluribusâ€ operates from a place of ambiguity about The Joining and its consequences. That Human Derived Protein? Itâ€™s a last resort because the hive canâ€™t kill whatâ€™s currently alive, so must make use of the dead for nutrition â€” no matter the species). Zosia (Karolina Wydra), the individual the hive deploys as its emissary to Carol, is chosen because she looks exactly like the romantic lead of Carolâ€™s novels, before the character was genderbent into a man to reach a broader audience.

Though â€œPluribusâ€ is a science fiction show, it eschews the mystery box structure deployed by so many of its genre peers. Questions remain about the hive, its motives and its mechanics, but theyâ€™re secondary to how Carol feels about the Joining and how she responds to it. For every new detail we learn about the hive, thereâ€™s a Carol-focused revelation like her painful history with anti-gay conversion therapy, which tells us all we need to know about her near-allergic reaction to the prospect of being forcibly assimilated into a dominant majority group. The hiveâ€™s unconscious natural instinct is to absorb whoever it can, and when Carol notes this fact on her whiteboard, she puts it in understandably personal terms: â€œWants to CHANGE MEâ€ â€” the last two words underlined. Carolâ€™s precious safe harbor has been inverted into her worst fear, an abstract anxiety â€œPluribusâ€ renders concrete as only great horror, and horror-adjacent character studies, can.

In the last couple episodes of â€œPluribus,â€ Carolâ€™s resolve is tested, as any heroâ€™s must be. She experiments with using the hive, as DiabatÃ© has, to manifest her deepest desires. Carol sleeps with Zosia, asks her to use â€œIâ€ pronouns instead of the hiveâ€™s preferred â€œweâ€ and generally performs coupled domesticity. (Carol and Helen went to an ice hotel; Carol and Zosia go skiing.) This results in an amusing reversal wherein Manousos, whoâ€™s traveled thousands of miles in search of another skeptic, is just as appalled by Carolâ€™s willing self-delusion as Carol once was by people like Laxmi (Menik Gooneratne), who refuses to acknowledge the obvious change in her own son. Carol is shocked out of her complacency only after learning that the hive has obtained her stem cells without her consent â€” from frozen eggs, so she could have a child with Helen â€” and could absorb her within the month.

The big shift in the â€œPluribusâ€ finale isnâ€™t in our understanding of the hive, whose intentions were already shared. Itâ€™s within Carol, who chooses to ally herself with a fellow misanthrope in Manousos as unlikely saviors of mankind. I think thereâ€™s something beautiful in Gilligan employing such abundant resources, from tracking down and casting a Quechua speaker to shooting in the Canary Islands, in service of one personâ€™s internal evolution. I also understand why itâ€™s not for everyone â€” though, in my less generous moments, Iâ€™m frustrated that a story centered on a queer woman seems to get a shorter leash than Gilliganâ€™s previous work about men doing crimes. To me, though, enjoying â€œPluribusâ€ isnâ€™t about eating oneâ€™s cultural vegetables. Itâ€™s about enjoying a strange, absurd, uncategorizable show thatâ€™s also thoughtful and restrained. And itâ€™s about Carol Sturka, a highly specific person whose unease with others is nonetheless broadly accessible. Iâ€™d never exchange her spiky, pushy personality for permanent affability, and I understand why she wouldnâ€™t either.

title: Pat Finn Dies: â€˜The Middleâ€™, â€˜Seinfeldâ€™ Actor Was 60
summary: Pat Finn, a prolific TV character actor and comedian best known for his recurring role as friendly neighbor Bill Norwood on ABC’s The Middle, died Monday, December 22, at his Los Angeles home following a three-year battle with cancer. He was 60. His death was announced by his family and confirmed to Deadline by his […]
content:
Pat Finn, a prolific TV character actor and comedian best known for his recurring role as friendly neighbor Bill Norwood on ABCâ€™s The Middle, died Monday, December 22, at his Los Angeles home following a three-year battle with cancer. He was 60.

His death was announced by his family and confirmed to Deadline by his manager Andrea Pett-Joseph, who called Finn â€œthe kindest , most joyful person in any roomâ€ and said the actor passed while surrounded by family and friends.

Finn was diagnosed in 2022 with bladder cancer, which went into remission but later returned and metastasized. In the months prior to the actorâ€™s death, Finnâ€™s friends launched a GoFundMe page on behalf of the family to help defray medical costs. To date the page has raised more than $118,000 in donations.

Even if I wanted to go, my schedule wouldnâ€™t allow it!â€ she says, holding in her lap a small dog wearing antlers like the Grinchâ€™s dog, Max. â€œ4:00 â€” exercise my voice. 4:30 â€” wake my children up. 5:00 â€” solve world hunger. title: Bari Weiss Defends Pulling â€˜60 Minutesâ€™ Story, Again: â€œRestoring The Integrity Of The News Is A Difficult Taskâ€

content:
Bari Weiss has once again defended her decision to pull a 60 Minutes story on the Trump administrationâ€™s deportation of migrants to a prison in El Salvador.

Weiss sent a note to staff on Christmas Eve addressing the controversial decision. She said that the majority of Americans say they do not â€œtrust the pressâ€.

â€œIt isnâ€™t because theyâ€™re crazy. To win back their trust, we have to work hard. Sometimes that means doing more legwork. Sometimes it means telling unexpected stories. Sometimes it means training our attention on topics that have been overlooked or misconstrued. And sometimes it means holding a piece about an important subject to make sure it is comprehensive and fair,â€ she wrote.

She added that in â€œour upside-down moment, this may seem radicalâ€.

Watch on Deadline

â€œSuch editorial decisions can cause a firestorm, particularly on a slow news week. And the standards for fairness we are holding ourselves to, particularly on contentious subjects, will surely feel controversial to those used to doing things one way. But to fulfill our mission, itâ€™s necessary. No amount of outrageâ€”whether from activist organizations or the White Houseâ€”will derail us. We are not out to score points with one side of the political spectrum or to win followers on social media. We are out to inform the American public and to get the story right. Restoring the integrity of the news is a difficult task. We canâ€™t think of a more important one,â€ she continued.

The message was signed by Weiss, who is Editor-in-Chief of CBS News, Tom Cibrowski, who is President and Executive Editor and editors Charles Forelle and Adam Rubenstein.

It comes two days after Weiss told colleagues that she decided to hold the piece because it was â€œnot readyâ€ and it did not advance the story.

That decision was criticized by Sharyn Alfonsi, the correspondent who worked on the story, who called it a â€œpoliticalâ€ one.

The piece featured interviews with Venezuelan deportees who were sent by Trumpâ€™s administration to the harsh CECOT prison in El Salvador.

Some viewers have already got a chance to watch the segment, after it leaked online. Canadian broadcaster Global TV, which airs 60 Minutes north of the border, had featured the piece on its app before it was pulled.

Weiss ended the memo by wishing her staff a Merry Christmas. â€œThank you, especially, to everyone who is working over this holiday,â€ she concluded.

title: How â€˜The Plagueâ€™ Artisans Capture the Horrors of Early Adolescence Through Score and Cinematography
summary: Foreboding title aside, one could reasonably begin watching Charlie Polingerâ€™s â€œThe Plagueâ€ and assume that it is a Y.A. coming of age dramaâ€” a modern-day â€œThe 400 Blowsâ€ or a male â€œWelcome to the Dollhouseâ€ about a group of teenaged boys spending their summer at a sleepaway water polo camp. However, as the film progresses, […]
content:
Foreboding title aside, one could reasonably begin watching Charlie Polingerâ€™s â€œThe Plagueâ€ and assume that it is a Y.A. coming of age dramaâ€” a modern-day â€œThe 400 Blowsâ€ or a male â€œWelcome to the Dollhouseâ€ about a group of teenaged boys spending their summer at a sleepaway water polo camp. However, as the film progresses, not only does its narrative get increasingly sinister, but the look and feel of the film subtly lull the audience away from a vivacious security and into the darkest psychological realms of early adolescence.

Because of the movieâ€™s water polo camp setting, much of it takes place in and around an indoor pool. Anyone who has been to a YMCA in the early morning knows the harsh fluorescence of these environments. Accordingly, the filmâ€™s first two acts are brightly lit, appearing almost sterilized at times.

Popular on Variety

In the opening shot, the camera is fully submerged in the pool, introducing the first of many underwater shots as the boys jump into the water, their legs kicking around and disrupting the aquatic stillness. While the swimming poolâ€™s chlorine-washed blue is unmistakable, cinematographer Steven Breckon says that he and Polinger were trying to avoid cliched underwater shots. â€œThe classic underwater shot is a perfume commercial with a woman in flowy drapery clothing and thereâ€™s like a God light beam on it,â€ Breckon tells Variety. â€œThatâ€™s nowhere close to what we wanted this material to look like and we were actually kind of inspired by more of a deep focus, like a painting.â€

To achieve the underwater shots, Breckon explains that the camera operator was beneath the surface, receiving instructions through speakers. â€œI could basically talk to him through a giant megaphone speaker that is placed underwater, so it was like garbled instructions and he would just nod the camera â€˜yesâ€™ or nod the camera â€˜noâ€™ to confirm that he heard me.â€

Even as the camera becomes less static, circling around the kids treading water, bobbing up and down with seeming serendipity, Breckon says that it was more carefully orchestrated than it appears. He says that the camera was â€œon a flotation rig that you can deflate to the perfect level where itâ€™s sort of half in and half out. And by pushing it on the surface through those boys and having all the splashing going on, it has a very chaotic energy,â€ however, â€œit was very diagrammed out. There really wasnâ€™t a lot of finding it in the moment because we just had to be so safe with the boys. You know, we had lifeguards on every corner of the frame.â€

The sequenceâ€™s handheld look is complemented by its sound and score, which synchronously cuts in and out every time the camera submerges and resurfaces. â€œIâ€™m pretty sure that the actual ducking of the sound of the music was done by Damien (Volpe) and Dave (Paterson) in the sound department. But I was there. I went for those sessions,â€ composer Johan Lenox tells Variety.

While the cinematography slowly morphs from the deceptive brightness of a bildungsroman to a darkness of a horror movie over the course of the runtime, the music is consistently eerie from the beginning, cluing audiences that not all is well for this group of kids. â€œThe music is scary, but itâ€™s also like, insanely weird,â€ says Lenox. â€œWe wanted to telegraph early that some goofy and insane shit is gonna happen.â€

The foreboding energy is accented by musicâ€™s surreal, sometimes liminal qualities. â€œYouâ€™re just hearing me wailing into this microphone,â€ Lenox continues, noting that while the music is strange throughout, there are subtle escalations as the movie progresses. â€œI donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a string instrument in the first third or half of the movie. And then these gritty, noisy sounds from string instruments start to creep in on top of the vocals and eventually supplant them just as the fun sort of stops,â€ explains Lenox. â€œThen also there are these tense swelling drone sounds pushing into these hallways and stuff like that. I think thereâ€™s a shorter one early in the movie and then thereâ€™s like a fucking three or four minute long one by the end.â€

â€œThe Plagueâ€â€™s sight and sound does have conspicuous breaks from its sinister mold. Notably, when the kids sneak out at night partway through the film, a handheld long take captures them partying in an alley.

â€œThatâ€™s probably the scene thatâ€™s the most extreme version of what I describe as â€˜the sandbox,â€™â€ says Breckon. â€œThereâ€™re these broad strokes that were very set up and diagrammed out, but then within that, itâ€™s just chaos, letting them go every which way. In terms of actually approaching it, I was trying my best to get us to commit to a 180 degree plus area, thinking weâ€™ll flip around and get the other side, but the kids were going in circles and doing everything, so it very quickly became a 360 area and that posed some challenges. As a cinematographer, you want everybody to be in the back light, and you donâ€™t want moments of too much front light. So I was trying to keep up with that scene as it was unfolding in front of us, but there was no version of me being like, â€˜Whoa, whoa, whoa. Hold up. This isnâ€™t the way that I want it to look.â€™ Instead, it was like, â€˜No, the kids are telling us what it needs to be.â€™â€

The scene reaches a crescendo when one of the boys pops a CD into a boom box and an Italian pop song plays. While the song could easily be mistaken for an obscure, but fitting needle drop, it is still an original piece composed by Lenox for the film. â€œLetâ€™s fucking write our own thing. Like, why not?â€ reflects Lenox, appreciating how that the filmâ€™s â€œsonic world is 90% of one thing and then this other thing that comes in. Itâ€™s intentional. It could not be more opposite to everything else. I really like it as a structure and shape.â€

The song is titled â€œCorsa Notturnaâ€ and it features Italian vocals from a child. It is some of the only vocals in the soundtrack that do not belong to Lenox himself. The song returns once more at the end of the film, in a dance sequence that once again showcases innovative camera techniques.

As the main character dances freely, we spin with him until a unique effect takes hold and it seems as if the rotation is continuing while seamlessly cutting between the boy and his revolving prospective. Breckon, however, explains that the shot was not cut at all. The team created a rotating six-sided mirror that the actor was stationary inside of, allowing him to intermittently appear in the reverse shot while maintaining the outward-facing circular motion.

â€œAs he becomes part of the image, and it goes from the people looking at him to just him, heâ€™s actually slowing down. Heâ€™s not himself spinning anymore, and heâ€™s starting to take stock of the situation in the moment, but its contrasted by the fact that this mirror is spinning faster and faster,â€ says Breckon. It is a transfixing effect that closes the film, effectively encapsulating the storyâ€™s dizzying approach to self-acceptance.

The influences for â€œThe Plagueâ€ are manifold. Between Breckon and Lenox, they mention taking inspiration from â€œRaw,â€ â€œCarrieâ€ and â€œThe Shining,â€ but also â€œFull Metal Jacket,â€ â€œ8 Â½â€ â€œThe Dark Knightâ€ and â€œSuperbadâ€ to shape the look and sound. The result is something wholly unique: a coming-of-age horror movie that explores the social, psychological and physical viscerality of growing up.

â€œThe Plagueâ€ debuted at the Cannes Film Festival in May. IFC acquired its distribution rights in August and will release the film in theaters on Dec. 24.

title: Diddy Files Appeal Asking for â€˜Immediate Releaseâ€™ From Prison

In the 84-page appeal, filed yesterday and reviewed by Variety, attorney Alexandra A.E. Shapiro argued that Combs’ 50-month sentence was greater than it […]
content:
Sean â€œDiddyâ€ Combs has filed an appeal for his 50-month sentence, claiming that the court handed down an excessive punishment in his federal trial and asking for his â€œimmediate releaseâ€ from prison.

In the 84-page appeal, filed yesterday and reviewed by Variety, attorney Alexandra A.E. Shapiro argued that Combsâ€™ 50-month sentence was greater than it should have been, laying the blame at the feet of Judge Aran Subramanian and stating that he â€œacted as the thirteenth juror.â€ The appeal stated that Subramanian defied the juryâ€™s verdict and found that Combs â€œcoerced,â€ â€œexploitedâ€ and â€œforcedâ€ his girlfriends to have sex and led a criminal conspiracy, which â€œtrumped the verdict.â€

â€œDefendants typically get sentenced to less than 15 months for these offenses â€” even when coercion, which the jury didnâ€™t find here, is involved,â€ reads the appeal.

Popular on Variety

Combs was initially convicted in July on two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution, and was acquitted of the more serious racketeering conspiracy and sex trafficking charges that carried heftier sentences. At his sentencing in October, Subramanian made it clear that Combsâ€™ violence would be a factor in his decision, citing the video of the 2016 incident where he attacked his former girlfriend, Casandra â€œCassieâ€ Ventura.

â€œThe same power you used to hurt women, you can use to help them,â€ he told Combs during the sentencing. â€œIâ€™m counting on you to make the most of your second chance.â€

Shapiro also argued in the appeal that the conviction should be reversed because Combsâ€™ sexual interactions and filming of said acts were protected by the First Amendment, an argument Subramanian had previously rejected.

Combs is currently serving out his sentence at New Jerseyâ€™s FCI Fort Dix with a projected release date set for May 2028.

title: Frank Darabont on Coming Out of Retirement for â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™: â€˜It Was a Hell of a Great Experienceâ€™
summary: Frank Darabont was still new to retirement when Netlix released the first season of “Stranger Things” in 2016. He had wrapped his final directing gig â€” the 2013 “Mob City” episode “Red Light”â€” and moved with his wife to California’s Central Coast, where he could bask in the wake of an incredible filmography that included […]
content:
Frank Darabont was still new to retirement when Netlix released the first season of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ in 2016. He had wrapped his final directing gig â€” the 2013 â€œMob Cityâ€ episode â€œRed Lightâ€â€” and moved with his wife to Californiaâ€™s Central Coast, where he could bask in the wake of an incredible filmography that included â€œThe Shawshank Redemption,â€ â€œThe Green Mile,â€ â€œThe Mist,â€ episodes of â€œThe Walking Dead,â€ â€œThe Shield,â€ â€œTales from the Cryptâ€ and more.

About a decade into retirement, however, Darabont received a call from his agent, informing him that Matt and Ross Duffer, the creators of â€œStranger Things,â€ were fans of his work. The feeling was mutual, as Darabont and his wife had binged the Netflix seriesâ€™ first four seasons several times over. The agents set up a friendly meeting between them when the Duffers were still developing the showâ€™s fifth and final season.

Shortly thereafter, Dan Trachtenberg, who was attached to direct two episodes of â€œStranger Things 5,â€ dropped out due to a scheduling conflict with his next film, â€œPredator: Badlands.â€ In a Hail Mary, the Duffers offered Darabont to take Trachtenbergâ€™s place, and after a weekâ€™s consideration, he decided to come out of retirement to join the â€œStranger Thingsâ€ team on set.

Popular on Variety

Winona Ryder as Joyce Byers and Noah Schnapp as Will Byers Courtesy of Netflix

Darabont, 66, directed Episodes 3 and 5 of the final season. Episode 3 released in with Volume 1 on Nov. 26. Titled â€œThe Turnbow Trap,â€ the episode is packed with action and emotion in the Upside Down and the Rightside Up, showcasing a triumphant return for the director. Episode 5, titled â€œShock Jock,â€ will kick off the three-episode second volume on Dec. 25. (The â€œStranger Thingsâ€ series finale releases in theaters and on Netflix Dec. 31.)

Between the volumes, Variety spoke with the director to hear about his experience working on â€œStranger Thingsâ€ and his return to the filmmaking craft after twelve years since he last sat in the directorâ€™s chair.

We heard that you were a fan of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ before you met the Duffer brothers. How did you get into the show?

My wife and I were fans of the show from early on. We actually had watched all four seasons three or four or maybe even five times. It was so good. Then one day out of the blue, my agent called me and said, â€œThe agent in the office next to me represents the Duffer brothers, and he just wanted me to tell you that theyâ€™re big fans of yours.â€ I said, â€œThatâ€™s fantastic. Thatâ€™s very flattering. Iâ€™m big fans of theirs.â€ So I thought, â€œWell, next time Iâ€™m in L.A., Iâ€™ll get together with them for lunch and just compliment them.â€ I also was fascinated to know where the heck they came from, because I never heard of the Duffer brothers before they created this huge success on Netflix. So I had lunch with them when I was down in L.A. and I think about a week later, my agent called me again and said theyâ€™re inviting you to come direct an episode.

And what was your initial reaction to that?

I hadnâ€™t done it in a while, but they said itâ€™s like riding a bicycle: You donâ€™t forget. And they were right. From the first moment on set, there was nothing unfamiliar about the process for me, though it had been about 13 years. The one episode offer wound up being two episodes and six months in Atlanta. It was a hell of a great experience.

The Duffer brothers told us that you took about a week to consider the offer. What was going through your mind during that week and what made you want to accept?

Well, once youâ€™re retired, itâ€™s bliss. My wife and I live on the Central Coast in Monterey, where we donâ€™t have the pressures of Hollywood on our back. Iâ€™m enjoying life, and for once Iâ€™m no longer the workaholic that I was for almost 30 years in Hollywood. So I had to wrestle with that question and, of course, talk to my wife about it, because I wasnâ€™t going to go to Atlanta unless she came also. I love being married, and Iâ€™m not going to be in some place for months without her. We also have five chihuahuas that we would have to take. It was kind of a big move, especially once it became two episodes. We were looking at six months living in a different place. When youâ€™re young and single, itâ€™s not that big of a deal, but when youâ€™re an old fart like me who has sunk roots in a community and is comfortable being an unemployed bum, you have to ask yourself â€œDo I really do this?â€ But ultimately, it was my love for the show and my wifeâ€™s love for the show that kind of overruled all those other concerns and we said, â€œWhat the heck? Letâ€™s do it!â€ Iâ€™m glad we did.

Natalia Dyer as Nancy Wheeler and Charlie Heaton as Jonathan Byers Courtesy of Netflix

While you were considering, were you allowed to read the scripts for the episodes that you would direct?

Yeah, they had sent me the scripts and I thought they were terrific. I asked for all of the scripts that they had written thus far so I could track what was going on in the whole thing. They were very generous with sending me those, as long as it was kept under strict secrecy. Theyâ€™re not quite the nuclear codes, but theyâ€™re pretty close. The fascinating thing about our culture is how much people want to dig into this stuff instead of wait to be surprised by what they see on screen. I am the ultimate no-spoilers guy. When I was in junior high, I went to go see â€œSoylent Greenâ€ and some asshole fellow students told me before I went in, â€œOh, Soylent Green is people.â€ Iâ€™ve never forgiven them. Itâ€™s part of the reason why Iâ€™m not on social media and Iâ€™m also reluctant to watch trailers. Too much is given away. If I have an interest in something, I want to enjoy it fresh.

Did you notice anything different in the process of filmmaking returning to the directorâ€™s chair after 12 or 13 years?

Oh gosh, yeah. Only on â€œMob Cityâ€ did I finally transition from film to digital, and I ended up loving it. It helps a director so much because you donâ€™t ever have to call a cut. Whenever a director calls cut, the energy on a set dissipates. Now you can just say, â€œEverybody back to oneâ€ and the energy remains where it needs to be. The actors remain in the same headspace as you roll three or four takes before calling cut. I love that aspect of it. Filmmakers have so many new tools now. [On â€œStranger Thingsâ€] our DP was shooting with a techno crane, which can sometimes be frustrating, but can do brilliant things. Also the camera operator is no longer where youâ€™d think he is. Heâ€™s not by the camera anymore, but often in some tent off to the side. Same with whoeverâ€™s pulling focus. Theyâ€™re longer next to the camera all the time. So much has been outsourced to these technological devices.



But I have to praise this crew. They were absolutely wonderful across the board. A directorâ€™s relationship with their crew is very important to me, especially the DP and AD, and I had great on both. Brett Jutkiewicz was my DP and Lisa Rowe was my AD, and they were both fantastic. The Duffers know how to crew up a show, and some of these folks had been with them since Season 1. There were so many resources all around me that could help answer any question. It was a great, collaborative vibe.

Episode 3 has lots of emotional scenes, including heavy dialogues between Will (Noah Schnapp) and Joyce (Winona Ryder), Will and Robin (Maya Hawke) and Holly (Nell Fisher) and Henry (Jamie Campbell Bower). What was it like working with this ensemble to create those dramatic dynamics?

Iâ€™ve always said that if you have the right actor, thereâ€™s not much that they need to hear from a director. I learned that on my very first theatrical feature, â€œThe Shawshank Redemption.â€ Sometimes a director can get too much into an actorâ€™s ear. Tim Robbins, for example, loves conversations with the director. Morgan Freeman does not. Heâ€™s a very intuitive, very instinctive actor, and does a brilliant work. Both of them do. I remember midway through the shoot, I was talking to Morgan about whatever scene weâ€™re going to shoot next and I could see his eyes glazing over. He was just being very polite and listening to me, so I stopped myself and said, â€œMorgan, you really donâ€™t need to hear this, do you?â€ and he goes â€œNo, just tell me where to stand and how to turn. That kind of stuff.â€ From that moment on, I let him do his job. It was a great lesson for a first-time director. Every actor is different.

Courtesy of Netflix

Did the cast of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ prefer more dialogue and direction, or did most of them take control of their own performances? Or was there a mix?

Theyâ€™d been doing it for so long, especially the youngsters who were around 10 when they started and now theyâ€™re young adults. Theyâ€™ve been with these characters for half of their lives, so theyâ€™re pretty dialed in. There were little, physical things that needed direction, like when Dustin [Gaten Matarazzo] comes out of the van and drops this big bag of tools right in front of the lens. To have it fall exactly where the camera is going to land took a lot of practice and blocking. I think there were five takes or something. There were also things like Caleb [McLaughlin] running down the stairs after heâ€™s thrown acetone at the Demogorgon. I needed him to pause and look back at a certain moment because I knew something was going to be added in post that needed an extra beat of time. Youâ€™re sort of doing all this calculus on set to make sure it can be cut together right. Thatâ€™s usually where I get more specific and precise with an actor, but aside from that, they know their characters. As a director, my job is to provide the raw materials for what you need in the editing room and also to be head cheerleader on set. Youâ€™re cheering everybody on and encouraging them. A small bit of encouragement or recognition from the director can fuel you for another 24 hours of exhausting work

Has this experience made you want to direct more, or are you comfortable returning to retirement?

I really do love being retired. However, I also love being on a set with creative people, as long as Iâ€™m not fighting battles with some evil empire, studio, or network. I bless Netflix for being so supportive. If you have a good situation like that and it can be about the creative process, then its a pleasure. So my longwinded answer winds up being, it depends. If thereâ€™s a friendly situation and Iâ€™m excited enough about the material, then itâ€™s certainly a possibility. Iâ€™m not ruling anything out, but it would have to be something special. â€œStranger Thingsâ€ was a special opportunity for me to be a small part of a very large, wonderful thing that so many people love. Iâ€™m grateful to the Duffers for that opportunity. It will always be a great memory working with them and that cast and crew. I will love seeing where their careers take them. content:

â€œPalm Royaleâ€™sâ€ Maxine and Douglas may be divorced, but their unmistakable connection crossed the point of no return this week when she was a surprise guest at her own funeral and his devastation sent him into an unhinged frenzy.

Popular on Variety

Meanwhile, Perry (Jordan Bridges) delivered â€œMaxineâ€™sâ€ ashes to a devastated Douglas (Josh Lucas), as the town gathered for the funeral, completely unaware that the very much alive Maxine is hiding inside the casket. Chaos erupted: mourners gasp, Mitzi (Kaia Gerber) ran screaming, and an inconsolable Douglas eulogized his ex, telling the â€œdeadâ€ Maxine how much he loves her.

Later that night, Maxine and Douglas connected, and she asked if he truly meant what he said at the church, that he loves herâ€¦ but his answer isnâ€™t exactly what she expected.

Douglas (Josh Lucas) and Mitzi (Kaia Geber) attend Maxineâ€™s funeral on â€˜Palm Royale.â€™ Erica Parise

Maxine and Douglasâ€™ love affair has changed since moving to Palm Royale. â€œWhen you have a relationship thatâ€™s that long â€” and even though you can dismiss it as these two are silly people â€” their souls are exploded,â€ he says. â€œSo I donâ€™t think Douglas is thinking about putting the pieces back together. I think heâ€™s now truly unleashed. â€¦ His world has been his oyster, and it no longer is.â€

It began with his infidelity and â€œeach piece of it, it just keeps getting worse,â€ Lucas adds. â€œHe loses Maxine, causes her to have a heart attack, and then when he finally [completely] loses her, I think heâ€™s not a man whoâ€™s ever gonna put it back together again. He is not going to therapy.â€

Lucas believes that up to the point he met Maxine, women were truly just â€œtransactionalâ€ for him â€”and marrying Linda/Penelope (Laura Dern) was just â€œthe next right thing to do for his life, career and money.â€

He continues, â€œI think when he met Maxine, he truly fell in love. There is something childlike about Douglas â€” or dog-like, as Lucas says.

One of the things I think is so terrific about this show is the candy-coated confection of it all â€” but in the center of it is kind of this bitter pill all the time of reality.â€

That dichotomy was part of the character design from the beginning. â€œAbe Sylvia and the creators, I donâ€™t want to say in any way are making fun of these people because theyâ€™re not. These people exist, particularly back in this time,â€ he says of the 1970s setting. â€œBut thereâ€™s obviously a through line to these, particularly white men of incredible wealth and privilege who just have no real understanding of the world. Theyâ€™re truly in their own bubble. And Douglas has been in it his entire life.â€

In a way, Maxine and Douglasâ€™ marriage is playing out in a very realistic 1970s scenario, when men had their roles in the family and career, and women had theirs. Pre-Palm Royale, Maxine was a traditional wife, and Douglas was just fine with that.

â€œShe talks about it â€” sheâ€™s a trad wife, and she takes great pride in that,â€ he says. â€œThereâ€™s honor in it. I do think thatâ€™s a very interesting thing thatâ€™s even going on in todayâ€™s time â€” the value or devalue of that. Thatâ€™s where the show finds all these lovely through lines â€” Roe v Wade, womenâ€™s rights and the civil rights movement. But Douglas and Maxine are completely devoid of that.â€

During a recent Q&A, Sylvia reminded the audience that during this period of time, in certain parts of this country, a woman could not have a checking account without her husbandâ€™s signature.

â€œThose would be things that Douglas would think would be good. And Maxine, her eyes are obviously being opened throughout the show by all these women who are showing her these layers of whatâ€™s possible in how societyâ€™s changing,â€ Lucas points out. â€œBut I also think she takes great pride in being a wife who really loves and takes care of her husband. â€¦ I think we really try and stay away from pounding any sort of obvious political or psycho sociological message and just purely allow the show to exist as a confection.â€

If you canâ€™t get enough Italian gangster prequels, are dying to know where Lupin protagonist Assane Diopâ€™s story goes next or need your fix of Disney+ bonkbuster, then youâ€™ve come to the right place, as we walk you through 2026 in TV terms.

Gomorrah (Sky)

Sky

Now hereâ€™s a prequel the world can get on board with â€“ or on the peddle bike if weâ€™re using the above image as a reference. Already envisaged as running for at least three seasons, Gomorrah â€“ The Origins takes audiences back to 1977 Naples, tracking the criminal coming-of-age of the young Pietro Savastano, a â€œtough city kid who grew up in the poorest parts of Secondigliano.â€ Produced by Sky Studios and Cattleya, the show will expand the world of one of Skyâ€™s most popular foreign dramas, inspired by Roberto Savianoâ€™s bestselling non-fiction novel. Across five seasons and more than 50 episodes, Gomorrah was a huge hit for the pay-TV giant, putting it on the map in Italy. Sky may not make an enormous amount of original content from the nation anymore, but if The Origins can attract the kind of ratings and awards buzz of its predecessor, that will go a long way to keeping its name relevant in the original content game. The prequel stars Luca Lubrano, Francesco Pellegrino and Flavio Furno.

Lupin (Netflix)

Watch on Deadline

â€˜Lupinâ€™ Netflix

When it lands in fall 2026, it will be three years since the previous instalment of Netflixâ€™s slick French-language drama about master thief Assane Diop, played by the charismatic Omar Sy. Thatâ€™s a long time to wait â€“ and will no doubt raise the regular debate around wait times between seasons of streaming shows â€“ but itâ€™ll also mean anticipation reaches a crescendo and itâ€™s bound to win over any frustrated fans. Based on the ArsÃ¨ne Lupin character Maurice Leblanc created in the early 1900s, the series initially followed Assaneâ€™s revenge mission against the Pellegrini family who wronged his father, before morphing into a search for his abducted son and then on to his mission to steal the Black Pearl. Viewers will know Part 3 ended with Assane finally in jail, but given his skills picking locks and disappearing from tight spaces, we can confidently say he wonâ€™t remain there for long. Ludivine Sagnier, Antoine Gouy and Soufiane Guerrab are among those returning, with the creative team of George Kay and FranÃ§ois Uzan back, and Louis Leterrier and Sy himself the showrunners.

Rivals (Disney+)

Disney

The buzz is building for the second season of Disney+â€™s Rivals to the point where the actual Queen consort of the UK visited the set earlier this month. Queen Camilla was on set to pay tribute to the late Jilly Cooper, the Rivals author who passed away earlier this year, and the cast and creative team behind the bonkbuster have been doing the same as they ready a second run of the adaptation starring David Tennant, Nafessa Williams and Aidan Turner. Following a dramatic cliffhanger ending to Season 1, audiences can expect more drama, swagger and jaw-dropping romps in the second run as Rupert Everett and Hayley Atwell join the cast and the show continues to delve deep into the cutthroat world of 1980s British TV franchise bidding (itâ€™s way more fun than it sounds, promise). This quintessentially British period drama may have seemed a bit leftfield when Disney+ first jumped aboard, but it is now firmly established as one of the streamerâ€™s most prominent international originals.

Berlin and the Lady with an Ermine (Netflix)

Felipe HernÃ¡ndez/Netflix

The secret sauce behind the success of Ãlex Pina and Esther MartÃ­nez Lobatoâ€™s hit Money Heist franchise has been the ability to reinvent while retaining DNA. With that in mind, enter Berlin and the Lady with an Ermine, the second season of Money Heist spin-off Berlin that brings a name change and some new characters, but the same sense of fun that has cemented the franchise as one of the most successful non-English-language shows of all time. This time around, Berlin and DamiÃ¡n are bringing the gang together to pretend to steal Da Vinciâ€™s â€˜Lady with an Ermineâ€™ portrait. But their real target is the Duke of MÃ¡laga and his wife, a couple who think they can blackmail Berlin. With his mix of deadly dark humor and a clearly tortured past, Pedro Alonsoâ€™s Berlin was always ripe for a spin-off, which has manifested in the showâ€™s success on Netflix. The Lady with an Ermine will likely prove that Pina and Lobato continue to be one of the deadliest duos in the biz today.

The Night Manager (BBC, Prime Video)

The Ink Factory/BBC/Amazon/Des Willie

Tom Hiddlestonâ€™s Jonathan Pine is back after a decade. Now living as Alex Goodwin â€“ a low-level MI6 officer running a quiet surveillance unit in London â€“ his life is comfortingly uneventful. It wonâ€™t surprise audiences to find out that this wonâ€™t be the case for long. Starring Hiddleston, Olivia Colman, Elizabeth Debicki and Hugh Laurie, The Night Manager was one of 2016â€™s most popular dramas and it has been welcomed back into the fold, with a deluxe double-season order and a new co-pro partner in Prime Video. This season, which kicks off on New Yearâ€™s Day on the BBC and mid-Jan on PV, welcomes Daisy Jones & The Six star Camila Morrone, but what of Laurieâ€™s Richard Roper? Last seen bundled into the back of a van, all eyes will be on Roperâ€™s potential return. John le CarrÃ© adaptations have proven to be a rich well for the BBC to mine â€“ it is also adapting The Spy Who Came in From the Cold and A Legacy of Spies starring Matthew Macfadyen with MGM+ â€“ and this one could be a banker.

How To Get to Heaven From Belfast (Netflix)

Christopher Barr/Netflix

Ever since Derry Girls wrapped in 2022, all eyes have been trained on where next for the stupendous comic talent of Lisa McGee. McGeeâ€™s next project may also have a Northern Irish city in the title, but the vibe has shifted, as has the commissioner, following a sign-of-the-times moment that saw Netflix swoop in and pick up the show from Channel 4 when the latter simply couldnâ€™t afford it. How to Get to Heaven From Belfast is described by McGee as a â€œmash up of two different genres, mystery and comedy,â€ following Saoirse, Robyn and Dara as they head out on a weird and wild adventure â€œfull of twists, turns, and arguments about eyelash extensions.â€ Expect some trademark McGee wit with perhaps a bit more bite and a few more weighty plot points than Derry Girls. Viewers are in for a treat.

4 Blocks Zero (HBO Max)

4 Blocks Zero will one of the big draws for HBO Max as it rolls out in more major European territories next year, especially in Germany, the country from where the prequel to the critically-acclaimed 4 Blocks hails. While the original series, made for Warner-owned German network TNT Serie between 2017-2019, focused on how Ali â€˜Toniâ€™ Hamadi, the leader of a Berlin-NeukÃ¶lln crime family, attempted to leave the gangsterâ€™s life behind, the prequel details how the Hamadi family became the most influential Arabic underworld clan in the city. Quirin Berg and Max Wiedemann are back to exec produce, with Bernd Lange leading a writing team. No detail yet on the cast, but this is certain to be one of 2026â€™s biggest European drama launches. The original 4 Blocks won major domestic prizes such as the Grimme-Preis for lead actor Kida Khodr Ramadan Ramadan, co-star Veysel Gelin, and director Marvin Kren, along with six German Television Awards, including Best Drama Series. 4 Blocks Zero will have similarly lofty ambitions.

El Homenaje (SkyShowtime)

This crime family thriller, whose English-language title is The Tribute, feels like it could be described as SkyShowtimeâ€™s answer to Succession. Shot in Spain, it tells the story of Adolfo Novak (Eusebio Poncela), patriarch of one of the most powerful families in the country, who gathers his family and close friends to celebrate his 80th birthday. As the evening unfolds, a dark truth gets revealed that has the potential to destroy everything. It quietly filmed last year, with the cast and production team primarily hailing from SkyShowtimeâ€™s well-received drama series Matices (Shades). Along with Poncela, who plays the steely lead, Miriam Giovanelli, Juana Acosta, Enrique Arce, RaÃºl Prieto, Luis Tosar, Luisa Mayol and Elsa Pataky all return in new roles, having appeared in Matices. Secuoya Studios, which has been attaching itself to several eye-catching Spanish-language dramas, is producing alongside Stellarmedia. Prime Video is attached for second window rights â€“ another sign that the Spanish-language project has been well received in Spain and could be set for further travel.

Vaka (Prime Video)

Deadline first told you about this dystopian thriller out of Sweden back in March. Aliette Opheim and Jonas Karlsson star in Vaka, which follows the spread of a deadly insomnia epidemic in Stockholm through the eyes of people in very different circumstances â€“ for example, a disgraced minister has to balance addressing the crisis and caring for his son, while an ambulance nurse goes to great lengths to save her lover and a teenage girl protects a neighborâ€™s son after his family succumbs. Their stories slowly intertwine and the living nightmare fuels growing panic. Skybound Entertainment, no stranger to end-of-times narratives thanks to its work on The Walking Dead, controls the rights and struck a deal with Prime Video Nordics to local rights, while shopping it elsewhere. Amazon MGM Studios, Unlimited Stories and Sagafilm, the latter of which was acquired by Skybound and 5th Planet Games last year, are also attached, with Nordic soft money also involved. In a post-pandemic world where a collective trauma has been felt worldwide, the six-part series will have a greater significance for many viewers. Prime Video now also has rights in Spain, Italy, France, Germany, Poland and the Netherlands, and will launch the show on January 30, 2026.

Harvest (New8)

DR Sales

Oscar-nominated writer-director Martin Zandvlietâ€™s latest TV series is rather fantastically billed by its distributor, DR Sales, as â€œSuccession with tractors and tradition.â€ The eight-episode show stars the likes of Katrine Greis-Rosenthal, Elliott Crosset Hove, Lars Brygmann, Charlotte Fich, Simon Bennebjerg and Joachim Fjelstrup in a drama set in rural Denmark, where in-fighting breaks out over the future of a family farm. When the patriarch names his youngest daughter as his successor, the family is torn apart as her brother, a resentful nephew and others vie for control. The family are further forced into the spotlight by a shocking scare involving two missing children. European commissioning club New8 is behind the show, which Danish pubcaster DR had initially ordered in 2024. International delivery is expected in Q4 2026, with a festival release expected before that, around the second quarter of next year. Maybe this is one for Canneseries? Fans of Zandvlietâ€™s Academy Award-nominated Land of Mine will be ploughing the fields in anticipation for this one.

content:
Howie Klein, a veteran record executive, radio DJ and political activist who was a top executive in the Warner Bros. Records family during its golden era of the 1980s and early â€˜90s, died Wednesday after a long battle with cancer, according to a social media post from his sister. He was 77.

Most notably, he was Seymour Steinâ€™s no. 2 at Sire Records during the labelâ€™s peak era â€” a time when the label had everyone from the Smiths and Depeche Mode to Madonna and Lou Reed on its roster â€” and later was president of Warnerâ€™s Reprise label from 1989 to 2001. He was a strong and vocal presence in the music industryâ€™s anti-censorship efforts in the late â€˜80s and early â€˜90s and focused on political activism in his later years.

Popular on Variety

Born in Brooklyn in 1948, Klein began his music career at Long Islandâ€™s Stony Brook University, where he began writing about music and later booked them to perform at the school: The formidable roster of acts he booked in the late 1960s includes the Who, Jimi Hendrix, Joni Mitchell, Otis Redding, Pink Floyd, the Doors, Janis Joplin, the Grateful Dead, Tim Buckley, Jackson Browne, and many others. He spent several years traveling in Asia and Europe before settling in San Francisco in 1976. There, he became a popular DJ at the cityâ€™s KSAN and a vocal supporter of the then-nascent punk and alternative scenes, where he interviewed such acts as the Sex Pistols, Devo, Iggy Pop, the Cramps and others. In 1978, he co-founded the San Francisco-based 415 Records, which released singles and albums by Romeo Void, Wire Train, the Nuns, Translator and others, several of which were distributed by major labels.

Klein moved to Los Angeles to join Sire Records in 1987, which was then at the peak of its reign as a mecca of alternative music.

content:
A Christmas Eve jazz concert held annually for two decades at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts was canceled by its host this year in protest of the addition of Donald Trumpâ€˜s name to the Washington, D.C., building.

Chuck Redd, a jazz drummer and vibraphonist who has hosted the annual holiday â€œJazz Jamsâ€œ at the Kennedy Center since 2006 (he took over for previous host Keter Betts, a jazz bassist who died in 2005), told the Associated Press last night that he decided to drop this yearâ€™s event after Trumpâ€™s name was added to the venue by its Trump-appointed board.

â€œWhen I saw the name change on the Kennedy Center website and then hours later on the building, I chose to cancel our concert,â€ Redd told The Associated Press. The concert would have included performances from seven jazz musicians.

Watch on Deadline

The addition of Trumpâ€™s name to the venue appears to be in violation of a 1964 law that prohibits the addition of names or memorials to anyone other than John F. Kennedy, who had been assassinated in 1963. Rep. Joyce Beatty (D-OH) filed a lawsuit on Monday in federal court in Washington, D.C., seeking a declaration that the name of the arts institution is the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and that a board vote last week to change the name is null and void.

â€œBecause Congress named the center by statute, changing the Kennedy Centerâ€™s name requires an act of Congress,â€ Beattyâ€™s lawsuit stated. â€œBut on December 18 and 19, 2025â€”in scenes more reminiscent of authoritarian regimes than the American republicâ€”the sitting President and his handpicked loyalists renamed this storied center after President Trump. This is a flagrant violation of the rule of law, and it flies in the face of our constitutional order. Congress intended the Center to be a living memorial to President Kennedyâ€”and a crown jewel of the arts for all Americans, irrespective of party. Unless and until this Court intervenes, Defendants will continue to defy Congress and thwart the law for improper ends.â€

After Trumpâ€™s name was added to the venue, Roma Daravi, spokeswoman for the center, defended the boardâ€™s authority to change the name. â€œThis action is in line with the precedent of the State Department adding President Trumpâ€™s name to the Institute of Peace. And the previous Administration renaming military bases.â€ she said in a statement. (The renaming of the military bases that had Confederate names was authorized by an act of Congress in 2021.)

The jazz concert is just the latest casualty of Trumpâ€™s takeover of the venerable arts institution. Earlier this week, the American College Theatre Festival suspended its 60-year partnership with the Kennedy Center, with Festival officials saying the affiliation is â€œno longer viableâ€ due to â€œcircumstances and decisions that do not align with our organizationâ€™s values.â€

The Kennedy Center has not yet commented on the jazz concert cancellation, with its official website merely confirming that the concert was canceled. The website also indicates that admission to the concert was free of charge.

Among the artists who have canceled Kennedy Center appearances post-Trump takeover are Issa Rae, Peter Wolf and a planned production of Hamilton, among others.

title: Is â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™ Based on a Real Person? Hereâ€™s the True Story of Ping Pong Champion Marty Reisman
summary: Spoiler warning: This article contains spoilers for “Marty Supreme,” now in theaters. Josh Safdie’s “Marty Supreme” is galvanized by an invigorating performance by TimothÃ©e Chalamet as the cocky young table tennis champion Marty Mauser. content:
Spoiler warning: This article contains spoilers for â€œMarty Supreme,â€ now in theaters.

Josh Safdieâ€˜s â€œMarty Supremeâ€ is galvanized by an invigorating performance by TimothÃ©e Chalamet as the cocky young table tennis champion Marty Mauser. Safdie and his crew faithfully recreated the world of 1950s ping pong players in New York, Tokyo and beyond, then populated that milieu with a cast of memorable supporting characters from movie star Kay Stone, played by Gwyneth Paltrow, to her ruthless businessman husband, played by Mr. Wonderful himself, Kevin Oâ€™Leary.

The details of the parlors and matches are so carefully rendered that itâ€™s no surprise that Safdie is very familiar with that world. In fact, his 2008 film â€œThe Pleasure of Being Robbedâ€ features a sequence set in a Chinatown table tennis parlor.

Popular on Variety

â€œThe people who excelled at table tennis were often people who didnâ€™t fit anywhere else,â€ says Safdie in the filmâ€™s press materials. â€œIt wasnâ€™t respected, so naturally it attracted weirdos, purists, obsessives.â€

In addition to doing extensive historical research, the crew consulted experts, including Steve Grant, publisher of Table Tennis History magazine, who spoke to Variety about the inspiration for the film.

Was Marty Mauser based on a real person?

Marty Mauser, played by Chalamet, is based on a real table tennis champion of the 1950s, Marty Reisman, who died in 2012. Sports Illustrated called him â€œthe gameâ€™s most celebrated hustler.â€ While the film is only loosely inspired by his story, the character definitely shares similarities with Reisman, Grant explains.

â€œHe was very good at marketing himself,â€ Grant says, â€œThat was his biggest skill. Of course, he was a very good player.â€ But like Marty Mauser, who plays pretty loose with the truth, Reisman likely inflated his stories, Grant says. Reismanâ€™s book, â€œThe Money Player,â€ is a â€œgreat book about his career back in the â€™50s,â€ Grant explains. â€œBut donâ€™t take everything in it as the word of truth. He liked to exaggerate things.â€

When Safdie came across an old copy of â€œThe Money Player,â€ he sparked to the idea of a story based on Reisman. â€œWhen I read that the sport was filling stadiums in the U.K. and throughout Europe, I realized that it was entirely plausible for a kid in 1952 to actually believe he could parlay the game into a life of fame and glory,â€ Safdie said in the press materials.

How many of Marty Supremeâ€™s stunts were real?

While many of Marty Mauserâ€™s antics stretch credulity, the real Reisman, nicknamed â€œthe needleâ€ for his slight build and fast swing, was known for his showmanship and hustle. He could split a cigarette in half with a ping pong ball from across the net and would play blindfolded or sitting down if the stakes were high enough. As shown in the film, he and a partner did tour the world with the Harlem Globetrotters with a comedy ping pong routine in which they hit balls with frying pans and sneakers.

Varietyâ€™s announcement of â€œThe Money Playerâ€ option

The real Reisman pulled off enough wild escapades to fill a whole other movie, according to an extensive Sports Illustrated profile â€” as he traveled the world, he was smuggling and selling goods, from nylon stockings to fine crystal, and challenging heads of state to high-stakes games. He really did fly on a military transport, as shown in the film, and did briefly work in a shoe store. Reisman told the magazine his book had sold to the movies, and he proposed that Robert De Niro could play him. But although it was optioned after publication, according to a 1974 Variety article, the project never got off the ground.

Did Reisman really lose the World Championship to a Japanese player?

Reisman traveled to India, not Japan as in the movie, to compete against Hiroji Satoh. As depicted in the film, he took a hard loss to Satoh, who was using a new sponge rubber-coated type of paddle. But the loss came in round 64, not the final. â€œThe truth was he would have had to win five more matches in 1952 to win the title, and he was not the top favorite,â€ Grant explains.

Were there other Jewish table tennis champions?

â€œFellow Jewish New Yorker Dick Miles won many championships in the 1940s and â€™50s, well before Reisman won much of anything,â€ Grant explains. In fact, Jewish Europeans, especially Hungarians, dominated table tennis in the 1920s and 1930s. In the 1950s, Asian and particularly Japanese players began to gain prominence in the sport.

Were any other characters based on real people?

While many of the filmâ€™s characters feel deeply authentic, most are fictional, with the exception of Koto Endo, played by real-life champion Koto Kawaguchi and based on Reismanâ€™s competitor Satoh. Thereâ€™s also basketball star George â€œThe Ice Manâ€ Gervin, who plays a character based on Herwald Lawrence, who owned a ping pong parlor that was the first Black-owned business in Times Square.

Playwright David Mamet has a cameo in the film and he has a historic ping pong connection. Mamet, who was a table tennis hustler himself in his college days, used to frequent Reismanâ€™s table tennis gym on the Upper West Side, along with other notables including Dustin Hoffman and Matthew Broderick.

Jimmy Kimmel has delivered a scathing â€” and typically comical â€” attack on president Donald Trump in a special Christmas Day address to the U.K. on Channel 4.

For its 2025 annual Alternative Christmas Message, broadcast by the Brit network since 1993 with an eclectic array of guests invited to speak over the years, Channel 4 turned to Kimmel, who used the opportunity to claim that â€œtyranny is boomingâ€ in the U.S. thanks to Trump, who he said â€œthinks he is our king.â€

Kimmel also reflected on the controversial â€” and brief â€” suspension of his talk show â€œJimmy Kimmel Liveâ€ from ABC after comments he made in the wake of Charlie Kirkâ€™s murder, accusing Trump of trying to â€œshut me up because I donâ€™t adore him in the way he likes to be adored.â€

Popular on Variety

His return to airwaves he likened to an (early) â€œChristmas miracle,â€ asserting it was because people stood up to support free expression of speech. â€œOur show came back stronger than ever. We won, the President lost and now Iâ€™m back on the air every night giving the most powerful politician on earth a right and richly deserved bollocking,â€ he said, deploying a rather British term. â€œThatâ€™s a word, right, I used it properly?â€

Kimmel concluded his message, broadcast shortly after the more traditional Kingâ€™s Christmas Day speech, by apologizing to the U.K. for the current state of the U.S., asserting that Americans are â€œnot all likeâ€ Trump and urging Brits to hold out.

â€œNo one knows better than you weâ€™re always just a little bit late to the game, but do we come through in the end? Maybe. Give us about three years. Please.â€

See the full transcript of Kimmelâ€™s Christmas Day message below:

Hi Iâ€™m Jimmy Kimmel.

I have no idea if you know who I am, but I was asked to deliver this yearâ€™s Alternative Christmas Message (which Iâ€™ve heard is a big deal) so I hope you do, but if not I host what you call a chat show (we call it a talk show) in what you call the colonies, I think? I honestly have no idea whatâ€™s going on over there.

I do know whatâ€™s going on over here though, and I can tell you that, from a fascism perspective, this has been a really great year. Tyranny is booming over here.

You may have read in your colourful newspapers my countryâ€™s President would like to shut me up because I donâ€™t adore him in the way he likes to be adored. The American government made a threat against me and the company I work for, and all of a sudden we were off the air. But then, you know what happened? A Christmas miracle happened. Well, it was September, it was a September miracle. But the holiday does seem to come earlier and earlier every year, doesnâ€™t it?

Millions and millions of people stood up and said: â€˜No, this is not acceptableâ€™. People who never watched my show, people who were on record saying they hate my show spoke out, they marched, they did this all to support the right to a free expression of speech and because so many people spoke out, we came back. Our show came back stronger than ever. We won, the President lost and now Iâ€™m back on the air every night givinâ€™ the most powerful politician on earth a right and richly deserved bollocking. Thatâ€™s a word, right, I used it properly?

And the reason Iâ€™m telling you this story is because maybe youâ€™re thinking: â€˜Oh a government silencing its critics is something that happens in places like Russia, or North Korea, or LA, not the UKâ€™. Well, thatâ€™s what we thought and now weâ€™ve got King Donny the Eighth calling for executions. It happens fast.

You know itâ€™s funny we Americans are very proud of not having a king. Itâ€™s kind of why we left. Earlier this year tens of millions of us marched at protests called No Kings. You had some of those there. And just for the record we have nothing against your king. I mean I donâ€™t know if you know this, but his son lives here. We just â€“ well some of us â€“ just have a problem with the guy who thinks he is our king.

Here in the United States right now we are both figuratively and literally tearing down the structures of our democracy. From the free press, to science, to medicine, to judicial independence, to the actual White House itself, we are a right mess. And we know this is also affecting you, and I just wanted to say sorry. And we want you to know or, at least I want you to know, that weâ€™re not all like him. Weâ€™re not all like that.

Look I know (from the musical Hamilton) that our countries didnâ€™t start off on the greatest note, but I also know (from seeing Love Actually) that we have a special relationship. So, if I might speak on behalf of my country â€“ which I most certainly do not â€“ our message to you, our friends across the pond this Christmas is: donâ€™t give up on us. Weâ€™re going through a bit of a wobble right now, but weâ€™ll come around. It may not seem like it, but we love you guys. We even love the things about you that you donâ€™t like, like Simon Cowell for instance. We are not bright. Weâ€™re Americans. No one knows better than you weâ€™re always just a little bit late to the game, but do we come through in the end? Maybe. Give us about three years. Please. Thank you for your patience, and thank you for Spider-Man. Merry Christmas, and happy holidays.

title: Martin Scorsese Remembers Rob Reiner: â€˜He Had a Beautiful Sense of Uninhibited Freedomâ€™

content:
Martin Scorsese honored the late Reiners in an essay published in The New York Times, writing, â€œRob Reiner was my friend, and so was Michele. From now on, Iâ€™ll have to use the past tense, and that fills me with such profound sadness. But thereâ€™s no other choice.â€

The Reiners, aged 78 and 70, were found dead in their Brentwood home on Dec. 14 with knife wounds. Their 32-year-old son, Nick Reiner, has been arrested and charged with two counts of murder.

Scorsese first got to know Rob Reiner shortly after moving to Los Angeles in the early 1970s, when he started going to get-togethers hosted by George Memmoli and filled with comedians and actors.

Popular on Variety

â€œRob and I were both Eastern transplants, in a way,â€ Scorsese wrote. Reiner came from show business royalty, his parents being the performers Carl and Estelle Reiner. â€œThis was 100 percent New York humor, and it was in the air I breathed.â€

â€œRight away, I loved hanging out with Rob. We had a natural affinity for each other. He was hilarious and sometimes bitingly funny, but he was never the kind of guy who would take over the room,â€ Scorsese wrote. â€œHe had a beautiful sense of uninhibited freedom, fully enjoying the life of the moment, and he had a great barreling laugh. When they honored him at Lincoln Center, Michael McKean did a bit, which was a brilliant parody of solemn official tribute speeches. Before he got to the punchline, Rob laughed so hard you could hear it throughout the auditorium.â€

Scorseseâ€™s favorite film directed by Reiner is â€œMisery,â€ which he described as â€œa very special film, beautifully acted by Kathy Bates and James Caan.â€ And he wrote that â€œThis Is Spinal Tapâ€ is â€œin a class of its own â€¦ an immaculate creation.â€ When Scorsese was casting his 2013 film â€œThe Wolf of Wall Street,â€ he â€œimmediately thought of Robâ€ to play the father of Leonardo DiCaprioâ€™s Jordan Belfort.

â€œHe could improvise with the best, he was a master at comedy, he worked beautifully with Leo and the rest of the guys, and he understood the human predicament of his character: The man loved his son, he was happy with his success, but he knew that he was destined for a fall,â€ Scorsese wrote of Reiner. â€œThereâ€™s that wonderful moment where Rob watches as Jon Favreau explains to Leo that he can get out relatively unscathed if he just walks away from his company before the S.E.C. has a chance to charge him with violations. The look on Robâ€™s face, as he realizes that Leo is hesitating and that he ultimately wonâ€™t stop, is so eloquent. â€˜You got all the money in the world,â€™ he says. â€˜You need everybody elseâ€™s money?â€™ A loving father, mystified by his son.â€

Scorsese added, â€œI was moved by the delicacy and openness of his performance when we shot it, moved once again as we brought the scene together in the edit and moved as I watched the finished picture. Now, it breaks my heart to even think of the tenderness of Robâ€™s performance in this and other scenes.â€

The filmmaker concluded his essay: â€œWhat happened to Rob and Michele is an obscenity, an abyss in lived reality. The only thing that will help me to accept it is the passing of time. So, like all of their loved ones and their friends â€” and these were people with many, many friends â€” I have to be allowed to imagine them alive and well â€¦ and that one day, Iâ€™ll be at a dinner or a party and find myself seated next to Rob, and Iâ€™ll hear his laugh and see his beatific face and laugh at his stories and relish his natural comic timing, and feel lucky all over again to have him as a friend.â€

Karen Glass, a former Disney studio exec who helped develop The Princess Diaries and Tuck Everlasting before she began producing holiday TV movies, died Monday, December 22. She was 63.

A sister of radio host Ira Glass, Karen Glass most recently exec produced this yearâ€™s Lifetime holiday movie A Pickleball Christmas starring James Lafferty and Zibby Allen. She reportedly was already working on a new mahjong-themed holiday movie.

Her death was announced by family in an obituary. A cause was not disclosed.

Watch on Deadline

According to previously published reports, Glass joined the Walt Disney Co. in 1989 as a member of the marketing team at Buena Vista Television. The following year she began a five-year association with Buena Vista Pictures Distribution, where she was a manager of sales administration before being promoted to director of theatrical strategy and planning. In 1995, she joined Buena Vista Pictures Marketing as a director of national promotions and in 1996 served as exec director on national promotions.

During her tenure at Disney â€“ she left in 2006 â€“ Glass helped spearhead The Princess Diaries (she bought the book for the studio and insisted on hiring Julie Andrews for the film), Tuck Everlasting, and Herbie Fully Loaded, among many others.

After leaving Disney, Glass became a prolific producer of TV holiday movies, including such films as Ice Princess starring Michelle Trachtenberg (2005) and Same Time, Next Christmas starring Lea Michele (2019). Glassâ€™ other holiday-themed TV credits include, among others, Never Kiss a Man in a Christmas Sweater (2020), Christmas Class Reunion (2022) and Leahâ€™s Perfect Gift (2024).

Glass, a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and the UCLA Anderson School of Business, recently started a business, Glassworks College Advising, to counsel high school students applying to college.

In addition to brother Ira Glass, Karen Glass is survived by son Zachary Sean Barry; sister Randi Glass Murray; in-laws David Meckel and Susanna Fogel; stepmother Sandy Glass; nephews Sam and Ben Murray; and uncle Bennett Politzer.
