content:
SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from Stranger Things 5 Volume 2.

Jamie Campbell Bowerâ€˜s Vecna only gets more terrifying in Volume 2 of the final season, which sees the monster get another step closer to enacting his plan to merge the human world with another dimension.

As viewers learn over the course of the three episodes, the Upside Down is a wormhole that has connected Hawkins to this alternate dimension that Dustin dubs â€œThe Abyss,â€ which they believe is the true home of the mind flayer, the demogorgons, and the rest of the evils that have been haunting them for the past four years â€” even, it seems, Henry Creel.

The characters have been completely unable to locate Vecna all season, because, as it turns out, heâ€™s been hiding in this alternate dimension that they were unaware of and canâ€™t access (since it is situated thousands of yards above them). While theyâ€™re unraveling this mystery, Vecna is busy trying to keep Holly (Nell Fisher) and Max (Sadie Sink) from escaping his mind prison. The girls realize that, in order to get out, theyâ€™ll need to trek their way through Henryâ€™s memories instead of their own, leading to a heartbreaking moment where they witness a very young Henry murder a man he encountersâ€¦in a cave. This seems to give insights on why Henry wonâ€™t enter the cave that Max and Holly have been hiding in within his mind, though there are still some questions left to be answered in the finale.

Watch on Deadline

While Max manages to get out, Holly isnâ€™t so lucky. By the end of the penultimate episode, sheâ€™s back in his clutches and Henry begins his process to merge the worlds, teasing one final face off to come in the 2-hour finale.

â€œ[Episode] 8 comes in steaming hot, right off the back of 7. Itâ€™s go time. Itâ€™s really, really explosive,â€ Campbell Bower tells Deadline.

In the interview below, the actor unpacks his descent further into the madness of Henry Creel for Volume 2 of the fifth and final season of Stranger Things.

L-R: Noah Schnapp as Will Byers and Jamie Campbell Bower as Vecna in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Courtesy of Netflix

DEADLINE: Was any of this information weâ€™ve learned about Henry since Season 4 pitched to you when you took the role? How much did you initially know?

JAMIE CAMPBELL BOWER: I donâ€™t think any of it was pitched to me when I joined. I do remember towards the end of filming the Henry portion of Season 4, Matt and Ross, sort of, we had a little aside conversation, and they were like, â€˜This has been amazing. We were always going to bring you back as Vecna, but now we feel like we should bring you back more as you.â€™ and I was just like, â€˜Cool. Sounds great. Whatever you guys want.â€™ So, with regards to the story arc, none of it was pitched to me, and I think it was, from what Iâ€™ve heard and read from Matt and Ross, it was something that sort of developed in the in-between time.

DEADLINE: I do really enjoy that we get to see more of Henry this season. And Iâ€™m curious how it was for you working with some of these younger kids, especially having to be so cruel to them? What did you gain from that experience? Because theyâ€™re giving you so much back emotionally. And I wonder, for you as such a as a more seasoned, older actor, how that was to kind of get to play in that sandbox with them.

CAMPBELL BOWER: It was awesome. I mean, there were definitely times where it was terrifying for me. Iâ€™ve been vocal about this today and when we were discussing the first chapters as well. The Mr. Whatsit side of things, this is a presentation, and the intention is buried. So when youâ€™re sat opposite a child, burying the intention, children, naturally, can see through the BS and lies. Itâ€™s a very terrifying experience at times to be sat thereâ€¦but it was also a lot of fun too, because the kids were so great. There was so many funny moments where weâ€™d be playing games between takes, and particularly that last scene in Episode 7, where weâ€™re all sat round the table, it was one of the first times where, I mean, you know, obviously, aside from the beginning of five, we were all together, and we had a lovely day. It was just a beautiful, fun experience to play with them. Theyâ€™re so great and so receptive, and it was a joy to be able to get to know them and work with them. All of them are amazing. I love Jake dearly. I just think heâ€™s the loveliest boy, and I got to know his family too, and heâ€™s just a great kid. Iâ€™m so glad that the fan base and the world has taken Derek into their hearts. It was always the thing that I hoped most for him. I was like, â€˜Heâ€™s so cool. I hope that that happens,â€™ and it has, and Iâ€™m so happy for him.

DEADLINE: Youâ€™ve talked about Henry and especially Vecnaâ€™s head being a hard place to live in as an actor, and Iâ€™m curious how this was for you to get to unpack some of what happened to him as he was a kid? Iâ€™m thinking particularly about the scene where we get to see Henry as a young boy kill that scientist in the cave, and thatâ€™s a really jarring scene.

CAMPBELL BOWER: It is something that I thought about going into Season 4, even, and had qualified between 4 and 5 when I went to go and see the play. So, getting to play those scenes out, I felt at times like a huge release, and it was also really important for me to go into those scenes understanding the trauma and the experience to bring that level of humanity forward. Iâ€™ve been describing Henry this season, and the way I approached it as, like, memory retention, but buried far away. So when I get to uncover that, dig that up, it does humanize the experience and the character for me, because there are times where I feel wildly inhuman, monstrous, and I know that sounds obvious, but like truly monstrous. So I took great pleasure in those moments for sure.

DEADLINE: Thereâ€™s a scene in Episode [5] that I really like where we see in real time Henry kind of transitioned from One to Vecna. How did you think about the subtle differences in the evolution of that character throughout those periods of time to be able to pull off something like that?

CAMPBELL BOWER: I mean, I think it was always that thing of, like, the mask failing, it falling away, and where I got to with Henry at the end of Episode 7 of Season 4 was the way in which I wanted to be bringing him back when we saw him again. It was in that emotional space. Having lived in Mr. Whatsit already in Season 5, there is a difference for me between them, subtle though it may be, there is a difference. So yes, there are emotional differences and difficulties, but also physical [ones]. That particular moment, the physicality of that was something that we worked on with, actually, with somebody who works in the video game space, and using things like called nodes, which are like particular moments that you strike and that youâ€™ll come back to. So the shift between Whatsit and Henry was something that we worked on off set prior to shooting it.

I was going through my videos the other day, and Iâ€™m there on the stage doing it, trying out different things, trying out how I wanted my head to move and where my arms were going to be. Yes, that is a very short moment, but it is something that we spent a long time on, just to make sure that it was right and that it felt cool. So much of that is about intuition and the work that goes into it beforehand, so that when you get into the space, itâ€™s just like, â€˜Oh, this is what naturally these characters would do here.â€™ It was really fun. It was really cool to do the sort of more shape-shifty bits. In England, we have three exams in your years between, like, 13 and 18, and the middle one is called your AS (Advanced Subsidiary) Levels, and I did dance AS Levels. I got to lean quite heavily into that dance side of my childhood, which was really fun. It was nice to know that that was still in there, and, God, like it hasnâ€™t completely gone.

Jamie Campbell Bower as Henry Creel in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Courtesy of Netflix

DEADLINE: How you view, emotionally, that separation between Henry and Vecna? Is it just a loss of humanity? How do you make that distinction in your head when youâ€™re playing those characters?

CAMPBELL BOWER: I mean, it depends on what weâ€™re referring to as a loss of humanity, really. Because, is it the distance from the heart, or is it like monstrous in the sense of monsters? I think Henry was so close, was much closer to innocence, was much closer to the experiences, and then when he was sent to that slippery, veiny demise at the end of [Season] 4, it became about resentment, and at that point, it felt like humanity had gone. It felt like the possibility of love was so far away. I refer to love as that thing that keeps us alive, and so I think Henry, if we look at it this way, like Henry is close to innocence, Whatsit is further removed, and Vecna is just likeâ€¦itâ€™s impossible â€” virtually impossible â€” for there to be anything that feels like love.

DEADLINE: What are you excited for from the finale, and what you ultimately hope people take away from this character that youâ€™ve spent so much time thinking about and playing?

CAMPBELL BOWER: So with regards to what we can expect for the finale, I am genuinely, really excited for Episode 8 to come out. I feel like Episode 7 is â€” because I obviously know whatâ€™s coming in 8, and we do leave on quite, in my opinion, knowing whatâ€™s coming, quite a hefty cliffhanger, and 8 comes in steaming hot, right off the back of 7. Itâ€™s go time. Itâ€™s really, really explosive. Iâ€™m really excited for people to see that, because I know how it felt to work on it, too, and thatâ€™s really cool. What do I hope people take away from this character? Wow, Iâ€™m still in process on that. Like, Iâ€™m genuinely still in process on that, because I spent so much time in it, and I donâ€™t know if I can yet see the wood from the trees. Iâ€™m not sure. So much of this character is based on the idea of loneliness. So much of this character is based on the idea of salvation. I had to fall in love, and I did fall in love with Henry Creel. I had to want to protect him. I had to want to nurture him and love him, because thatâ€™s my duty as the person thatâ€™s playing him. I have to understand him, and I donâ€™t know how it feels to be a viewer, yet, watching that from afar, I donâ€™t know. Iâ€™d have to give myself another six months to truly be able to absorb that.

title: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€² Creators & Star Noah Schnapp Unpack Will Byersâ€™ Leap Of Faith In Volume 2: â€œIt Was So Freeingâ€
summary: SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from Stranger Things 5 Volume 2. Will Byers (Noah Schnapp) takes a big leap of faith in the penultimate episode of Stranger Things 5. After escaping Vecna’s mind invasion, Will realizes that he’ll continue to be vulnerable to the monster unless he comes clean about a secret he’s been […]
content:
SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from Stranger Things 5 Volume 2.

Will Byers (Noah Schnapp) takes a big leap of faith in the penultimate episode of Stranger Things 5.

After escaping Vecnaâ€™s mind invasion, Will realizes that heâ€™ll continue to be vulnerable to the monster unless he comes clean about a secret heâ€™s been keeping. So, rather than continue to let Vecna pray on his guilt and shame, he takes control of his own destiny. In a moving scene in Episode 7, â€œThe Bridge,â€ Will comes out as gay in front of all of his friends and family.

â€œIt was so freeing. I mean, thereâ€™s been so much build up for this scene for so long. Since, I would argue, episode one of the first season,â€ Schnapp tells Deadline. â€œSo getting to finally have that moment and just have that dialogueâ€¦ Will is always speaking through so much of his facial expressions, but to actually verbalize his emotions and express them to everyone was so freeing to finally get to do.â€

Watch on Deadline

While this is the first time that Will has said out loud that he doesnâ€™t like girls, creators Matt and Ross Duffer seemed to be dropping hints regarding his sexuality in earlier seasons. Throughout Season 5, it became much more obvious when Will found out about Robinâ€™s (Maya Hawke) relationship with Vickie (Amybeth McNulty) and began peppering his friend with questions about how she came to terms with her own sexuality.

But, it isnâ€™t until heâ€™s tortured again by Vecna that he realizes the only way forward is to open up about this part of his identity. In part, Schnapp says, Will refrained from doing so sooner because, even though heâ€™d come to accept his sexuality, he was still grappling with his feelings for his best friend, Mike Wheeler (Finn Wolfhard).

By the time he comes clean, Schnapp thinks heâ€™s made peace with the fact that Mike is likely not going to reciprocate those feelings â€” a realization he says felt quite relatable.

â€œHe accepts his own identity by the first volume, and thatâ€™s what allows him to unleash these powers,â€ Schnapp explains. â€œBut then, like he says, it takes him through kind of Volume 2 to really understand that it was never about [Mike], itâ€™s about himself. I mean, I think it was just really well done and really authentic to how the story unfolds. I know I could definitely relate to some of those feelings of being in love with a best friend whoâ€™s not in love with you. It feels [like a] realistic representation of being queer and growing up.â€

Noah Schnapp as Will Byers and Finn Wolfhard as Mike Wheeler in â€˜Stranger Things: Season 5â€™ Courtesy of Netflix

Schnapp has been very vocal about his thoughts on Willâ€™s sexuality, though it was never explicitly confirmed by series creators Matt and Ross Duffer before now, which has only fueled online discussion as fans began to suspect that it might play a pivotal role in his Season 5 arc. As he pointed out, the series has been alluding to this moment since Season 1, when Willâ€™s friends used to tease him about not liking girls.

Now, creators Matt and Ross Duffer admit the scene is â€œsomething weâ€™ve been building to for a long time,â€ as the latter tells Deadline.

â€œI think mostly we were nervous, as we just wanted to do right by Noah. Obviously, weâ€™ve been working with him for so long, since he was a little kid, and we knew that this scene, obviously, weâ€™ve talked about it over the years with him,â€ Ross continued. â€œWe knew it was important, and we all wanted to get it right. Thereâ€™s not a scene, I donâ€™t think, in the entire series that we spent as long on as we did that coming out scene, just working it and working it until it felt right to us.â€

How did they know when they got it right? Getting the seal of approval from the actor who has been playing the character for a decade and arguably knows him better than anyone.

â€œThe litmus test was giving it to Noah, but then seeing how he responded to it and reacted to it gave us confidence,â€ Ross added.

Schnapp says that, in some ways, Willâ€™s coming out felt parallel to his own, allowing him to draw from his own experience to access his characterâ€™s emotions for that moment and â€œmake it feel so real.â€ Still, there were some cultural and political differences in the 40-year span between the two boysâ€™ revelations that the actor wanted to ensure were taken seriously as well.

â€œ[It was about] making sure I really understood the environment and the landscape that Iâ€™m declaring this in, where the AIDS epidemic was rampant, the Reagan administration wouldnâ€™t even acknowledge that gay was a real word. If you even so much as came out, people thought you were sick and were contagious,â€ he said.

Will has a genuine concern that he â€œcould be abandoned and lose everything,â€ Schnapp says, â€œso just having the stakes in my head that I really wanted to make sure I got right.â€

â€œI just, of course, wanted it to feel as authentic as possible. Itâ€™s such an important scene, because itâ€™s going to affect so many real young Wills out there struggling with their own identity, and I wanted it to be perfect for them and do justice to this character, which has been leading up to this for so long. So, yeah, just making it feel as authentic and natural as possible,â€ he continued.

(L to R) Noah Schnapp as Will Byers, Finn Wolfhard as Mike Wheeler, and Winona Ryder as Joyce Byers Netflix

During the scene, Will breaks down as he confesses that Vecna had tried to convince him that his loved ones wouldnâ€™t stand by him if they knew the truth. While he was trapped in Vecnaâ€™s mindscape, he says the monster showed him a false reality where he lost several of them to this admission. It wasnâ€™t that they outright rejected him, but according to Vecnaâ€™s vision of the future, many began to slowly distance themselves from him once he revealed his full self. He says he hopes that, by telling them the truth, he can prove to himself â€” and to Vecna â€” that wonâ€™t happen.

While trepidatious at first, once Will begins his monologue, the words just start pouring out of him, almost uncontrollably.

â€œHe had [the scene] months in advance, and he just worked it and worked it,â€ Ross Duffer recalls. â€œI remember him telling usâ€¦he wanted to not even have to think about the words on the day, because it would just allow him to sort of access this part of himself where heâ€™s not thinking about the language of it all, heâ€™s just letting the emotion come through. Thatâ€™s exactly what we did, and weâ€™re so proud of him [and] what he accomplished on that thing.â€

To his relief, Will is met with unwavering support from everyone in the room. And, when it came time to film the scene, so, too, was Schnapp. To capture both Schnappâ€™s performance and the reactions of the rest of the cast took an entire 12-hour production day, after which Matt Duffer says the actor â€œlooked like he was about to collapse.â€

Even when the camera was firmly on Schnapp, the rest of the cast made sure to be there for every single take. Likewise, Schnapp repeated the lengthy speech several times with the same fervor when the cameras were focused on coverage of everyone else.

â€œHe poured everything into every single take,â€ Matt said. â€œI think that brought out these incredible performances in [the cast], and I think they got lost in what he was saying, and it was moving them in a very real way, because Noah was very, very, very emotional that day, and very moving.â€

As a result, says Shawn Levy, who directed the episode with the Duffers, â€œthe thing that makes that scene even more beautiful and memorable is the reactions of the other characters and actors.â€

Throughout Willâ€™s speech, the camera cuts repeatedly to Jonathan (Charlie Heaton) and Robin, who are both beaming with pride at his extraordinary display of vulnerability, and the rest of the teenagerâ€™s closest confidantes â€” all of whom are giving them their undivided attention as he pours his heart out to them.

Usually, â€œitâ€™s always so loud and chaotic on set, especially when the whole cast is there. There is no silence. Everyoneâ€™s messing around. Everyoneâ€™s making jokes,â€ Schnapp says. But, on that day, â€œyou could hear a pin drop.â€

Stranger Things 5

â€œThey were so respectful and gave me so much space to get into the character, which I really appreciated. I didnâ€™t really get to fully take note of all their reactions, just because thereâ€™s so many people in the room, and Iâ€™m so emotional,â€ he continued. â€œSo it really only hit me after, when I watched it, seeing how genuine it felt. And then, of course, when we cut the cameras, Charlie and I started hugging and crying for real. So it definitely hit home.â€

Willâ€™s coming out is a big milestone not only in his personal life but also, presumably, in the fight against Vecna. As for how things will pan out in that department, Schnapp is staying quiet for now.

â€œI guess youâ€™re gonna have to wait and see,â€ he teased. â€œIâ€™m excited to to share it with the world.â€

The finale of Stranger Things arrives on December 31.

summary: Rukmini Vasanth is having a moment. Fresh off Rishab Shetty’s blockbuster “Kantara: A Legend – Chapter 1,” the Indian actor has Yash’s “Toxic” and a Prashanth Neel film with NTR Jr. on deck, and her approach is clear: women with agency who make decisive choices. content:
Rukmini Vasanth is having a moment. Fresh off Rishab Shettyâ€˜s blockbuster â€œKantara: A Legend â€“ Chapter 1,â€ the Indian actor has Yashâ€˜s â€œToxicâ€ and a Prashanth Neel film with NTR Jr. on deck, and her approach is clear: women with agency who make decisive choices.

The Royal Academy of Dramatic Art graduate, who gained recognition for her nuanced work in the critically acclaimed â€œSapta Sagaradaache Elloâ€ films (2023) opposite Rakshit Shetty, tells Variety that her performance as Kanakavathi in Rishab Shettyâ€™s mythological prequel was carefully architected from the start.

Set centuries before the events of the 2022 sleeper hit, â€œKantara: A Legend â€“ Chapter 1â€ follows the conflict over sacred forest land, with Vasanthâ€™s character harboring secret ambitions that ultimately drive the narrative. The pivotal nature of her role was established from her first meeting with Shetty and his writing team of Anirudh Mahesh and Shanil Guru, with the characterâ€™s carefully concealed motivations and dramatic reveal integral to the filmâ€™s structure from the beginning.

Popular on Variety

â€œWhen Sir [Rishab Shetty] called me in for my first narration with him, and he told me upfront that this is all going to hinge on this girlâ€™s sudden twist and the deep-held desire of hers to take over this land that she doesnâ€™t reveal until the last moment,â€ Vasanth says. â€œThat was very much planned, and that was something that I walked into fully aware of from the first meeting.â€

The actor acknowledges the responsibility was daunting, particularly given the massive success of the first â€œKantaraâ€ film. However, the prequelâ€™s distinct historical setting and visual identity helped establish different audience expectations.

â€œFrom all the material that the filmâ€™s team had released, audiences were kind of prepared for the fact that this is a very different world that weâ€™re going into,â€ she explains. â€œItâ€™s not the same 1990s Kundapura that we had seen in the previous film. This is a very different world, and I think that leveling of the ground helped me because I didnâ€™t feel as if people were expecting to see a certain kind of character.â€

Bringing her London drama school training to bear, Vasanth discusses the challenge of calibrating performance style to match the scale of â€œKantara: A Legend â€“ Chapter 1â€ while maintaining emotional authenticity â€“ a marked departure from her breakthrough work in Hemanth M. Raoâ€™s â€œSapta Sagaradaache Elloâ€ films, which she describes as prizing silence and spaces within dialogue and interaction.

â€œOne of the beautiful things that Iâ€™ve been able to learn over my career is which style and where it belongs,â€ she says. â€œIn the world of â€˜Kantara: Chapter 1,â€™ some of the more restrained stuff can look too subtle to register because the scale is so large that you need to be able to match that scale.â€

Vasanth uses a vivid analogy to explain her approach to calibrating performance. â€œYou kind of need to regulate what is needed of you,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s like speaking â€“ in a quiet living room, you can afford to whisper, but if youâ€™re in the tube, you need to shout a little bit.â€

Rukmini Vasanth â€“ â€œKantara: A Legend â€“ Chapter 1â€ Hombale Films

The actor credits her disciplined approach to her background, with a father in the military and a mother who is a dancer. However, she emphasizes that her time at drama school was where she truly internalized the necessity of preparation and consistency.

â€œThe discipline and preparation gives you the ability to show up regardless of what the outside variables may be,â€ Vasanth says. â€œYou canâ€™t really be too precious about the kinds of environments that you require in order to put out a good performance for a film that deserves that.â€

She describes the challenging production conditions on â€œKantara: A Legend â€“ Chapter 1,â€ with constant rain and limited shooting windows. â€œYouâ€™d have the crew members carrying these giant rigs up and down a hill. So at that point you canâ€™t really be like, it doesnâ€™t feel right to me. You just have to get on with it and do it as well as you possibly can.â€

Looking at her filmography, Vasanth has gravitated toward characters who are emotionally decisive, even when constrained by circumstances. She attributes this pattern to what makes for compelling storytelling.

â€œCharacters that make decisions, that may not be the right ones necessarily or the wrong ones, but that make decisions of some kind, and then that pulls the story along â€“ I think I know what to do in those moments,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s just women with some sort of agency doing things.â€

Vasanthâ€™s upcoming projects include â€œThe Elder Oneâ€ director Geethu Mohandasâ€™ highly anticipated â€œToxicâ€ opposite â€œK.G.Fâ€ star Yash, and a film with â€œSalaarâ€ and â€œK.G.Fâ€ filmmaker Prashanth Neel featuring â€œRRRâ€ lead NTR Jr.

Of â€œToxic,â€ she says that it has challenged her in unprecedented ways. â€œItâ€™s unlike anything that Iâ€™ve taken on before, which has equal doses of nerves to see how it unfolds,â€ she says. â€œThe working style has been really, really fascinating and very different from anything Iâ€™ve encountered. The way that Yash Sir and Geethu approach this film, the scripts, the way that weâ€™ve gone about shooting has been an incomparable experience for me.â€

As for working with Neel and NTR Jr., she praises their continued enthusiasm for the craft. â€œItâ€™s always very lovely when you work with people who come with such a strong body of work, but are very unencumbered by whatever that may have brought. You still see the sense of play and the sense of enjoyment.â€

On the topic of pan-India casting, Vasanth suggests the label is more relevant to the commercial side of cinema than the creative. She points to historical precedents, including actor-director V. Ravichandranâ€™s multi-industry production â€œShanti Krantiâ€ (1991).

â€œI think pan-India films have been happening. Theyâ€™ve been attempted for a really long time,â€ she says. â€œThose are just labels and actors have been working across multiple industries all the time. Weâ€™re all very lucky that itâ€™s successful and lucrative also now.â€

Vasanth is now working across multiple South Indian film industries, with upcoming projects in Kannada, Tamil and Telugu cinema, representing a new generation of actors operating fluidly across linguistic markets. She declined to comment on reports of a collaboration with director Mani Ratnam.

Ilya teased Shane about maybe marrying his best friend, Svetlana (Ksenia Daniela Kharlamova), or another woman so as not to blow their cover. But then he admitted he had a problem â€“â€“ none of those women were Shane. Shane, in turn, pulled an all-nighter churning out a plan for them to slowly ease the world into the idea of their relationship, starting with Ilya joining the Ottawa team to be closer to him in Montreal, and then they would co-found a charity to start melting the supposedly frigid animosity between them. It was a long-game plan, but the mere mental gymnastics of trying to set up their future together moved Ilya to tears, and left him coughing up those three wordsâ€“â€“ â€œI love you.â€ Shane immediately reciprocated it with lightning-fast urgency, obliterating one of the last barriers between them.

Popular on Variety

Hudson Williams, Connor Storrie, Dylan Walsh and Christina Chang Courtesy of Sabrina Lantos/HBO Max

From there, the tenor of their cottage getaway changed, and ultimately felt more romantic than ever. That is, until Shaneâ€™s dad, David (Dylan Walsh), walked in on them kissing and fled before his son could explain. Shane had put off telling his parents about being gay or loving his archrival. But now, Shane and Ilya both went to see David and Yuna (Christina Chang) to break the news. It was a tough pill to swallow, but not because they donâ€™t approve of their son. Rather, it completely shatters his hockey-loving parentsâ€™ 10-year-plus belief they hated each other. Instead, they finally see two young men, who have been crazy about each other since rookie year (or rather, the summer before!), now sitting at the Hollandersâ€™ dinner table as a couple. Ilya even comforts Shane in a moment of panic by calling him his boyfriend, a simple but monumental step for Hollanov, as the internet has dubbed them.

Season 1 ends as the boys drive back to their refuge away from the world, staring down a beautiful sunset that hides everything that waits on the other side of their cottage chapter, which will play out in an already-ordered Season 2. Thatâ€™s a little different from the conclusion of Rachel Reidâ€™s book, on which the series is based, in which they launch their foundation to lay the groundwork for the future. However, series creator/writer/director Jacob Tierney wanted something more romantic for his final shot, just in case the series didnâ€™t become the phenomenon that it has.

â€œI wanted to leave the viewer with what the book left me with emotionally, which was the warm, fuzzy feeling of them getting to be happy together,â€ Tierney tells Variety. â€œI thought of doing something with just a bit of elegance, and thereâ€™s a simplicity to the two of them in a car, driving off into the sunset, and not over a cliff. That was all I ever wanted out of this story.â€

Below, Tierney tells Variety about how he pulled the much-anticipated cottage episode together; whether fan-favorite couple Scott (FranÃ§ois Arnaud) and Kip (Robbie GK) will play a bigger role in Season 2 â€” and why he thinks women have gravitated toward this unabashedly queer love story between two men.

There are some things that happen at the cottage in Rachel Reidâ€™s book that arenâ€™t here in the finale. Shane and Illya playing against each other in Shaneâ€™s hockey training facility, and a pretty explosive oral sex scene that could have been an homage to the beginning of â€œQueer As Folk.â€ How did you figure out what would make the cut for your version for this chapter for Shane and Ilya?

I wanted to make sure we were still on the same journey with them, and still learning things about them. If we are talking specifically about the sex scenes in the book, theyâ€™d eaten ass in Episode 2, so I didnâ€™t really feel like I needed to hit that hard here. I wanted to make sure that we were still watching this change and evolve for them, and the sex that we were seeing this time around was more intimate, playful and sweet. And as evolved as it could be, particularly from the stuff that we were seeing in Episodes 1 and 2. Ultimately, the stuff that mattered to me at the cottage was the stuff that continued the journey of understanding them and their relationship. There was no set agenda. It ended up being the stuff I remember from reading it, if Iâ€™m being honest.

5 Courtesy of Sabrina Lantos/HBO Max

By the end of the episode, they have learned to better communicate with each other. Not perfectly, but previously sex was their only means of doing that. Does that mean you envision less sex in Season 2, and more sitting on the couch scrolling their phones and touching toes now that they can use their words more efficiently?

Oh, the touching toes! I love that scene. You know, Rachel talks a lot about the promise that I made to her to take her characters seriously. She takes them very seriously in â€œThe Long Game,â€ and that doesnâ€™t mean thereâ€™s no sex. Thereâ€™s quite a bit of sex in â€œThe Long Game.â€ But I think it functions differently in the second book, and thatâ€™s just what I want to do. The journey of this show, no matter how long it goes on for, will always be centered around the relationship between Shane and Ilya. Sex will always be a big part of it, like it is with any romantic relationship. But itâ€™s really about continuing that progress of what happens after that first blush of love, what happens after you decide youâ€™re in love and how do you sustain it? Thatâ€™s a very adult question: â€œWe love each other, and now what? Does that mean everythingâ€™s easy?â€ No, it does not. Thereâ€™s loads of challenges that get thrown Shane and Ilyaâ€™s way. Beyond whatâ€™s in the books, I really donâ€™t have an agenda besides that I love this couple and I love these characters, and I want to just hang out with them more and watch them grow more and watch them become better for each other.

Since you loved the touching toes scene, was that something you planned ahead of time or was it a choice you and Hudson and Connor made in the moment while filming?

No, that was planned. What I really wanted to be part of the cottage episode was that, when youâ€™re in a relationship, youâ€™re just doing things like being on your phones at the same time. I want them to live in the real world, and to do those little things that people do when they are in a relationship, because Shane and Ilya are. They canâ€™t always be fucking. God knows, thatâ€™s just exhausting! I just wanted to capture little normal couple moments and I donâ€™t think Iâ€™m the only one in a relationship who occasionally sits on a couch scrolling on our phones separately and then showing our partner what we are seeing.

It certainly shows how far they have come since their fleeting hotel meetups. But there is still a little bit of Reidâ€™s book that you donâ€™t cover in the finale. In the book, months later they announce Shaneâ€™s big plan to start a foundation together, the first step in chipping away at their rivalry until they can come out as a couple. But your season ends with them riding home from Shaneâ€™s parentsâ€™ house in the car, just holding hands and laughing. Do you see Season 2 starting with that announcement, or was this your end to the first book?

Well, books are so different from TV and I didnâ€™t know if I was even going to get to make more of these. As much as I care about their charity and what theyâ€™re going to do, I donâ€™t know that we need a bunch of exposition at the end of a season of TV like this. I wanted to leave the viewer with what the book left me with emotionally, which was the kind of warm, fuzzy feeling of them getting to be happy together. I thought of doing something with just a bit of elegance, and thereâ€™s a simplicity to the two of them in a car, driving off into the sunset, and not over a cliff. That was all I ever wanted out of this story.

Part of the balancing act of the storytelling for me was always that you get this big moment with Scott and Kip in the last episode. It is this massive rom-com public declaration of love, and what I love about Shane and Ilyaâ€™s story is that you get another version of that kind of happiness, which is this small moment with the two of them just being allowed to be in love. That was the sweetest ending I could come up with for them, for now.

Speaking of Scott and Kip, there has been such an enthusiasm for them, maybe more than some people expected. Last weekâ€™s episode, which ended on Scott bringing Kip out on the ice to announce their relationship, now shares the top spot on IMDbâ€™s list of the highest-rated episodes of television of all time. Does that encourage you to include more of their story in Season 2, or do you foresee keeping this format of seeing them when they intersect with Shane and Ilya?

This will continue to be Shane and Ilyaâ€™s story, and Scott and Kip will continue to intersect with them on occasion. But just because â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ is Shane and Ilyaâ€™s story doesnâ€™t mean that precludes potentially doing stuff with Scott and Kip outside of that specific show. We optioned all Rachelâ€™s books, and part of the reason we did that was because, obviously, these characters appear throughout all the books. Thereâ€™s a real richness to a lot of the stories there, and fans will know that Scott and Kip feature very strongly in â€œCommon Goal.â€ They are all over the place. I donâ€™t know exactly what weâ€™re going to do yet, but there are places we could go with them that I would definitely be excited to explore.

Courtesy of Sabrina Lantos/HBO Max

In the finale, we get a scene with Shane and his mom, Yuna, after he comes out. This is a bit of a change from the book, where the conversation is entirely between Shane, Ilya, Yuna and David. Why did you give Shane and his mom this separate moment?

Yuna is such a crucial character in the story. I know itâ€™s not always on display in this season, but as fans of the books know, Yuna is such a big part of both Shane and Ilyaâ€™s lives moving forward. In trying to take this stuff seriously, I wanted to show complicated, interesting adult relationships here, and that includes the parents. It was just really important to me for Shane and Yuna to have a conversation. They needed to have a moment together. Theyâ€™re obviously very close. Theyâ€™re obviously very similar, and his mom has very similar blinders that he does. So thereâ€™s something really important about reminding people that even though we can hurt each other in these relationships, and they can be difficult, there is love and allyship there as well. Sometimes, it just requires a little conversation.

The queer community is understandably hooked by this show, but there has also been an intense embrace from female viewers, specifically straight women. Why do you think that is?

I think thatâ€™s a very complicated question, and there are a lot of answers to it. Women love these books. These are books written by a woman. These are books largely consumed by women. So I wouldnâ€™t want to speak on behalf of a female audience, but I think that what women are presented in romance is not always something that interests them in that way. I think that women are also, in real life and in culture, endlessly exposed to sexual violence. Seeing things like this, that are depictions ultimately of male vulnerability, can be very refreshing. From what Iâ€™ve heard, from the women who have written to me and Rachel and the boys, thereâ€™s a safety in seeing a woman being removed from the conversation. So youâ€™re watching something happen between two men, and there is no fear of violence. There is no fear of things turning into stuff that women have to deal with too much in real life, and donâ€™t want to deal with in their fantasies, and ultimately, this is a romantic fantasy. I think itâ€™s also that maybe romance â€” which is a genre that women love and write and read and are the primary consumers of â€” just doesnâ€™t get treated with a lot of respect. Nor do the people that make it, or those that adapt it either. So I think that they are responding to, at least I hope, the fact that we came to it pretty fullhearted, and as fans and as people who want to honor this material and want to honor the genre and make it as romantic as we can. Thatâ€™s certainly what I wanted to do.

Every week, despite the soaring success of your show, you have had to respond to controversies and people wanting to tear it down. This week, Hudson responded to Deuxmoiâ€™s comments about his personal life, and who he might be dating. But Deuxmoi also said the show has no plot and bad acting. What do you say to opinions like that?

This show wouldnâ€™t work if any of that were true. I mean, it just wouldnâ€™t. Nobody would give a shit about this if the acting was bad, or if there was no story. I think this is a show that actually requires you to pay attention. If youâ€™re glib and youâ€™re on your phone the whole time, or youâ€™re looking to not pay attention, then God bless, and do whatever you want. But you have to be there in the moment if you want to watch. This is a show where thereâ€™s a lot of communication between the lines. Itâ€™s a lot about behavior. Itâ€™s a lot about watching. And if you donâ€™t have the attention span for it or the interest, then Iâ€™m gonna be super honest with you. I could give a fuck what Deuxmoiâ€™s criticism is of the show. I literally donâ€™t even know who these people are. I donâ€™t give a fuck what they think about anything. But I understand that, from what I have read multiple times now, people say this is a show that is not a co-viewing experience. You canâ€™t be on your phone. If you wanna get what itâ€™s doing, you have to pay attention to it. Itâ€™s definitely made to hold your attention. And if it doesnâ€™t, then thatâ€™s a good criticism too. This is not for everybody, and that is A-OK. But I think at a certain point, the show speaks for itself, and the reaction to it speaks for itself, and thereâ€™s no way that these boys would be on the receiving end of the attention that theyâ€™re getting if they werenâ€™t good. The papa bear in me does not like comments like this, obviously, because I know how hard they work. I think theyâ€™re fucking amazing. But we also live in a time where everybody gets their opinion, then they get to put it out on whatever platform they have, and so I get it. Keep doing your thing, Deuxmoi!

Looking ahead to Season 2, youâ€™ve spoken about how you havenâ€™t started writing yet, but is there anything specific you are most looking forward to adapting from â€œThe Long Game?â€

Thereâ€™s so many new characters that are going to be really fun to bring in. But I think that next season will end up feeling different because itâ€™s a more focused book. It takes place over a shorter amount of time. Thereâ€™s more a sense of getting to know that team in Ottawa that Ilya is going to play for and getting to know Hayden and Jackie more. And thereâ€™s more Yuna and David. Hopefully what will happen, like with any good second season in general, is that we will get to enrich the stuff you already know and how those threads began, and then pull on them and really get into it. But Iâ€™m also really looking forward to seeing Ilya in therapy. Itâ€™s probably a really good thing for him. I know that my therapist has been crucial to getting through the past few months.

This interview has been edited and condensed.

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from Season 5, Volume 2 of â€œStranger Things,â€ now streaming on Netflix.

Ever since â€œStranger Thingsâ€ first debuted on Netflix in 2016, it was evident that Noah Schnappâ€˜s Will Byers was different from his friends. His own father derisively called him queer, as his mother Joyce (Winona Ryder) recounts early in Season 1. And while he shared his friendsâ€™ affinity for playing Dungeons & Dragons, biking around town and geeking out on the latest pop-culture, fantasy or scientific phenomenon of the showâ€™s 1980s setting, Will disappeared during the very first episode, setting the wide-eyed, bowl-cutted boy apart from the group.

Despite his friends rescuing him from the Upside Down at the end of the first season, Will only grew more distinctive as the series continued. As his friends came of age and found girlfriends, he remained outside the group, not only from his traumatic abduction, but from a more elusive feeling of isolation. In Season 3, Mike (Finn Wolfhard) snaps at Will for not liking girls, which further sparked fan speculation regarding the characterâ€™s sexuality.

Popular on Variety

Those speculations seemed to be confirmed, though never explicitly stated, in Season 4 when Will breaks down trying to profess his feelings toward Mike. However, itâ€™s not until Season 5, Episode 7, â€œThe Bridge,â€ when Will finally admits to his friendsâ€” â€œI donâ€™t like girls.â€

The emotional monologue rounding out the seriesâ€™ penultimate episode is a powerful, touching and poignant delivery on Willâ€™s highly anticipated coming out. It pays off on Willâ€™s arc toward self-acceptance and assurance. While the character has spent much of the series as the victim, he takes center stage as a hero in Season 5, revealed to have sorcerer-like supernatural abilities in the seasonâ€™s fourth episode that concluded Volume 1.

These triumphant moments also demonstrate Schappâ€™s growth as an actor over his 10 years playing Will. The coming out monologue is Schnappâ€™s most emotionally intense and verbose in the series. The performance is further accented by Schappâ€™s real-world relationship to the topic, having publicly come out as gay in 2023.

Variety spoke with Schnapp to unpack the distinguished scene, how he shaped it with series creators Matt and Ross Duffer and director Shawn Levy and his feelings about closing the book on his decade-plus role in â€œStranger Things.â€

Courtesy of Netflix

At what point did you find out that Will was going to come out in Season 5, Episode 7?

You know that itâ€™s coming. This season, we read the first six episodes together, and I was like â€œOK, it didnâ€™t happen yet, so itâ€™s going to be in Episode 7 or 8,â€ which hadnâ€™t been written yet. So then from January of filming on through the year, I kept texting the Duffers, â€œIs it done? Did you write it? Is it in 7 or 8? How are you gonna write it?â€ Eventually, they said they had it, and I read it by the end of the year in August or September. And I was just in tears. It was perfect.

Did you get the opportunity to workshop the script with the Duffers or with Shawn Levy, who directed â€œThe Bridgeâ€ with the Duffers?

I was worried that I might need to, but honestly, it was perfect. I really had no notes about it.

Do you recall your co-starsâ€™ reactions the first time that you rehearsed the scene, or did a table read? Shawn Levy told us that the reactions on camera were genuine.

Honestly, I was so wrapped up in my emotions and what I was feeling that I kind of blocked out everyone around me. I kind of had to because it was so nerve-racking to know that the entire cast was there watching me. I had Winona next to me, and the boys and Maya [Hawke] around me. It was all a blur. I donâ€™t really remember anyoneâ€™s reactions, but watching it back, it was nice to see. It did feel genuine.

How many takes did you do of the scene?

Oh my God, it was endless. It was like a 12-hour day of just that monologue. And we werenâ€™t even done after the 12-hour day. We came back a week later to reshoot certain parts of the scene for another 12 hours. It was like, â€œOh my God, how many more times can I do this scene?â€ But it was also nice because it allowed me to try so many different things. I never felt stuck to anything. I got advice from Maya on how to prepare for it, because there were so many lines, more lines than Iâ€™d ever had before.



Maya speaks like a madman so I asked, â€œHow do you learn all these lines and not think about it in the scene?â€ She said, â€œItâ€™s not about how well you know it, itâ€™s how long youâ€™ve known it for, so just prep for months before.â€ So Iâ€™d just go through it morning and night every day for months before shooting, but I wouldnâ€™t prep how to say it or how to feel. It would just be plain saying the lines out loud with no emotion, just to sink it in. But then on the day, I was able to explore the feelings and emotions, and it was fun to have those 12 hours to play and feel. The cast was so gracious. Iâ€™ll never forget how supportive they were on that day and how respectful and giving they were to me, because they had to sit there through an entire night just hearing me ramble. They were supporting me on all these angles where they werenâ€™t even caught on camera. They could have gone and sat in Video Village or hung out, but they all sat there in their spots through the whole day. It was really special.

Courtesy of Netflix

In those 12 hours of takes, did you film versions of the scene that are different from what ended up in the final cut?

There were so many different choices in the different takes. I remember being asked, â€œDo you want to do your close up first or do you want to do it at the end of the day?â€ Because that was the most important shot. So I could either start with a wide and kind of explore it and feel out the scene and then go to the close up, or go straight into it. I was really struggling with whether I was ready to bang it out first or get comfortable before it. I decided last minute, â€œLetâ€™s just start with the close up. Iâ€™m ready to go and I just want to do it.â€ And then it was like one of the first takes of the day, and that was most of the meat of the scene. It was so nice because it hadnâ€™t been exhausted yet. It was real and raw and Iâ€™m glad I did it that way.

Was there anything that surprised you in the final cut of the scene and the way it was edited?

Literally for every scene, Iâ€™m like â€œOh I didnâ€™t expect that.â€ You donâ€™t realize the power of editing and how it can change a scene. For this scene, it was nice because there were moments where I tried the first paragraph of the monologue to the boys where it was a lot more sad, and then there were times when I was a lot more happy reliving the memories with them. Iâ€™m glad that they edited it the way they did, where itâ€™s nice to see him not just sob through the whole scene, but kind of smile through the memories and give that lighter feel. It makes it hit harder.

Itâ€™s interesting that Will says â€œI donâ€™t like girlsâ€ rather than â€œIâ€™m gay.â€ How was that wording decided on? Was there fear about being too explicit, or do you think Will is still sort of figuring out his identity?

Yeah, I noticed that and I spoke to the Duffers about it specifically. We have to remember that its the 1980s. When I came out, I didnâ€™t say the word â€œgay.â€ Itâ€™s hard, and it feels scary to say it. In the â€™80s, I canâ€™t imagine how much more pressure there was and how much more there was to lose. When Will is first coming to terms with it in front of his friends, heâ€™s probably scared to use that word, but thereâ€™s nothing wrong with it. I think he just felt more comfortable phrasing it that way.

Do you think discovering that heâ€™s a sorcerer has given Will the confidence to embrace what makes him different? How has discovering Willâ€™s newfound power changed your approach to the character?

I think it helps him accept himself, and you totally see it from the beginning of the season. Heâ€™s kind of more assertive and self-assured. Itâ€™s nice to play that side of him, and not just play someone whoâ€™s always walked all over. Even with the coming out scene, having that much dialogue and actually getting to express myself through my words, which this character has never really done until then, was so nice.

Courtesy of Netflix

A lot of those scenes you share with Winona Ryder. What was it like working so closely with her this final season after having played her son for almost a decade?

It was really special. I was kind of sad in Seasons 3 and 4 that I got separated from her, and I really missed working with her. Sheâ€™s one of my favorite scene partners and people, and it was so nice to be with her for most of this season. I feel so comfortable around her, and it was hard to say goodbye. I didnâ€™t expect to have such trouble letting go of her on that last day. I didnâ€™t want to let her go, and I realized she really became this motherly figure to me at work during these 10 years.

You also share a lot of scenes with Maya Hawke this Season. How was collaborating with her?

We definitely got closer. Iâ€™d barely spoken to Maya before then. I mean, I donâ€™t even think we were friends. Now, we spent the whole season together, and sheâ€™s part of my little â€œStranger Thingsâ€ family.

Lastly, you had the ability to collaborate with younger actors this season. For so long, you and the main ensemble were the youngest people on the show. What was it like to now have new rising actors on set who might have looked up to you?

It definitely helped me realize, â€œWow, weâ€™ve come so far. Weâ€™re not kids anymore.â€ Theyâ€™re looking to us. You always feel like you donâ€™t know anything and you have so much more to learn, but then it makes you realize that weâ€™ve spent 10 years here, and we do have some experience now. It was nice to get to work with them and they were so cute. They just brought this childlike energy that reminded us that we were still kids too. I was making handshakes with them and I felt like I was 12 years old again. It was so fun.

content:
SPOILERS: This post contains details about the Heated Rivalry, Season 1 finale episode â€˜The Cottageâ€™

With the conclusion of Heated Rivalryâ€˜s rookie season, writer/director/creator Jacob Tierney is taking a breath before hitting the ice again with the wildly popular LGBTQ hockey drama series.

Ahead of the highly anticipated Season 1 finale â€˜The Cottageâ€™, which is now available to stream on Crave and HBO Max, Tierney teased that despite the satisfying closure of the episode, Season 2 and beyond â€œwill always be centered aroundâ€ Shane Hollander (Hudson Williams) and Ilya Rozanovâ€™s (Connor Storrie) love story, with author Rachel Reidâ€™s final book in the series, The Long Game, serving as the basis.

Watch on Deadline

â€œBut we have a whole universe here, and so thereâ€™s loads of other things that weâ€™re thinking about and that weâ€™re gonna explore and that weâ€™re gonna start to take more seriously now that we know that thereâ€™s an audience for it,â€ explained Tierney, following the showâ€™s Season 2 renewal. â€œAnd thatâ€™s pretty exciting, so Iâ€™m looking forward to really digging into this world.â€

Taking LGBTQ and female audiences by storm with its bold depictions of gay sex and romance, Tierney revealed that his favorite intimate scenes were in the finale.

â€œWhat I was committed to was making sure that we watch this relationship evolve through the sex, because itâ€™s one thing to just make smutâ€”which Iâ€™m thrilled to be doing. No shame in that game,â€ he said. â€œBut it would be numbing and boring to watch the same f*ck scene over and over again. Who cares at a certain point? We are certainly not starved for sex, as viewers.â€

Connor Storrie as Ilya Rozanov and Hudson Williams as Shane Hollander in the â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™, Season 1 finale episode â€˜The Cottageâ€™

Tierney added, â€œThatâ€™s why I love the sex in episode 6 so much, because itâ€™s both incredibly sweet and then incredibly playful and funny. And I like those two juxtapositions. Thatâ€™s when I feel like theyâ€™re a real couple, like when youâ€™re giving somebody a blowjob to annoy them. Thatâ€™s what a boyfriend does.â€

Read on about the Heated Rivalry, Season 1 finaleâ€™s sex scenes, why the showâ€™s depiction of LGBTQ fame appealed to him and whatâ€™s ahead for Season 2.

DEADLINE: Are you surprised that the show has taken off on this level, outside of Canada?

JACOB TIERNEY: No, this is exactly what I expectedâ€”yes, Iâ€™m very surprised. Weâ€™re all a bit overwhelmed by the reaction to the show. Obviously, itâ€™s very gratifying and itâ€™s very nice, but itâ€™s certainly not anything you can expect, and then coupled with, plan for anything like that. Itâ€™s crazy.

DEADLINE: And it was awesome seeing the fan reaction to the Scott [FranÃ§ois Arnaud] and Kip [Robbie GK] kiss in the last episode. It was such a good wrap-up for that episode.

TIERNEY: It was very moving to see all those reactions. It was very, very moving for me.

Connor Storrie as Ilya Rozanov and Hudson Williams as Shane Hollander in the â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™, Season 1 finale episode â€˜The Cottageâ€™ (Sabrina Lantos/HBO Max)

DEADLINE: And now, all of the gays and the girls are super excited for â€˜The Cottageâ€™.

TIERNEY: Iâ€™m telling you, no Canadianâ€™s that excited.

DEADLINE: Was the pressure on to bring that part of the book to life? Because Iâ€™ve seen a lot of people are really anticipating it.

TIERNEY: I mean, I made the show. I didnâ€™t think anybody was gonna care this much. Iâ€™m relieved that I made it the way that I did. I mean, there was pressure for me internally to end the show well. And I think that the thing that I was aware of, though it might not seem that way on the surface, itâ€™s a big swing cause itâ€™s a two-hander essentially. To go from an episode like 5, which is so big and epic, into â€˜The Cottageâ€™, which is relatively tinyâ€”I think 38 of the 52 minutes are the two of them alone in a cottage. Thatâ€™s kind of a big structural and narrative swing to pull off, or to attempt, I suppose. But I just wanted to continue to do right by this relationship, these characters, and to give their journey the kind of last push that I thought it needed to successfully finish the book.

DEADLINE: And I really appreciated the scene with Shaneâ€™s parents because coming out was obviously such a big fear for him, and just seeing how perfectly they handled it. Tell me about bringing something that gay kids really need to see to the screen like that.

TIERNEY: Yeah, itâ€™s a big part of the book, so I certainly didnâ€™t invent it whole cloth. But yeah, that stuff is very important, and itâ€™s always been an interesting distinction between Shane and Ilya. And I think itâ€™s quite stark when Ilyaâ€”itâ€™s a small line that he says in episode 5, but he says that about his father, â€œI wish he could have known me.â€ And I think thatâ€™s what he means, and I think that Ilyaâ€™s very aware. Part of the reason that heâ€™s kind of gently probing Shane in that episode and being like, â€œDo they know about you?â€ And heâ€™s like, â€œNo, about you. Who f*cking cares about me? Do they know you? If they donâ€™t, youâ€™ll regret it at a certain point. You need to take this leap.â€ And itâ€™s scary as those of us whoâ€™ve come out to parents [know], which is most gay kids at this point, or queer people in general. Itâ€™s very scary and itâ€™s a big deal, but itâ€™s something thatâ€™s pretty important in that journey. And what was important to me throughout the show was to make sure that we had sophisticated and complicated relationships with parents going on here. It was why it was so important for me to keep Skipâ€™s dad in the show, to see somebody be supportive like that, to see somebody whose love cup is endless. And I think that to see Yuna [Shaneâ€™s mom, played by Christina Chang] is such an important part of this show, and sheâ€™s such an important part moving forward, especially. And I think that in these moments, you see that her and Shane are so similar, and they have very similar limitations, and that it was really important to me for the two of them to have a moment together beyond what was already in the book and what was already in the story. It felt very important to me that these two haveâ€”I donâ€™t think itâ€™s a reckoning, but that they have their own moment of intimacy where they can clear things up for one another. Because I think theyâ€™re both the kinds of people that build things up in their heads, and when you say things out loud, I think you can kind of take the air out of them, and it suddenly becomes a lot more manageable than whatever youâ€™ve created in your brain. And it helps to have two very, very good actors there to do the heavy lifting for me.

Christina Chang as Yuna and Dylan Walsh as David Hollander in the â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™ Season 1 finale episode â€˜The Cottageâ€™ (Sabrina Lantos/HBO Max)

DEADLINE: And one thing thatâ€™s really tragic, even though it was such a great finale, just the fact that Shane wants to just keep their relationship a secret until they retire. And it kind of struck me how itâ€™s almost like art imitating life, or vice-versa, with the pressure and speculation that the actors are facing. Was that exploration of fame in the back of your head when you were making this?

TIERNEY: I mean, Iâ€™ve been an actor my whole life. I know what thatâ€™s like. Iâ€™ve known loads of actors in the closet. Iâ€™ve known loads of actors who have come out. And I do think that part of the reason that this story appealed to me is because I can relate to it. I can understand that pressure, especially when you come up at a young enough age that you donâ€™t know, that you donâ€™t know what an answer to a question like that would be, but you certainly live in a world where you got a lot of people telling you not to talk about it, and that if you want the things you want, youâ€™ll kind of keep toe-ing a line. And I think thatâ€™s also part of what makes the story resonate with so many people is that weâ€™re not pretending we live in a world without homophobia, and weâ€™re not pretending we live in a world where coming out is easy. I think thatâ€™s part of the beauty of what Scott does is so brave, and itâ€™s so big, and it does crack something open for other people, but I think what it cracks open for them is just allowing them to know that they are allowed to be together. The rest of it, they can figure out at a later dateâ€”and the fans of the book know how this is gonna goâ€”but I think that part of what is interesting and different and unique about Shane and Ilyaâ€™s story is that this journey that weâ€™re watching them go on in this first book, in this first season of TV now, is a journey to just understanding that they love each other. And thatâ€™s such a hurdle for them. Thatâ€™s hard enough for them, that to then add in the rest of the world, I think will take a whole other season of television. So, thatâ€™s kind of part of the journey that will be explored down the road. But I have a lot of empathy and I have a lot of time for Shaneâ€™s journey with that stuff. Itâ€™s not easy. Itâ€™s hard, and I do think that thereâ€™s actors, a lot of professionals, especially people who begin their professional journey at 12 years old. Thereâ€™s so much baked in, and thereâ€™s so much built in around you that you can often lose yourself. I think itâ€™s quite easy to do that, and again, Iâ€™ve seen it happen with so many actors that I came up with.

DEADLINE: Speaking of which, I just recently discovered that you were in Are You Afraid of the Dark?, which was such a big part of my childhood.

TIERNEY: I am a campfire kid forever.

DEADLINE: I love that. Were there moments on Heated Rivalry where you had to compromise your vision or the story?

TIERNEY: Sure, there were moments along the way â€¦ my execs at Crave were so f*cking amazing about that. There were people along the way. But my execs, they didnâ€™t want it toned down at all.

Hudson Williams as Shane Hollander and Connor Storrie as Ilya Rozanov in the â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™, Season 1 finale episode â€˜The Cottageâ€™

DEADLINE: Well, itâ€™s great to see such a fearlessly queer show, especially when GLAAD recently released their study that almost half of LGBTQ characters are disappearing. So, it just feels very needed right now, and I love it.

TIERNEY: We added a bunch, so at least thereâ€™s that. Itâ€™s not a great time for stuff like that, and I think, unfortunately, the more thereâ€™s consolidation among broadcasters and streamers too, itâ€™s not gonna get a lot better, I donâ€™t think. But it is nice to be a part of a show that is doing something like this, thatâ€™s reminding people that thereâ€™s loads of audiences here and that they can be queer and queer adjacent, our allies, our friends, our families. If this was just gay people watching this show, we wouldnâ€™t be talking about it right now, letâ€™s be real. So, the fact that itâ€™s gotten to this level of conversation in the culture is because there are people that want to watch this, and they donâ€™t care if itâ€™s two men in a love story, or maybe even want that specifically. And then even more so, itâ€™s just such a pleasure to be involved in a show thatâ€™s making people happy and that is providing joy. I still read people being like, â€œI know that this show is gonna end on a cliffhanger.â€ And I keep wanting to shout it from the rooftops, â€œIt wonâ€™t! I donâ€™t want to do that to you, thatâ€™s not what weâ€™re doing here.â€

DEADLINE: Honestly, I had that thought too, watching it. Itâ€™s such a good ending, and then they get in the car. Iâ€™m like, â€œOh, theyâ€™re about to get into a car accident or something. I just know it.â€

TIERNEY: You know whatâ€™s really funny, is that if I let that footage just run and run and run, because we shot that in the studio, my producing partner Brendan [Brady] will run out in front of that car and get hit by it. So you will see our straight producer dying. Does that help? Is that the secret twist that nobody saw coming?

DEADLINE: Thatâ€™s the one we want.

TIERNEY: There you go. Thatâ€™s it.

DEADLINE: Another thing I thought was funny, Iâ€™m reading a lot of the social media reactions, and youâ€™ve introduced a lot of viewers to frottage.

TIERNEY: Frottage at the cottage, baby!

Connor Storrie as Ilya Rozanov and Hudson Williams as Shane Hollander in the â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™, Season 1 finale episode â€˜The Cottageâ€™

DEADLINE: Yeah, exactly. So thatâ€™s cool, itâ€™s really opening a lot of eyes to queer sex. And Iâ€™ve also seen some people talk about how very accurate the sex scenes are to the book, and Iâ€™m wondering if you were very committed to maintaining accuracy to those scenes.

TIERNEY: Some of them are super accurate to, or close to the book, and some of them go different ways. But what I would say I was committed to, that Rachel and I are both committed to, was kind of using this sex to tell their story, that this is not separate from their story. The sex isnâ€™t like, â€œAnd then they fuck! Letâ€™s put it in a new room or do it on a kitchen counter.â€ Their sex is the way that they understand each other, and itâ€™s the way that we understand them as a couple. So, what I was committed to was making sure that we watch this relationship evolve through the sex, because itâ€™s one thing to just make smutâ€”which Iâ€™m thrilled to be doing. No shame in that game. But it would be numbing and boring to watch the same f*ck scene over and over again. Who cares at a certain point? We are certainly not starved for sex, as viewers. You can go watch sex wherever you want to. So, what would have to keep this interesting, is to watch it evolve and to watch their intimacy change. Thatâ€™s why I love the sex in episode 6 so much, because itâ€™s both incredibly sweet and then incredibly playful and funny. And I like those two juxtapositions. Thatâ€™s when I feel like theyâ€™re a real couple, like when youâ€™re giving somebody a blowjob to annoy them. Thatâ€™s what a boyfriend does. Thatâ€™s annoying. Thatâ€™s great. Thatâ€™s what I want to see.

DEADLINE: Another thing I loved, as great as the sex scenes are, I noticed that episode 5, thereâ€™s not as many sex scene.

TIERNEY: Thereâ€™s none.

DEADLINE: But thereâ€™s a lot of more emotional intimacy, and it made it feel so earned and real. Like when Ilya tells Shane â€œI love youâ€ in Russian.

TIERNEY: I think thatâ€™s part of the evolution too, itâ€™s a story. It was really important to me that you have to earn these moments. Thatâ€™s why episode 3 is where it is, and thatâ€™s why 5 ends the way it does. This stuff, it has to imprint on you, and then, you get that those big feelings like that. And I donâ€™t think you get those big feelings that you get in 5 if you havenâ€™t sat through how painful 4 was for them, or the ending of 2, where youâ€™re like, â€œOh God, will these two ever f*cking learn to talk to each other?â€ And then when they do in 5, itâ€™s in two different languages. I think thatâ€™s also part of whatâ€™s amazing when romance works, that youâ€™re just endlessly watching two people bypass each other. When they hit, youâ€™re like, â€œNo, wait! Itâ€™s not that.â€ And that aching. Yeah, itâ€™s been so fun to see people react to that.

Connor Storrie as Ilya Rozanov and Hudson Williams as Shane Hollander in the â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™, Season 1 finale episode â€˜The Cottageâ€™

DEADLINE: Where are you at with Season 2, or are you just kind of letting it ruminate?

TIERNEY: Itâ€™s all gonna be underwater. It takes place in the lost city of Atlantisâ€”no, listen, Season 2 will be based around The Long Game. I donâ€™t have details. I have not started writing, so Iâ€™m not just trying to be evasive. I genuinely donâ€™t know yet. Iâ€™m so lucky to have a whole world of books here to grab things from, to use, to add color, to add context, to add story. I can tell you Iâ€™m really excited to get back to writing. Iâ€™m excited to get back into this world with them, and Iâ€™m looking forward to it. I guess, hereâ€™s what I can say too, is that Heated Rivalry will always be centered around Shane and Ilya, this show. But we have a whole universe here, and so thereâ€™s loads of other things that weâ€™re thinking about and that weâ€™re gonna explore and that weâ€™re gonna start to take more seriously now that we know that thereâ€™s an audience for it. And thatâ€™s pretty exciting, so Iâ€™m looking forward to really digging into this world.

But the Kennedy Center is not the current owner of trumpkennedycenter.org or trumpkennedycenter.com â€” because back in August, comedy writer Toby Morton registered those two domain names, expecting Trump and his allies to add Trumpâ€™s name to the D.C. landmark.

â€œAs soon as Trump began gutting the Kennedy Center board earlier this year, I thought, â€˜Yep, that nameâ€™s going on the building,â€™â€ Morton recently told the Washington Post. â€œThe Kennedy Center has always been a cultural institution meant to outlast any one administration or personality. Snapping up domain names and using them to troll politicians has been an active pursuit for Morton, who has â€œSouth Parkâ€ and â€œMad TVâ€ writing credits (and once provided the voice of Scott Tenorman, the half-brother and nemesis of Eric Cartman, on â€œSouth Parkâ€). Morton, whose bio on BlueSky says he is a â€œCreator of Anti-Fascist websites,â€ hasnâ€™t launched websites on trumpkennedycenter.org or trumpkennedycenter.com at this point. But he pledged that when he does, they will â€œabsolutely reflect the absurdity of the moment. Lots of surprises. Some things are truly hard to parody, though.â€

title: Gwyneth Paltrowâ€™s â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™ Performance Is So Meta and So Brilliant
summary: In the new film â€œMarty Supreme,â€ a fondly remembered legend of the screen is attempting a comeback. This actress, still resplendent, emerges onstage and receives a round of applause, a bit of homage from an audience that knew her years before, and is waiting to see what she can do now â€” how time has […]
content:
In the new film â€œMarty Supreme,â€ a fondly remembered legend of the screen is attempting a comeback. This actress, still resplendent, emerges onstage and receives a round of applause, a bit of homage from an audience that knew her years before, and is waiting to see what she can do now â€” how time has changed her. To this point, weâ€™ve seen her deny her ambitions, as well as her lust for the filmâ€™s title character: Sheâ€™s too composed to give herself away. Now, though, the audience cannot see her face as she turns her back on them, but the camera follows her and so we can. She has burst into the gladdest grin, remembering, all at once, what the attention of the crowd felt like.

The performer is Kay Stone, a fictional mid-century star whoâ€™s receded into private life. And the performer playing her is Gwyneth Paltrow, whose very public life has, for years now, not made room for acting. To see Paltrow at work is to be reminded of what a vital and urgent screen presence she is, how alive she manages to be in every moment and how adept she is at showing the way her characters hide that vividity behind shades of cool. Itâ€™s also to be aware that perhaps Paltrow needed the time away to conjure a performance quite this majestic.

Popular on Variety

Paltrow made no secret of her ambivalence about acting after becoming a mother; her business interests, in the form of her Goop suite of media entities and products (kicked off with a newsletter in 2008), have allowed her to more proactively define her brand, and what roles sheâ€™s held on to have plainly not been that exciting anyhow. (She practically seems to delight in going viral when, in various on-camera interviews, she canâ€™t remember appearing in various Marvel films.) Many actresses, past 40, find opportunities drying up. As if to pre-empt the question, Paltrow stepped away from the set and found opportunities elsewhere.

That choice compels us in other ways. Many people who are not inherently interested in wellness culture, or in self-help jargon, or in a woo-woo redefinition of the concept of â€œdivorceâ€ as â€œconscious uncoupling,â€ got on board the Goop train, at least as gawkers. I reserve judgment on whether the ideas Goop puts forward are valid. Theyâ€™re interesting to the onlooker because the figure speaking about them has that Paltrovian assurance and composure.

But while Paltrow has been making her way in the world of business, somethingâ€™s been missing on-screen. The passionate anger thrumming under Margot Tenenbaumâ€™s seen-it-all glare in â€œThe Royal Tenenbaumsâ€; the lust for life Viola de Lesseps must tamp down under boy drag in â€œShakespeare in Loveâ€; the slowly dawning repulsion Marge Sher- wood struggles to hide in â€œThe Talented Mr. Ripleyâ€: Those werenâ€™t flukes. They were proof of Paltrowâ€™s particular interest in playing with the concept of concealment, of showing us just how hot her blood can run under the hauteur. The defining pre-Goop image of Paltrow in the public imagination is of her facade breaking while accepting an Oscar. Done up in princessy Ralph Lauren, she openly, loudly wept: The passion underlying the pink couture is what sheâ€™s shown us in movies too.

Thatâ€™s also at work in â€œMarty Supreme,â€ and perhaps itâ€™s no wonder the script appealed to Paltrow. By contrast to the frosty but secretly yearning Kay Stone, TimotheÌe Chalametâ€™s Marty Mauser is all bravado, pushing his career as a table-tennis player forward through his insistence that he is destined for the pantheon. (Marty, too, makes for a metatextual meal for the actor playing him â€” Chalamet is as un-shy about his ambition for himself as any star currently working.)

Their pairing is one of opposites: Marty seems, for much of the film, resistant to the idea of an inner life. Life, for him, is meant to be lived aloud. Kay, though, has been seasoned enough by the Hollywood system and lifeâ€™s disappointments to know just how much of herself to keep in reserve. And so when Paltrow lets loose and shows us the flare of uncontrollable emotion undergirding Kayâ€™s careful control, we who have missed this talent of hers are powerless to do anything but mirror the audience on-screen, and let out a cheer.
