title: Box Office Studio Report Card: Warnersâ€™ Bets Pay Off, Disney Scores but Marvel Struggles, Tom Cruise Canâ€™t Save Paramount
summary: Family films flourished, video game adaptations triumphed, and superheroes flew too close to the sun. Welcome to 2025 at the multiplexes! It was a roller-coaster year at cinemas and for the studios tasked with keeping their screens filled. Warner Bros. enjoyed an epic run at the box office, fielding hits as diverse as a vampire […]
content:
Family films flourished, video game adaptations triumphed, and superheroes flew too close to the sun. Welcome to 2025 at the multiplexes!

It was a roller-coaster year at cinemas and for the studios tasked with keeping their screens filled. Warner Bros. enjoyed an epic run at the box office, fielding hits as diverse as a vampire flick set in the Jim Crow South (â€œSinnersâ€), an old-school star-driven racing drama (â€œF1: The Movieâ€) and a sandbox-game-turned-big-screen-smash (â€œA Minecraft Movieâ€). Meanwhile Paramount, which spent hundreds of millions of dollars on yet another â€œMission: Impossible,â€ barely released anything that turned a profit.

And then thereâ€™s Disney, which backed three movies that topped $1 billion (weâ€™re assuming that will be the case with â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€) and stands out as the only studio to cross a combined $6 billion globally, but also distributed nearly twice as many big-budget duds (â€œElio,â€ â€œSnow Whiteâ€ and â€œTron: Ares,â€ to name a few). More troubling, Marvel, once Hollywoodâ€™s biggest hitmaker, struggled to regain its mojo. Itâ€™s all coming down to next yearâ€™s â€œAvengers: Doomsdayâ€ to get the franchise back on course.

Popular on Variety

Our annual report card includes the five major studios as well as A24, which is nominally an indie, but spent lavishly on â€œThe Smashing Machineâ€ and â€œMarty Supreme.â€ But it doesnâ€™t include streamers such as Amazon and Apple, which didnâ€™t release enough movies in cinemas for us to judge their slate. Come on, guys, start spending those Bezos bucks!

As 2025 draws to a close, itâ€™s time for Hollywood to get its report card. Some of you may not want to hang it on your fridge.

Disney

Highs: â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ ($1.03 billion against a $100 million budget), â€œZootopia 2â€ ($1.31 billion against a $150 million budget), â€œFreakier Fridayâ€ ($153 million against a $42 million budget), â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ ($506 million and counting against a $250 million+ budget)

Lows: â€œCaptain America: Brave New Worldâ€ ($415 million against a $180 million budget), â€œSnow Whiteâ€ ($205 million against a $250 million budget), â€œElioâ€ ($154 million against a $150 million budget) â€œTron: Aresâ€ ($142 million against a $180 million budget), â€œPredator: Badlandsâ€ ($181 million against a $105 million budget), â€œElla McCayâ€ ($4 million against a $35 million budget)

Takeaways: Disney deserves props for fielding two (and likely three after â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ gets through the holiday season) billion-dollar hits, a feat that illuminates the chasm between the studio and its rivals, none of whom had a single film cross $1 billion since 2023. Yet almost nothing else worked for Disney beyond the live-action â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ remake, â€œZootopia 2â€ and â€œAvatar 3.â€ Marvel continued its lousy streak, producing three consecutive commercial duds in â€œCaptain America: Brave New World,â€ â€œThunderboltsâ€ and â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Steps.â€ (Next yearâ€™s Sony-produced â€œSpider-Man: Brand New Dayâ€ and â€œAvengers: Doomsdayâ€ canâ€™t arrive soon enough.) â€œElioâ€ underscored Pixarâ€˜s continued struggle to launch original animation. Meanwhile, â€œSnow White,â€ â€œTron: Aresâ€ and â€œPredator: Badlandsâ€ proved that some aging properties are better left in the vault. Thatâ€™s a problem for Disney, which relies almost entirely on recycling whatâ€™s worked in the past. Let it be a mantra for Hollywood: Brand recognition doesnâ€™t equal box office dollars.

Grade: B

Paramount

Highs: â€œSmurfsâ€ ($124 million against a $58 million budget), â€œThe Naked Gunâ€ ($102 million against a $42 million budget), â€œRegretting Youâ€ ($90.4 million against a $30 million budget)

Lows: â€œMission: Impossible â€“ The Final Reckoningâ€ ($598 million against a $400 million budget), â€œRoofmanâ€ ($33 million against a $20 million budget), â€œThe Running Manâ€ ($68 million against a $105 million budget)

Takeaways: In its defense, Paramount spent most of the past year stuck in a painful limbo as it waited for government regulators to approve its sale to Skydance. That left studio executives â€” many of whom correctly deduced theyâ€™d be shown the exit as soon as David Ellisonâ€™s crew took over â€” punching the clock. Paramount did write a blank check to Tom Cruise, only to find that he had embarked on one impossible mission too many. It also gambled that Edgar Wright and Glen Powell could crack â€œThe Running Man,â€ the second adaptation of the Stephen King novel; the first attempt flopped when it hit theaters with Arnold Schwarzenegger. Sadly, the pair shouldnâ€™t have bothered lacing up their sneakers. Paramount fielded a few cost-effective hits, like â€œSmurfsâ€ and â€œThe Naked Gun,â€ but these are not the kind of modest successes one expects from one of Hollywoodâ€™s most storied studios. Will the new management fare better?

Grade: C

Sony

Highs: â€œDemon Slayer: Infinity Castleâ€ ($664 million against a $20 million budget), â€œChainsaw Manâ€ ($153 million), â€œOne of Them Daysâ€ ($51 million against a $14 million budget), â€œKarate Kid: Legendâ€ ($117 million against a 45 million budget), â€œ28 Years Laterâ€ ($151 million against a $60 million budget), â€œI Know What You Did Last Summerâ€ ($64.8 million against an $18 million budget), â€œMaterialistsâ€ ($71 million at the international box office)

Lows: â€œCaught Stealingâ€ ($32 million against a $40 million budget), â€œA Big Bold Beautiful Journeyâ€ ($20 million against a $45 million budget)

Takeaways: Sony didnâ€™t have any home runs, but it also avoided any strikeouts. It wasnâ€™t a terribly strong year for the studio, to be sure. But weâ€™re grading based on whatâ€™s been released and not what could have been. Anime was a massive boon, with Crunchyrollâ€™s â€œDemon Slayerâ€ and â€œChainsaw Manâ€ scoring back-to-back wins while demonstrating a voracious appetite for manga adaptations in the U.S. The studio also kept the theatrical comedy alive with the Keke Palmer and SZA-led â€œOne of Them Days,â€ and turned A24â€™s romantic drama â€œMaterialistsâ€ into an international hit. Neither â€œKarate Kid: Legendâ€ nor â€œI Know What You Did Last Summerâ€ were necessary sequels, but both films scraped together modest grosses. As for â€œA Big Bold Beautiful Journey,â€ the collective wattage of Margot Robbie and Colin Farrell couldnâ€™t overcompensate for terrible reviews and bad buzz. Star power only gets audiences to theaters if the movie is, ya know, good.

Grade: B

Universal

Highs: â€œHow to Train Your Dragonâ€ ($636 million against a $150 million budget), â€œJurassic World Rebirthâ€ ($868 million against a $180 million budget), â€œBlack Phone 2â€ ($132 million against a $30 million budget), â€œWicked: For Goodâ€ ($488 million and counting against a $150 million budget), â€œFive Nights at Freddyâ€™s 2â€ ($206 million against a $36 million budget)

Lows: â€œWolf Manâ€ ($34 million against a $25 million budget), â€œLove Hurtsâ€ ($17 million against a $18 million budget), â€œM3GAN 2.0â€ ($39 million against a $25 million budget), â€œHimâ€ ($28 million against a $27 million budget)

Takeaways: Sequels and reboots delivered in a big way for Donna Langley and her team. On paper, rebooting â€œJurassic Worldâ€ a mere three years after the last installment in the â€œwhen dinosaurs attackâ€ franchise might have seemed like a bad idea. But it turns out people really like watching velociraptors dine out on some pesky humans, especially when Scarlett Johansson is trying to avoid becoming dessert. The studio also scored with follow-ups to â€œWickedâ€ and â€œFive Nights at Freddyâ€™sâ€ that wonâ€™t do anywhere near the same business as their predecessors but should turn a tidy profit. There were flops, of course. But failures like â€œWolf Manâ€ and â€œM3GAN 2.0â€ didnâ€™t cost much to produce. The main issue that Universal faced is that Blumhouse, which made both those films, was uncharacteristically inconsistent. â€œFive Nights at Freddyâ€™s 2â€ and â€œBlack Phone 2â€ helped the company get back on track, but it needs to deliver new franchises instead of just servicing old ones.

Grade: B+

Warner Bros.

Highs: â€œA Minecraft Movieâ€ ($958 million against a $150 million budget), â€œSinnersâ€ ($367 million against a $90 million budget), â€œFinal Destination Bloodlinesâ€ ($315 million against a $50 million budget), â€œF1: The Movieâ€ ($631 million against a $250 million+ budget fronted by Apple), â€œSupermanâ€ ($616 million against a $224 million budget), â€œWeaponsâ€ ($268 million a $38 million budget)

Lows: â€œMickey 17â€ ($133 million against a $118 million budget), â€œThe Alto Knightsâ€ ($10 million against a $50 million budget), â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ ($204 million against a $140 million budget)

Takeaways: Itâ€™s the comeback of the year. After a rough end to 2024 (â€œJoker: Folie Ã  Deux,â€ anyone?) and a rocky start to 2025 (â€œMickey 17â€ and â€œThe Alto Knightsâ€ were pricey bombs), the studio rebounded the old-fashioned way â€” by banking on bold directors and new ideas at a time when reboots and sequels reign supreme. Seven consecutive releases, from video game adaptation â€œA Minecraft Movieâ€ and Ryan Cooglerâ€™s vampire thriller â€œSinnersâ€ to the Brad Pitt-led sports drama â€œF1: The Movieâ€ and Zach Creggerâ€™s genre-bending mystery â€œWeapons,â€ opened above $40 million domestically, a first in Hollywood history. Although Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s comedic adventure â€œOne Battle After Anotherâ€ isnâ€™t in danger of turning a profit against its hefty $140 million budget, the film surpassed the $200 million mark and achieved a milestone by getting adult audiences to theaters for original fare. Plus, â€œOne Battleâ€ could be valuable beyond the balance sheet as a major Oscar contender. This might be Warner Bros.â€™ last year as a stand-alone studio. If thatâ€™s the case, it went out with a bang.

Grade: A

A24

Highs: â€œMaterialists ($104 million against an $18 million budget), â€œBring Her Backâ€ ($39 million against a $10 million budget), â€œFriendshipâ€ ($16.5 million after being acquired for $3 million), â€œEternityâ€ ($28 million against a $12 million budget)

Lows: â€œThe Smashing Machineâ€ ($21 million against a $50 million budget), â€œEddingtonâ€ ($13 million against a $25 million budget), â€œThe Legend of Ochiâ€ ($4.9 million against a $10 million budget), â€œWarfareâ€ ($33 million against a $20 million budget), â€œDeath of a Unicornâ€ ($15 million against a $15 million budget)

Takeaways: The indie studio is trying to play with the big boys by moving beyond its low-budget roots. But it found out the hard way that spending more money doesnâ€™t always result in bigger profits. Benny Safdieâ€™s â€œThe Smashing Machine,â€ featuring a change-of-pace performance by Dwayne â€œthe Rockâ€ Johnson as a troubled MMA fighter, was too dark for the actorâ€™s fans and failed to earn the critical acclaim it needed to pack in art-house audiences. Oh, and it cost $50 million to produce and millions more to market, making it one of the yearâ€™s bigger bombs. The same was true of Ari Asterâ€™s â€œEddington,â€ a political satire set during COVID that discovered that most moviegoers would rather memory-hole the pandemic. A24 did score with â€œMaterialists,â€ a starry rom-com from Celine Song that became a true mainstream hit. And it has a chance to end things on a high note with â€œMarty Supreme,â€ a table-tennis drama starring one-man hype machine TimothÃ©e Chalamet. If it scores, A24 deserves some extra credit.

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from Season 5, Volume 2 of â€œStranger Things, now streaming on Netflix.

In one week, weâ€™ll have all the answers. But for now, weâ€™ve got a lot of questions.

During the Christmas Day release of Volume 2 of â€œStranger Things 5,â€ many key plot points were fleshed, and we received a lot of information heading into the series finale, dropping on Dec. 31. We learned things we never knew â€” like, that Elevenâ€™s powers come from Henryâ€™s blood, as transfused by Dr. Brenner, and that the Upside Down isnâ€™t its own dimension, but instead is a wormhole connecting our world and Vecnaâ€™s, which Dustin has named the Abyss.

As we process â€œShock Jock,â€ â€œEscape from Camazotzâ€ and â€œThe Bridge,â€ the latest â€œStranger Thingsâ€ episodes, weâ€™ve rounded up the biggest burning questions ahead of the finale.

Popular on Variety

BIG QUESTION: What is the ultimate importance of Nov. 6?

Itâ€™s the night Will Byers went missing in the series premiere in 2016, and itâ€™s the night Vecna wants to enact his plan to use the children heâ€™s kidnapped to bring the Abyss and Earth together â€” but why on this date? What was the significance in the first place that led Vecna to take Will?

Courtesy of Netflix

AND, why does Vecna want to bring the Abyss and Earth together?

Is he just a nihilist who wants to burn it all down at this point? Or is something else going on?



SOMETHING WEâ€™D LOVE TO KNOW: How did Hopper, El and Kali get out of the Upside Down?



The Upside Down was in chaos, falling apart at the seams, and Nancy, Jonathan, Steve and Dustin were still stuck down there â€” but Hopper, El and Kali managed to get out off-screen. By the start of Episode 7, Hopper and the girls are back in Hawkins, but we donâ€™t see how they managed to get out amid the chaos after Nancy shot a hole in the exotic matter barrier. What did they do to get back out?

WHILE WEâ€™RE AT IT: What blocked the Demogorgon from getting into the elevator to get Max and Lucas?

That Demo was coming right at them and when it jumped, something prevented it from getting through. And Karen Wheeler could only do so much in a day to save the kids, so what else was going on there?

BIG QUESTION: What stopped the white goo from spreading in the Upside Down?

Nancy and Jonathan were saved from certain death in the Upside Down when the world stopped melting into white goo around them, and hardened enough that they could walk on it. While this happened just in time to keep the two alive â€” but not their relationship â€” itâ€™s not clear what caused it all to stop and stabilize, as the Upside Down is still seemingly compromised after Nancy shot through the barrier.

SOMETHING WEâ€™D LOVE TO KNOW: Also, what happened to the ring?

No, itâ€™s not that important, but it was flung on the floor and ultimately, it was what showed them that everything had hardened soâ€¦ did someone pick it up?

BIG QUESTION: Who is the man young Henry finds with the briefcase down in that mine shaft in the Nevada desert?

Fans who have seen the Broadway play â€œStranger Things: The First Shadowâ€ will have a leg up on what is going on here, but itâ€™s still largely a mystery. We know Henry had a traumatic experience in the desert as a child, after which he was never the same. â€œFirst Shadowâ€ reveals Henry entered an alternate dimension, known as Dimension X, and returned after 12 hours with altered blood, a changed personality and psychokinetic powers. Who is the stranger Henry came across, what was he holding onto â€” and what exactly happened to Henry to make him into this darker person?

BIG QUESTION: What is the connection between Dimension X, the Abyss and the Upside Down?

We now know the Upside Down is a wormhole that connects Earth to this other world Vecna inhabits, the Abyss. Vecna was banished to the Abyss at Hawkins Lab by El back when he was Henry/One. Despite their shared mistreatment from Brenner, El refused to join Henry in his plans for world domination and ripped a hole in reality that pushed him through to the Abyss. And Brenner, the other scientists and the military put up the exotic-matter barrier that stabilizes the Upside Down and separates the wormhole that goes between the Abyss and Earth from nothingness. And are the Abyss and Dimension X the same thing?

Courtesy of Netflix

BIG QUESTION: Will Eleven sacrifice herself?

At the end of Episode 7, Kali told El that, for everyoneâ€™s benefit, they should kill themselves after defeating Vecna. Itâ€™s a sacrifice, Kali says, the two need to make so that the military cannot use their blood to try to create new kids like them, ending the cycle that began when Brenner gave Henryâ€™s blood to pregnant women to create El, Kali and the other telekinetic kids at Hawkins Lab. But will El actually go through with that?

BIG QUESTION: Will any main characters die in the finale?

In Episode 5, El got very angry with Hopper for having revealed that he would have tried to fight Vecna alone, and for wearing the suicide vest as a failsafe. But now sheâ€™s hiding her own secrets â€” from Hopper, and from everyone â€” about Kaliâ€™s plan. If Eleven does somehow make it out alive, doesnâ€™t someone have to die, even if Matt Duffer told Variety that the show â€œis not Game of Thrones'â€? (And will it be Hopper, in some incredibly noble way?)

ALSO: Is Will going to reveal his feelings to Mike?

Will came out in Episode 7, and was embraced by support and love from his friends and family members. And he seems to accept himself for who he is, and, on Robinâ€™s advice, not to rely on reciprocated feelings from someone to feel validated. But does that mean Will wonâ€™t have a more direct conversation with Mike about his crush before the end of the series? And if he does, how will Mike react to it? (Also, not that Mike understood this slight, but was it kind of mean for him to refer to Mike as his Tammy?)

BIG QUESTION: How much will Max be able to get inside Henryâ€™s head?

After Max died and was brought back to life in the Season 4 finale, her physical body was in a Hawkins hospital â€” but her mind was in the Abyss with Henry, in Vecnaâ€™s mindspace. As Max makes it clear to Holly, sheâ€™s spent the past 18 months exploring that terrain as she successfully hid from him. She knows heâ€™s afraid of the cave, and that he has vulnerabilities. As they gear up for their final battle with Vecna, Max tells Eleven to call upon her so they can use that knowledge against him.

AND FINALLY: Will Nancy and Steve end up together?

Letâ€™s end with some silliness. Now that Nancy and Jonathan have called it quits, does this pave the way for Steve to get his dream of having a bunch of little nuggets with his ex? Just because â€œJancyâ€ is over and she said nothing was really there with Steve, we all saw the chemistry. At the very least, it does open a door that has been firmly closed since Season 2.

title: Henry Cavill Wears Christopher Reeveâ€™s Superman Suit in Newly-Revealed Test Photos; Zack Snyder Says: â€˜We Showed Warner Bros.â€™ and â€˜Everyone Agreed Henry Was Supermanâ€™

content:
Zack Snyder marked the Christmas holiday with a special gift to fans in the form of photos of Henry Cavill wearing Christopher Reevesâ€™ original Superman suit. The images are what Snyder showed to Warner Bros. executives when he was trying to cast Cavill as Clark Kent/Superman in his new DC Universe, which was kicking off with 2013â€™s â€œMan of Steel.â€

â€œHenry Cavill. The original Superman suit. This photo. It was undeniable,â€ Snyder wrote in one caption, while adding in another: â€œWith the last image I shared, and this one, we showed WB [and] everyone agreed: Henry Cavill was Superman. Thatâ€™s where the journey began.â€

Cavill played Superman across three movies in Snyderâ€™s DC Universe: â€œMan of Steel,â€ â€œBatman v Superman: Dawn of Justiceâ€ and â€œJustice League.â€ Then things got complicated. After a five-year hiatus that left fans wondering about Cavillâ€™s Superman future, he popped up as the Man of Steel in the post-credits scene of 2022â€™s â€œBlack Adam.â€ Cavillâ€™s reappearance coincided with reports that a standalone Superman sequel for him was finally in development with the studio soliciting pitches from writers. The post-credits scene teased the DC Universe would then be heading towards a battle between Cavillâ€™s Superman and Dwayne Johnsonâ€™s Black Adam.

Popular on Variety

â€œI am back as Superman,â€ Cavill wrote in an Instagram post at the time. â€œThank you for your support and thank you for your patience. I promise it will be rewarded.â€

Two days later, Cavill spoke publicly for the first time about his Superman return during a live recording of the â€œHappy Sad Confusedâ€ podcast at 92NY in New York City and said: â€œThere is such a bright future ahead for the character. Iâ€™m so excited to tell a story with an enormously joyful Superman.â€

Cavillâ€™s return was not long for this world, however. Just a day after the announcement, news broke that James Gunn and Peter Safran were taking over DC Studios and launching a new DC Universe. This would effectively end Snyderâ€™s DC Universe, in which Cavill had been front and center. Gunn said on the â€œHappy Sad Confusedâ€ podcast earlier this year that an â€œunfairâ€ situation was created when his deal to take over DC Studios closed just as Cavill was announcing his return. Gunn had planned on rebooting Superman from the start, which he successfully did this summer with his David Corenswet-starring â€œSuperman.â€

â€œThe day our [DC] deal closed, all of a sudden, they were announcing that Henry was back,â€ Gunn said. â€œAnd Iâ€™m like, â€˜What is going on?â€™ We know what the plan is. The plan was to come in and do â€˜Superman.â€™ So it was really unfair to him and a total bummerâ€¦ â€œThat was really unfortunate. So Peter and I [thought] the right thing to do was to sit down with [Cavill] and talk to him. And we sat down and we talked to him. He was an absolute gentleman, a great guy about it. He said, â€˜The only thing I ask is that Iâ€™m able to reveal it myself as opposed to it coming from you guys.â€™â€

Through all of the presumable drama, Gunn and Snyder stayed in touch. Gunn revealed on X shortly after taking over DC Studios that he had touched base with Snyder and there were no hard feelings between them. Gunn told Fandango earlier this yea that he even consulted with Snyder when it came to designing the new Superman suit and whether or not to add the red trunks.

â€œOne of the biggest questions was, â€˜Were we gonna have trunks, or were we gonna not have trunks?â€™â€ Gunn said. â€œI talked to Zack Snyder, who was like, â€˜I tried a billion different versions with the trunks, and at the end of the day, I tried it, but I just couldnâ€™t get there.â€™ And I was feeling exactly the same way. â€¦ Theoretically, I liked the idea of trunks because itâ€™s the Superman I grew up with.â€

Gunnâ€™s DC Universe continues in summer 2026 with â€œSupergirlâ€ and then the â€œSupermanâ€ sequel film â€œMan of Tomorrow.â€

title: Netflixâ€™s â€˜Run Awayâ€™ Is a Mind-BendingÂ Harlan Coben Mystery Thriller: TV Review
summary: As per tradition, Netflix is kicking off the New Year with a new Harlan Coben mystery thriller â€” in this case, it’s â€œRun Away.â€ Adapted for television by Danny Brocklehurst, who was also at the helm of 2024â€™s â€œFool Me Once,â€ the eight-episode limited series follows a desperate father determined to find his vanished, drug-dependent […]
content:
As per tradition, Netflix is kicking off the New Year with a new Harlan Coben mystery thriller â€” in this case, itâ€™s â€œRun Away.â€ Adapted for television by Danny Brocklehurst, who was also at the helm of 2024â€™s â€œFool Me Once,â€ the eight-episode limited series follows a desperate father determined to find his vanished, drug-dependent daughter. Full of shocking twists and turns and gruesome violence, which are par for the course with all of Cobenâ€™s works, the show is an entertaining maze from its opening scene until the close. â€œRun Awayâ€ reminds audiences that one secret is typically just the tip of the iceberg; as you begin to dig into it, more mysteries often reveal themselves.

â€‹

Set in the U.K., â€œRun Awayâ€ follows financier Simon Greene (James Nesbitt), whose life appears picturesque on the surface. Heâ€™s happily married to his pediatrician wife, Ingrid (Minnie Driver), and he has three lovely children, Paige (Ellie de Lange), Sam (Adrian Greensmith) and Anya (Ellie Henry). Unfortunately, the Greene household is in disarray. Sam and Anya are thriving at university and high school, respectively, but Paige has gone missing. After a troubling start in college and becomin g dependent on drugs, she has now disappeared completely. While Ingrid insists on letting their eldest child hit rock bottom, Simon is driven to bring her home.

â€‹

With his tenacity and a wealth of financial resources, Simon discovers Paigeâ€™s whereabouts after six months of no contact. Unfortunately, the father/daughter reunion turns sour quickly, as Simon violently pummels Paigeâ€™s volatile boyfriend, Aaron Corval (Thomas Flynn), in front of a park full of spectators. When Aaron is found slaughtered a short time later, Simon becomes the prime suspect for Detectives Isaac Fagbenle (Alfred Enoch) and Ruby Todd (Amy Gledhill). Desperate to clear his name and find Paige again, Simon joins forces with private investigator Elena Ravenscroft (Ruth Jones), who connects Paige to a separate missing personâ€™s case she has been hired to work on.

â€‹

Fans of Cobenâ€™s frequent adaptations, including Netflixâ€™s â€œFool Me Once,â€ â€œMissing You,â€ and â€œThe Stranger,â€ know his series are tapestries of riddles, and â€œRun Awayâ€ is no different. The mystery around Paigeâ€™s disappearance stands at the center of this story, yet it is only one component of the tale. Shocking revelations, horrifying cruelty and complex lies engulf the narrative itself, even when it leans toward the preposterous. Still, the stellar cast, taut pacing and inventive storylines keep the show engaging, even when it couldâ€™ve very well fallen apart.

â€‹

From the Greene family to Elenaâ€™s personal life and the biases of Inspector Fagbenle, there is a wealth of information embedded in the series. However, whatâ€™s most compelling, as is the theme in many of Cobenâ€™s works, is how little we really know about our loved ones. As human beings, we all have secrets, things weâ€™ve tried to forget or instances weâ€™re ashamed of. These are fragments of our beings we are scared to confess, for they could alter how others perceive us or how we see ourselves. â€œRun Awayâ€ does an exquisite job at honing in on why we choose to bury traumas and destructive behaviors, both past and present.

â€‹

Fascinating and intensely detailed, â€œRun Awayâ€ is an astonishing web involving an array of seemingly unrelated characters and circumstances that all weave themselves together in the end. The show puts a spotlight on the secrets we keep from those we love most, and how, once exposed, those skeletons can alter who we are and how we view our loved ones forever. Amid the vast array of clues that slowly reveal themselves, to shootouts and haunting flashbacks, the show is as expansive as it is intense. Moreover, just as viewers believe theyâ€™ve grasped the truth, the plot shifts, moving the narrative into a different direction. In the end, the series reminds us that digging into other peopleâ€™s lives may bring you answers, but you may not want to face these truths when they come to light.

â€œRun Awayâ€ premieres on Netflix Jan. 1.

title: Film Limbo: 18 High-Profile Movies That Were Shot But Havenâ€™t Seen The Light Of Day
summary: Getting a film through production, post and released is no small feat. Multiple high-profile films remain stuck in limbo. We even broke news about one of them this year. That got us thinking about buzzy projects down the years that were made but still havenâ€™t seen the light of day. Check out our piece below […]
content:
Getting a film through production, post and released is no small feat. Multiple high-profile films remain stuck in limbo. We even broke news about one of them this year. That got us thinking about buzzy projects down the years that were made but still havenâ€™t seen the light of day.

Check out our piece below on 18 such projects, all starry features that were largely shot, but sadly havenâ€™t had a release for one reason or another.

A Woman of the Sea

A Woman of the Sea, also known by its working title Sea Gulls, is the unreleased silent film produced in 1926 by Charlie Chaplin. The love story set against the sea was a starring vehicle for his former leading lady Edna Purviance. But it is one of only two lost Chaplin films, having been destroyed by Chaplin himself as a tax write-off, despite six months of filming and an estimated $90,000 spent on production. Filmmaker John Grierson, who reportedly saw some of the film before the negatives were burned, called it â€œextraordinarily beautiful â€” but empty.â€

The Deep

Orson Welles worked on this film from 1966-1969 and still harbored hopes it might be completed in the years after that. The drama was to follow a coupleâ€™s honeymoon trip aboard a yacht. The production was plagued by financial and technical problems and as work on the film became more sporadic and difficult, Welles is said to have become increasingly withdrawn. The original negative was lost and the film only exists in two work prints. Despite its challenges, lead Jeanne Moreau was among those to look back on the production as â€œa fantastic experience,â€ adding that â€œthe only disastrous thing was that later on, the film disappeared.â€ Another lead actor in the film, Laurence Harvey, died in 1973, effectively ending hopes the project could film its last remaining scenes.

Watch on Deadline

The Day The Clown Cried

Jerry Lewis in â€˜The Day the Clown Criedâ€™ Everett Collection

This 1972 Swedish-French drama, directed by and starring Jerry Lewis, was about a circus clown imprisoned in a Nazi concentration camp. The film has gained notoriety and mystique over the decades both for its controversial premise and because it never saw the light of day. Lewis repeatedly insisted the film would never be released, but later donated an incomplete copy to the Library of Congress in 2015 under orders that it wasnâ€™t to be made available until 2024. A journalist screened the five-hour footage that year but said that the film wasnâ€™t complete. It later emerged that a complete copy had existed but was stolen by an actor in the film.

Big Bug Man

This unreleased American animated TV film starred Brendan Fraser and Marlon Brando, marking the latterâ€™s last film role. It followed a candy company worker who gains special abilities after being bitten by insects. The hand-drawn film is reported to have cost as much as $20 million. Pic was written by Bob Bendetson, who also wrote episodes of The Simpsons, and was directed Bendetson and Peter Shin. Brando was originally asked to voice a male character, but Brando thought it would be fun to voice the old lady Mrs. Sour instead. Brando reportedly wore a blonde wig, a dress, white gloves, and full makeup while recording the voice. An unwell Brando died shortly after recording his part in the film. It was originally scheduled for release between 2006 and 2008, but never got a release.

Hippie Hippie Shake

Hippie Hippie Shake is an unreleased UK drama from Working Title chronicling the release of an Australian satirical magazine in 1960s London and the staffâ€™s trial for distributing an obscene issue. Cillian Murphy and Sienna Miller starred in the film, which was repeatedly delayed. In 2007 the film finally began shooting, but by 2009 creative differences led to director Beeban Kidron quitting during post. By 2011, Working Title admitted the film wouldnâ€™t be released.

Black Water Transit

Black Water Transit is an unreleased 2009 American crime-drama directed by Tony Kaye of American History X fame. Laurence Fishburne and Karl Urban are among cast of the film set in post-Katrina New Orleans, where a shipping exec finds himself getting more than he bargained for after agreeing to help feds expose a smuggler. The film got bogged down in various complex lawsuits over many years. Along the way, exec producer David Bergstein went to prison for a separate fraud charge.

The Magic 7

The Magic 7 is an animated TV film written and directed by Roger Holzberg. The film centers on the adventures of two children and a dragon as they fight the arch-enemies of Earth. The stellar voice cast included John Candy, Michael J Fox, Ted Danson, Ice-T, Jeremy Irons, Demi Moore and James Earl Jones. It was slated to air on Earth Day, April 22, 1997, but was postponed. After later plans for a 2005 release, the film was again suspended.

Gore

Based on Jay Pariniâ€™s biography of Gore Vidal, the 2017-shot film was in post-production when Netflix decided to cancel it following the sexual assault allegations against Kevin Spacey. It would have been an early prestige Netflix original and came on the heels of the streamerâ€™s hit collaboration with Oscar winner Spacey on House of Cards. But the film was killed in post. Thereâ€™s speculation online that the largely finished film privately screened for one or two top-ranking Netflix executives at the time.

Leslie Grace as Batgirl Warner Bros Discovery

The DC Comics adaptation is possibly the highest-profile instance of an unreleased movie. Directed by Adil El Arbi and Bilall Fallah, the film starred Leslie Grace as Batgirl alongside JK Simmons, Jacob Scipio, Brendan Fraser, Michael Keaton and Ivory Aquino. Joss Whedon was originally attached to write and direct but left a year into work on the movie. El Arbi and Fallah were hired to direct in 2021 when the film was confirmed as an HBO Max original. In summer 2022, DC Films and WBD announced that, while the film had entered post-production, the studio no longer planned to release it as scheduled due to the companyâ€™s cost-cutting measures and a refocus on theatrical releases. The shelving of a nearly complete, $90 million film for tax write-off purposes drew widespread condemnation, but it wasnâ€™t the last time a studio pulled such a move.

Scoob 2

This HBO Max mystery-comedy, scheduled for release in 2022, was a prequel to the studioâ€™s 2020 film Scoob!, both based on the Scooby-Doo franchise. Mark Hamill, McKenna Grace and Maya Hawke were among cast but WBD shelved the film citing cost-cutting measures and an intent to refocus on theatrical films over projects made for streaming.

Newborn/Solitary

This Nate Parker drama, shot back in 2020, follows a man who is released into a newly self-isolating society after years of solitary confinement. David Oyelowo is in the lead role and support comes from Barry Pepper, Olivia Washington and Jimmie Fails. Parkerâ€™s career hit major turbulence some years before this movie was shot and the filmâ€™s financier Bron has subsequently gone under, making a release even harder. We hear from sources that there may still be hope of a release for this one, however. Watch this space.

The Way of the Wind

â€˜The Way of the Windâ€™

Few films have been shrouded in more mystery over the years than Terrence Malickâ€˜s The Way of the Wind, a perennial entrant on our list of movies that could appear at major festivals. Malick drew a typically stacked cast for his retelling of Jesusâ€™ life including Mark Rylance, Matthias Schoenaerts, Aidan Turner, Ben Kingsley, Joseph Fiennes, Tawfeek Barhom, Matthieu Kassovitz and Douglas Booth. Rylance is said to play Satan and some in the cast play Saints. The film is understood to have shot in 2019. Kassovitz told French media that Malick filmed an average of five hours per day, leading to 3,000 hours of footage by the end of filming. As of 2025, Malick is reportedly still editing, so thereâ€™s hope we may still see this one.

As we revealed, the conspiracy thriller directed by Mark Pellington and starring Bryan Cranston, Lily Gladstone, Jennifer Ehle and others, shot early this year but came to an abrupt halt when the money ran out and cast and crew stopped being paid. Cranston told us he wouldnâ€™t return to set until the crew got their money, but so far, the project remains in limbo.

Kung Fury 2

This martial arts comedy sequel, directed by David Sandberg, who also co-wrote the screenplay with Tyler Burton Smith, features a starry cast of Sandberg, Michael Fassbender, Arnold Schwarzenegger, Alexandra Shipp, Jorma Tacone and David Hasselhoff. Filming took place in 2019 but wok on post stopped in late 2020 due to a lawsuit with investors, and the filmâ€™s release was indefinitely delayed. As of December 2025, the film remains incomplete, with legal issues still ongoing.

All Starr Weekend

This all-star sports comedy-drama, written and directed by Jamie Foxx, marked his directorial debut. Foxx also acted in the film with Jeremy Piven, Eva Longoria, Robert Downey Jr, Ken Jeong, Gerard Butler, Benicio Del Toro, Jessica Szohr and others. The premise is said to be about two truck drivers who get tickets to see their favorite players in the NBA All-Star Game. After many twists and turns, the guys find themselves and their NBA heroes in a precarious life-or-death situation. Filming began in 2016. Foxx previously said he would portray a â€œwhite, racist copâ€ and â€œmanaged to convince Robert Downey Jr. to play a Mexicanâ€ in the film. The project was originally scheduled for release in 2018 but was delayed multiple times. By 2022, it was shelved.

The Long Home

James Franco directed and stars in this indie drama alongside Josh Hutcherson, Tim Blake Nelson, Courtney Love, Ashton Kutcher, Josh Hartnett and Giancarlo Esposito. Filming began in May 2015 and the film went through post, but after an actress on the film accused Franco of inappropriate sexual behavior it has never been released.

The Mothership

Halle Berry in â€˜The Mothershipâ€™ YouTube screenshot

The Mothership, another unreleased Netflix project, is a sci-fi starring Halle Berry, Molly Parker and Omari Hardwick. The synopsis for Matt Charmanâ€™s directorial debut reads: â€œOne year after her husband mysteriously vanishes from their rural farm, single mother Sara Morse and her children discover a strange, extraterrestrial object underneath their home, which leads them to embark on a race to find their husband and father.â€ Filming wrapped in 2021, but by 2024 Netflix announced it no longer planned to release the film due to the lengthy post-production and said it was never completed. Netflix content chief Bela Bajaria would later say of the filmâ€™s canceled release: â€œEverybody just felt like it was the right thing to not do it.â€

Golden

Michel Gondryâ€™s musical, shot in 2024, was said to be inspired by Pharrell Williamsâ€™ childhood in Virginia Beach, with Williams on board to write original songs for the film. Kelvin Harrison, Halley Bailey, Daâ€™Vine Joy Randolph, Janelle Monae and Brian Tyree Henry were among the starry cast of the ambitious project, which was initially slated to be released in the U.S. by Universal in May 2025. In February, it was reported that due to producer disagreements the $20M+ film would be permanently shelved and not offered to other studios for completion and/or distribution.

title: Mickey Lee Dies: â€˜Big Brotherâ€™ Contestant Was 35
summary: Mickey Lee, a contestant on CBS’ Big Brother last summer, died last night following a series of cardiac arrests in recent days. She was 35. content:
Mickey Lee, a contestant on CBSâ€™ Big Brother last summer, died last night following a series of cardiac arrests in recent days. She was 35.

Leeâ€™s death was announced by her family on her Instagram page today.

â€œWith profound sadness,â€ the post reads, â€œthe family of Mickey Lee announces her transition on Christmas in the early evening. Mickey captured the hearts of audiences nationwide through her appearance on â€˜Big Brother,â€™ where her authenticity, strength and spirit left a lasting impression on fans and fellow cast members alike.â€

Lee, the message continues, â€œwill be remembered for the joy she brought into the lives of so many and for the genuine connections she formed on and offscreen.â€

Watch on Deadline

Leeâ€™s passing follows a December 22 GoFundMe posting that indicated the Atlanta-based TV personality had been hospitalized following the cardiac arrests, which themselves had followed Leeâ€™s bout with the flu.

Originally of Jacksonville, Florida, Lee was a cast member on Season 27 of the longrunning reality show. That installment of Big Brother ran from July to September, 2025; Lee was voted out of the Big Brother house by her co-competitors during the eighth week of the season.

According to the GoFundMe page, Leeâ€™s â€œsudden health crisisâ€ left her and her family â€œfacing enormous emotional and financial strain from mounting hospital bills to ongoing care and recovery costs.â€ As of today, the page had raised $31,747 of a $40,000 goal. The money is to be used for medical expenses not covered by insurance and other related costs.

Todayâ€™s Instagram post announcing her death expresses the familyâ€™s â€œdeepest gratitude to everyone who has offered prayers, love and support,â€ and asks for â€œprivacy during this critical time of bereavement.â€

â€œMickeyâ€™s light, legacy and impact will never be forgotten,â€ the post concludes.

In an exit interview with Deadlineâ€™s sister site Gold Derby, Lee said she actually preferred to leave the show when she did (she was evicted by a 6-1 vote on September 4, 2025. â€œI get to go out and live my life a little bit before coming back for finale,â€ she said. The season was won by contestant and lawyer Ashley Hollis on September 28.

Among Leeâ€™s co-stars offering condolences on social media were Rachel Reilly (â€œSorry for your loss and my prayers for your family RIP MICKEY you are missed â€“ love to all of youâ€), Clifton â€œWillâ€ Williams (â€œThis is absolutely horrible. Life is so short. Mickey was an incredible spirit and a joy in the house. Prayers to her family. The big brother family will miss her dearlyâ€) and Zach Cornell (â€œMickey, thank you for being such an incredible friend and inspiration to me both in and out of the houseâ€).

Big Brother housemate Jimmy Heagerty writes, â€œMickey, my heart is absolutely broken. In the house you were my friend, my first #1, and my ride or die. Outside of the house we reaffirmed our friendship, and that meant more to me than youâ€™ll ever know. What we built wasnâ€™t just a game relationship, it was real, and it mattered. Iâ€™m grateful for every laugh, every late-night talk, and every moment we had each otherâ€™s backs. Losing you hurts in a way I wasnâ€™t prepared for, but Iâ€™ll always carry the love, trust, and memories we shared. Youâ€™ll forever have a piece of my heart.â€

Information on Leeâ€™s survivors was not immediately available.

title: Connor Storrie on â€˜Heated Rivalryâ€™ Finale, Ilya Saying â€˜I Love Youâ€™ First and Crying With Hudson Williams While Filming Their â€˜Happy Endingâ€™ Last Scene
summary: SPOILER ALERT:Â This article contains details about the finale of â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ Season 1, now streaming onÂ HBO Max. “Heated Rivalry” star Connor Storrie knew early on he wanted to be an actor. He made that perfectly clear in YouTube videos he made when he was 12 years old under the name Actorboy222. The adorable videos were […]
content:
SPOILER ALERT: This article contains details about the finale of â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ Season 1, now streaming on HBO Max.

â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ star Connor Storrie knew early on he wanted to be an actor.

He made that perfectly clear in YouTube videos he made when he was 12 years old under the name Actorboy222. The adorable videos were discovered by rabid â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ fans shortly after Storrie became an instant star when the first two episodes of the queer hockey romance series premiered on HBO Max just a month ago.

â€œHe was on to something,â€ Storrie says looking back at his pre-teen self. â€œHe got me here. He was part of it.â€

Popular on Variety

What would 25-year-old Storrie say to his younger self now? â€œI would say, â€˜Cut that damn hair,â€™â€ he cracks, before pausing to give it a think. â€œI would tell him to make more stuff sooner, make more of his own stuff sooner. Just be more diligent about not just being an actor, as in trying to get cast in something and waiting for opportunities. I would be like, â€˜Try putting yourself in your own things.â€™â€

Storrie continues, â€œI love that little guy. I love him. I used to not like him.â€

It wasnâ€™t easy for a kid like him growing up in Odessa, Texas.

â€œI was this artist, sissy boy in West Texas that didnâ€™t want to play football,â€ he explains. â€œI wanted to play pretend and play dress up and disappear into weird worlds and entertain and try to connect with people that way, and that was just not the norm out there.â€

That kid is now one of Hollywoodâ€™s hottest young talents.

Storrie stars in â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ as Ilya Rozanov, a Russian hocky champion having a steamy sex-filled years-long affair with his Canadian counterpart Shane Hollander (played by Hudson Williams). The show â€” an adaptation of the â€œGame Changersâ€ novels â€” chronicles Rozanov and Hollanderâ€™s relationship as it goes from something purely physical to to being a deeply romantic and emotional relationship.

The sixth and final episode of Season 1 finds Rozanov visiting Hollander at his cottage. They finally admit to each other that theyâ€™re in love. But then Hollander unexpectedly comes out to his parents as not only being gay but also in a relationship with his career arch-nemesis as his father walks in on the couple kissing after making an unannounced trip to the cottage.

I spoke to Storrie over Zoom video from his Los Angeles-area home ahead of the season finale.

Were you surprised Ilya was the first to say, â€œI love youâ€? He said it in the Russian monologue in Episode 5 but this was different because he says it in English and in person.

Yeah, but I think this shows Ilya is in it for the long haul and heâ€™s enthusiastic about that.

Heâ€™s also the first to refer to them as boyfriends.

Thatâ€™s the thing about these eastern Europeans. They donâ€™t let you in on it. But once youâ€™re in, youâ€™re in for life.

What was it like walking into the cottage for the first time?

That was the element of the story that I was most excited to get to because itâ€™s really cool the way that Jacob Tierney wrote it. Thereâ€™s this kind of cool crescendo where it was so fast and rapid â€” the editing, the writing â€“ with so much energy upfront, and then it kind of lands and weâ€™re just two people in a house for a few days. As an actor, thatâ€™s where a lot of the cool acting moments are, where we really get to sit in some of those scenes for a long, long time. Itâ€™s kind of the episode where thereâ€™s officially a catharsis. People donâ€™t realize because of all the intimate scenes but this story really is about people falling in love at a distance. To finally see that come together, thereâ€™s a catharsis.

I think viewers may go into Episode 6 thinking itâ€™s going to be a sex fest because Shane and Ilya will be by themselves. Thereâ€™s some sex, but the episode is about much more than that.

You get to kind of breathe. They get to be normal on some level, which is what Jacob talks about when he says the â€œhappy ending.â€ I think what heâ€™s referring to is being emotionally regulated, emotionally aware enough to look each other in the eyes and be like, â€œI love you, letâ€™s do this.â€ And then whatever that looks like afterwards, theyâ€™re like, â€œWeâ€™re going to sign up for it. Weâ€™re signed up and weâ€™re locked in.â€

And then you literally ride off into the sunset when Shane and Ilya get in the car and leave Shaneâ€™s parentsâ€™ house.

We filmed that twice. I donâ€™t know which take they ended up using, but the first take, because we sit there for three or four minutes â€” we do the full length of that song, which I fucking love â€” Hudson and I just kind of rode in silence and just cried during that whole scene. As actors, we were like, â€œWeâ€™re killing. Weâ€™re in it. This is real, weâ€™re so in love.â€ Then the music stops and Jacob comes around and is like, â€œAlrighty, letâ€™s do one where you guys donâ€™t look like you want to kill yourselves. Letâ€™s start over.â€ He was like, â€œBe cute. This happy. This is fun.â€ We interpreted it in a very dramatic way. But, yeah, we literally get to ride off into the sunset.

I think Shane and his momâ€™s talk outside is going to resonate so much with people. Every kids wants to hear their parents apologize for something they had or hadnâ€™t done.

Theyâ€™re both accepting the truth of the matter, and that lets them actually heal from it, rather than it just being a placate-y kind of thing to each other.

My friend Ben texted me this morning and said the show has â€œrewiredâ€ his brain and he feels he can now finally be able to pursue a relationship.

Wow. Itâ€™s all about love, baby and realizing the stuff we internalize from the outside world hurts and it affects us. But at the end of the day, you gotta do your thing â€” whatever that is.

Youâ€™ve talked about being ostracized in high school when some classmates found those Actorboy222 videos. What would you say to those people now?

I donâ€™t feel any sort of way about it. I donâ€™t really villainize anyone no matter how nasty they get because I fully do believe that people are doing their best. I think that people are hurt. I think everyone is so insecure and sad, and we all have these things that are so tender to us, and I just feel blessed to be to have had a human experience thatâ€™s been just rugged enough to give me that perspective, to be like, â€œI donâ€™t really give a shit what words you use to describe me, or if you try to embarrass me because Iâ€™ve embarrassed myself a million fucking times. I donâ€™t give a shit anymore. So bring it on. I donâ€™t feel bad about it because, especially how visible everything is now on the internet, if youâ€™re a nasty person, I think that just makes you look nasty. I donâ€™t need to try and make you look nasty. I just try to hold myself with grace and understanding. If youâ€™re trying to belittle someone, itâ€™s probably because you feel pretty small yourself because I know when Iâ€™ve been mean in the past â€” weâ€™ve all done things â€” itâ€™s because I felt this big [he pinches a thumb and finger together]. I felt itty bitty.

Before we go, I have to ask â€“ do you actually like tuna melts?

I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve had a real legit tuna melt. Maybe I had one from Subway once. We didnâ€™t eat the best when I was growing up.

This Q&A has been edited and condensed.

title: Amos Poe, New York Underground Filmmaker, Dies at 76
summary: Amos Poe, the New York underground filmmaker who chronicled the punk scene and directed films including “Blank Generation” and “Alphabet City,” died Thursday of cancer. He was 76. His wife Claudia Summers posted on his Instagram account on Dec. 25, “Amos took his last breath today at 3:33 pm, surrounded by loved ones. ‘Adios’ â€” […]
content:
Amos Poe, the New York underground filmmaker who chronicled the punk scene and directed films including â€œBlank Generationâ€ and â€œAlphabet City,â€ died Thursday of cancer. He was 76.

His wife Claudia Summers posted on his Instagram account on Dec. 25, â€œAmos took his last breath today at 3:33 pm, surrounded by loved ones. â€˜Adiosâ€™ â€” AP.â€

Friends including Kim Gordon and Jim Jarmusch paid tribute on his Instagram, with Jarmusch writing â€œlove you so very much.â€

Born in Tel Aviv, he got started with the short music film â€œNight Lunchâ€ with Roxy Music and David Bowie. The 1976 â€œBlank Generationâ€ was his second film, co-directed with guitarist Ivan Kral, and was one of the first to chronicle the burgeoning punk rock movement in New York. Filmed partly at CBGB, it featured appearances from Patti Smith, Talking Heads, Television, Richard Hell and Wayne County.

Popular on Variety

But Kral took control of â€œBlank Generationâ€ and several of Poeâ€™s other films after a disagreement, reediting them and removing Poeâ€™s name.

â€œIâ€™m trying to be grown up about it. But theyâ€™re trying to rewrite history,â€ Poe told the New York Times when he discovered what had happened.

As the No Wave music movement was getting started in the city, he pioneered the concept of No Wave filmmaking, directing films such as â€œThe Foreignerâ€ with Debbie Harry and â€œSubway Ridersâ€ with Susan Tyrell, Robbie Coltrane and Cookie Mueller.

â€œOur whole esthetic, or the way we approached it, was that you didnâ€™t necessarily have to have the professionalism or the understanding of making films, you had to have the inspiration and the will to put yourself completely into it,â€ Poe told Reuters in 2011.

Poe also directed music videos for acts including Anthrax and Run-DMC, as well as the public access TV show â€œTV Party,â€ hosted by Blondieâ€™s Chris Stein and Glenn Oâ€™Brien.

His other films include Steve Earle documentary â€œJust an American Boy,â€ â€œTriple Bogey on a Par Five Holeâ€ with Philip Seymour Hoffman and 2012â€™s â€œA Walk in the Park.â€

title: â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™ Almost Ended in the 1980s, But Tears for Fears Stayed on the Soundtrack Anyway
summary: Josh Safdieâ€™s “Marty Supreme,” now in theaters, is filled with â€˜80s bangers, including Tears for Fearsâ€™ â€œEverybody Wants to Rule the Worldâ€ and Peter Gabrielâ€™s â€œI Have the Touch.â€ But Safdieâ€™s latest film â€” starring TimothÃ©e Chalamet as a young man from New York’s Lower East Side who dreams big and aspires to conquer the […]
content:
Josh Safdieâ€™s â€œMarty Supreme,â€ now in theaters, is filled with â€˜80s bangers, including Tears for Fearsâ€™ â€œEverybody Wants to Rule the Worldâ€ and Peter Gabrielâ€™s â€œI Have the Touch.â€

But Safdieâ€™s latest film â€” starring TimothÃ©e Chalamet as a young man from New Yorkâ€™s Lower East Side who dreams big and aspires to conquer the world of table tennis â€” is set in the 1950s.

Itâ€™s an intriguing juxtaposition that totally works because itâ€™s not an ordinary period piece.

Safdie, who also edited the film and wrote the screenplay alongside Ronald Bronstein, was inspired while watching a video of a 1948 British Open table tennis event. â€œThis wiry young guy was bouncing all over the place, couldnâ€™t stand still, cocky, but also totally vain,â€ he recalls. The guy was much like Marty.

Popular on Variety

Around the same time, he became obsessed with Gabrielâ€™s 1982 song, which he says he listened to over 1,000 times. â€œI decided to set the footage to that song, and it just worked. Something was happening there; it felt mythic,â€ Safdie explains. He adds, â€œThere was a contemporary quality to seeing the anachronistic music paired with the â€˜40s or early â€˜50s.â€

Safdie explains how the new wave-flavored music actually makes sense with the filmâ€™s themes. â€œPresident Reagan was nostalgically in that first era of postmodernism, actively trying to recall the â€˜50s. In the face of defeat from Vietnam, culture was really just starting to redo itself in the vein of the â€˜50s. You saw it in style. You saw it in movies. â€˜Back to the Futureâ€™ is literally going back to the â€˜50s. But on a very simple level, what happens when you do that is the past starts to feel like itâ€™s haunting the future, and the future feels like itâ€™s haunting the past.â€

At one point, Safdie had written a version of the film where Marty was shown in the 1980s. It was an alternate ending. Safdie says, â€œHeâ€™s at a Tears for Fears concert with his granddaughter, listening to the lyrics of â€˜Everybody Wants to Rule the World,â€™ and reflecting on his youth.â€

That scene was ultimately removed. But Safdie stayed committed to the 1980s tunes including New Orderâ€™s as â€œpropulsive, energetic, and funâ€ while still exploring the concept of the past and future in conversation.

For the score, Safdie turned to composer Daniel Lopatin (Oneohtrix Point Never), who scored both â€œGood Timeâ€ and â€œUncut Gems.â€ Lopatin, known for inventing vaporwave â€” a genre of electronic music from the 2010s that offers a nostalgic, surreal take on 1980s music â€” was the perfect choice to tie the filmâ€™s needle-drop moments together. Lopatin says there was no real differentiation between the game of table tennis that Marty plays and his spirit. â€œHeâ€™s buoyant and energetic, and no one believes in him. Thereâ€™s an energy to him, a buoyancy and a lightness that is mirrored in the game itself,â€ he says.

Lopatin used fast, percussive strikes to keep the score melodic, incorporating mallet strikes to mirror the ping-pong balls. He notes, â€œThose mallet sounds are also really prominent in new wave music and synth-pop of the â€˜80s.â€

Lopatin was inspired by the concept of memory and time, as well as that original ending. â€œThe score goes back to, what would it be like to think back on your coming of age in the 1950s while hearing Tears for Fears blasting in your ears, and maybe youâ€™re side by side with your children, but somewhere else in your mind?â€ The result, in Lopatinâ€™s words, was â€œan abstraction of that Tears for Fears concert.â€ He describes it as what happens when the present dissolves, and memory and the present converge. â€œThe score is a kind of abstraction or an undercurrent â€” a symbolic wave of what was in the script.â€

To align with the songs, which also include New Orderâ€™s â€œThe Perfect Kiss,â€ Lopatin used digital synthesizers from the 1980s, including the Yamaha DX7 from 1983. He also incorporated flutes, saxophones, and string arrangements on top.

His score became was an expression of Martyâ€™s youth, energy and ambition. If Marty is a builder and a bridge between worlds â€” past, present, and future â€” so too is the score and its accompanying songs. Safdie concludes, â€œI think all those things coming together in sync with one another â€” the synchronicity â€” has that additive effect of like, â€˜Oh my god, this movieâ€™s teeming with life.â€™â€

Toby Morton, a comedian and former writer for South Park and Mad TV, saw the writing on the wall, as it were. Last August, months before President Donald Trump began floating the idea of renaming The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in his own honor, Morton made a couple prescient purchases.

Morton bought the domain names â€œtrumpkennedycenter.orgâ€ and â€œtrumpkennedycenter.com.â€ Earlier this month, the centerâ€™s Trump-appointed board announced that his name would be added to the arts organization, with workers subsequently installing lettering to the Washington D.C. building to read â€œThe Donald Trump and The John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing Arts.â€

In an interview with the Washington Post, Morton said he decided to purchase the domain names after Trump â€œbegan gutting the Kennedy Center board earlier this year.â€

â€œI thought, Yep, that nameâ€™s going on the building,â€ Morton said in the interview. â€œThe rest followed on schedule.â€ Morton had previously bought domain names domain names associated with Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, Rep. Nancy Mace and Sen. Chuck Schumer, using them to create parody accounts.

Asked how heâ€™ll use the Trump-Kennedy domain names, Morton, who wrote for South Park from 2001 to 2003 and Mad TV from 2006-2007 and whose Instagram page identifies him as a â€œCreator of Anti-Fascist Websitesâ€, said, the Trump sites will â€œabsolutely reflect the absurdity of the moment. In the wake of the installation of the Trump name on the building, the American College Theatre Festival ended a 58-year partnership with the center, a noted jazz musician canceled a Christmas Eve Kennedy Center concert that had been a tradition for more than 20 years, and Congresswoman Joyce Beatty (D-OH) filed a lawsuit insisting the board vote to change the name is null and void.

â€œThe Kennedy Center has always been a cultural institution meant to outlast any one administration or personality,â€ Morton, who owns about 50 various domain names typically purchased for about $15 to $30, told the Post. â€œItâ€™s meant to honor culture, not ego. Once it was treated like personal branding, satire became unavoidable.â€

Perry Bemonte, the longtime guitarist and keyboardist for the influential UK band The Cure, died over the Christmas holiday, the band confirmed on its official website Friday. He was 65.

In a statement, the band wrote that Bemonte passed away after a short illness at his home. No other details were provided by the goth alt-rock bad, which has sold more than 30 million albums worldwide and is in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

â€œQuiet, intense, intuitive, constant and hugely creative, â€˜Teddyâ€™ was a warm hearted and vital part of The Cure story,â€ the band wrote. It added, â€œOur thoughts and condolences are with all his family. He will be very greatly missed.â€

Born in London in 1965, Bamonte and his brother were both roadies in the mid-1980s for the Robert Smith-led band, with Perry eventually elevated to band member status in 1990 after the exit of original member Roger Oâ€™Donnell, one of many comings and going within the group over the years.

Bamonte played guitar, six-string bass and keyboard first on the The Cureâ€™s 1992 album Wish, the bandâ€™s ninth studio record and itâ€™s biggest chart-topper; it flew to No. 1 in the UK and No. 2 in the U.S. behind hits â€œWish and â€œFriday Iâ€™m in Love.â€ He also played on the albums Wild Mood Swings and Bloodflowers among others. The band said he performed more than 400 shows over a 14-year period before his own exit from the group.

He reunited with his former bandmates in 2019 for its induction into the Rock hall, and then rejoined The Cure officially in 2022, playing another 90 shows.
