title: Tyler Perry & Lionsgate Hit With $77M Christmas Day Sexual Assault Suit From â€˜A Madea Halloweenâ€™ Actor; â€œFailed Money Grabâ€ Perryâ€™s Lawyer Says
summary: A vivid $77 million sexual assault and sexual battery lawsuit against Tyler Perry filed by the same lawyer who is behind a previous similar action earlier this year is just more of the same in search of a payout, claims the “betrayed” Madea star’s high-profile attorney. “Having recently failed in another matter against Mr. Perry, […]
content:
A vivid $77 million sexual assault and sexual battery lawsuit against Tyler Perry filed by the same lawyer who is behind a previous similar action earlier this year is just more of the same in search of a payout, claims the â€œbetrayedâ€ Madea starâ€™s high-profile attorney.

â€œHaving recently failed in another matter against Mr. Perry, the very same lawyer has now made yet another demand from more than a decade ago which will also be a failed money grab,â€ Alex Spiro said today of the big bucks jury trial seeking claims from Mario Rodriguez against Perry and â€œBoo! A Madea Halloween distributor Lionsgate.

Spiro, who has successfully repped Alec Baldwin, Jay-Z and many an A-lister over the years with a sluggerâ€™s approach is certainly putting forth the narrative of how he wants the Jonathan Delshad represented Rodriguezâ€™s LA Superior Court case to go down in flames.

Watch on Deadline

There is no denying Rodriguezâ€™s suit is very similar in tone and format to the ongoing $260 million seeking sexual harassment and assault suit initially filed in June in LASC by Delshad for his client The Oval actor Derek Dixon against Perry. At the same time, there is no denying also that Rodriguezâ€™s 23-page complaint of December 25 is full of potentially damning text message screen grabs, oral sex remarks and other suggestive conversation from an allegedly predatory Perry. There are also apparent cringey proclamations by the filmmaker of â€œYou know Mario, Iâ€™m not a bad person to know and have in your corner.â€

Focusing on the making of Boo! and number of subsequent meet-ups, such as a November 14, 2018 Beverly Hills dinner at Mastroâ€™s Steakhouse to discuss more potential roles for model Rodriguez that saw a cameo of sorts from John Cena, the complaint is also full of graphic and specific details. â€œMr. Perry reached into Mr. Rodriguezâ€™s underwear and grabbed his penis,â€ the filing exclaims of an allegedl assault eight years ago. â€œMr. Perry was making sexual moaning noises and saying, â€˜Stay here, stay here,â€™ while he pressed his body against Mr. Rodriguez and continued to grab his penis.â€

Capping off that alleged incident, the filing claims Perry â€œstuffed $5,000.00 in Mr. Rodriguezâ€™s pocketâ€ as the slightly inebriated latter was waiting for an Uber to take him home from Perryâ€™s house. Other alleged attempts by Perry to offer Rodriguez financial security and on-screen roles for what the plaintiff understands to be sex followed up to 2024.

Claiming â€œPTSD â€¦psychological, emotional and economic injuriesâ€ from Perryâ€™s alleged actions towards him, Rodriguez (who did play a â€œvery good looking college studentâ€ in 2016â€™s Boo!) and lawyer Delshad have hauled Lionsgate into all this.

Lionsgate Bryan Bedder/Getty Images

Their argument is disarmingly simple, though with an odd misspelling of the studioâ€™s name. â€œLions Gate should have known of Perryâ€™s misconduct as Perry has had many such allegations made against him in the past,â€ the Christmas Day filed complaint states. â€œBut for Lions Gateâ€™s failure to act and enforce their morality clauses and other safeguards, the sexual assaults would not have occurred as Perry would not have been in a position of power.â€

Lionsgate, as it is actually spelled, did not respond tonight to Deadlineâ€™s request for comment on the December 25 lawsuit and their place in it.

Now, in terms of someone who did have the courtesy to respond, Spiro may be swinging in defense of his client, but the NYC-based Quinn Emanuel Urquhart & Sullivan partner is not all together off the mark with his strong statement this Boxing Day. Rodriguez decided to take action with his claims after a Sean â€œDiddyâ€ Combs referencing friend texted him on June 18 with news of Dixonâ€™s case.

â€œMr. Rodriguez realized that Mr. Perry was continuing to use his power and influence to sexually assault hopeful actors, and, with the voice of others, decided it was time to tell his story, obtain justice, and finally stop Mr. Perry,â€ this weekâ€™s filing says. â€œWhen Perry became aware that Rodriguez was going to file this action, Perry once again reached out to Rodriguez by text, telling Rodriguez that Perry did so much to help Rodriguez and was that (sic) Perry was feeling betrayed by Rodriguez,â€ the document adds.

Interestingly, with all the text exchanges displayed in Rodriguezâ€™s filing, this possibly explosive one is not there to see.

Now, to Spiroâ€™s slamming of Rodriguez via Delshad and the Dixon matter, it is a bit more nuanced in reality. For instance, the case hasnâ€™t actually â€œfailed,â€ as New Yorker profiled Spiro claims.

Delshadâ€™s case against Perry for Dixon hasnâ€™t exactly nosedived, but it has had an unconventional path through the legal system so far. Filed in LASC in June, the matter was pulled from state court in California and moved to federal court in the Golden State earlier this year. Then Dixon filed to have his case remanded back to LASC. On December 12, a federal judge ruled that Dixon had not proved he had residence out West and denied the return to state court. A consequence of Judge John Walkerâ€™s decision was that Dixonâ€™s case was then shifted to federal court in Georgia, Perryâ€™s home base.

Sitting with Judge Sarah E. Geraghty out in the Peach State the past two weeks of this holiday season, Dixonâ€™s case hasnâ€™t seen much more movement. Which means, once Lady Justice picks up the pace and assuming there is no settlement, 2026 could very likely see Tyler Perry fighting pricey sexual assault cases on two sides of the country, which could prove very very messy indeed.

title: Kennedy Center President Threatens $1 Million Lawsuit Against Jazz Musician Who Canceled Christmas Eve Concert Over â€˜Trump Kennedy Centerâ€™ Name Change
summary: Ambassador Richard Grenell, the Trump-appointed president of the Kennedy Center, said the organization will seek $1 million in damages from noted jazz musician Chuck Redd after Redd abruptly canceled this year’s Christmas Eve concert in protest of the center’s renaming to “The Donald J. Trump and The John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing […]
content:
Ambassador Richard Grenell, the Trump-appointed president of the Kennedy Center, said the organization will seek $1 million in damages from noted jazz musician Chuck Redd after Redd abruptly canceled this yearâ€™s Christmas Eve concert in protest of the centerâ€™s renaming to â€œThe Donald J. Trump and The John F. Kennedy Memorial Center for the Performing Arts.â€

In the letter sent Dec. 26 to Redd, first reported by the AP, Grenell wrote: â€œYour decision to withdraw at the last moment â€” explicitly in response to the Centerâ€™s recent renaming, which honors President Trumpâ€™s extraordinary efforts to save this national treasure â€” is classic intolerance and very costly to a non-profit Arts institution.â€

â€œThis is your official notice that we will seek $1 million in damages from you for this political stunt,â€ Grenell wrote.

Popular on Variety

In a post on X Saturday night about his legal threat to Redd, Grenell said, â€œThe left is boycotting the Arts because Trump is supporting the Arts. But we will not let them cancel shows without consequences. The Arts are for everyone â€” and the Left is mad about it.â€

Redd did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Redd had led the annual Christmas Eve jazz concert at the Kennedy Center since 2006. On Wednesday, he told the AP that he nixed this yearâ€™s event after Trumpâ€™s name was added to the organizationâ€™s building and website. â€œWhen I saw the name change on the Kennedy Center website and then hours later on the building, I chose to cancel our concert,â€ Redd said, per the AP.

Workers on Dec. 19 added Trumpâ€™s name to the center, coming one day after the White House claimed that the Kennedy Center board of trustees â€” handpicked by President Trump â€” voted unanimously to rename the facility the â€œTrump Kennedy Center.â€

Legal experts say the renaming of the center was illegal, because a 1964 federal law established its name as â€œthe John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Artsâ€ after the slain president and explicitly prohibits the board of trustees from adding any other name to the buildingâ€™s exterior. On Monday (Dec. 22), U.S. Rep. Joyce Beatty (D-Ohio) sued Trump and the Kennedy Centerâ€™s board seeking to force the removal of Trumpâ€™s name from the organization, saying an act of Congress is required to change its name.

The free Dec. 24 concert at the Kennedy Center had been scheduled to take place Tuesday at 12 p.m. at the centerâ€™s Millennium Stage. â€œJoin in our annual Christmas Eve Jazz Jam for an evening of music thatâ€™ll fill you with holiday cheer,â€ the cultural center had said in promoting the event.

Redd, 67, is â€œwell known internationally as a performer on drums and vibraphoneâ€ and is featured on more than 80 recordings, according to his website. The musician began recording and touring at the age of 21 when he joined the Charlie Byrd Trio. He also became a member of the Great Guitars (Barney Kessel, Byrd and Herb Ellis) and served as artist-in-residence at the Smithsonian Jazz CafÃ© in Washington, D.C., from 2004-08. Redd also was a member of the Smithsonian Jazz Masterworks Orchestra for 15 years.

title: The WTF Moments That Shook The Global Film & TV Biz In 2025
summary: And so we say au revoir to another year in showbiz. Itâ€™s rarely quiet, and thereâ€™s always something dominating the pixels of this website, so we endeavored to take a moment and reflect on some of the stories that have shaped 2025. From Karla SofÃ­a GascÃ³n’s car crash awards campaign, to the gawp-inducing resignation of […]
content:
And so we say au revoir to another year in showbiz. Itâ€™s rarely quiet, and thereâ€™s always something dominating the pixels of this website, so we endeavored to take a moment and reflect on some of the stories that have shaped 2025. From Karla SofÃ­a GascÃ³nâ€™s car crash awards campaign, to the gawp-inducing resignation of the BBCâ€™s top brass, and a new birth for James Bond, hereâ€™s a rundown of the WTF moments that shook the global film and TV industry.

January

Karla SofÃ­a GascÃ³n attends the 2025 Netflix Oscar party Gonzalo Marroquin/Getty Images for Netflix

January 2025 will be remembered as the month that wildfires caused devastation in Hollywood, killing 31 people. It was a heartbreaking time for the town, and the fallout was felt far beyond Los Angeles. International stars, including Anthony Hopkins and Eugene Levy, were among the thousands who lost homes in the blaze. Hopkins spoke for many when he said: â€œThe only thing we take with us is the love we give.â€

In the same month, Karla SofÃ­a GascÃ³nâ€™s bid for Oscar glory was dramatically derailed when the Emilia PÃ©rez starâ€™s ugly historical tweets about Muslims and George Floyd were uncovered. She was the front-runner for Best Actress and would have been the first openly trans person to clinch a golden statuette. In the end, she skipped the red carpet and was roasted by host Conan Oâ€™Brien. â€œYOU TWEETED WHAT?â€ he screamed â€” words that will have resonated with Netflixâ€™s campaign team.

Watch on Deadline

February

â€˜Skyfallâ€™

We were left shaken (and perhaps a little stirred) in February, when Amazon MGM Studios signaled a new era for James Bond. Michael G. Wilson and Barbara Broccoli relinquished control of the British super spy in a $1 billion deal with Jeff Bezosâ€™ studio, paving the way for development to begin on Bond 26, four years on from Daniel Craigâ€™s last tour of duty in No Time to Die.

Amazon later announced that Denis Villeneuve would helm the new 007 movie, with David Heyman and Amy Pascal producing. No word yet on who will fill Craigâ€™s shoes, but Villeneuve will begin the search for a fresh-faced Brit once heâ€™s done with Dune: Part Three. As for Broccoli, our Baz Bamigboye revealed the loss of Bond was like a â€œdeath in the family.â€

From a British hunk to a Spanish one: February was also the month for the â€œMontoya, por favor!â€ viral sensation on Spainâ€™s version of Temptation Island. Contestant JosÃ© Carlos Montoya hijacked our social media feeds as he made a desperate charge across a moonlit beach to confront his girlfriend as she slipped between the sheets with another man. It was a moment of pure cinema from one of the worldâ€™s top reality shows.

March

Adolescenceâ€˜ Netflix

Adolescence went from low-key British original on Netflix to globe-straddling giant in March 2025. The story of a British teenager radicalized by the manosphere â€” told through the prism of four episodes all captured in one shot by a pioneer of the form, Philip Barantini â€” became Netflixâ€™s second most-watched series of all time. It established Stephen Graham as one of the UKâ€™s finest acting exports, burnished the credentials of prolific writer Jack Thorne, and birthed a breakout star in the shape of Owen Cooper.

Adolescence went on to win eight Emmys and made its way into political conversation in the UK, where Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced a deal with Netflix to stream the series for free in secondary schools. It also marked a peculiar bit of dissonance: while Adolescence was conquering Netflix, British drama producers were wringing their hands about a funding crisis on home soil. Despite Channel 4 accusing Netflix of â€œTV tourism,â€ Adolescence showed that, at its best, UK drama is both a commercial and creative force.

April

Russell Brand

The White Lotus and Aimee Lou Woodâ€™s teeth (thanks in part to a Saturday Night Live sketch slammed as â€œmean and unfunnyâ€ by the British actress) were the talk of the internet in April, but it was a slower-burning story that caught the eye. Two years after The Sunday Times published allegations that Russell Brand sexually assaulted four women at the height of his fame, the Forgetting Sarah Marshall star was charged with rape, indecent assault, and sexual assault by Londonâ€™s Metropolitan Police. In December, the Met brought two fresh charges of rape and sexual assault against him.

Brand has reinvented himself as a Christian convert who evangelizes about free speech and free thinking in MAGA America, but he saved UK authorities a potential extradition headache by appearing in court in May. Brand pleaded not guilty and will face trial in June 2026. â€œIâ€™m now gonna have the opportunity to defend these charges in court, and Iâ€™m incredibly grateful for that,â€ he told his followers.

Brand was not the only British actor to be charged with rape in 2025: Micheal Ward appeared in court over similar allegations. The Top Boy star, who was quickly dropped by UK agency Olivia Bell Management after the charges were announced, had not long returned from Cannes, where he was on the promotion trail for Ari Asterâ€™s Eddington.

May

Donald Trump Getty

Donald Trump surprised the industry by revealing that he planned to slap 100% tariffs on film imports, describing overseas production as a â€œnational security threat.â€ He would later say that luring Hollywood shoots away from the U.S. with tax breaks was like taking â€œcandy from a baby.â€

Overseas producers heaved a collective groan of disbelief at Trumpâ€™s Truth Social pronouncement, with a feeling that the tariffs would be disastrous for countries that have become heavily dependent on U.S. production, not least the UK. Although the tariffs are yet to materialize, Trump has continued to chunter about the film biz in recent months, and history tells us heâ€™s prepared to follow through with threats.

May was also the month when the new Harry Potter was introduced to the world. Step forward young Scottish actor Dominic McLaughlin, who will star as the titular wizard in HBOâ€™s hugely anticipated TV adaptation of J.K. Rowlingâ€™s behemoth. He will be joined by Alastair Stout and Arabella Stanton, who will play Potterâ€™s trusty sidekicks Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger, respectively.

Harry Potter casting has been one of the themes of 2025, with others attached including Nick Frost as Rubeus Hagrid, John Lithgow as Albus Dumbledore and Janet McTeer as Professor McGonagall. Filming has been ongoing for months ahead of a 2027 premiere.

June

(L-R) Netflixâ€™s Greg Peters and TF1â€™s Rodolphe Belmer at the 2025 Cannes Film Festival Getty Images

June was the month that Netflix hugged good old-fashioned linear TV, striking a â€œnew kind of partnershipâ€ with TF1 to carry the French commercial network and 30,000 hours of its on-demand content. The distribution pact was the equivalent of NBC, or another major American commercial network, handing over its output to Netflix.

At the time, Deadline noted that the deal was probably â€œthe start of something bigger.â€ We were right. Just a month later, Disney inked a content-swap agreement with UK network ITV, under which shows like Iâ€™m A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here! stream on Disney+ and ITV gained access to Star Wars titles like Andor. Disney has since struck similar deals with ZDF and Atresmedia.

Elsewhere in June, punk rap band Bob Vylan became a household name in the UK after their performance at Glastonbury Festival. Frontman Bobby Vylan screamed â€œDeath, death to the IDFâ€ on stage, and his words were streamed live by the BBC, causing an almighty stink. It would pile pressure on the BBCâ€™s director general Tim Davie in a way that would take on extra significance later in the yearâ€¦

July

Christopher Nolan Getty Images

One of the bigger headlines of July was the defenestration of presenter Gregg Wallace from the UK version of MasterChef following a misconduct investigation, but we wanted to focus on a couple of peculiar movie stories.

Christopher Nolanâ€™s The Odyssey is shaping up to be the cinema event of 2026, so itâ€™s no surprise that details from the movie, as well as first-look pictures and trailers, have gone very viral throughout this year. One story from production that raised eyebrows, however, was the backlash against Nolanâ€™s decision to briefly film in Morocco-occupied Western Sahara.

Moroccoâ€™s authority over Western Sahara, which is roughly the size of New Zealand, is not recognized by the international community. Nolanâ€™s entry into this sensitive political arena was painful for indigenous Sahrawi people and their supporters. The Western Sahara International Film Festival (FiSahara), which takes place in the Sahrawi refugee camps in Algeria, issued a provocative statement saying that the celebrated British director was fueling â€œbrutal repression.â€

July also gave us a literary scandal that had ramifications in the film world, when The Observer newspaper alleged that author Raynor Winn gave misleading information about her life story in her beloved book The Salt Path. The novel had only just been the subject of a film starring Gillian Anderson as Winn and Jason Isaacs as her ailing husband, Moth Winn. Winn denied wrongdoing and said the reporting was â€œgrotesquely unfair.â€ Number 9 Films and Shadowplay Features said they were unaware of the claims at the time of optioning the book.

August

KPop Demon Huntersâ€˜ Netflix

August was the month when KPop Demon Hunters confirmed its status as a monster hit, with the Sony Pictures Animation becoming Netflixâ€™s most popular movie of all time. The milestone was announced after a sing-along version of the film hit big screens in the U.S., finishing No. 1 at the box office with an estimated $19.2 million. Little wonder then that, in the same month, Netflix started early talks about a sequel.

September

Tilly Norwood Xicioa

While Jimmy Kimmel was briefly taken off air by ABC in a real-world, dismay-inducing free speech row, the business was equally spooked by an artificial intelligence creation. Introducing Tilly Norwood, an AI â€œactressâ€ who went massively viral after Deadline reported on the thoughts of her creator, Eline Van der Velden, at the Zurich Summit.

Norwood was a vessel for all the industryâ€™s worst fears about AI replacement, even if UK-based Van der Velden tried to reassure people that Norwood was less a Skynet baddie and more â€œa piece of art.â€ She told Zurich that agents were circling Norwood, but a couple of months later, Van der Velden was still being coy about potential representation in an interview with Deadline. Expect Norwood to be back in the headlines in 2026.

October

StudioCanalâ€™s Paddington Bear vs the â€˜Spitting Imageâ€™ puppet StudioCanal/Avalon

Paddington Bear is the genial literary creation that has spawned a movie franchise, a West End stage play, and now, a bizarre legal tussle. Deadline revealed in October that StudioCanal, maker of the Paddington movies, was suing UK producer Avalon for satirizing the marmalade-loving mammal in its iconic puppet sketch show Spitting Image. A YouTube version of the sketch show depicted Paddington as a potty-mouth podcast host with a series titled The Rest is Bulls*!t.

Spitting Image responded to the High Court proceedings by having its version of Paddington wiping his derriÃ¨re with the legal filing and declaring: â€œYour writ, my s**t.â€ Avalon later removed episodes featuring Paddington, but not before The Rest is Bulls*!t was watched by 191 million viewers. Avalon is yet to file its defense, but is expected to make a full-throated case for freedom of expression against the company described by rogue Paddington as â€œStudio C Anal.â€

Another big, but less surprising story, was Disneyâ€™s decision to drop BBC sci-fi series Doctor Who. Deadline spoke with multiple sources in Doctor Whoâ€˜s orbit who said the co-production deal fell apart for a variety of reasons, including concerns over the Ncuti Gatwa showâ€™s failure to break out from its established fan base and big-ticket budget. Others suspected that fears of a â€œwokeâ€ backlash may have been a factor.

November

BBC director general Tim Davie Getty

A true shocker dominated November, as the BBC became entangled in a ghastly dispute with the most powerful man in the world.

In case you missed the scandal, Panorama, the BBC current affairs show, clumsily edited Donald Trumpâ€™s January 6 speech to make it appear as if the U.S. president had incited violence. BBC executives spent the better part of a year privately defending the edit. The row then exploded into the open when a BBC editorial advisorâ€™s misgivings about the edit were leaked to The Daily Telegraph.

BBC boss Tim Davie dramatically quit on a Sunday evening, as the Trump scandal became the final straw in a tumultuous year. Deborah Turness, the BBCâ€™s news chief, also resigned. Then Trump promised to sue â€” a threat he made good on in December, taking the BBC to court in Florida, seeking up to $10 billion in damages.

The BBC believes it can argue strongly that the Panorama film did not harm Trump, but is now in the invidious position of having to make this case in an expensive legal battle. U.S. networks have folded under similar pressure â€” will the BBC stand strong?

December

(L-R) Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos, WBD CEO David Zaslav & Netflix co-CEO Greg Peters

The war for Warner Bros. Discovery reached something of a climax in December, with Netflix apparently winning out. Thereâ€™s a long way to run on this one, and itâ€™s still unclear how any takeover will shake out for Warner Bros. Discoveryâ€™s international operations. Experts say the EU is unlikely to block any deal, but Europe and beyond have echoed Hollywoodâ€™s concerns about theatrical windows, licensed content, and the power that will be concentrated in Netflixâ€™s hands after it has already won the premium streaming wars.

title: Simu Liuâ€™s Espionage Thriller â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Is a Dastardly Disappointment: TV Review
summary: â€œThe Copenhagen Testâ€ is an espionage thriller that turns on loyalty, revenge and integrity. The Peacock series follows Alexander Hale (Simu Liu), an intelligence analyst with The Orphanage, an organization that serves as a watchman for the United States intelligence communities. Founded by the clandestine St. George (Kathleen Chalfant) and with Peter Moira (Brian dâ€™Arcy […]
content:
â€œThe Copenhagen Testâ€ is an espionage thriller that turns on loyalty, revenge and integrity. The Peacock series follows Alexander Hale (Simu Liu), an intelligence analyst with The Orphanage, an organization that serves as a watchman for the United States intelligence communities. Founded by the clandestine St. George (Kathleen Chalfant) and with Peter Moira (Brian dâ€™Arcy James) at the helm, The Orphanage has never been compromised. When Alexander is promoted to field work, however, things take a shocking, perilous turn. â€œThe Copenhagen Testâ€ has a great deal of potential, but its overly complicated plot, crammed with too many characters, leads nowhere.

Three years after his last in-field mission as a special forces soldier, Alexander feels stunted in his current role at The Orphanage. Though his personal life is looking up â€” he recently started dating a woman named Michelle (Melissa Barrera) â€” his career has gone stale. Disillusioned with his position as an analyst, Alexander interviews for a more expansive role in a newly formed operation, putting him and his work rival, Edmond Cobb (Mark Oâ€™Brien), in competition.

Popular on Variety

But Alexander isnâ€™t exactly honest about his health: Heâ€™s secretly suffering from migraines and panic attacks, mitigated only by the pills his ex-fiancÃ©e, Dr. Rachel Kasperian (Hannah Cruz), covertly gives him. Whatâ€™s more, the last three assets he was assigned to track have been exposed, prompting a review of all analysts at the organization.

Still, following the guidance of his mentor, Victor Simonek (Saul Rubine), Alexander lands the promotion. On the heels of that, he discovers his brain has been hacked for months, thus the headaches: A new technology has given the hacker unprecedented access to everything he sees and hears. Horrified that he might be seen as disloyal, he comes clean to Moira, who, along with St. George, decides to use this knowledge to their advantage and smoke out the perpetrator. The pair enlist Samantha Parker (Sinclair Daniel) to act as Alexanderâ€™s handler, documenting and anticipating his every mood.

Despite the intriguing premise, â€œThe Copenhagen Testâ€ never fulfills its promise. What should be a gripping thriller centered on new, uncharted technology and questionable loyalties degenerates into a jumbled mess. The eight-episode first season is so overstuffed that audiences likely wonâ€™t be able to follow all the threads, which barely come together in the end. From the sprawling cast of characters to the various missions and timelines, there is too much to wade through. Forming a genuine connection to Alexander, or feeling sympathy for him, is a stretch because the character remains wooden, never fully realized. Moreover, when the villain and their motivations are finally revealed, the discovery feels neither revelatory nor meaningful.

â€œThe Copenhagen Testâ€ presents plenty of compelling plot points. In addition to uncovering who hacked Alexander and why, there is also the history of the previously â€œunhackableâ€ Orphanage, as well as commentary on xenophobia, racism and birthright citizenship and the question of who is â€œallowedâ€ to be an authentic American. Yet, because creator Thomas and his writersâ€™ room take viewers on such a dull and unwieldy mission, the show loses momentum and interest as it muddles its way to the climax.

Ultimately, the Peacock show may have a stellar cast and a solid concept, but the execution falls flat. The pacing is overlong, removing much of the tension and excitement that make thrillers so fascinating to watch. A tighter episode count and a streamlined timeline likely would have improved the seriesâ€™ structure. However, amid so much other programming in the thriller genre, â€œThe Copenhagen Testâ€ isnâ€™t clever enough to stand out.

All eight episodes of â€œThe Copenhagen Testâ€ premiere Dec. 27 on Peacock.

title: â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™: How Production Designer Jack Fisk Worked With Josh Safdie to Recreate 1950s New York: â€˜He Was Always Ahead of Meâ€™
summary: Jack Fisk is behind the looks of some of the most distinctive films of the past 30-plus years, from David Lynch’s â€œMulholland Driveâ€ to Paul Thomas Anderson’s â€œThere Will Be Blood.â€ For Josh Safdieâ€™s â€œMarty Supreme,â€ Fisk brought his long experience working with auteurs to create the expansive world of 1950s New York that TimothÃ©e […]
content:
Jack Fisk is behind the looks of some of the most distinctive films of the past 30-plus years, from David Lynchâ€™s â€œMulholland Driveâ€ to Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œThere Will Be Blood.â€ For Josh Safdieâ€™s â€œMarty Supreme,â€ Fisk brought his long experience working with auteurs to create the expansive world of 1950s New York that TimothÃ©e Chalamet inhabits as scheming ping pong champ Marty Mauser.

The three-time Oscar-nominated production designer, who just turned 80, is likely the only one on the crew who remembers what the city looked like back then. But Safdie was just as obsessed with getting things right, Fisk says â€” even down to searching for the right size ping pong balls, since balls were slightly smaller in the 1950s than todayâ€™s version.

â€œJosh has got so much energy and is such a lover of New York, and I was always trying to find things that I could tell him that were a little different. But he was ahead of me,â€ says Fisk.

Popular on Variety

Working with the likes Terrence Malick, Brian De Palma and Martin Scorsese, Fisk says, â€œwas exciting times â€” we thought, like, weâ€™re taking over the film business. And so now this was exciting for me, because thereâ€™s a whole new wave of young filmmakers that are brilliant,â€ he says.

â€œMarty Supremeâ€ takes place over numerous settings, from the atmospheric Lower East Side of 1950s New York, with its street vendors and small shops, to Japan, where the crew prepped and filmed for two weeks.

Locations included New Yorkâ€™s Plaza Hotel and Indonesian Embassy, which stood in for swanky London hotels, and the Woolworth mansion on East 80th Street, where Gwyneth Paltrow and Kevin Oâ€™Learyâ€™s wealthy characters lived. â€œI couldnâ€™t believe they let us shoot there. It was over the top,â€ Fisk recalls. International table tennis tournaments were recreated at Meadowlands Arena in New Jersey.

Fisk worked closely with Safdie to envision some of the filmâ€™s biggest set pieces, including the table tennis parlor Marty Mauser frequents that is based on Lawrenceâ€™s Broadway Table Tennis Club.

Chalamet, too, was involved in the production design, Fisk says. â€œHis enthusiasm and his dedication to acting, and what he was doing was inspirational. Iâ€™m married to an actress (Fisk is married to Sissy Spacek), so Iâ€™m always building sets for the actors to help them, and he just took advantage of all of it. He knew what kind of research we were doing. He would come in all the time and look at drawings and models, and show up at locations. His excitement about the film made you excited to be a part of it.â€

Fisk details what went into creating some of the filmâ€™s most important settings.

Lawrenceâ€™s Broadway Table Tennis Club

The Table Tennis Club

When Fisk read â€œThe Money Player,â€ written by Marty Reisman, the 1950s ping pong champ who loosely inspired the story, he realized that Lawrenceâ€™s Broadway Table Tennis Club, where Marty hangs out, would be a central location. Though the building no longer exists, Fisk found vintage photos taken by the city.

He then asked Safdieâ€™s wife, executive producer Sara Rossein, who was working on research for the film, to see if she could find the blueprints. â€œNot only did she find the blueprints, but she found an article from Look magazine or one of those magazines that had beautiful black and white photos of the place. We were able to see exactly how it was set up,â€ he says.

The art department even added the hand-painted landscape murals that were created when the space housed an indoor miniature golf course, though they arenâ€™t very visible in the final cut.

Why was this level of detail so important?

â€œYou like to start somewhere, and you think that if itâ€™s closer to authenticity, it might help the actors understand their character,â€ says Fisk. â€œWe start with the most accurate representation we can find, and then we alter it to work for the film.â€

â€œI think in my heart, I approach a lot of these films that I do as documentaries. So research is fun, exciting, and it gives you a starting point,â€ Fisk says.

Josh Safdie, right, on location at the shoe store. Atsushi Nishijima

The Shoe Store and 1950s Orchard Street

Fisk lived in New York in the early 1960s, so he had a fairly good idea of the right look. In addition, the crew studied N.Y. experimental filmmaker Ken Jacobsâ€™ short film â€œOrchard Street,â€ which shows the crowds and streetscape of the Lower East Side neighborhood in color.

â€œWe actually shot Orchard Street on Orchard Street,â€ Fisk says. â€œWe found a store there that we wanted to make the Northridge shoe store, and right next to it was a brand-new hotel. So we had a problem up and down the street. Everybody had modernized their buildings and put in tall plate glass,â€ he recalls. Plus, the street signs were different, and there was graffiti everywhere, which wasnâ€™t there in the 1950s. Fisk explains that set designers built a modular system of tenement fronts that covered the ground-level building fronts.

â€œThen Adam Willis, our decorator, started doing layers from the awnings over these modular fronts to the tables with all the things they were selling, and the storefronts, the windows we kept working on layers right out into the middle of the street. And it started to look very real.â€

â€œThe graphic artist created signs for us, and then the scenic artist aged them beautifully, and we used those to hide a lot of the modern signs underneath and anything else that was offensive.â€

â€œIt was fun to be on the street at that time, because you could kind of lose yourself and think youâ€™re in the 1950s,â€ Fisk remembers.

While the tenement interiors were shot on a stage, the shoe store was shot in an actual store that was rebuilt because the ceiling was falling down and the floor was unsafe, Fisk recalls. It was important to him to communicate a 1950s feeling through the colors of the interiors.

â€œWhenever I go into an old place, I start peeling away paint or moving light switches to see what was under it, trying to get back in time,â€ he says. â€œWe use a lot of colors from the â€™50s, because they were just beautiful. Looking at period color charts, thereâ€™s very little white, but a lot of really rich colors. In my career, Iâ€™ve tried to always bring that color back in and avoid white like the plague. White just seems more contemporary to me, but it also just burns a hole in the film. If you look at white on a piece of celluloid, itâ€™s just clear thereâ€™s nothing there.â€

The Japanese table tennis tournament in â€œMarty Supreme.â€

Tokyo

In a climactic scene, Marty heads to Japan for a championship game. Fisk exchanged drawings and photographs with the Japanese art department for a month before the crew traveled to Tokyo, and they had already pulled together most of the graphics.

â€œWe had a plan on how to design the stage where they were going to have the tournament. We just didnâ€™t know which stage it was,â€ Fisk says. After touring locations, they found a concert shell in a park outside Tokyo. â€œIt was perfect. It was close to the period and it looked like you were in another country. Our crew put together some towers out of bamboo that we then covered with Japanese graphics.â€

â€œWe found photographs of some artwork from the World Tournament in Tokyo, just a year or two after our film, and we were able to borrow from that,â€ says Fisk.

Safdie, who speaks Japanese, was thrilled with how the scene came together, Fisk says. â€œIt was such an easy place to work, and the people were so kind, and the art department was so talented. You would just kind of wish something and it would show up. The ping pong table was based on an old Japanese table. I sent them a picture of it, and next thing I knew, we had one.â€

Itâ€™s the most wonderful time of the year at the box office, and the sleigh full of Christmas Day releases continued to deliver on Friday. However, it was James Cameronâ€™s â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ that led the pack for the second weekend in a row.

Rounding out the top five were two holiday newcomers, including Jack Black and Paul Ruddâ€™s â€œAnacondaâ€ and TimothÃ©e Chalametâ€™s â€œMarty Supreme,â€ as well as holdovers like Disneyâ€™s â€œZootopia 2â€ and Paul Feigâ€™s â€œThe Housemaid.â€

Thatâ€™s $145,933 per theater, which is the best per-screen-average (PSA) of the year, the highest PSA of all time for A24 and the best PSA for a platform release since 2016â€™s â€œLa La Land,â€ according to A24. The early hype is thanks to a stellar promotional campaign led by Chalamet, who channeled a Mauser-esque bravado to make â€œMarty Supremeâ€ one of the most talked about holiday films in recent memory.

title: Kennedy Center President Threatens Lawsuit Against Musician Who Canceled Christmas Eve Concert Because Of Venue Renaming After Trump

content:
Kennedy Center President Richard Grenell has threatened a $1 million lawsuit against musician Chuck Redd after the jazz artist pulled out as host of the venueâ€™s annual Christmas Eve concert in response to the establishmentâ€™s renaming after President Donald Trump.

â€œYour decision to withdraw at the last momentâ€”explicitly in response to the Centerâ€™s recent renaming, which honors President Trumpâ€™s extraordinary efforts to save this national treasureâ€”is classic intolerance and very costly to a non-profit Arts institution,â€ the letter, shared with the Associated Press, read.

Grenell continued, â€œYour dismal ticket sales and lack of donor support, combined with your last-minute cancellation has cost us considerably. This is your official notice that we will seek $1 million in damages from you for this political stunt.â€

Watch on Deadline

Redd, a jazz drummer and vibraphonist, has hosted the yearly fete â€œJazz Jamsâ€ at the historical arts venue since 2006, having taken over duties following former host and jazz bassist Keter Bettsâ€™ death. â€œWhen I saw the name change on the Kennedy Center website and then hours later on the building, I chose to cancel our concert,â€ he told the AP of his decision.

The addition of Trumpâ€™s name to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts â€” named in honor of the former president, who was assassinated â€” appears to be in violation of a 1964 statute that prohibits the addition of names on memorials to anyone other than JFK. Rep. Joyce Beatty (D-OH), an ex officio board member, filed a lawsuit in federal court Monday seeking a declaration that the name of the arts institution is the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and that a board vote last week to change the name is null and void.

Though a renaming of the center may require authorization from Congress, the Trump-led board moved to do so anyway. The Kennedy family deemed the vote an â€œinsultâ€ and â€œshort-sighted actionâ€ that is â€œbeyond comprehension.â€

Niece Kerry Kennedy wrote, â€œPresident Trump and his administration have spent the past year repressing free expression, targeting artists, journalists, and comedians, and erasing the history of Americans whose contributions made our nation better and more just. President Kennedy proudly stood for justice, peace, equality, dignity, diversity, and compassion for those who suffer. President Trump stands in opposition to these values, and his name should not be placed alongside President Kennedyâ€™s.â€

Earlier this year, Trump named himself chairman of the Kennedy Center, after he ousted roughly half of the arts organizationâ€™s board members who were appointed by Joe Biden. He later tapped his own appointees, including chief of staff Susie Wiles, longtime aide Dan Scavino and Second Lady Usha Vance.

title: In â€˜Marty Supreme,â€™ New York Cityâ€™s Most Iconic Mobsters Inspired TimothÃ©e Chalametâ€™s Retro-Chic Suiting
summary: A short film from the experimental filmmaker Ken Jacobs, documenting the predominantly Jewish immigrant life in Manhattanâ€™s Lower East Side in 1955, served as a main reference point for Josh Safdie and costume designer Miyako Bellizzi when building out the bustling downtown world in â€œMarty “Supreme.” â€œObviously I was looking at the young cool kids,â€ Bellizzi tells Variety about the short film, which she says Safdie showed […]
content:
If you purchase an independently reviewed product or service through a link on our website, Variety may receive an affiliate commission.

A short film from the experimental filmmaker Ken Jacobs, documenting the predominantly Jewish immigrant life in Manhattanâ€™s Lower East Side in 1955, served as a main reference point for Josh Safdie and costume designer Miyako Bellizzi when building out the bustling downtown world in â€œMarty â€œSupreme.â€

â€œObviously I was looking at the young cool kids,â€ Bellizzi tells Variety about the short film, which she says Safdie showed her after stumbling across it at the Museum of Modern Art.

In the colorized vignette, boys wear pleated trousers, white tanks, slim ties, sleeveless knit vests. Girls wear culottes and vintage tees. â€œThey almost look contemporary to us,â€ Bellizzi says, noting that downtown New York was the epicenter of style, even then. Women werenâ€™t wearing pants in the 1950s but â€œthe girls in the Lower East Side were.â€

Getty Images

Atsushi Nishijima

Atsushi Nishijima

The grotty tenements of the Lower East Side â€” and the distinct fashion within â€” is as much of a character in A24â€™s drama as the eponymous ping pong player himself. In the film, TimothÃ©e Chalamet plays the mousy, arrogant and delusionally ambitious Marty Mauser as he hustles for the chance to prove his greatness at a sport that nobody takes seriously.

Authenticity and historical accuracy is of utmost importance to both Bellizzi and Safdie, who previously worked with each other on â€œUncut Gemsâ€ and â€œGood Time.â€ For production design, this meant using the exact right font on a Delancey storefront. For the costumes, it meant no contemporary brands â€” anywhere.

â€œEven down to the underwear!â€ Bellizzi quips. The womenâ€™s tights in the film, for example, were sourced from Williamsburgâ€™s Hasidic Jewish Center.

But once those markers for historical accuracy were set, it was really about inhabiting the mind of Marty Mauser. â€œWhat was he looking at? What were his references? Who did he look up to? Who were the types of people that he saw on a regular basis?â€ These were the questions that were top of mind for Bellizzi when constructing his wardrobe, she says.

The hustler subculture was specifically compelling for Bellizzi, who looked to 20th century Wise Guy gangsters to evoke Martyâ€™s gritty swagger. This reference ultimately informed his boxier, oversized suits; tailored two-piece sets with strong, padded shoulders, in dark colors such as deep charcoal and navy blue, became his uniform for much of the film.



â€œItâ€™s kind of like dressing for the job you want,â€ she says. â€œItâ€™s not even â€˜Fake it till you make it,â€™ itâ€™s just him wanting to show heâ€™s in the know.â€

Of course, the real-life table-tennis sensation Marty Reisman, who Chalametâ€™s Marty is loosely based on, was also on her mood board. â€œThe real Marty was eccentric, so I wanted to give him a little bit of flair and style without being overly stylized,â€ she says. â€œHeâ€™s pretty classic â€“ itâ€™s more in the shapes and in small details.â€ One standout fashion moment includes a pair of red leather gloves he wears while shoveling a hot dog down his throat in the middle of a traffic-riddled street.

Of course, it would be remiss to write about the costume design in â€œMarty Supremeâ€ without mentioning Kay Stone (Gwyneth Paltrow), the retired movie star that Marty is intent on seducing. Kayâ€™s refined style â€“ made up of ivory wool coats, pillbox hats and delicate face veils â€“ is Martyâ€™s aspirational opposite. While we mostly see her in neutral colors, her most striking ensemble is a red, satin evening coat she wears to the opening of her play â€” and later, to a secret rendezvous with Marty.

â€œThat was her ending when she felt the most alive again, and thatâ€™s why we chose red,â€ Bellizzi says. â€œThis dress is her moment. Sheâ€™s so excited â€“ this is the party for her big new theatrical show and then we find out it doesnâ€™t do well, it doesnâ€™t get great reviews.â€

â€œThis emotional, alive feeling gets destroyed,â€ she continues. For Bellizzi, this moment comes close to encapsulating the entire point of the film: â€œSometimes you have big dreams for yourself, and then sometimes they donâ€™t go the way you want them to.â€

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This article contains details about Episode 6 of â€œHeated Rivalry,â€ now streaming on HBO Max.

In what proved to be one of the most powerful scenes of the six-episode queer romance sports drama â€œHeated Rivalry,â€ pro hockey star Shane Hollander has a heart-to-heart with his momanger Yuna, when he comes out as gay to his parents.

Shane has not only told his mother and father about his sexuality, but heâ€™s revealed heâ€™s in a relationship with his career arch nemesis, Ilya Rozanov (Connor Storrie).

Yuna, played by â€œThe Good Doctorâ€ actress Christina Chang, apologizes to Shane for making him feel like he could not talk to her sooner. â€œI am so proud of you,â€ she says, embracing her son. â€œPlease forgive me.â€

Popular on Variety

Shane responds, â€œI forgive you, Mom.â€

â€œYou do actually have a choice how to love somebody, and sometimes itâ€™s a split-second decision that you can make,â€ Chang tells me over Zoom from her home in Vancouver, Canada. â€œI wanted to make sure that when she steps outside, itâ€™s not about herâ€¦Itâ€™s about a lot of things. You donâ€™t know what sheâ€™s going to say. There is a moment of suspension.â€

Yuna could have unloaded on Shane, telling him she is worried about his career and his endorsements. â€œIt could have gone that way, but ultimately, she chooses Shane,â€ Chang says.

Hudson Williams as Shane Hollander, Connor Storrie as Ilya Rozanov, Dylan Walsh as David Hollander and Christina Chang as Yuna Hollander. sabrina lantos

In fact, Williams recently told me that it was this mother-and-son conversation that was a driving force behind wanting to play Shane. â€œThat scene was the scene that ruined me the most when I read the script,â€ he said. â€œIt was the scene that I was like, â€˜If I donâ€™t get to play Shane Hollander.â€™ Itâ€™s also a scene thatâ€™s not in the book, but to me it is the quintessential wrap-up scene to that arc for him and his mom. Period.â€

â€œHeated Rivalryâ€ is from creator Jacob Tierney and is based on Rachel Reidâ€™s gay hockey romance novel series â€œGame Changers.â€ Chang read the scripts for the six-episode season after being offered the role of Yuna.

â€œI was like, â€˜Is this soft core porn? Whatâ€™s happening? Itâ€™s hot. What the heck is happening right now? This is amazing. Itâ€™s like â€˜Fifty Shades ofâ€¦â€™ Oh, my God!â€™â€ she says, before adding with a laugh, â€œThank God it wasnâ€™t me getting naked.â€

What was it like filming the scene with Hudson? Did it feel heavy?

Not on the day. I think Jacob said in an interview that these boys were so dedicated and so focused. First of all, just the way they were eating and the way that they were maintaining their health and their physique and then on top of that, they had skating lessons. And then, of course, Connor had his Russian lessons, which is a whole other impressive situation. So they were very focused. That said, we always knew how to have a good time and joke around. And though there was a lot of laughter on set because thatâ€™s a great outlet for when things are intense, nobody was making jokes while filming the scene. It was the last scene of the day, which I appreciated. I thought, â€œWell, good. I donâ€™t want to feel like they have to rush to another scene.â€ When I read the scene, I was emotional, and then ever since then, I have been emotional.

Whatâ€™s your advice to parents who have a child who has come out to them?

Your love for your child and their well-being is the most paramount. Everyone has a different definition of protection, but loving and protecting them means seeing them for who they are and embracing that. If your child has the courage to tell you this, just know that it likely wasnâ€™t easy. So just love them for that, and work through it together.

What did you think when you heard that HBO Max acquired the show from [Canadian streamer] Crave?

I was like, â€˜Now we have a shot. Now we are going to be seen.â€™ Didnâ€™t know still how it would be received.

An NHL spokesperson has said that they welcome any opportunities that bring in new hockey fans. And then the next phenomenon is everyone asking their trainers at the gym how they can get hockey asses.

Isnâ€™t that crazy? Those boys [Williams and Storrie] are the nicest. Obviously, Iâ€™m not their mother, and I do like to have a good time with them because I am their friend, but I also feel protective of them.

You worry about them?

Iâ€™m not experiencing [their fame] at all, but Iâ€™m watching it, and itâ€™s really weird, and I think itâ€™s weird for them. Iâ€™m not worried yet. The conversation online about their own personal lives is kind of an interesting topic. I understand the different perspectives.

What are your hopes for Season 2?

That I get to spend as much time with Hudson and Connor as possible. Jacob expanded Yunaâ€™s role just a tiny bit from the books. My hope is that we see this next chapter with them fleshed out, and we get to see her and Ilya form a relationship. I think itâ€™s going to be lovely and fun to do.

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from Season 5, Volume 2 of â€œStranger Things, now streaming on Netflix.

The biggest show of the streaming era is turning out to be, in large part, about one young manâ€™s coming out process.

In the final episode of Volume 2, released on Christmas Day, Will Byers (Noah Schnapp) realizes he needs to talk to his friends about something. Theyâ€™re, together, fighting Vecna, the malign force that wants to destroy the entire world, but that has been bedeviling Will in particular since the showâ€™s first episode. Back when he was first kidnapped and taken to the Upside Down, Will had been a slight and awkward boy who found himself picked on and scrutinized. Older and somewhat more secure now, Will realizes that Vecna, the evil being, is manipulating his insecurities. Heâ€™s trying to prise him away from his friends by showing him a vision of himself as abandoned by his friends and totally alone; in order to make sure thatâ€™s just a dark fantasy, Will needs to unburden himself.

In one of the episodeâ€™s final scenes, Willâ€™s words come in a torrent, painfully earnest and meandering until he finally arrives at his point. â€œThe truth is,â€ he says, â€œI am different. I just pretended like I wasnâ€™t because I didnâ€™t want to be.â€ Anyone whoâ€™s ever had to give a speech whose substance is like that of Willâ€™s will recognize the halting, awkward cadence here, as well as the manner in which he announces his sexuality: â€œI donâ€™t like girls.â€ He canâ€™t quite bring himself to say what he does like, but this, for now, is enough.

Popular on Variety

This, a pivotal character opening up about being queer on a show as massive as â€œStranger Things,â€ feels seismic â€” and, oddly, like the culmination of a very long journey. In the showâ€™s earliest episodes, Willâ€™s mom Joyce (Winona Ryder) says that her son has been cruelly mocked by his own father for being â€œqueerâ€; back then, Schnapp, the actor playing Will, was a young child. (Heâ€™s 21, and an out gay man today.) Throughout the series, Willâ€™s slight isolation from the rest of his peer group has been a note the showâ€™s creators, Matt and Ross Duffer, have struck from time to time. He was singled out as uniquely vulnerable by Vecna, who needed an easily culled outsider to use as a vessel; this connection between Will and a being from another dimension has, this season, given Will magical powers himself.

Being queer, in other words, is a sort of superpower â€” and, this season, a boy who previously had stared wistfully out of windows waiting for his life to begin is now actually living it. Among the older-kid cohort of the showâ€™s Hawkins, Indiana is Robin (Maya Hawke), who is somewhat more open about her own desires; sheâ€™s a semi-out lesbian whose brashness and ability to be forthright with Will give him no small measure of encouragement. (Will asks her how, exactly, she knew that she was barking up the right tree when she started pursuing her girlfriend; she told him that she knew how to read signals. Gaydar is its own magic power, too, honed with practice!)

And this message, that in difference one finds strength and not weakness, sits right at the center of a show watched by many, many kids of all ages. (Numbers may not tell the full story of the â€œStranger Thingsâ€ juggernaut; I recently attended a holiday party at which a passel of middle-schoolers bemoaned the fact that theyâ€™d have obligations on Christmas Day, like opening presents, that would keep them from binging the new set of episodes immediately.) There have been harder times, perhaps, to be growing up aware of oneâ€™s own difference â€” like, say, 1987, when â€œStranger Things 5â€ is set â€” but I wouldnâ€™t wager itâ€™s terribly easy right now. The fact of queerness occupying such a crucial thematic role in the showâ€™s endgame means that many young people may take the idea that their friends will love them for who they really are to heart.

For, after all, Will isnâ€™t shamed or cast out by his friends; to a one, they hear what heâ€™s saying and affirm their support. (One senses, in some of the performances, that this news does not come as an Earth-shattering shock to a few of the characters.) And then they return to the matter at hand. They need to save the world, so that they all, differences aside, may go on living in it.

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from Season 5, Volume 2 of â€œStranger Things, now streaming on Netflix.

Jamie Campbell Bower is used to playing the big bad â€” whether his name is Vecna, One or Henry. But in Volume 2 of â€œStranger Things,â€ he takes the character a step further into possibly his creepiest yet, a cult-leader-like performance as Mr. WhatsIt.

â€œJim Jones was an early reference for me,â€ Bower says, citing the leader of the cult the Peoples Temple, who in November 1978 led more than 900 of his followers to commit mass suicide in Jonestown, Guyana. â€œHe was on the mood board, even with regard to certain things that heâ€™s saying when the kids are all in front of him. There were points where I thought, â€˜Do I say the word â€œyouâ€ or do I use the word â€œweâ€? Weâ€™re a family now.â€™ Thatâ€™s really grim! It totally can remove the idea of autonomy, so definitely there had to be that level of cult leader-esqueness about him.â€

Popular on Variety

Although Mr. WhatsIt doesnâ€™t look as villainous as Vecna, it was just as â€œterrifyingâ€ to take on the different character, says Bower: â€œThere was so much fear in playing that.â€

His approach for Season 5 overall was very different than Season 4, when he was crafting Henryâ€™s memories.

â€œWhat you saw in Season 4 happened, and it was real. This is very much like, how nice can I be to these poor children to make them feel as comfortable as possible in this world? And how much of my experience am I burying within that? And itâ€™s always a really terrifying prospect when youâ€™re sat opposite another actor, and your intentions are so deeply buried,â€ he says. â€œThereâ€™s a level of real dishonesty in that, and thatâ€™s really scary. Itâ€™s really hard, particularly opposite a child.â€

Courtesy of Netflix

When Bower first took on the role, he told Variety about the humanity he focused on while playing Vecna. Now, thatâ€™s a bit tougher to access, as the character gets worse and worse and kills more and more people â€” but, Bower says, itâ€™s still there.

â€œThereâ€™s definitely a humanity that I can see,â€ he says now. â€œHow much of that is portrayed in this volume is open for discussion and interpretation â€” thereâ€™s definitely trauma and experience that is present but unexplored at this point.â€

Having seen the showâ€™s prequel play â€œStranger Things: The First Shadowâ€ ahead of Season 5, Bower knew that something that happens to Henry at age 8 in a cave had been a â€œmonumental experienceâ€ that was â€œlife-alteringâ€ â€” he was never the same after that. Then, he begged the Duffer brothers for more information about Henryâ€™s backstory.

â€œIt was something that I really felt like I had to pry out of Matt and Ross Duffer. They werenâ€™t wildly forthcoming with that, because obviously, they wanted to protect it, but it was important for me to know what that was and why that was the case,â€ he says. â€œSo, it was just a question of taking with me what Iâ€™d learned from the play, and then also just being irritating and asking questions.â€

In Episode 6, as Max (Sadie Sink) and Holly (Nell Fisher) make their way through Henryâ€™s memories, looking for a way out of his mindscape, they come upon what may be the answer to what happened to him. In a mine shaft, young Henry comes upon an injured man holding a silver suitcase, who shoots Henry in his hand in a panic. Holly and Max watch as Henry beats the man to death in self-defense, and start to open the case â€” but then Max calls Holly away. When asked whatâ€™s inside that silver suitcase, Bower has a one-word tease: â€œreason.â€

As for what he can say about the series finale, which drops on Netflix on Dec. 31? Expect the unexpected. The last scene in Episode 7, â€œThe Bridge,â€ is Henry and the 12 children heâ€™s kidnapped â€” most of whom worship him, as with a cult leader â€” joining hands at the Creel dinner table. He needs them to complete Vecnaâ€™s quest to remake the world, presumably replacing the Rightside Up with the Abyss.

â€œThe end of 7 is an incredible setup for what is to come. And if you think you know what is to come at the beginning of 8, youâ€™re probably wrong,â€ Bower says. â€œIt really does blow the fuck up. Whatever you think you know will be exceeded.â€

title: Simu Liu On Why â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Felt Like Being On â€˜Love Islandâ€™, Calls Melissa Barrera A â€œSpectacular Action Star In The Makingâ€

content:
SPOILERS: This post contains details about The Copenhagen Test, Season 1

With his new Peacock sci-fi thriller series, Simu Liu is living out his super spy fantasy in an edge-of-your-seat, eight-episode binge.

The Copenhagen Test star told Deadline it was â€œsomething that Iâ€™ve always wanted to doâ€ before starring in the Thomas Brandon-created series, which is now available to stream on Peacock, starring Liu as intelligence agent Alexander Hale, whose mind is hacked by a mysterious enemy using the intel to bring down his agency.

â€œI think on the one hand, it was definitely the premise and the world building, just dealing with themes of surveillance and technology,â€ he said. â€œI feel like a lot of those things are really just topical and relevant today. And so, I think there was that. I really appreciated Thomasâ€™ take on this 5 minutes into the future, set in this world of intelligence.â€

Watch on Deadline

Liu added, â€œAnd then on the other hand, it was the cultural specificity. I really was struck by Alexanderâ€™s backstory in the script and feeling like he was somebody who, in a fully three dimensional way, kind of embodied what it was like for someone from an immigrant family to be in a situation or to work in a situation, an environment where theyâ€™re constantly being second-guessed, constantly being overlooked and underestimated. I think, for myself, itâ€™s something that a lot of people who grew up in those immigrant families, something that I think resonates a lot.â€

As star and executive producer, Liu is happy to be â€œdoing my part and trying to get things made that feel kind of universal, but also culturally specific and just my own unique brand of different.â€

Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Amanda Matlovich/Peacock

With Haleâ€™s mind compromised, his superiors decide to use the hack to their advantage, assigning fellow agent Michelle (Melissa Barrera) to play his girlfriend as they track down the source.

â€œI told her, it almost feels like being on Love Island. It feels like Michelle and Alexander are in their own reality TV show about finding love, because theyâ€™re playing out this romance,â€ he joked. â€œAnd of course, they know the cameras are on, so thereâ€™s a part of them that knows that theyâ€™re playing it up. â€¦ Itâ€™s a lot of layers to get to play, and sheâ€™s a great scene partner.â€

Read on about Simu Liuâ€™s The Copenhagen Test character, the showâ€™s scary real-world parallels and his fight scene with Melissa Barrera.

DEADLINE: What about the project drew you in?

SIMU LIU: I think on the one hand, it was definitely the premise and the world building, just dealing with themes of surveillance and technology. I feel like a lot of those things are really just topical and relevant today. And so, I think there was that. I really appreciated Thomasâ€™ take on this 5 minutes into the future, set in this world of intelligence. And just getting to play a super spy, I think is something that Iâ€™ve always wanted to do. And then on the other hand, it was the cultural specificity. I really was struck by Alexanderâ€™s backstory in the script and feeling like he was somebody who, in a fully three dimensional way, kind of embodied what it was like for someone from an immigrant family to be in a situation or to work in a situation, an environment where theyâ€™re constantly being second-guessed, constantly being overlooked and underestimated. I think, for myself, itâ€™s something that a lot of people who grew up in those immigrant families, something that I think resonates a lot. And so, even though itâ€™s through this terrible hack that happens to him, itâ€™s watching him get to kind of come into his own, watching him get the opportunity to prove himself, everything that heâ€™s capable of. It just was really rewarding to read on the page, and I thought Thomas Brandon did a fantastic job writing the pilot, and when him and James first approached me with it, I was just really sold.

Melissa Barrera as Michelle and Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Christos Kalohoridis/Peacock

DEADLINE: I definitely noticed that kind of element of American nationalism. It was very an interesting perspective on that topic, and also on surveillance. It made me paranoid like watching it. Did it like give you ideas, like, â€œOh my God, this is where things are headedâ€?

LIU: I mean, itâ€™s less of â€œthis is where things are headedâ€ and more like, â€œno, this is where weâ€™re already at,â€ except instead of being hacked against our will, we do it voluntarily, give our information. And we voluntarily keep these recording devices with us and are on it hours and hours and hours a day, and weâ€™re just feeding it data about all of our behaviors and our interests and literally everything. So, it got me really thinking about that, and it made me really want to put my phone away. it was funny, Melissa and I were comparing our screen time apps earlier today, and I donâ€™t know if she told you what her daily average screen time is, but it is astounding, and I donâ€™t think mine is low either by any means. Iâ€™m like desperately trying to get that number lower, but I think we both looked at each other and weâ€™re like, â€œThis has gotta change.â€

DEADLINE: And I loved the romantic comedy within the spy thriller between the two of you, even though sheâ€™s manipulating you the whole time. What was it like balancing that dynamic with her?

LIU: I loved it. To have someone like Melissa to play opposite of, itâ€™s just such a privilege. One of the first things that I realized about her was that she worked in a really similar way as I did. I think thereâ€™s actors that come to set, they do their job, and as long as the cameras are rolling, weâ€™re best friends. And then, cut, everyone goes home, and thatâ€™s it. But, for me, and I think for Melissa, I think a lot of what we believe is that the on-screen rapport is informed by the off-screen rapport, and so really just invested a lot of time with each other to get to know each other, to get to know how we work. And I really appreciated just how down she was and how much she pushed herself. As much as I realize itâ€™s rare for someone like me to be in a lead position, I feel like she feels the same. And both of us come from immigrant families, from different visible minority communities. And so, we were just like, â€œWow, first of all, itâ€™s so incredible that weâ€™re here. Letâ€™s do everything we can to make this the best experience ever, and to do the best we possibly can.â€

DEADLINE: I thought it was kind of wild of them to just have sex, knowing that theyâ€™re being watched by multiple people, but I thought that was a funny element to their whole up and down.

LIU: Yeah, I told her, it almost feels like being on Love Island. It feels like Michelle and Alexander are in their own reality TV show about finding love, because theyâ€™re playing out this romance. And of course, they know the cameras are on, so thereâ€™s a part of them that knows that theyâ€™re playing it up. But of course, if thatâ€™s all it was, I donâ€™t think that would be compelling for an audience to watch. There has to be an element of the audience has to believe that part of that is real, and I think if they do, and if you believe that itâ€™s real, then you believe that thereâ€™s a part of both of their characters that really wants it. And whether or not itâ€™s for somebody else, itâ€™s also a little bit for them as well. Itâ€™s a lot of layers to get to play, and sheâ€™s a great scene partner.

Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Christos Kalohoridis/Peacock

DEADLINE: I also thought your fight scene with Melissa was incredible. It was really fun to watch. Do you have a favorite fight scene or a favorite moment from any of the fights that you filmed on the show?

LIU: I really loved our fight with each other in episode 7. I loved just everything coming to a head with their relationship, and itâ€™s like, finally, maybe for the first time, this is who they really are, each of them. So, I love that so much of Michelle and Alexander is meeting each other for the first time, and then meeting each other for the first time in the basement of the bookstore, and then meeting each other again for the first time, when kind of all bets are off, and itâ€™s just like one has to kill the other. After the whole season and after all the training that she had been through, Melissa was looking really sharp as a fighter, and so, she came to set and she was just ready to come to blows. And it was really fun just to get to to play that with her, and Iâ€™m really proud of what we did too. Iâ€™m really proud of her. She did a lot, most, if not all of her own stunts, and sheâ€™s just the best, a spectacular action star in the making.

DEADLINE: It must have been easy for you with the Shang-Chi experience and all of that.

LIU: Itâ€™s weirdly my bread and butter. When I see choreographer or I see stunt people on set, there is weirdly a part of me that feels at ease because Iâ€™m like, â€œOh, Iâ€™m about to go into my flow state.â€ And for whatever reason, the fight scenes, and the choreography, and the lines, and the rhythm, it all just kind of makes sense to me. Itâ€™s almost like a second nature, and I really love doing it. I wish I could do it more. But maybe in a season two, who knows?

Simu Liu as Alexander Hale in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Christos Kalohoridis/Peacock

DEADLINE: I hope thereâ€™s a season 2. The last episode, we find out not only his ex-fiancÃ©e was in on this, but also his mentor, and Iâ€™m wondering, do you think that he can trust anyone going forward after everything heâ€™s been through?

LIU: Yeah, thereâ€™s a lot of trust [issues]. After reading the last script and seeing the few cuts, as they were coming through, I was joking with Thomas and [co-showrunner Jennifer Yale], just like, â€œThis guyâ€™s gonna need so much therapy because heâ€™s been betrayed so many times just in the span of just these few weeks.â€ Itâ€™s a really rough time, but also, what I appreciate about his character at the end of the first season is that heâ€™s at a point where he is no longer looking to others to figure out what to do. Heâ€™s not looking to others to give him a sense of belonging. He is very much trusting in himself and his own moral compass, and realizing, â€œAt some point, I have to stop caring what other people think. Iâ€™ve spent so long trying to fit in and trying to belong, and now itâ€™s time for me to really just step out and do what I need to do.â€ And I think if we get the chance to continue his story, I think itâ€™ll be really, really exciting seeing where he takes that.

title: â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Showrunners On Potential Season 2 Ideas, â€œWeird Consent Issuesâ€ Raised By Paranoid Spy Thriller & Cut Shower Scene That Was â€œToo Funnyâ€ For Pilot
