For creator Thomas Brandon, he told Deadline that writing the show’s sci-fi mystery brought up “some weird consent issues” around […]
content:
SPOILERS: This post contains details about The Copenhagen Test, Season 1

The Copenhagen Testâ€˜s eight-episode binge leaves a lot for viewers to digest as the show unpacks some topical issues through a thrilling spy mission.

For creator Thomas Brandon, he told Deadline that writing the showâ€™s sci-fi mystery brought up â€œsome weird consent issuesâ€ around its intelligence agent Alexander Hale (Simu Liu), whose mind is hacked by a mysterious enemy using the intel to bring down his top-secret government agency, The Orphanage.

â€œWe had a shower scene,â€ he noted. â€œIt was at the end of the pilot, and it was kind of indicative of him accepting the mission. Heâ€™s getting undressed to go in the shower â€¦ and then he just looks down.â€

Watch on Deadline

As The Orphanage keeps the hack open, Alexander comes to accept that both the enemy and his own superiors have full surveillance of his life until he can help them find the source, going undercover with fellow agent Michelle (Melissa Barrera) as an unwitting couple.

Brandon explained of the cut scene, â€œIt was kind of a little too funny for the end of the pilot, but it what it spoke to was this larger thematic [element] of your question, which is, hereâ€™s a guy who is now in his effort to prove to his country, â€œI can be trusted.â€

Melissa Barrera as Michelle and Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Peacock

Comparing the series to the paranoia of The Truman Show (1998), the fun of The Copenhagen Test comes with not knowing â€œwhoâ€™s in on it and whoâ€™s not.â€

As the show unravels the mystery behind Alexanderâ€™s brain hack, so does it explore the lives and histories of its characters, including those who built The Orphanage. Could a prequel be in store, in addition to a potential second season?

â€œThereâ€™s been a thought there, but itâ€™s just thoughts,â€ noted Brandon. â€œBut yeah, it was always designed as an ongoing series, so thereâ€™s plans and ideas and hopes for what a second season could be.â€

Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Christos Kalohoridis/Peacock

Read our interview with The Copenhagen Testâ€˜s creator Thomas Brandon, his co-showrunner Jennifer Yale and executive producer James Wan, below.

DEADLINE: You really create a sense of paranoia with the lack of privacy in his life as you start to realize more and more of whatâ€™s going on. So tell me what about the whole privacy element kind of intrigued you and made you wanna create the story.

JAMES WAN: Can I just ask you guys this? The whole time, obviously Iâ€™m thinking in my head, how does he go shower? Does he look down when he goes to the bathroom?

THOMAS BRANDON: We had a shower scene. It was at the end of the pilot, and it was kind of indicative of him accepting the mission. Heâ€™s getting undressed to go in the shower â€¦ and then he just looks down. And it was kind of a little too funny for the end of the pilot, but it what it spoke to was this larger thematic [element] of your question, which is, hereâ€™s a guy who is now in his effort to prove to his country, â€œI can be trusted.â€ Theyâ€™re like, â€œGreat, give us your entire life. Be a double agent in your life, sacrifice your family, your friends, your loved ones, your body, everything.â€ And heâ€™s like, â€œOKâ€ and heâ€™s doing it to prove it. And the journey of the show is asking, â€œShould I be doing this?â€ What is the line of how much you give to your country, when youâ€™ve lost a part of yourself? And that was one of the things that we were really looking at for the privacy aspect of it all. And the other thing we did stylistically was, a lot of times in the spy genre, thereâ€™s heavy use of shadows. Very noir-ish, the shafts of light, and whatâ€™s creepy is the things you canâ€™t see. What we decided in our show is what would be creepy is the things you see but you donâ€™t understand. So, thatâ€™s why we really see a lot of the architecture in our show. You see a lot of the things around Alexander, and heâ€™s looking at these things, but the paranoia comes not from what I canâ€™t see. The paranoia comes from what I canâ€™t understand. And so, what we did is we made sure the camera really stayed with Alexander on him over his shoulder from his point of view, so you could see the workings of this Truman Show office and not know whoâ€™s in on it and whoâ€™s not, and that was part of what we were driving to do.

DEADLINE: Itâ€™s funny you mentioned that because thatâ€™s literally what I was thinking during the sex scene. Iâ€™m like, they know multiple people are watching this, right?

JENNIFER YALE: Thatâ€™s why she says, â€œAre you sure?â€ And she turns off the light.

BRANDON: And those were some of the longest conversations we had in the writing room. It brings up some weird consent issues.

Melissa Barrera as Michelle and Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Christos Kalohoridis/Peacock

DEADLINE: On that note, I also love kind of the romantic comedy within the spy thriller, even though you soon figure out sheâ€™s just manipulating him, which is even more fun to watch. But tell me about balancing their chemistry with her manipulations.

YALE: I mean, we had a lot of fun, and this was also in the same conversations about, how do you have sex without them listening and watching. But we took a lot of time to make sure that we built up their chemistry before you find out that sheâ€™s manipulating him, because you want to want them to get together and to have that love affair. And so, that was why we took a lot of time to show you part of a scene, and then the audience is with Alexander. experiencing the scene, only to have the floor drop out when you realize that this is all a script.

BRANDON: Yeah, and thatâ€™s really fun in the second episode to unravel a lot of the intentional tropes we leaned into the first episode, which is like, youâ€™re down on your luck and thereâ€™s a helpful sweet bartender who, this time itâ€™s real. This time, sheâ€™s really attracted to you. And you start to realize like, oh, these are all the story that Parker is telling. Sheâ€™s using these forms of these characters we think weâ€™ve seen before, because sheâ€™s essentially creating this television show around him, and it worked on him. And part of the fun for him is realizing, â€œYes, this worked, but Iâ€™ve understood that Iâ€™m still in The Truman Show.â€ And so him starting to begin to fight back and ultimately him telling the story back to the rest of them, where theyâ€™re not sure what heâ€™s about to do.

WAN: Thee romantic comedic aspect also reminded me of things like Mr. and Mrs. Smith, just the interplay between the two of them, and it actually goes even further back to like your classic Hitchcock, just the really old-school sort of caper mystery between the two characters. And thereâ€™s always this tension between two, but thereâ€™s also a lot of romantic tension as well. And I think you guys did a great job pulling that into this modern setting.

DEADLINE: Michelle hints at her past, that sheâ€™s done something very bad and thatâ€™s why sheâ€™s here, and then by the end, Parker burns her file. She gets that fresh start. But I was curious, had you come up with a backstory for her that you told Melissa or something to keep in the back of her head?

YALE: Yes, that was one of the big things that we did with each one of the characters is, we had a backstory that each one of the teasers gave you a little bit more about each one of the characters and where they came from and where they were going. And we had shot a teaser that was Michelle, but we wanted to wait, because we thought it gave the audience too much information. And we do want to keep where she went at the end of Episode 8, and this idea that she wants to go home or have a life different, outside of this world. Is that really where she went? Or is she undercover still? Is she still in the game?

Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Christos Kalohoridis/Peacock

BRANDON: Yeah, and part of the kind of Russian nesting doll of Michelle is the fact that you never know if youâ€™re getting the real her. And so, even though we kind of have built a backstory, the question is, is that real? Or is that the backstory thatâ€™s in a file somewhere, that is not the actual real story. Because to us, the most interesting aspect of Michelle is not, â€œOh, whatâ€™s the truth here?â€ The most interesting aspect is, is there someone whoâ€™s played so many roles that sheâ€™s forgotten what the truth actually is? Has she really lost sight of who that person actually was? And could you ever separate out whatâ€™s real and whatâ€™s not?

YALE: And then playing with her relationship with Parker, and what she wants out of that relationship, and is that genuine in, the chemistry that they have and the friendship that they have, or did she just want Parker to burn her file?

DEADLINE: And that was another character Iâ€™m really intrigued by, Parker, just cause she relates to Hale so much or she understands him so much. And Iâ€™m wondering if thatâ€™s because theyâ€™re similar or because itâ€™s her job, and sheâ€™s just very good at thinking ahead of everyone?

BRANDON: Yeah, thatâ€™s a great question. We wrestle with that a lot. I think there has to be some similarity. One, she is great at her job, and sheâ€™s great at figuring outâ€”she is kind of the stand-in for the writer in the show, which it is my job to put myself in this personâ€™s shoes and understand them, whether theyâ€™re like me or not. But there is a unique special power she has, which we hinted at the end of the second episode, when she has found his seven words and her words are similar. Theyâ€™re not exactly the same, but she understands whatâ€™s driving him, because they have a similar drive, sheâ€™s able to imagine what is he about to do next. And like you, we love the character and thought Sinclair was fantastic in this, what could be a very dry person who stands and looks at a lot of monitors, and she brought such energy and empathy to that. And in the midst of a show that has a lot of action and intrigue and thought-provoking twists and turns, what we really liked is she gave us a chance for a kind ofâ€”they told me not to use this word because itâ€™s too arcaneâ€”but Cyrano de Bergerac. It is a very unrequited love, right? Sheâ€™s kind of slowly falling in love with her own creation. Through Michelle, she is romancing Alexander, and she has this parasocial relationship with him. Like all of us watching TV, we know that character infinitely and that character does not know us. And then, watching how the real life starts to fuse into her little hermetically sealed world sheâ€™s in was fascinating.

Melissa Barrera as Michelle in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™

DEADLINE: Back to Michelle, I liked where that story went and how it teases the potential for a second season. So, I am curious if there are plans for that, but Iâ€™m also curiousâ€”because St. Georgeâ€™s love story was so heartbreaking and beautiful, and thereâ€™s all this backstory from how The Orphanage startedâ€”Iâ€™m curious if you have thought about doing some kind of prequel series or something.

YALE: Ooh, Peacock!

BRANDON: Yes. Thereâ€™s been a thought there, but itâ€™s just thoughts. But yeah, it was always designed as an ongoing series, so thereâ€™s plans and ideas and hopes for what a second season could be.

content:

Watch on Deadline

â€œWe had some bumps in the road along the way, early on. I was on â€˜Weekend Updateâ€™, on SNL, new to the show, making fun of all the celebrities and I made fun of him and it didnâ€™t go well. And he called me and we had it out.â€

title: Melissa Barrera On â€œLetting Goâ€ Of Control Over Her â€˜Copenhagen Testâ€™ Character & Fansâ€™ Ongoing Support After â€˜Screamâ€™ Firing
summary: SPOILERS: This post contains details about The Copenhagen Test, Season 1 As The Copenhagen Test hits Peacock, viewers will undoubtedly develop some trust issues towards Melissa Barrera‘s spy character Michelle. With Season 1 now available on the streamer, the actress told Deadline that was one of her favorite aspects of the femme fatale role in […]
content:
SPOILERS: This post contains details about The Copenhagen Test, Season 1

As The Copenhagen Test hits Peacock, viewers will undoubtedly develop some trust issues towards Melissa Barreraâ€˜s spy character Michelle.

With Season 1 now available on the streamer, the actress told Deadline that was one of her favorite aspects of the femme fatale role in Thomas Brandonâ€™s sci-fi thriller, which also stars Simu Liu as intelligence agent Alexander Hale, whose mind is hacked by a mysterious enemy using the intel to bring down his agency.

â€œIt was an interesting challenge, and unlike anything else that Iâ€™ve ever done, where Iâ€™m having to give in a little bit and trust that the prep that Iâ€™m doing and the levels of these versions of the character that Iâ€™m portraying will pan out, even though I donâ€™t know where theyâ€™re going,â€ explained Barrera.

Watch on Deadline

Barreraâ€™s Michelle plays a thrilling game of manipulation with Alexander, infiltrating his life to gauge whether or not heâ€™s a threat. The pair then keeps up the faÃ§ade of a blossoming romance, with both seemingly developing real feelings, despite neither fully trusting the other.

As Michelle, Barrera was left nearly as in the dark as the audience about the characterâ€™s mysterious backstory, which is never quite revealed amid multiple layers of lies and deceit.

Melissa Barrera as Michelle and Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Peacock

â€œSo, for me, Iâ€™m a very controlling, planning kind of person as an actor,â€ she added. â€œI kind of had to let go and be like, â€˜You know what? Iâ€™m not going to know, because theyâ€™re still writing and I donâ€™t know where theyâ€™re going to take her.â€™ And that was exciting in a way and anxiety-inducing in another way. But I think in the end, it helped with the mystery of it all.â€

Starring opposite Liu, Barrera had â€œthe most funâ€ during their fight scene, which she describes as having â€œvery Mr. & Mrs. Smith vibes.â€ Meanwhile, the Shang-Chi star praised her as â€œa spectacular action star in the making.â€

Two years after Barrera was unceremoniously fired from the Scream franchise, the actress is grateful for the fans who continue to support her work and â€œin their way, kind of lift me up,â€ following a recent Scream 7 boycott in her honor.

Melissa Barrera as Michelle in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™

Read on about Melissa Barreraâ€™s complex The Copenhagen Test character, her hopes for Season 2 and her reaction to the Scream 7 boycott.

DEADLINE: One thing I love about Copenhagen Test is thereâ€™s kind of a rom-com element within the spy thriller. Was that a fun line to walk?

MELISSA BARRERA: I am always drawn to romance. That is my favorite thing. No matter the genre, I always kind of look for the love story. And so, I thought that it was so cool that there was that element in this show, particularly, and that I got to be a part of it, because I would have gotten FOMO if it wasnâ€™t my character involved. But I do love the performance within the performance within the performance of that dynamic and that you donâ€™t really know how much of that connection is real and how much of that is performance on either side. And so, I think as an audience member, those that are drawn to the relationship will always be kind of rooting for them, for that to be real. But you wonâ€™t really know what the thing is because thatâ€™s the thing of the show, every episode you kind of get a new piece of information and it takes the rug out from under you.

DEADLINE: Yeah, I definitely gasped a few times while watching it.

BARRERA: Love that. Love to hear.

DEADLINE: And what was it like playing Michelle, who obviously has such a complicated past? Itâ€™s just so fun to watch her seem so sincere in one moment and then, the nextâ€”

BARRERA: I mean, Iâ€™m an actor, right, so it felt like a big part of her job. And thatâ€™s why I love that beat where we go back to the first episode and you get to see it from her perspective, where sheâ€™s preparing to go out and pretend to be this damsel in distress. And sheâ€™s asking questions about who is she, whoâ€™s her scene partner, basically, because she is basically an actor in a different setting. She has to prep in the same way that us doing movies and TV would, and really commit to a character for a lot longer than someone that is just acting on set would have to. But I found it kind of easy to think about it in that way. So, I wasnâ€™t stressing out about all the information that I didnâ€™t have, because we started shooting the show, and I didnâ€™t have all the scripts, so I didnâ€™t know where they were going to take her. And it was an interesting challenge, and unlike anything else that Iâ€™ve ever done, where Iâ€™m having to give in a little bit and trust that the prep that Iâ€™m doing and the levels of these versions of the character that Iâ€™m portraying will pan out, even though I donâ€™t know where theyâ€™re going. So, for me, Iâ€™m a very controlling, planning kind of person as an actor. I kind of had to let go and be like, â€œYou know what? Iâ€™m not going to know, because theyâ€™re still writing and I donâ€™t know where theyâ€™re going to take her.â€ And that was exciting in a way and anxiety-inducing in another way. But I think in the end, it helped with the mystery of it all. And sometimes, I was like, â€œIâ€™m going to play this a few different ways and you guys are going to use the take that you feel will be best for whatever comes next because I donâ€™t know where youâ€™re taking me.â€ So, it was kind of like an interesting experiment.

Melissa Barrera as Michelle and Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™ Christos Kalohoridis/Peacock

DEADLINE: And I really appreciated how you never really discover what happened in Michelleâ€™s past, and then at the end, Parker burns the file. So, Iâ€™m wondering if you and Thomas discussed her backstory, or is it something you kind of filled in in your head.

BARRERA: I filled it in in my head. I had an idea of what I needed it to be for me to be able to play that moment of relief, and what sheâ€™s running away from, because for her to accept this mission where she knows that if she becomes visible and recognizable by the enemy, that means that she canâ€™t work anymore. The enemy will know who she is, and she decides to take on the mission anyway. So, Iâ€™m like, what could make a person take on that mission? What happened? And so I had to fill in that storyline, but I hope that I get a Season 2, so that we can learn more about her and see more of what her life is and what she ran towards or ran away from. Itâ€™s an exciting character for me in a very different way than other characters have been. Like when I was doing Vida, I was excited to return to a character because I loved playing with her and I had fun, but here Iâ€™m excited to return to Michelle when we get a Season 2 because I was always surprised by where they took her, and so, itâ€™s exciting to play something like that.

DEADLINE: Well, I definitely hope thereâ€™s a Season 2, especially after that little teaser at the end of her being a â€œloose end,â€ but I also love the dynamic between Michelle and Parker. I felt like theyâ€™re just girls bonding over gaslighting boys, and itâ€™s my favorite.

BARRERA: Yes, thereâ€™s a level of innocence and unexpectedness to that friendship. And I love that pairing because it feels very high school. It feels like, even though theyâ€™re in such a high-stakes situation, girls are girls, women are women, and like the existential crises that we go through are kind of always the same since weâ€™re teenagers. And I think that itâ€™s really sweet that Michelle becomes Parkerâ€™s friend. The way that I played those scenes with Parker, I tried to keep it always in truth, obviously, but keep it ambiguous enough to where you could believe that sheâ€™s being honest and that sheâ€™s letting herself be vulnerable and let Parker in, like itâ€™s actually a genuine relationship. But if tomorrow, the writers decide that in Season 2, it was all fake and she actually neverâ€”it wouldnâ€™t surprise me if she was also playing Parker. That could also work. So, it was finding that fine line in the performance of, it could go either way. And if you watch it back with new information later, youâ€™ll believe it. That was the challenge.

DEADLINE: There are quite a few fight scenes in here, and I just have to say youâ€™re such a badass, watching you. What was your favorite fight scene to film, or do you have a most memorable fight moment?

BARRERA: The most fun that I had on set was doing the physical fights. I think I was very much looking forward to that final fight with Simu, just us in his apartment, because it was very Mr. & Mrs. Smith vibes, and I would have loved if it was like five times as long. I could have just kept going, â€™cause heâ€™s such a fun scene partner to have, not only in acting scenes, but in physical scenes. Heâ€™s so good. Obviously, heâ€™s an action star, right? So, heâ€™s got it down, and I had to do a lot of training and a lot of practicing, a lot of rehearsals to get to the point where I didnâ€™t have to think about the fighting and think about what comes next, and I could focus on the storytelling. And we had an incredible stunt team that was very patient with me. I asked for a million extra sessions on my days off, and they would always be available to me. I just wanted Michelle to really look like sheâ€™s been in this life for a while, and she knows what sheâ€™s doing, and thereâ€™s a reason that she keeps getting paired on these important missions where she is trusted to protect this person or take him down, and I love physical stuff. I loved it. And so, that was a fun day on set, because we got to move through the whole apartment. I would have loved it if we like destroyed the whole thing, but you know, I think we still had scenes to shoot in different order, so we couldnâ€™t really do that. I proposed it, but maybe next season.

Melissa Barrera as Michelle and Simu Liu as Alexander in â€˜The Copenhagen Testâ€™

DEADLINE: Separately, the trailer for Scream 7 came out recently and a lot of people have even started a boycott. How does it feel to have these loyal fans after the last two years?

BARRERA: Obviously, having support always feels great, and Iâ€™m so grateful for the love that Iâ€™ve been shown, and for the support and the new people that have come into my life, and that are now supporting the other things that Iâ€™m doing and that are trying to, I think in their way, kind of lift me up. So, that honestly feels really nice.

content:
The filmmakers behind Yashâ€˜s highly anticipated â€œToxic â€“ A Fairytale for Grown-Upsâ€ have revealed the first look at Huma Qureshi as Elizabeth, unveiling a character that blends old-world glamour with unsettling gothic menace.

The newly released image captures Qureshi against a cemetery backdrop, her character positioned next to a classic black automobile. Her costume features a dramatic black gown with exposed shoulders and striking sleeve design, presenting a character whose refined appearance masks darker undertones. The funereal location and subdued color palette hint at a figure whose influence derives from composure and sophistication rather than explicit aggression.

Qureshi has built a formidable reputation across film and streaming platforms through acclaimed performances in Anurag Kashyapâ€™s crime drama â€œGangs of Wasseypur,â€ the black comedy â€œDedh Ishqiya,â€ and revenge thriller â€œBadlapur.â€ Her work in streaming series includes the dystopian Netflix drama â€œLeilaâ€ and the SonyLIV political thriller â€œMaharani,â€ for which she received a Filmfare OTT Award. She was most recently in Season 3 of Netflix series â€œDelhi Crimeâ€ and the lead in Bikas Ranjan Mishraâ€™s film â€œBayaan,â€ which bowed at the Toronto Film Festival.

Popular on Variety

Yash, the Kannada-language film industry actor who rose to pan-Indian stardom with the â€œK.G.Fâ€ franchise, has become one of the most sought-after stars in Indian cinema. Known for his portrayal of Rocky Bhai in â€œK.G.F: Chapter 1â€ (2018) and â€œK.G.F: Chapter 2â€ (2022) Yashâ€™s transformation into a larger-than-life action hero propelled the films to unprecedented box-office success, breaking language barriers. The second instalment in the franchise is the fifth highest Indian grosser of all time. While the â€œK.G.Fâ€ series cemented his star power, Yashâ€™s early career in Kannada-language films showcased his versatility, with notable performances in projects such as â€œMr. and Mrs. Ramachariâ€ (2014) and â€œGooglyâ€ (2013).

â€œToxicâ€ is helmed by festival circuit darling Geetu Mohandas (â€œMoothonâ€). The ambitious project represents a watershed moment for Kannada cinema, which has been steadily gaining international traction following the â€œK.G.Fâ€ phenomenon. Written by Yash and Mohandas, â€œToxicâ€ is breaking new ground as the first major Indian film conceptualized, written and shot simultaneously in both the Kannada and English languages â€“ with dubbed versions planned for Hindi, Telugu, Tamil, Malayalam and additional languages.

â€œCasting for this role was perhaps the trickiest,â€ said director Geetu Mohandas. â€œThe character demanded a performer with high octane caliber and an undeniable presence. From the moment Huma entered my frame, I witnessed that she possessed something rare. She carried an effortless sophistication and intensity that immediately brought the character of Elizabeth alive for me. Huma is an actor who questions, probes, and challenges the artistic interpretation of a role and that dialogue became an essential part of our creative journey. She has always been known as a powerhouse of talent, but this performance will mark as a turning point for the arrival of an undeniable, commanding new presence on celluloid.â€

The first look at Kiara Advaniâ€˜s character Nadia was unveiled recently.

The production has assembled a notable technical crew including Indian National Film Award-winning cinematographer Rajeev Ravi, composer Ravi Basrur, editor Ujwal Kulkarni and production designer T.P. Abid. Action sequences have been choreographed by Hollywoodâ€™s J.J. Perry, known for his work on â€œJohn Wick,â€ alongside Indian National Film Award-winning duo Anbariv and Kecha Khamphakdee.

Produced by Venkat K. Narayana and Yash through KVN Productions and Monster Mind Creations, â€œToxic â€“ A Fairytale for Grown-Upsâ€ is scheduled for theatrical release March 19, 2026, capitalizing on the extended holiday weekend that encompasses Eid, Ugadi and Gudi Padwa celebrations.

title: Sheena Chohan to Star in Tamil Folk Drama â€˜Arjunanin Allirani,â€™ Lilith Tale â€˜Bhaayavaâ€™ (EXCLUSIVE)
summary: Indian actor Sheena Chohan, who made her Hindi-language feature film debut in the biopic “Sant Tukaram” earlier this year, has been cast as the lead in “Arjunanin Allirani,” a Tamil-language drama centered on folk artists and caste discrimination. The film, written by acclaimed Tamil author B. Jeyamohan and directed by Vino Vikraman Pillai (“Kafir”), will […]
content:
Indian actor Sheena Chohan, who made her Hindi-language feature film debut in the biopic â€œSant Tukaramâ€ earlier this year, has been cast as the lead in â€œArjunanin Allirani,â€ a Tamil-language drama centered on folk artists and caste discrimination.

The film, written by acclaimed Tamil author B. Jeyamohan and directed by Vino Vikraman Pillai (â€œKafirâ€), will feature music by legendary composer Ilaiyaraaja. The project marks Chohanâ€™s entry into Tamil cinema after acting across Malayalam, Hindi and international productions.

â€œArjunanin Alliraniâ€ follows two impoverished artists â€” a folk dance performer and a Dalit singer â€” whose relationship forms the heart of the narrative. The story traces the female leadâ€™s journey through family tragedy and her eventual pursuit of justice through her art.

Popular on Variety

In the film, produced by Irfan Khan for EBG Films, Chohan will portray Rani, a character whose arc spans from her teenage years to middle age across four distinct life phases. The role requires extensive martial arts training, including Chilambattam, a traditional Tamil stick-fighting technique.

â€œRani is a young woman who spends her formative years immersed in devotion, singing hymns to God in temples,â€ Pillai tells Variety. â€œBeginning with the vibrancy and innocence of her twenties, her life unfolds across four distinct phases, tracing her journey from youth to middle age. To authentically portray this evolution, the actress taking on the role must master martial arts, including Chilambattam. As the narrative moves through different eras, the character undergoes significant physical and emotional transformations, requiring the actress to adapt her appearance and presence accordingly.â€

The director says that casting Chohan was â€œentirely serendipitous.â€ â€œFrom our very first conversation, I was struck by her deep passion and dedication to her craft,â€ he says. â€œWhen I shared the story of Allirani, she showed a genuine and immediate interest. The character of Rani is a powerful and resilient woman, whose journey spans from her teenage years to middle age. The role also demands extensive martial arts sequences, a challenge Sheena is exceptionally well suited for, given her many years of training and experience in martial arts.â€

For Chohan, the role aligns with her longstanding commitment to socially grounded material. â€œI did so much theatre and acting training, that itâ€™s a waste to do a flat character,â€ she tells Variety. â€œAlso, if you have your acting skills sharpened, you can, and should, give what appears to be a one-note character more depth â€“ of course the most important thing is to be a blank page for your director and give them what they want for the story, but no real people are shallow and morally simple, so I donâ€™t like any of my characters to be.â€

Chohan, who serves as United for Human Rights South Asia Ambassador, adds that her human rights advocacy has directly influenced her project choices. â€œI turn down so many films because of derogatory or degrading roles,â€ she says. â€œBut the good news is that the industry is changing â€“ with all of the good work of women like the Womenâ€™s Collective in Kerala, and women and men across the country and world pushing against discrimination â€“ new characters and stories are being written which show women as equal citizens â€“ real-life, breathing, thinking humans, not just pretty Christmas tree decorations.â€

Chohanâ€™s recent work includes Aditya Omâ€™s â€œSant Tukaram,â€ in which she portrayed Avali Jijabai opposite the title character in the Hindi biopic. The film was widely described as showcasing her quiet power and emotional depth. She describes her performance approach as rooted in thorough character research and technique developed during intensive training at The Acting Center in Los Angeles while working on the Hollywood film â€œNomad.â€

â€œWhat I learned was how to develop a character in terms of understanding their inner thoughts and motivations overall and in each scene,â€ she says. â€œSo, while I read and watched everything connected to Avali Jijabai, including having the original 17th century historical texts read to me and working and eating with the village women who still work the fields Avali worked in, I then used all of that gathered information to truly understand and fit into her character, so that my reactions were natural.â€

Reflecting on her Hindi debut, Chohan notes the significance of seeing the film play across theaters in Mumbai, where she is based. â€œAfter doing five years of theater, training in my craft, martial arts and dance in Kolkata, I shifted to Mumbai keeping it as a base but working pan India in different languages with legendary directors nationally and internationally,â€ she says. â€œBut living in Mumbai, it was deeply special to see â€˜Sant Tukaramâ€™ playing across theatres here and release nationwide. Having friends and colleagues join me at the Mumbai â€“ national premiere did feel like an arrival. But creatively, it was never a reset â€“ it was a continuation.â€

The actor has also completed J.D. Chakravarthyâ€™s pan-India thriller â€œJatasya Maranam Dhruvam,â€ in which she plays a police officer. â€œI literally followed a policewoman around into her dangerous job, in her home life â€“ I did so much to get into the head-space of that character, and that too in such a dark, complex thriller, that I can only feel what I brought to the character gave the director an insight that he was desperate for,â€ she says.

Her upcoming slate includes the VFX-heavy streaming series â€œBhaayava,â€ in which she portrays Lilith. The platform has not yet been locked as the production team completes extensive visual effects work. â€œI went from playing the wife of a saint, to a devil, and perhaps thatâ€™s what made me take the role â€“ it was so different â€“ I went from the most simple scenes in fields where weâ€™ve worked in saris for a thousand years, to being flung out of a car in a harness for a flying scene after five hours of prosthetics in front of one of the biggest green screens in Mumbai,â€ she says. â€œHowever, again, the character was so rich â€“ Lilith was Adamâ€™s first wife in the bible â€“ she was banished from Eden for refusing to be dominated by and obey every word from Adam â€“ so that was a character I had to sink my teeth into.â€

Chohanâ€™s international credits include â€œAnt Storyâ€ (2013) directed by Mostofa Sarwar Farooki, which played at the Shanghai and Dubai International Film Festivals. She has also appeared alongside Madhuri Dixit in Netflix series â€œThe Fame Gameâ€ (2022) and Kajol in JioHotstar show â€œThe Trialâ€ (2023).

Her career began with a debut opposite Mammootty in the Malayalam-language film â€œThe Trainâ€ (2011), directed by Jayaraj. Reflecting on her work with renowned actors including Mammootty, Dixit and Kajol, Chohan notes how different directors have shaped her approach. â€œActing in India has changed a lot since I was launched by Mammootty â€“ what my director Jayaraj wanted in terms of restraint on the set of â€˜The Trainâ€™ was quite opposite to what Suparn Varma wanted on the set of â€˜The Trial,'â€ she says. â€œFor Jayaraj I was much more expressive but for Suparn I had to keep it subtle and do so much character research to get into her mind and be my character, without â€˜acting.â€™ What I learned from these legends in terms of command and screen presence in many ways tie in with professionalism â€“ they are really there, doing what theyâ€™re doing while theyâ€™re doing it.â€

On balancing wider reach through big platforms versus roles that leave a lasting cultural impact, Chohan says, â€œWhat I care most about is character and story, so thatâ€™s what matters most, but of course, a rich, nuanced character in a well-told, original, larger-than-life, rooted story, that reaches the whole world â€“ thatâ€™s the dream â€“ and I want to live the dream.â€

title: Brigitte Bardot, Star of â€˜And God Created Womenâ€™ and â€˜Contempt,â€™ Dies at 91
summary: Actor, singer, sex symbol and style icon Brigitte Bardot, who retired from acting and became controversial for her right-wing politics in her later years, has died. She was 91.Â  Bardot died Sunday at her home in southern France, according to Bruno Jacquelin of the Brigitte Bardot Foundation for the protection of animals, who confirmed the […]
content:
Actor, singer, sex symbol and style icon Brigitte Bardot, who retired from acting and became controversial for her right-wing politics in her later years, has died. She was 91.

Bardot died Sunday at her home in southern France, according to Bruno Jacquelin of the Brigitte Bardot Foundation for the protection of animals, who confirmed the news to The Associated Press. No cause of death was provided, and arrangements for funeral or memorial services have not yet been announced. She had been hospitalized last month.

In the 1950s Bardot ignited an international zeal for boldly sexual European movies, often directed by her first husband, Roger Vadim, such as â€œAnd God Created Woman.â€

Though Bardotâ€™s reign as a major box office draw was relatively brief, and she retired from films in the early â€™70s, her influence was far-reaching: She made youthful, pouty, nubile blondes a staple in cinema, particularly in American movies, as opposed to a more mature, womanly blonde like Marilyn Monroe. Between Bardot and Audrey Hepburn, the rage for youth in female sexuality became entrenched in movies â€” and all media â€” and has never subsided.

Bardot (and Vadim) also opened the door on sexuality, for which foreign films became famous in the uptight America of the â€™50s. This boldness of approach (if not of substance) would eventually catch on in the U.S. and other countries and signal an end to decades of censorship. By then Bardot had tried to cross over and attain the mantle of a serious actress with such films as Jean-Luc Godardâ€™s â€œContempt,â€ but met with only limited success.

Her breakthrough came with â€œAnd God Created Woman,â€ written and directed by Vadim and released in late 1956 while her marriage to him was breaking up. The movie was only modestly successful in France but it took off overseas, earning $8.5 million around the world. New and older films by Bardot such as â€œMamâ€™zelle Pigalle,â€ â€œPlease! Mr. Balzacâ€ and â€œThe Girl in the Bikiniâ€ (from 1952) all washed up on U.S. shores, solidifying Bardot as a sex goddess. In France she climbed to the top of the box office with films like â€œThe Bride Is Much Too Beautiful,â€ â€œLa Parisienne,â€ which brought out her lighter side; â€œThe Night Heaven Fell,â€ â€œThe Woman and the Puppetâ€ and â€œIn Case of Emergency.â€

In 1959, Simone de Beauvoir wrote a treatise called â€œBrigitte Bardot and the Lolita Syndrome.â€ But by then, Bardotâ€™s girlish sensuality was so well entrenched in the culture that it was not about to be dislodged by serious studies.

Already the countryâ€™s highest-paid film performer, Bardot tried to further prove herself an actress in â€œBabette Goes to War,â€ as a member of the French Resistance; Louis Malleâ€™s â€œA Very Private Affairâ€ and Henri-Georges Clouzotâ€™s â€œLa Veriteâ€ in 1960. She continued to work for Vadim during this period, long after heâ€™d moved on to other actresses and she to her second husband, actor Jacques Charrier.

Godardâ€™s â€œContempt,â€ in 1963, exploited her reputation and brilliantly commented on it. She also appeared in American-made films such as â€œDear Brigitteâ€ (in a cameo), about an 8-year-old who desperately wants to meet Bardot; and â€œViva Maria,â€ directed by Malle in English and pairing her with Jeanne Moreau (Bardot received a BAFTA Award nomination for best foreign actress). Later in the â€™60s she appeared in the Western â€œShalakoâ€ with Sean Connery.

Bardotâ€™s last two films, both made in 1973, were Nina Companeezâ€™s â€œThe Edifying and Joyous Story of Colinotâ€ and the sad â€œMs. Don Juan,â€ another pallid Vadim attempt to exploit her sexuality. The latter was released in the U.S. in 1976.

She was born Camille Javal to an upper-middle-class Parisian family. Early on she evidenced talent as a dancer, studying ballet and attended the Hattemerâ€™s private school and then the Paris Conservatory. At age 15, at the recommendation of a friend, she modeled for the cover of Elle magazine, where she was seen by director Marc Allegret, who was looking for a new face for his film â€œThe Laurels Are Cut.â€

Though she didnâ€™t get the part, Allegretâ€™s assistant, Vadim, took her under his wing and got her small roles in small films before marrying her in a much publicized 1952 event that helped promote the young would-be actress. More small roles followed in films, the first of which to be released in the U.S. was Anatole Litvakâ€™s â€œAn Act of Loveâ€ (1953), which starred Kirk Douglas but was shot in France. She then appeared in Allegretâ€™s film â€œFuture Starsâ€ and got her first lead in a chapter of the English Doctor series, â€œDoctor at Sea.â€ She next worked with legendary French director Rene Clair in â€œThe Grand Maneuverâ€ (1956) before starring in â€œAnd God Created Woman.â€

In addition to her film work, Bardot also recorded some 80 songs, some quite popular, mostly in the 1960s and â€™70s.

She did not, however, work in movies again, and in 2010 the former actress expressed outrage over rumors that an American-made biopic about her was in the works.

Bardot would nevertheless remain a media star, in part because of her numerous love affairs, advocacy for animals and zeal for right-wing politics. In 1986 she created the Brigitte Bardot Foundation. Her efforts in the service of animal rights brought her the French Legion of Honor (she refused it), and Bardot was not unwilling to protest or even be arrested to protect four-legged creatures. But she also drew fines imposed by French courts for inciting racial hatred after repeatedly making controversial remarks in which she criticized immigration to France and Muslims in particular.

Bardot was married to German playboy Gunter Sachs in the late 1960s, and she married wealthy industrial Bernard dâ€™Ormale, a supporter of the far right in France, in 1993.

Bardot is survived by dâ€™Ormale; a son from her marriage to Charrier; and two granddaughters.

content:
French actress, 1960s sex symbol and militant animal rights activist Brigitte Bardot has died. She was 91.

The Brigitte Bardot Foundation for the protection of animals announced that the actress had died at her home in Saint Tropez in the South of France on Sunday.

Bardot first leapt to fame in then husband Roger Vadimâ€™s controversial 1956 Saint Tropezâ€“set movie And God Created Woman, in the role of a free-spirited 18-year-old whose natural sensuality stirred up passions and jealousies in the then simple fishing village.

The film sparked scandal at the time for its portrayal of female sexuality and was banned in a number of countries, and parts of the U.S.

Watch on Deadline

Bardot had first met Vadim when she was 16 years old, marrying him in 1952 when she was 18 years old. Their marriage began to unravel on the set of And God Created Woman, when Bardot had an affair with co-star Jean-Louis Trintignant.

They divorced amicably in 1957, but Vadim would forever be part and parcel of the Bardot myth, while And God Created Woman would mark the beginning of Saint Tropez as a jet set destination.

Bardot made 28 movies across her career with other highlights including Christian Jaqueâ€™s Babetteâ€™s War and Jean-Luc Godardâ€™s Contempt, but for France, she was more than an actress.

With her â€œsex kittenâ€ moniker, voluptuous figure and overt sensuality, she came to symbolize a moment in French history as the country emerged from World War Two, and society loosened its ties with the Catholic church and political conservatism.

In a move that would also define her myth, Bardot announced her retirement in 1973 at the age of 39 years old to devote herself to animal rights. She launched the Brigitte Bardot Foundation in 1986, which has since save hundreds of thousands of animals.

â€œI gave my youth and beauty to men, I give my wisdom and experience to animals,â€ she would say later.

title: Box Office: â€˜Avatar 3â€™ Adds $88 Million Over Christmas Weekend, â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™ Scores A24â€™s Second-Biggest Debut With $27 Million

content:
James Cameronâ€™s sci-fi threequel â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ remained comfortably atop the domestic box office over the Christmas stretch. Meanwhile a trio of new holiday releases, A24â€™s sports dramedy â€œMarty Supreme,â€ the Focus Features musical tear-jerker â€œSong Sung Blueâ€ and Sonyâ€™s action comedy â€œAnaconda,â€ helped keep multiplexes bustlingâ€¦ but they werenâ€™t enough to fend off the Disney animated sequel â€œZootopia 2,â€ which returned to No. 2 in its fifth weekend of release.

â€œAvatar 3â€ added a solid $64 million over the traditional weekend and $88 million since the Christmas holiday on Thursday. The three-day figure is a scant 28% decline from its $89 million domestic debut, a stronger hold than its predecessor, 2022â€™s â€œThe Way of Water,â€ which dropped by 52% after a larger $134 million debut. So far, â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ has generated $217.7 million in North America and $760 million worldwide after two weekends of release. Based on past precedent, â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ should stick around at the top of box office charts well into the new year. After all the first two â€œAvatarâ€ films were No. 1 for seven consecutive weekends, eventually earning well over $2 billion each.

Popular on Variety

â€œMarty Supremeâ€ enjoyed the best debut among newcomers in third place with $17.4 million from 2,600 theaters over the weekend and $27.1 million through the four-day holiday frame. Domestic ticket sales stand at $28.3 million after a weekend in limited release. The three-day figure marks the second-biggest opening weekend to date for A24, the beloved indie behind â€œEverything Everywhere All at Once,â€ â€œHereditaryâ€ and â€œLady Bird.â€ Alex Garlandâ€™s â€œCivil Warâ€ remains the studioâ€™s best debut with $25 million over the traditional three-day weekend.

For â€œMarty Supreme,â€ the stellar start can be attributed to director Josh Safdie for making a movie thatâ€™s resonating with audiences, as well as star TimothÃ©e Chalamet, who plays a fictional tennis table champ and has been a one-man marketing machine, going to great lengths â€” and heights â€” to get out the word about the original film. A24 spent roughly $70 million to produce â€œMarty Supreme,â€ which is expected to remain a box office draw due to positive reviews and great word-of-mouth. Moviegoers â€” roughly 65% of whom were 35 or younger â€” gave the R-rated film a â€œB+â€ grade on CinemaScore exit polls. Thatâ€™s a far better reception than the â€œC+â€ grade that was bestowed upon Safdieâ€™s prior film, the deeply unsettling â€œUncut Gems.â€

â€œSports dramas are not big movies to begin with, but the right cast can elevate them, says David A. Gross, who runs the movie consulting firm Franchise Entertainment Research. Heâ€™s referring to films like â€œF1: The Movie,â€ starring Brad Pitt, and â€œAir,â€ led by Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. â€œTimothÃ©e Chalamet is making that kind of difference.â€

â€œAnacondaâ€ landed at No. 5 with $14.6 million over the weekend and $23.7 million since Christmas. A $45 million-budgeted meta-reboot, â€œAnacondaâ€ stars Jack Black and Paul Rudd as best friends who travel to the jungle to pursue their childhood dream of remaking their all-time favorite movie, 1997â€™s â€œAnaconda.â€ The project starts to unravel when life imitates art and a real anaconda begins hunting them down. Critics and audiences were mixed on â€œAnaconda,â€ which has a 51% Rotten Tomatoes average and â€œBâ€ grade on CinemaScore.

â€œSong Sung Blueâ€ opened in eighth place with $7.6 million over the weekend and $12 million through the four-day holiday frame. Craig Brewer directed the $30 million-budgeted movie, featuring Hugh Jackman and Kate Hudson in the true story of two down-on-their luck musicians who form a Neil Diamond tribute band. Opening weekend crowds dug the film, which earned an â€œAâ€ grade on CinemaScore, the best marks among the new releases. In terms of ticket buyers, 65% were female while 53% of audiences were above the age of 55.

â€œThis is a crowd-pleaser, and word-of-mouth should build now among older moviegoers, who take their time getting to the cinema,â€ Gross says.

Meanwhile Disneyâ€™s animated juggernaut â€œZootopia 2â€ outpaced the newcomers with $20 million over the weekend and $25.2 million since Christmas on Thursday. Since its debut around Thanksgiving, the PG film has generated $320 million domestically and $1.42 billion globally, making â€œZootopia 2â€ the highest-grossing Hollywood release of the year.

Another holdover, Lionsgateâ€™s psychological thriller â€œThe Housemaid,â€ notched the No. 4 spot with $15.4 million over the weekend and $18.9 million through the four-day holiday period. The film, starring Sydney Sweeney and Amanda Seyfried, has earned an impressive $46.6 million domestically and $64.9 million worldwide to date.

More to comeâ€¦

â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ has surpassed $760 million globally after two weekends of release.

Over the busy Christmas stretch, James Cameronâ€˜s sci-fi epic collected $181.2 million from 51 overseas markets and $245.2 million globally. Those ticket sales mark a minimal 25% decline from its international opening weekend. So far, the Disney and 20th Century film has grossed $217 million in North America and $542 million at the international box office. Outside of the United States and Canada, top markets are China with $99.6 million, France with $54.4 million, Germany with $43.1 million and Korea with $32.1 million.

â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ is already the sixth-highest grossing Hollywood release of the year, and itâ€™ll continue to climb above hits like â€œDemon Slayer: Infinity Castleâ€ ($714 million), â€œJurassic World: Rebirth ($869 million) and â€œA Minecraft Movieâ€ ($958 million) in the coming weekends. Soon, â€œAvatar 3â€ should become 2025â€™s third blockbuster to surpass the $1 billion mark, following two other Disney behemoths, Mayâ€™s â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ remake ($1.03 billion) and Novemberâ€™s â€œZootopia 2â€ ($1.3 billion and counting). To underscore Disneyâ€™s box office dominance, none of its rival studios has fielded a single billion-dollar film since 2023.

Popular on Variety

A key question for box office watchers is where â€œAvatar: Fire and Ashâ€ will end its theatrical run. The third installment in the otherworldly franchise has a high bar to clear in terms of theatrical expectations because the first two trips to Pandora, 2009â€™s â€œAvatarâ€ and 2022â€™s â€œAvatar: The Way of Water,â€ stand as two of the biggest movies in history with $2.9 billion and $2.3 billion, respectively. â€œAvatar 3â€ doesnâ€™t necessarily need to hit the $2 billion mark to be considered a commercial success, though the mega-budgeted film does need to keep playing in theaters to justify its massive price tag for Disney. That shouldnâ€™t be a problem, since â€œAvatarâ€ films have become synonymous with box office staying power, meaning the visual spectacles are known to stick around in theaters.

So far, the animated sequel has generated a $321.4 million domestically and a stellar $1.099 billion internationally, bringing its global tally to $1.42 billion.

In other box office milestones, Universalâ€™s big-budget musical â€œWicked: For Goodâ€ finally crossed the $500 million mark. The film, starring Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo, has earned $172 million overseas and $503.9 million worldwide. â€œWicked: For Goodâ€ should turn a tidy profit against a $150 million production budget, but the movie has earned far less than its predecessor, 2024â€™s â€œWicked,â€ with $758 million globally.

title: â€˜Marty Supremeâ€™ Director Josh Safdie Made TimothÃ©e Chalamet Wear Strong Prescription Glasses: â€˜He Canâ€™t See Sâ€”â€˜ Without Them
summary: In Josh Safdieâ€™s â€œMarty Supreme,â€ now in theaters, Timothee Chalamet plays an ambitious young man from New Yorkâ€™s Lower East Side convinced that table tennis is the way forward. content:
In Josh Safdieâ€™s â€œMarty Supreme,â€ now in theaters, Timothee Chalamet plays an ambitious young man from New Yorkâ€™s Lower East Side convinced that table tennis is the way forward.

The time period is 1952, and Marty is a hustler who works at the family shoe store, pretending not to have a size in stock so he can sell a customer a more expensive pair. On the side, heâ€™s always looking for that next get-rich quick scheme.

The film stars Fran Drescher as Martyâ€™s mother, Tyler, the Creator, Odessa Aâ€™zion, â€œShark Tankâ€ personality Kevin Oâ€™Leary and Gwyneth Paltrow.

Popular on Variety

Safdie spent over six years writing the project. To bring that authenticity to the performance, Safdie didnâ€™t just put Chalamet in prop glasses; he went one step further.

Speaking in front of a packed audience earlier this month at a Hollywood panel, Safdie said, â€œAt the time, we said, we were going to put +10 contact lenses in your eyes, and weâ€™re gonna put -10 prescription lenses in front of them so that when his glasses fall off, he canâ€™t see shit.â€ When Chalamet tried on that combination, Safdie recalled receiving a call from the actor. â€œHe calls me, and he says, â€˜Iâ€™ve got the +10s in right now, Iâ€™m pretty dizzy.â€™â€

According to Safdie, Chalamet described it as feeling like â€œhe was in a fishbowl.â€ But Chalamet was determined. Safdie said Chalamet told him, â€œIâ€™ll do anything you ask me to do.â€

Prosthetics artist Michael Fontaine applied pockmarks, freckles and nicks to Chalametâ€™s face. â€œYou felt that with the scars and nicks, heâ€™s been in fights, and heâ€™s from the street,â€ Safdie said.

The makeup was so convincing that even co-star Paltrow believed it was real. Paltrow plays faded movie star Kay Stone, who is wooed by Marty. She admitted, â€œI had no idea.â€ She went on to say, â€œI was like, â€˜Oh my gosh, heâ€™s got little acne scars,â€™ and was like, â€˜Iâ€™m so surprised by how you never see that.â€™â€

With Fontaineâ€™s prosthetics and the glasses, and his hair in the 1950s style, Safdie says, â€œWhen he had them in, he was Marty.â€

Chalamet also strived for authenticity in his performance and spent years preparing for the role. He took every opportunity to play table tennis because he wanted to appear like a professional player when shooting began. He also trained with table tennis expert Diego Schaaf to help coordinate and choreograph the games.

In the film, Marty faces off against Koto Endo, who is played by real-life table tennis champion Koto Kawaguchi. He loses to him during a tournament in London, then finds himself face-to-face with him during a match in Japan.

Asked about playing against Kawaguchi, Chalamet said the pressure was â€œhuge.â€ But he also needed to get it right and felt â€œa responsibility to that community and to the aficionados and people that are passionate about that sport.â€

Safdie added that during filming, Chalamet â€œwould be so in character, heâ€™s like, â€˜I want to win the next points. We have to play.'â€ Kawaguchi was game. â€œAt one point he said to me, itâ€™s like, you know, Iâ€™m not an actor, you know, Iâ€™m a table tennis player. And you know, Iâ€™m doing a lot of acting right now.â€

title: â€˜Iâ€™m Chevy Chase, and Youâ€™re Notâ€™ Director on Going Toe-to-Toe With Chevy, the â€˜Communityâ€™ Cast Turning Down Interviews and the Doc Being a â€˜Hard Watchâ€™ For the Chase Family

content:
Marina Zenovichâ€˜s â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase, and Youâ€™re Notâ€ is not your average celebrity documentary. From the filmâ€™s outset, it is clear that the 82-year-old comedian had zero editorial control over the project.

A minute into the CNN doc, Zenovich (â€œLance,â€ â€œRobin Williams: Come Inside My Mindâ€) can be heard off camera saying to Chase, â€œIâ€™m just trying to figure you out.â€

His response: â€œNo shit. Itâ€™s not going to be easy for you.â€

â€œWhy is it not going to be easy?â€ Zenovich asks.

Popular on Variety

â€œYouâ€™re not bright enough,â€ Chase deadpans. â€œHowâ€™s that?â€ Then the comedian grins.

Zenovich says that while she was taken aback by Chaseâ€™s response, she was also relieved.

â€œIâ€™d never done an interview where someone was so rude to me,â€ Zenovich tells Variety. â€œBut I was so worried going into that first interview with him about how I was going to say to him, like, â€˜Everyone thinks youâ€™re an asshole.â€™ I thought if I did, he would throw me out of his house. So the minute he said that to me, I had a way in.â€

The doc, premiering Jan. 1 on CNN, charts Chaseâ€™s rise from breakout â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ to leading man, his three marriages, his addiction to cocaine and alcohol, heart failure that led to a coma, childhood abuse, depression, a failed talk show, and the starâ€™s various on-set disputes with actors like Terry Sweeney and the entire cast of the NBC comedy â€œCommunity.â€

â€œI wanted to figure out who was the real person behind the conflicted, guarded and somewhat fragile man we see on camera,â€ Zenovich says. â€œWhat was behind the surface of his slightly intimidating superstar bravado? Was there any self-awareness there? Having interviewed Chevy at length, I have to say that yes, itâ€™s all there â€“ and a whole lot of pain and heartache too.â€

In addition to Chase and his family, the doc includes revealing interviews with the starâ€™s former collaborators and confidants, including Mike Ovitz, Dan Aykroyd, Beverly Dâ€™Angelo, Goldie Hawn, Lorne Michaels, Ryan Reynolds and Martin Short.

Variety spoke with Zenovich and her husband, and long-time producing partner P.G. Morgan, about why Chase decided to make the doc and getting someone, anyone, from â€œCommunityâ€ to give an interview.

You have worked together on quite a few docs about celebrities, including â€œLance,â€ about Lance Armstrong, â€œRobin Williams: Come Inside My Mind,â€ â€œRichard Pryor: Omit the Logic,â€ â€œJerry Brown: The Disrupter,â€ and â€œRoman Polanski: Wanted and Desired.â€ Where does Chevy Chase rate on the difficulty meter?

Zenovich: When I first sat down with Lance Armstrong, he was sitting at the edge of a seat and ready to spar with me. That is exciting because you donâ€™t know what youâ€™re going get. Then I did Jerry Brown, whom I tried to do that wit,h but he had no interest whatsoever. So, each person is different. Chevy was willing to go there, but he would stop himself. He wouldnâ€™t go all the way. The interviews with him were very hard.

Morgan: There were a lot of unknowns going into the interviews. Chevy is incredibly quick-witted and always on, so you have to be able to go toe-to-toe with him. Heâ€™s a bit intimidating as well, and we had a lot of stuff that we wanted to talk to him about â€“ the good stuff and the touchy stuff.

When it comes to celebrity documentaries, the celebrity is usually promoting something like a tour, a fashion line or a book. Chase wasnâ€™t promoting anything. Why do you think he wanted to make this film, which isnâ€™t exactly a flattering portrait of him?

Zenovich: Someone wrote a book about him, and I donâ€™t think that [Chaseâ€™s] family liked it. I think they were trying to right a wrong. I donâ€™t know if they think that they did because it has been hard. [The doc] was a hard watch for him and his family, but I think in the end they appreciate it.

Morgan: Iâ€™m guessing that they felt as a family that he wasnâ€™t getting his due. That thereâ€™s been a whole run of these documentaries about other people from his generation. I think it hurt that he hadnâ€™t had the same recognition.

Do you think that the people who said no to interviews, like Steve Martin and Christopher Guest, were really saying, â€˜We donâ€™t like the guyâ€™?

Zenovich: I canâ€™t answer for them, but I think that the absences speak for themselves. Whether itâ€™s scheduling, personal, or saving it for their own doc. In the end, I think we got the right mix of people. I was initially disappointed that we didnâ€™t get more people from â€œCommunity,â€ but there are things people donâ€™t want to talk about.

How hard was it to get anyone from â€œCommunityâ€ to sit down with you?

Every single person said no. I ran into (â€œCommunityâ€ creator) Dan Harmon at a screening of â€œDeaf President Now!â€ and I got his number. I was so excited. I thought it was going to happen but then he declined. I was so lucky to get Jay Chandrasekhar (â€œCommunityâ€ director). He has such an amazing delivery and he was willing to go there. If Jay had said no, I would have been screwed.

â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase, and Youâ€™re Notâ€ premieres Thursday, Jan. 1, on CNN. The film streams live for pay TV subscribers via CNN.com, CNN Connected TV and mobile apps on Jan. 1.

title: Media Spin Cycle: The M&A Outlook In 2026
summary: Media and entertainment is seeing a major shakeup in a burst of dealmaking from M&A to spinoffs, AI investment and leveraged buyouts, setting the stage for a pivotal 2026. Streaming consolidation, local broadcast ownership and Middle Eastern money are big themes. Donald Trump, his donor and friend Larry Ellison, and son-in-law Jared Kushner are key […]
content:
Media and entertainment is seeing a major shakeup in a burst of dealmaking from M&A to spinoffs, AI investment and leveraged buyouts, setting the stage for a pivotal 2026.

Streaming consolidation, local broadcast ownership and Middle Eastern money are big themes. Donald Trump, his donor and friend Larry Ellison, and son-in-law Jared Kushner are key players.

Netflixâ€™s headline-grabbing $82 billion pact for Warner Brosâ€˜ studios and streaming assets toplines deals announced in 2025. Silver Lake, Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Public Investment Fund and Kushnerâ€™s investment firm Affinity Partners are taking video game giant Electronic Arts private for $55 billion. Broadband behemoth Charter Communications is buying Cox for $34.5 billion. The nationâ€™s biggest broadcaster Nexstar inked a deal to acquire smaller rival Tegna for $6.2 billion. The latter deal requires a loosening of rules prohibiting broadcast owners from owning TV stations reaching more than 39% of the national television audience. All need approval by the Trump administration.

Comcast cable spinoff Versant Media will start trading in days and WBD plans to separate Discovery Global networks from Warner Bros in third quarter of 2026 amid the decline of linear television.

Watch on Deadline

Disney rounded out 2025 with a milestone $1 billion investment in Sora parent OpenAI, breaking bread with the behemoth thatâ€™s been ripping off its IP. Industry pundits expect more of those deals.

â€œResistance is futile,â€ says one industry insider, recalling the famous Star Trek line. â€œThat became clear for the music industry 25 years ago with online distribution. Eventually we legalized it by making it accessible. And the same is going to be true, is true, for AI.â€

â€œFor the scraping and the training part, I feel like that ship has left. How do you go back when all the models have already done all the illegal sh*t that they shouldnâ€™t have done, and untrain them? Now it really is going to be a focus on output. And thatâ€™s important because with Sora, for example, you tell it, â€˜Create something like Star Wars characters for me,â€™ and it will, and thatâ€™s infringement, clearly. Itâ€™s just a question of how Disney is going to get compensated for that. These AI companies have the money to make deals and they should make deals with IP owners. They should do it legally. They should do it above board.â€

â€œWeâ€™re starting to see people that may have always been on opposite sides of the table talk to each other and play together, and play well in the sandbox, to see whatâ€™s â€¦ possible,â€ says Bart Spiegel, Partner, Media & Entertainment at PwC US.

One deal did not make it. Venu Sports, a planned venture of Fox, Warner Bros. Discovery and Disney, fell apart. But Disney speedily announced and closed an acquisition of Fubo, which it merged with Hulu + Live TV. Fox launched new streaming service Fox One. Disney debuted its flagship ESPN streamer.

PwCâ€™s recently published US Deals 2026 Outlook noted a major uptick in media and telecom transaction volume and value over the past six months â€œcharacterized by headline-grabbing megadeals, increased consolidation within streaming, and a pronounced shift toward profitability and scale â€” underscoring a renewed confidence among both strategic and financial buyers in deploying capital.â€

â€œA lot of trends came to a head this year,â€ Spiegel says.

CEOs and fund managers across sectors had, in fact, back in the fall of 2024, anticipated a flood of deals this year if Trump emerged as president on a tide of deregulation. But POTUS himself choked deal flow by unleashing intense tariff chaos in the first part of the year. â€œWe were expecting it to be the year of just a ridiculous amount of M&A,â€ says one Wall Streeter. â€œBut there was a lot of volatility in the system, and uncertainty in the markets.â€

Then the dust settled, although average tariffs â€“ taxes on imports â€“ are still hovering at about 16.8%, the highest theyâ€™ve been since 1935, according to The Budget Lab at Yale.

High Hollywood Drama

And even as M&A across sectors accelerated this summer and fall, media deals appeared to be in the hot seat, as many had predicted.

President Trump often disparages mainstream news outlets and has sued CNN, ABC, CBS, the New York Times and the BBC, among others. He frequently threatens to pull broadcast licenses if he dislikes coverage. Brendan Carr, whom Trump named to lead the FCC, approved Paramountâ€™s long-gestating merger with Skydance only after the CBS parent settled its lawsuit for $16 million. â€œAmericans no longer trust the legacy national news media to report fully, accurately, and fairly. It is time for a change,â€ Carr said in a statement along with the commission greenlight.

So, as the next momentous deal takes shape around Warner Bros Discovery, it wasnâ€™t a surprise exactly when Trump said, â€œIâ€™ll be involved in that decision too.â€

WBD earlier this month inked the deal with Netflix after spurning a half dozen bids from Paramount Skydance including a hostile takeover offer by the Ellison-backed studio. CEO David Ellison and his father Larry with partner RedBird Capital are offering $30 a share in cash for the entire company and insist it has a clearer path to regulatory approval. The Netflix deal is for $27.75 for the studio and streaming businesses, made up of $23.25 in cash and $4.50 in Netflix stock. Both sides have been wooing Trump.

(L-R) Netflix-co-CEO Ted Sarandos, WBD CEO David Zaslav and Netflix co-CEO Greg Peters Warner Bros

â€œThe race is neck and neck right now,â€ says analyst Peter Supino of Wolfe Research. He thinks â€œParamount will get it because they need it more.â€

Netflix â€œis evidently serious. But Paramount has an imperative to get bigger. They need to matter more to consumers.â€

â€œItâ€™s a â€˜nice-to-haveâ€™ for Netflix because it will give them control over more IP,â€ agrees Seaport Research Partners analyst David Joyce. â€œItâ€™s more of a must-have for Paramount Skydance because they do need more scale.â€

He and others think Paramount has a good shot at derailing Netflix if it raises its bid. WBD has said itâ€™s considering Parâ€™s latest offer, which included a new $40 billion+ financing guarantee by Larry Ellison personally, but did not add more cash. Outside funders include Public Investment Fund (Saudi Arabia), Lâ€™imad Holding Company PJSC (Abu Dhabi) and Qatar Investment Authority. Kushnerâ€™s Affinity Partners was initially part of the group but dropped out.

â€œWeâ€™re waiting for the Warner Bros board to officially opine on their offer â€¦ but they didnâ€™t increase the value of their bid. I think that they do need to do that,â€ Joyce says. Paramountâ€™s offer values Discovery Global assets at $1 a share. â€œI think itâ€™s worth more like $3.50 to $4 per share. So I think Paramount Skydance will come back with a higher offer. And that will be a way for Netflix to exit gracefully.â€ He doesnâ€™t expect the giant streamer to counter a higher bid from Paramount.

â€œStudios and streamer and network companies are in reinvention mode. Have been for several years,â€ Joyce recalls. â€œIn streaming, you had this transition from land-grab mode, which was kind of from when Disney bought [21st Century] Fox [in 2018], up until 2022, when Netflix stock fell 80% and all the streamers decided they had to get profitable.â€ Netflix shares plunged in 2022 as it reported the first subscriber losses in over a decade. It marked and end to the era of streamers spending massively to gain share in an increasingly competitive market.

â€œOver the last two years, you were transitioning out of that land-grab mode into a focus on efficiency. And part of efficiency was increasing prices and cutting costs, and part of it is merging with other companies. And so we see Warner Bros deciding to spin off Discovery. And then Skydance taking over Paramount, and making a hostile bid for Warner. And Netflix taking a shot at Warner Bros. Comcast spinning off Versant is kind of the opposite of consolidation. Itâ€™s de-consolidation. But itâ€™s an important acknowledgment that these companies all want to focus their capital on getting stronger in the areas that matter to the future.â€

TikTok & The Free Radicals

In other pending deals, a consortium of investors including Oracle, private equity firm Silver Lake and the United Arab Emiratesâ€™ state-backed investment firm MGX look set to take about 80% of a new American version of TikTok. That would be a notable deal for the hugely popular video app currently controlled by Chinaâ€™s ByteDance, which would control about 20%. The future of TikTok in the U.S. has been an ongoing legal and strategic muddle.

TikTok CEO Shou Chew told staff the U.S. JV transaction is set to close January 22. Fox Corp. had also been in talks to join the U.S. investment consortium.

And companies that Liberty Media founder John Malone once dubbed as â€œfree radicalsâ€ â€” like Lionsgate Studios and Starz (now separate publicly traded entities) and AMC Networks (controlled by the Dolan family) â€” have seen their shares climb recently and may ultimately find strategic partners.

Starz has been talking with Disney and Hearst-owned A+E Global Media.

At Lionsgate, a one-year shareholder-rights plan, or so-called poison pill, which protects companies against hostile takeovers, expires in May.

â€œThere has been some value recognition that has come back into these shares of the smaller companies in the space,â€ says Seaportâ€™s Joyce.

Sports valuations are surging across the ecosystem, PwC notes. â€œCapital continues to flow into the sports value chain, from team ownership, up-and-coming leagues outside traditional Big Four, and stadium assets, to media rights and womenâ€™s leagues, as investors pursue durable, fan-driven returns.â€

The sale of Los Angeles Lakers to Dodgers owner Mark Walter for a $10 billion valuation, a new benchmark, reinforces â€œthat sports intellectual property (IP), live rights, and venue infrastructure now sit at the intersection of media, entertainment, and private capital.â€

Says Spiegel: â€œItâ€™s about where are people going to be spending their free time, and what are people focused on.â€
