content:
The team behind Yashâ€˜s highly anticipated â€œToxic â€“ A Fairytale for Grown-Upsâ€ has revealed the first look at Nayanthara as Ganga, presenting the actress in a role that combines visual intensity with a commanding presence.

The poster positions Nayanthara in front of an ornate casino entrance, weapon in hand, projecting controlled power within a high-stakes luxury environment. The image marks a departure for the actor, suggesting a character defined by calculated authority rather than conventional heroism.

Nayanthara has established herself as one of Indiaâ€™s most acclaimed actor over a two-decade career spanning more than 75 films across Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam and Kannada-language cinema. Her filmography includes women-centric successes like â€œAramm,â€ â€œKolamaavu Kokilaâ€ and â€œNetrikann,â€ alongside Shah Rukh Khanâ€™s blockbuster â€œJawan.â€

Popular on Variety

Yash, the Kannada-language film industry actor who rose to pan-Indian stardom with the â€œK.G.Fâ€ franchise, has become one of the most sought-after stars in Indian cinema. Known for his portrayal of Rocky Bhai in â€œK.G.F: Chapter 1â€ (2018) and â€œK.G.F: Chapter 2â€ (2022) Yashâ€™s transformation into a larger-than-life action hero propelled the films to unprecedented box-office success, breaking language barriers. The second instalment in the franchise is the fifth highest Indian grosser of all time. While the â€œK.G.Fâ€ series cemented his star power, Yashâ€™s early career in Kannada-language films showcased his versatility, with notable performances in projects such as â€œMr. and Mrs. Ramachariâ€ (2014) and â€œGooglyâ€ (2013).

â€œToxicâ€ is helmed by festival circuit darling Geetu Mohandas (â€œMoothonâ€). The ambitious project represents a watershed moment for Kannada cinema, which has been steadily gaining international traction following the â€œK.G.Fâ€ phenomenon. Written by Yash and Mohandas, â€œToxicâ€ is breaking new ground as the first major Indian film conceptualized, written and shot simultaneously in both the Kannada and English languages â€“ with dubbed versions planned for Hindi, Telugu, Tamil, Malayalam and additional languages.

â€œWe all know Nayan as a celebrated star with a commanding screen presence, and a remarkable career spanning two decades but in â€˜Toxic,â€™ audiences will witness a talent that had been quietly waiting to explode,â€ said director Geetu Mohandas. â€œI wanted to portray Nayan in a way that sheâ€™s never been showcased before. But as the shoot progressed I began to see how closely her own personality echoed the soul of the character. It wasnâ€™t imitation, it was alignment. The depth, the honesty, the restraint, and the emotional clarity she brought were not performances layered on top of the character, they were qualities she already possessed. I found my Ganga, so brilliantly performed by her, and even more unexpectedly, I found a dear friend.â€

The reveal follows previous character unveilings for the production, including Kiara Advani as Nadia and Huma Qureshi as Elizabeth, each presenting distinct visual aesthetics within the filmâ€™s narrative world.

The production has assembled a notable technical crew including Indian National Film Award-winning cinematographer Rajeev Ravi, composer Ravi Basrur, editor Ujwal Kulkarni and production designer T.P. Abid. Action sequences have been choreographed by Hollywoodâ€™s J.J. Perry, known for his work on â€œJohn Wick,â€ alongside Indian National Film Award-winning duo Anbariv and Kecha Khamphakdee.

Produced by Venkat K. Narayana and Yash through KVN Productions and Monster Mind Creations, â€œToxic â€“ A Fairytale for Grown-Upsâ€ is scheduled for theatrical release March 19, 2026, capitalizing on the extended holiday weekend that encompasses Eid, Ugadi and Gudi Padwa celebrations.

title: Queen Camilla Opens Up For First Time About Her Experience Being Assaulted On A Train
summary: Queen Camilla has opened up for the first time about her experience being attacked by a man on a train as a teenager. Speaking to the BBCâ€™s Today program during a discussion about violence against women, the Queen detailed the assault that had been “lurking in the back of my brain for a very long […]
content:
Queen Camilla has opened up for the first time about her experience being attacked by a man on a train as a teenager.

Speaking to the BBCâ€™s Today program during a discussion about violence against women, the Queen detailed the assault that had been â€œlurking in the back of my brain for a very long time.â€

When she was a teenager, she said that â€œa boy, I thought it was an old man at the time but he was probably not a great deal older than me,â€ had attacked her while she was reading a book.

She did not know the person and says she fought back. When she got off the train, Camilla recalled her mother â€œlooking at me saying, â€˜Why is your hair standing on end and why is a button missing from your coat?â€™.â€

â€œI had sort of forgotten about it but I remember at the time being so angry,â€ she added. â€œI just thought, â€˜Why is this boy doing this?â€™.â€

Watch on Deadline

Earlier this year, a book by former Times royal editor Valentine Low first revealed the assault, in which it was reported that Camilla had told former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson about the experience in 2008. The book reported that the Queen had been 16 or 17 years old at the time, had hit the man with her shoe and had reported him at Paddington Station. He was then arrested. Buckingham Palace made no official statement on the story but didnâ€™t dispute the details.

Camilla was speaking on the BBC this morning with another former UK Prime Minister, Theresa May, and John and Amy Hunt. Former BBC racing commentator John Huntâ€™s wife and two daughters were killed in a crossbow attack last year by one of his daughtersâ€™ ex-boyfriends. The man, Kyle Clifford, was sentenced to life in prison earlier this year and his crimes were described in court as being â€œfuelledâ€ by the â€œviolent misogyny promotedâ€ by social media influencers like Andrew Tate.

Amy Hunt, who is John Huntâ€™s one surviving daughter, thanked Queen Camilla for sharing her story.

Camilla went on to say that the assault had â€œlurked for many years, and when the subject of domestic abuse came up, suddenly you hear stories like John and Amyâ€™s and it is something I feel very strongly about and want to do something about.â€

â€œA lot of people donâ€™t know how bad it is out there,â€ added the Queen. â€œThe majority of people donâ€™t want to know. Itâ€™s been a taboo subject for so long, people havenâ€™t talked about it. I thought if Iâ€™ve got a tiny soapbox to stand on I will stand on it and talk to people and get them together.â€

content:
Canal+ and Warner Bros. Discovery have signed a new multi-year, multi-territory agreement to strengthen their partnership internationally, including the expansion of HBO Max to two more countries.

Through the pact, which a press release calls a â€œmajor milestoneâ€ in the companiesâ€™ collaboration, distribution of HBO Max via Canal+ will be renewed in Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, and Romania, and will expand to Belgium and Austria. Distribution of Cartoon Network, Cartoonito and CNN International in Romania, Hungary, the Czech Republic and Slovakia will also be renewed, as will Warner TV in the Czech Republic.

Across MultiChoice Group territories in Africa, distribution of 12 WBD thematic channels will be renewed, including CNN International and Cartoon Network, Cartoon Network Porto, Cartoonito, Cartoonito Porto, Discovery Channel, Discovery Family, Real Time, ID, TLC, HGTV, Travel, TNT Africa and Food Network.

Popular on Variety

The agreement between WBD and the French media group builds upon previous deals made in 2024, including the renewal of the exclusive pay-TV window for Warner Bros. Pictures films six months after their theatrical release in France and the integration of HBO Max within select Canal+ group offers.

It also comes during Netflixâ€™s pending purchase of WBD, which could further position Canal+ as a power player on the global stage as the company already has distribution deals in place with Netflix. On Dec. 16, Netflix boss Ted Sarandos made a surprise appearance at Canal+ Groupâ€™s Paris showcase and reassured the audience of his plans in purchasing WBD.

â€œOur intentions when we buy Warner Bros. will be to continue to release Warner Bros. studio movies in theaters with the traditional windows,â€ Sarandos said during a conversation with Canal+ chair and CEO Maxime Saada. â€œThen those movies would flow through the Canal+ output deal. Thatâ€™s very exciting for us.â€

title: Warner Bros. Discovery & Canal+ Strike â€œMilestoneâ€ International Agreement Over HBO Max

content:
HBO Max will be available in two more territories on Canal+ as the French powerhouse strikes a fresh multi-year, multi-territory agreement with Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD).

The agreement renews HBO Max in Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungrary and Romania on Canal+, but will also see the streamer distributed via Canal+ in Belgium and Austria.

HBO Max has rolled out to major European markets over the past year or so and will soon go live in the UK, where it has previously been unable to launch due to WBDâ€™s long-running deal with Sky.

Canal+ and WBD said todayâ€™s partnership marks a â€œmajor milestone in the development of their collaboration on an international scale.â€

Watch on Deadline

Overall, the agreement covers the distribution of HBO Max, the renewal of several WBD channels and the renewal of the exclusive pay-TV window for Warner Bros. movies, which land on Canal+ six months after their theatrical release in France.

Around 12 WBD channels have been renewed across territories in Africa on MultiChoice Group, the firm that Canal+ acquired earlier this year. CNN International and Cartoon Network will air exclusively in South Africa and non-exclusively in other territories. A number of other networks have also been renewed in African markets.

Canal+ also has distribution deals in place with Netflix and could become an important player if Netflixâ€™s acquisition of WBD goes through, which will give Netflix control over two of the worldâ€™s biggest streamers.

title: French Box Office Posts 13.6% Drop In Admissions For 2025 With U.S. Movies & Arthouse Titles Winners In Complex Year
summary: French cinema admissions dropped 13.6% year-on-year in 2025 to 156.79M admissions, against 181.52M last year, for a rough gross of $1.36B (â‚¬1.16b), according to figures released byÂ Franceâ€™s National Cinema Centre (CNC). content:
French cinema admissions dropped 13.6% year-on-year in 2025 to 156.79M admissions, against 181.52M last year, for a rough gross of $1.36B (â‚¬1.16b), according to figures released by Franceâ€™s National Cinema Centre (CNC).

The figures confirmed a complex year at the French box office in which only January and December saw small year-on-year admission gains, while the summer months saw drops in admissions of 28.5% in May and 29.6% in August.

The top performing films across 2025 were Zootopia 2 with 6.18 million entries, followed by Lilo & Stitch (5.1m), Avatar: Fire and Ash (4.58m), F1: The Movie (3.31m) and Jurassic World Renaissance (2.97m).

The best performing French film was comedy franchise God Save The Tuche, which came in sixth with 2.95 million entries and was the only local production to make it into the top ten.

Watch on Deadline

This was in contrast to 2024 when French films dominated the top five, led by The top surprise breakout title A Little Something Extra with 10M entries and The Count Of Monte Cristo (9.1M).

Looking for silver linings, the CNC noted that Franceâ€™s box office remained the biggest in Europe, listing admissions of 85 million for Germany, 67 million for Italy and 65 million for Spain up until December 28, as well as the fact that French films took a 37.7% market share.

The latter figure was down on 2024 when French films accounted for 44% of admissions, but is in line with pre-pandemic levels. The U.S. share of the market was stable at 35.8%, against 35.6% last year.

The CNC also pointed to the small 0.9% year-on-year rise to 20.73 million admissions in December, on the back of strong performances by Avatar: Fire and Ash, Zootopia 2, The Housemaid and French documentary Whispers in the Woods.

â€œ2025 was a mixed year for cinemas, with a declining market due to a lack of crowd-pleasing films and surprise hits like those of 2024 but saw strong rebound at the end of the year, driven by a robust offering of films, particularly American ones,â€ said CNC President GaÃ«tan Bruel.

â€œThis result should not overshadow the long-term relevance of our model: an unparalleled network of cinemas that allows a wide variety of films to reach all audiences, and a market share of French films that makes France an exception in Europe and worldwide,â€ he added.

In spite of the lack a big box office hits, the CNC noted that a number of French films had put in respectable showings at the box office. After God Save The Tuche, the top performing films were My Mother, God, And Sylvie Vartan with 1.4M admissions, How To Make A Killing (1.39M), Colours of Time (887,000), The Richest Woman In The World (883,000), The Ties That Bind Us (750,000), The Stranger (734,000) and Case 137 (645,000).

Another bright spot was the performance of arthouse films, with the CNC pointing to the performances of One Battle After Another with 1.5M admissions, Mickey 17 (1.2M), SirÃ¢t (700,000), It Was Just An Accident (625,000), The Brutalist (487,000), Sentimental Value (400,000), The Voice of Hind Rajab (265,000), Arco (434,000) and The Little Sister (385,000).

In an article in the Le Figaro last week pre-empting Wednesdayâ€™s figures, the head of Franceâ€™s independent arthouse cinema theatre association AFCAE David Obadia said 2025 had been a good year for its members.

â€œItâ€™s our best year in a decade. More than a third of the entries this summer were in our cinemas,â€ he said, referring to AFCAEâ€™s network of some 1,250 cinemas.

Shorts is one of several microdrama platforms emerging across Europe, as […]
content:
EXCLUSIVE: French microdrama platform Shorts has teamed with L.A.â€™s Fumero Films for 40 vertical video projects for 2026.

Fumeroâ€™s bosses, Adriana Santos and Alejandro Fumero, claim the deal is one of the largest ever international slate orders in the emerging microdrama industry to date.

Shorts is one of several microdrama platforms emerging across Europe, as the medium continues to build. The appâ€™s creative partnership with Fumero is being billed as â€œlandmark, with Shorts exec Sylvain Daressy saying: â€œWhat Alejandro and Adriana have built at Fumero Films is extraordinary, but even more powerful is what weâ€™ve built together.

â€œTheir precision, creativity, and cultural authenticity elevate the vertical format in a way that resonates worldwide. Collaborating with a Latino-led studio of this caliber sets a new global standard for short-form storytelling.â€

Watch on Deadline

Microdrama episodes tend to run for between 60 and 90 seconds, and follow melodramatic themes in genres such as romance, sci-fi and thriller. Top apps include ReelShorts, Dramabox, Goodshort and Candyjar, with the earliest ones originating from China and Korea.

Shorts and Fumero have been working together over the past year on their slate, which they say has helped to develop â€œnarrative rhythm,â€ refine production speed, and elevate â€œthe emotional intensity that defines modern microdramas.â€

They are sharing the financial risk on the productions, giving Fumero a production pipeline and Shorts a slate of new series. Episodes previews will be made available through teasers and unlock entire series for fees ranging from $15 to $50.

AJ Letterel, Head Creative Producer at Shorts said: â€œFumero Films brings a cinematic boldness that is rare in fast-turnaround formats. Their ability to innovate under pressure, their emotional instinct, and their respect for craft make them essential partners. This 40-project slate is just the beginning of what we can achieve together.â€

Santos and Fumero claim to be the first Latino-led studio to strike a vertical video deal of this scale. They plan to focus on diverse voices and cross-cultural storytelling â€“ the lack of which has been one consistent criticism of the medium.

â€œRepresenting the next generation of storytellers is at the core of everything we do,â€ said Alejandro Fumero. â€œVertical films allow us to connect with global audiences instantly and intimately. Weâ€™re honored to help shape this new mediumâ€”and to do so alongside Shorts, a partner who believes just as deeply in authentic, impactful stories.â€

â€œOur collaboration with Shorts has shown what happens when diverse perspectives and strong creative alignment come together,â€ added Santos. â€œWe hope this opens doors for more Latino writers, directors, and performers across vertical cinema.â€



Having originated in China in 2020, the microdrama industry is worth upwards of $10B, with several analysts pegging its worth by 2030 at around $25B. The excitement has led to several Hollywood and international executives to launch production businesses around the apps, and many actors to move into the space to find work.

This edition: Why Black Mirror creator Charlie Brookerâ€˜s idea to deepfake cinemagoers into movies was typically prescient.

Charlie Brooker is the grandmaster of predicting how the human experience could be shaped by technology. Whether itâ€™s Domhnall Gleesonâ€™s replicant boyfriend pre-dating grief chatbots, creepy social credits systems, or killer robots, Black Mirror is often the dystopian nightmare we come to recognize in reality.

Watch on Deadline

With that in mind, my ears pricked up when Brooker cheerily sketched out an AI vision to boost cinema ticket sales during an on-stage interview in 2025. He proposed scanning the faces of cinemagoers as they enter the theater and then using AI to cast them â€œrandomlyâ€ in the actual movie. â€œSo imagine if you went to see Raiders of the Lost Ark and you donâ€™t know if youâ€™re going to be Indiana Jones, or a melting Nazi,â€ he told the Edinburgh TV Festival.

This was August. Little more than a month later, OpenAI launched Sora 2, allowing users to insert themselves into infinite movie realms through its â€œCameosâ€ feature. The results went astoundingly viral. Brookerâ€™s prescience had struck again.

The screenwriter touched on something fundamental about how AI content is being voraciously consumed as novelty. â€œItâ€™s telling, isnâ€™t it, that a lot of the AI-generated imagery you see is a remix of other things,â€ Brooker said.

But does it have the legs to walk into cinema theaters? The technology is there, but itâ€™s fair to say that storytelling and audience expectations are not.

Attempts to revolutionize the cinema experience through innovation have flopped. Theaters flirted with choose-your-own-adventure-style ideas (something Brooker pulled off on Netflix with Bandersnatch), with little traction. 3D is now largely seen as a gimmick. And in 2013, the Dutch film APP allowed users to synchronize and expand the storyline via their phones, but it did not make the switch to Hollywood.

â€œPeople just donâ€™t go to the cinema for this stuff,â€ says Sarah Atkinson, professor of screen media at Kingâ€™s College London. Julian Hanich, professor of film studies at the University of Groningen, is equally skeptical. â€œThe pleasure of watching a film is partly based on self-extending into a different world,â€ he explains. â€œIf you are already part of that world through AI, thatâ€™s kind of contradictory.â€

Itâ€™s perhaps instructive that the two exhibition executives approached for this Rendering column did not wish to speak about deepfaking their audience members into works of art. And Brooker would likely be the first to acknowledge the pratfalls of such an endeavor.

But thatâ€™s not to say movie studios are dismissing these ideas. The best indication of this was Disneyâ€™s shock deal to hand over characters from titles like Frozen and Toy Story to Sora, with the best user-generated videos set to be hosted on Disney+.

Itâ€™s not quite Brookerâ€™s cinema vision, but who would have predicted at the start of 2025 that Disney superfans could star in AI-generated videos on the Mouse Houseâ€™s own streaming service? It would have sounded very Black Mirror.

title: Women Directors Make Up 8% of This Yearâ€™s 100 Top-Grossing Filmmakers in a Steep Drop From 2024, Study Shows
summary: A new study describes 2025 as a â€œGreat Recessionâ€ for women directors, with just 9 women directors attached to the 100 top-grossing films at the U.S. box office. According to the latest report from the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, of the 111 directors who helmed those films, 9 of them were women: Nisha Ganatra (“Freakier […]
content:
A new study describes 2025 as a â€œGreat Recessionâ€ for women directors, with just 9 women directors attached to the 100 top-grossing films at the U.S. box office.

According to the latest report from the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative, of the 111 directors who helmed those films, 9 of them were women: Nisha Ganatra (â€œFreakier Fridayâ€), Emma Tammi (â€œFive Nights at Freddyâ€™s 2â€), Domee Shi (â€œElioâ€), Madeline Sharafian (â€œElioâ€), Celine Song (â€œMaterialistsâ€), Jennifer Kaytin Robinson (â€œI Know What You Did Last Summerâ€), Maggie Kang (â€œKPop Demon Huntersâ€), Hikari (â€œRental Familyâ€) and previous best director Oscar winner ChloÃ© Zhao (â€œHamnetâ€).

The 2025 figure (8.1 %, which calculates a ratio of 11.3 men to every 1 woman) represents a steep drop from 2024, when the percentage of women directors on the 100 top-grossing films was 13.4% (15 directors), when the U.S. was in the throes of the Great Recession.

Popular on Variety

â€œThe 2025 data reveals that progress for women directors has been fleeting,â€ stated Dr. Stacy L. Smith, the studyâ€™s author and founder of the Annenberg Inclusion Initiative. â€œWhile it is tempting to think that these changes are a result of who is in the Oval Office, in reality, these results are driven by executive decision-making that took place long before any DEI prohibitions took effect. Many of these films were greenlit and in pre-production before the 2024 election.â€

The study, titled â€œInclusion in the Directorâ€™s Chairâ€ and now in its seventh iteration, examines the gender and race/ethnicity of directors across 2025â€™s 100 top-grossing films, as well as analyzes trends including hiring patterns by distributor, as well as the average and median Metacritic scores by director gender and race/ethnicity. The report surveys a total of 1,900 films released between 2007 and 2025.

Of the 111 directors in 2024, only three of the women (Song, Zhao and Tammi) have previously helmed a film in the sample. Just 24 women have directed more than one top-grossing film between 2007 and 2025. Top-performing women directors were Anne Fletcher (4 films), Lana Wachowski (4 films) and Greta Gerwig (3 films), while 21 women helmed 2 movies.

Less than a quarter (24.3%) of directors in 2025 were from underrepresented racial/ethnic groups in 2025. This figure is unchanged from 2024 (24.1%) and significantly higher than the 12.5% reported in 2007.

At the intersection of race and gender, only 5.4% of directors this year were women of color, but 2025 marks the first year where the number of women of color (6) outnumbered the number of white women (3). Furthermore, all of the women of color directors this year were Asian (Ganatra, Shi, Song, Kang, Hikari and Zhao); none were Black, Hispanic/Latina, Native American, Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, or Middle Eastern/North African. Overall, women of color still represent just 1.9% of all top-grossing movie directors across 19 years, despite the fact that their films earned the highest average and media scores compared to white male directors, white women and men of color.

â€œIt is clear that when it comes to directors, hiring decisions are not made solely on the basis of performance,â€ said Dr. Smith. â€œIf that were the case, then women of color would receive significantly more opportunities to work behind the camera in film. These results demonstrate that the quality of movies by women of color is not only overlooked, it is actively ignored.â€

By distributor, Universal Pictures (9.4%) and Walt Disney Studios (8%) (8.3%) lead the way in terms of hiring women directors over the studyâ€™s 19-year span; meanwhile, Paramount (2%), Lionsgate (4.3%), and 20th Century (4.6%) hired the lowest percentage of women. In 2025, Walt Disney Studios attached 3 women directors to top-grossing films while Universal Pictures and â€œotherâ€ distributors attached 2. Paramount, Warner Bros. and Lionsgate did not have a woman director across the top films this year.

The report contrasts these results by indicating significantly higher percentages of women directing films in U.S. Dramatic Competition at the Sundance Film Festival (63.6% for 2026), directing television episodes (37% in the 2023-2024 season) and helming Netflix movies (20.5% in 2024).

Read the full study on the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiativeâ€™s website.

content:
Itâ€™s no exaggeration to say that 2025 was a landmark in the annals of showbiz dealmaking. The year saw several transactions that not only involved billions of dollars changing corporate hands but also transformed the entertainment landscape. There was also unprecedented drama. Skydance Media closed its $8.4 billion merger with Paramount in August, putting the 113-year-old studio in the hands of David Ellison, the scion of tech mega-billionaire Larry Ellison. Five months later, the resulting corporate entity, Paramount Skydance, made a hostile, $108 billion takeover bid for Warner Bros. Discovery, which had just agreed to a $82.7 billion acquisition by Netflix. Complicating it all are Paramount Skydanceâ€™s dealings with the Trump administration and related parties, including initial backing from Trump son-in-law Jared Kushnerâ€™s Affinity Partners in its bid for WBD, which was pulled in mid-December.

Less publicized was Affinityâ€™s participation alongside Saudi Arabiaâ€™s Public Investment Fund and Silver Lake in a $55 billion leveraged buyout of game-making giant Electronic Arts.

Along the way, there were some bright spots, like Taylor Swift realizing her long-held ambition to buy back the masters to her first six albums, which she accomplished in a deal with Shamrock Partners worth a reported $360 million. Meanwhile, the appetite for high-dollar music catalog acquisitions continued unabated, which speaks to the good overall health of the music industry.

Above everything looms the fast-rising specter of AI. Some view it as an existential threat; others as an unprecedented opportunity. Whatever it is, you can rest assured that the Variety Dealmakers profiled on this page will find a way to profit from it.

title: Investment Banker Invasion: How Boutique Firms Dominated Hollywoodâ€™s Biggest Deals in 2025
summary: Look at the biggest recent mergers and acquisitions in the worlds of entertainment, media and sports, from the record-setting $55 billion buyout of ElecÂ­tronic Arts to the Skydance-Paramount merger and the dueling offers for Warner Bros. Discovery, and youâ€™ll notice the same handful of names showing up again and again, often together in the same […]
content:
Look at the biggest recent mergers and acquisitions in the worlds of entertainment, media and sports, from the record-setting $55 billion buyout of ElecÂ­tronic Arts to the Skydance-Paramount merger and the dueling offers for Warner Bros. Discovery, and youâ€™ll notice the same handful of names showing up again and again, often together in the same deal. Theyâ€™re investment firms with names like RedBird Capital Partners, the Raine Group, LionTree Advisors and Silver Lake. Most provide financing for these huge transacÂ­tions, while others, like Moelis & Company, are pure advisors who help structure and execute capital raises.

If you donâ€™t work in or near the gilded trenches of high finance, you might be askÂ­ing yourself, â€œWhat the hell is going on?â€

Popular on Variety

â€œWhen youâ€™re dealing with artists and film and music, it is as relationship-driven as Iâ€™ve ever seen,â€ explains Angelo Rufino, who, as head of special situations at the 41-year-old Bain Capital, works in the same sectors and spirit as those younger comÂ­panies. â€œIt is really important who you are, what you can add and bring to the table. I think at times that can be lost with the bigger firms.â€

Once upon a time, corporate M&A was dominated by decades- and, in some cases, century-and-a-half-old Wall Street beheÂ­moths that controlled trillions in assets. Then came the 2008 financial crisis, trigÂ­gering massive losses that pushed some to the brink of ruin and others (e.g., LehÂ­man Brothers) into extinction. Survivors like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley were forced to transform into bank holdÂ­ing companies to gain access to the Federal Reserveâ€™s discount window lending proÂ­grams and deposit insurance, subjecting them to stricter government oversight.

The challenges faced by the old giants were compounded by post-crisis federal regulations (via the Dodd-Frank Act and the Volcker Rule), which targeted specuÂ­lative trading that created conflicts of interest with clients and required higher asset-to-debt ratios for leveraged investÂ­ments. As a result, the most aggressive strategies were no longer legal or profitÂ­able enough to pursue at scale, opening the door for smaller, more nimble firms drawing on private equity, led by ambiÂ­tious refugees from money center banks.

Many of these upstarts developed a niche in showbiz. According to Carlos Jimenez, a managing director at Moelis & Company, the reason for this is very simÂ­ple: â€œNo one ever gets bored talking about media, sports and entertainment,â€ he says.

That was especially true in 2025, when the most talked-about drama in Hollywood was not anything on the big or small screens, but rather Skydance Mediaâ€™s on-again, off-again and, finally, on-again $8.4 billion merger with Paramount, backed by RedBird.

RedBird founder and managing partner Gerry Cardinale says that the deal wasnâ€™t necessarily the emotional roller coaster it appeared to be.

â€œTo a certain extent, it was business as usual,â€ says Cardinale, who retired from Goldman Sachs in 2012 and launched RedÂ­Bird two years later. â€œObviously, this was a very complicated transaction where, in a certain way, we had to almost buy it three times. [But] the one thing that has distinguished us over my 35 years [in the business] is that weâ€™re persistent, weâ€™re tenacious, we donâ€™t get emotional about these things.â€

Nonetheless, Cardinale agrees that this investment is uniquely significant, both personally and financially. It gives his company RedBird 22.5% voting power in the resulting company, Paramount SkyÂ­dance, and Cardinale a seat on its board of directors. It puts him second in line behind Skydance Media founder David Ellison, who took the title of chairman and CEO, and his father, tech mega-billionaire Larry Ellison, who collectively control 77.5% of the voting power.

â€œI looked at a lot of things and passed on them,â€ says Cardinale. â€œAnd what changed it for me was that you had someone like David Ellison, who is a true owner-operator.â€

This isnâ€™t the first time a New York-based power broker has gotten a hand on the reins of Paramount. In 1966, Austrian-born Charles Bluhdornâ€™s automotive parts manÂ­ufacturing and distribution conglomerate Gulf+Western bought the financially trouÂ­bled studio, eventually leading to a golden age that produced such classics as â€œThe Godfatherâ€ films and â€œChinatown.â€

Unlike Bluhdorn, Cardinale isnâ€™t a HolÂ­lywood newcomer. As heâ€™s quick to point out, this is far from the only significant showbiz investment made by RedBird in recent years. In 2021, it was part of a conÂ­sortium that bought a significant minority stake in LeBron James and Maverick CarÂ­terâ€™s media and entertainment firm SprinÂ­gHill Company, and the following year it committed a minimum of $100 million to Ben Affleck and Matt Damonâ€™s proÂ­duction company Artists Equity. Itâ€™s also been active in the sports world, with bets that include paying $750 million for an 11% minority stake in Fenway Sports in 2021 and $1.3 billion for the full acquisition of AC Milan in 2022. More importantly, itâ€™s been investing in Skydance since 2019.

â€œRedbird, to a certain extent, is an intelÂ­lectual property monetization engine,â€ says Cardinale. â€œWeâ€™ve had a long track record of being able to buy into IP-based businesses and effectively we underwrite them, reinvigorate them and reposition them for the 21st century for technological disintermediation,â€ where middlemen are removed from the supply chain, enabling more efficient and profitable direct-to-consumer transactions.

On the investment side, the results are clear: the entity putting in the money gets an ownership stake. But what do these firms get for their advisory services? TypiÂ­cally, advisors collect retainer fees ($10,000 to $50,000 a month) and success fees (1.5% to 10% of deal value), with the larger deals commanding larger retainers, but lower success fee percentages. With a mega-deal like the sale of Warner Bros. Discovery, which has received dueling offers from NetÂ­flix and Paramount topping out at $108.4 billion, the worst-case piece of the deal pie canâ€™t help but be impressive.

And what do the companies get from the advisors?

â€œWe basically do two or three things,â€ explains Jimenez. â€œWe put our arm around clients during their most important transÂ­actions, and that typically is M&A when folks are looking to buy or sell. Also, capÂ­ital raising, which is when theyâ€™re raising debt equity or going public. And then we also have a restructuring business, which is good when things go sideways,â€ he says, pointing to the work Moelis has done with AMC Theatres, which includes advising on a $600 million strategic investment from Silver Lake in 2018 and its 2020 restrucÂ­turing strategy. â€œIf you ask [AMC chairman and CEO] Adam Aron, heâ€™d tell you that we had a big hand in keeping his company afloat during really tough times during the pandemic,â€ he says.

After serving as one of the advisors to Skydance on its Paramount merger, MoeÂ­lis advised Netflix on its deal to buy WarÂ­ner Bros. Discovery, which was quickly met with a hostile offer from the company it just helped create. The Raine Group also advised Skydance on the merger (along with BofA Securities and, of course, RedÂ­Bird), while LionTree and Rothschild & Co. advised Paramount, along with Centerview Partners, which advised the independent special committee of the Paramount board.

But when you untangle these deals, things tend to be a bit less crowded than they might appear to an outsider, accordÂ­ing to Jimenez.

On big transactions, â€œthereâ€™s just so much to do in a short period of time, you often need a lot of help, but thatâ€™s not always the case,â€ he says. â€œDepending on the transaction, sometimes even on some of the big ones, thereâ€™s only one or two banks on each side.â€

The â€œAvengers: Doomsdayâ€ marketing campaign continued with a Thor-centric teaser that delighted many Marvel fans by standing in stark contrast to the divisively silly â€œThor: Love and Thunder,â€ the 2022 tentpole that marked Chris Hemsworthâ€˜s last outing as the God of Thunder. The actor doubled down a year later in Vanity Fairâ€™s May 2024 issue, saying: â€œI got caught up in the improv and the wackiness, and I became a parody of myself. I didnâ€™t stick the landing.â€

title: If I Had an Oscar Ballot: Brazilâ€™s Secret, Gazaâ€™s Voice and the Year Sin and Grief Became Cinema
summary: 2025 offered cinematic encounters of a rare kind. Thunderous spectacles unfurled alongside hushed, inward-facing character studies. content:
2025 offered cinematic encounters of a rare kind. Thunderous spectacles unfurled alongside hushed, inward-facing character studies. Some films swung wildly and missed â€” gloriously so â€” while others landed with such quiet authority, they seemed to rearrange the room. It was a year defined by daring, by filmmakers who trusted audiences to lean in rather than sit back.

Start with the consensus triumphs â€” films that felt instantly canonical.

ChloÃ© Zhaoâ€™s â€œHamnetâ€ is a masterwork of grief rendered as poetry. Jessie Buckley delivers a performance of almost unbearable emotional clarity as a mother splintered by loss, yet somehow still breathing.

Ryan Cooglerâ€™s â€œSinnersâ€ is something else entirely â€” muscular, ambitious and alive. Itâ€™s the work of a filmmaker proving, yet again, that his range knows no borders. Michael B. Jordanâ€™s dual performances are feats of control and intensity. Breakout Miles Caton and the indelible Wunmi Mosaku provide the emotional ballast that keeps the film grounded even as it soars.

Still, the pulse of my deepest excitement beats in Brazil, for the second straight year after Oscar winner â€œIâ€™m Still Here.â€

Kleber MendonÃ§a Filhoâ€™s â€œThe Secret Agentâ€ is a slow-burning thriller that tightens its grip almost imperceptibly. Wagner Moura is hypnotic, coiled with tension and weary intelligence, while TÃ¢nia Maria storms in with scene-stealing authority. Meanwhile, Tunisian auteur Kaouther Ben Haniaâ€™s â€œThe Voice of Hind Rajabâ€ is a gut punch â€” filmmaking that refuses comfort or distance. Saja Kalani, criminally overlooked, gives a raw performance of elemental power as an emergency call center volunteer in Gaza. And Oliver Laxeâ€™s Spanish-language â€œSirÄtâ€ is a fever dream that feels like the long-lost cousin of â€œMad Max: Fury Road,â€ built for the biggest screen you can find.

Then there are the films fighting for oxygen, the ones that slipped through the cracks or hovered just outside the safety of consensus.

Clint Bentleyâ€™s â€œTrain Dreamsâ€ gives William H. Macy a late-career performance of startling grace, a meditation on American solitude etched into every line of his face. Yorgos Lanthimosâ€™ â€œBugoniaâ€ divided audiences with its trademark strangeness. Still, Emma Stone and Jesse Plemons are mesmerizing together, while Aidan Delbis announces himself as a talent of rare specificity and soul. Rian Johnsonâ€™s latest â€œKnives Outâ€ whodunit, â€œWake Up Dead Man,â€ offers Josh Oâ€™Connor another showcase for his chameleonic range, while James Vanderbiltâ€™s â€œNurembergâ€ sees Russell Crowe delivering his most commanding work in two decades in a historical drama that feels uncomfortably contemporary. And the discovery of multi-hyphenate Eva Victor with the poignantly moving â€œSorry, Babyâ€ is a moment weâ€™re taking for granted.

If I had an Oscar ballot, Iâ€™d use it to honor films that risked misunderstanding, performances that revealed something frightening or tender about being human and directors who believed audiences would meet them halfway.

We canâ€™t forget about the best of TV.

Television is considered here with the same rigor as the films championed, and not through the mechanics of Emmy categories, but through cultural impact and artistic achievement. This list prioritizes series and performances that defined the yearâ€™s conversation, measuring critical distinction alongside visibility, virality and sustained audience engagement. These selections reflect television experienced in real time: debated, dissected, memed and argued over. Itâ€™s an Oscar-style snapshot of TV in 2025, honoring the shows and singular achievements that didnâ€™t just excel, but dominated the cultural imagination.

Always nice to include a disclaimer. If a movie isnâ€™t present in any given category, it doesnâ€™t mean â€œI hated it.â€ Making the top five in anything is difficult. Every ballot tells a story about what we value in art. This is mine.

title: Varietyâ€™s 2026 Media Predictions: â€˜The Odysseyâ€™ Domination, Disney CEO Shuffle and Netflix Winning Warner Bros. Deal
summary: From megamergers to disruptive new technologies, the media industry has a lot to pack into the next 12 months. Artificial intelligence continues to reshape the way movies, shows and music is made, roiling a business that is worried it will lead to more job cuts. Bob Iger is finally ready to move on from Disney […]
content:
From megamergers to disruptive new technologies, the media industry has a lot to pack into the next 12 months. Artificial intelligence continues to reshape the way movies, shows and music is made, roiling a business that is worried it will lead to more job cuts. Bob Iger is finally ready to move on from Disney (he pinkie-promises this time), setting up a succession battle for the ages. And Netflix and Paramount are locked in an epic fight over Warner Bros., a clash of titans â€” and egos â€” that shows no sign of abating. All of this is taking place as the box office is in a rut, cable is in free fall and the overall economy is teetering. So yeah, fun times!

We canâ€™t say for certain what 2026 has in store, but weâ€™re going out on a limb and channeling Nostradamus with predictions about the drama to come.

Popular on Variety

â€œThe Odysseyâ€ Will Be the Yearâ€™s Biggest Hit

The name on everybodyâ€™s lips is gonna be Odysseus. Some of the biggest franchises in Hollywood history are returning to screens with sequels and spinoffs to â€œStar Wars,â€ â€œThe Avengers,â€ â€œToy Story,â€ â€œSuper Mario Bros.â€ and â€œDune.â€ But the film that will reign above them all is based on a piece of IP thatâ€™s been in the public domain for millennia. Christopher Nolanâ€™s adaptation of Homerâ€™s â€œThe Odysseyâ€ will dominate popcorn season: Who but Nolan could put Imax tickets on sale an entire year in advance and have fans snap them up in record time? And if he could turn the creation of the atomic bomb into a blockbuster, having people show up for an epic survival story that dates to the sixth century B.C. should be a piece of cake.

Netflix Will Win the Warner Bros. Deal

The year is ending on a major M&A cliffhanger: Will Netflix or David Ellisonâ€™s Paramount Skydance score Warner Bros. Discovery? It sure looks like Netflixâ€™s to lose, having swayed the WBD board with strong financials, its status as the No. 1 subscription streamer and co-CEO Ted Sarandosâ€™ promise to keep the studio putting films in theaters. But thereâ€™s some regulatory uncertainty about the tie-up, and Trump remains a wild card. Meanwhile, Ellison and ultra-wealthy dad Larry Ellison arenâ€™t going away without a fight. But to prevail in the hostile takeover move, the Ellisons need to get 90% of WBD shares voted for their all-in offer. Itâ€™s hard to see that happening unless Paramount and its backers are willing to go higher than the $30-a-share proposal on the table.

The Next Leader of the Magic Kingdom Is â€¦

Bob Iger (finally!) is exiting stage left with his Mickey Mouse gold watch at the end of 2026. Who will get the call? Wall Street expects the shortlisted candidates to be Dana Walden, co-chair of Disney Entertainment, and Josh Dâ€™Amaro, head of the conglomerateâ€™s parks and experiences division. Walden has the entertainment bona fides; Dâ€™Amaro is a respected leader at the company. Itâ€™s possible the board opts for a co-CEO arrangement, but that doesnâ€™t feel like the Disney way. The board could also throw a curveball â€” and hire someone from the outside. But the directors are surely doing their fullest due diligence, given how things turned out last time. Letâ€™s give the edge to Dâ€™Amaro.

Can Hollywood Get Its Arms Around AI?

In the Wild West of artificial intelligence, entertainment companies are trying to swing both sticks and carrots. Disney, Universal and Warner Bros., for example, have sued two AI startups alleged to have ripped off their intellectual property. And Disney is trying to control its own AI destiny by going into business with OpenAI. Ultimately, Disney is betting eventual technical and legal guardrails will let it participate in the gold rush â€” and not be sideswiped by the slop. Expect the rest of the industry to explore similar strategies.

Meanwhile, the music industry faces its own struggles with AI. For a few months, it seemed as though the biz was on the same page in viewing generative AI as a looming threat to human creativity and compensation. In July 2024, Sony, Universal and Warner teamed with the Recording Academy for two copyright infringement cases against AI music services Suno and Udio. But as AI music has gone from fringe to foreground â€” Xania Monet, for instance, became the first AI act to debut on a Billboard radio chart in November â€” the majors have instead struck deals; by the end of 2025, Warner had partnered with Suno. The big three forged licensing deals with AI music startup Klay, and joined forces with Spotify to address issues with AI usage. The concern from artist and songwriter communities is valid â€” almost all of the deals were announced in amorphous terms. Proof of concept is likely to come in 2026, when the products resulting from these partnerships are expected to launch.

Big Questions for the Small Screen

In 2026 all eyes will be on what two powerful ex-Netflix execs do at their new homes: Paramount Skydance streaming chief Cindy Hollandâ€™s ultimate vision for Paramount+ should come into view. And new Amazon MGM Studios head of global TV Peter Friedlander will put his stamp on that company. Meanwhile, as Versant kicks off as a stand-alone company, keep an eye on what its networks might do in live TV and program acquisitions. In broadcast, the future of CBS News under Bari Weiss will be a top concern. In late night, what happens on CBS after â€œThe Late Show With Stephen Colbertâ€ ends its run (our prediction: The Eye network expands its 11 p.m. local news to an hour) will soon be known. In development, a hot topic will be the microdrama business â€” and how it might be adapted to TV. And the unscripted world is focused on runaway productions as more series find it cheaper to ship contestants overseas. Then thereâ€™s the looming specter of Hollywood strikes with the guild contracts expiring.

title: Top-Grossing Films Directed By Women Take Steep Drop In 2025, Report Finds

content:
A new study finds just nine women directors helmed top-grossing films at the domestic box office in 2025.

According to the USC Annenberg Inclusion Initiative report, out of 111 directors who helmed the top 100-grossing films, only nine were women, representing 8.1%, a steep drop from 2024, when the percentage of women directors on those films was 13.4%.

The nine women directors who ranked at the top of 2025â€™s list were Nisha Ganatra (Freakier Friday), Emma Tammi (Five Nights at Freddyâ€™s 2), Domee Shi (Elio), Madeline Sharafian (Elio), Celine Song (Materialists), Jennifer Kaytin Robinson (I Know What You Did Last Summer), Maggie Kang (KPop Demon Hunters), Hikari (Rental Family) and previous best director Oscar winner ChloÃ© Zhao (Hamnet).

The lower number of female directors is not a product of a lack of talent, according to the report, and women of color received the highest praise.

Watch on Deadline

â€œIt is clear that when it comes to directors, hiring decisions are not made solely on the basis of performance,â€ said the studyâ€™s author Stacy L. Smith in a news release. â€œIf that were the case, then women of color would receive significantly more opportunities to work behind the camera in film.â€

Of the 111 directors, 5.4% or six were women of color across the 100 top-grossing films of 2025, marking the first time in the 19-year study where the number of women of color directors outnumber the number of white women directors, the report found.

Paramount Pictures, Warner Bros. and Lionsgate did not hire a single female director for the films included in the Annenberg study in 2025.
