Popular on Variety

While the above data from Nielsen refers to viewership in the U.S. alone, Netflixâ€™s NFL games were available across the globe. The streamer reports that viewers from over 200 countries and territories tuned in to at least one of the games, with the Lions-Vikings game hitting an average minute audience of 30.5 million viewers worldwide and the Cowboys-Commanders game reaching 22.4 million.

The NFL games added to an already strong viewership day for Netflix, which also debuted Volume 2 of the fifth and final season of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ on Christmas Day. While exact an exact Christmas Day total wasnâ€™t shared, the season was Netflixâ€™s No. 1 most-watched title worldwide on Dec. 25 and achieved 34.5 million views throughout the week of Dec. 22-28.

Besides the games themselves, the NFL telecasts featured an extensive lineup of entertainment including some Netflix talent: Snoop Dogg brought out the singers behind Huntr/x, the fictional girl group from the animated film â€œKPop Demon Hunters.â€ Snoop was also joined by Lainey Wilson, and Martha Stewart introduced the show with a Snoop-themed parody of â€œâ€˜Twas the Night Before Christmas.â€ For the Cowboys-Commanders game, the halftime show was led by Sugarhill Gang.

More to comeâ€¦

title: Deadlineâ€™s Theater Critic Greg Evans Picks His Top 10 Broadway Shows Of 2025
summary: Last spring, Broadway prognosticators would have been well within the boundaries of common sense to posit that the big theater story of 2025 might be the arrival of big-name Hollywood stars on Manhattan stages. George Clooney, Denzel Washington, Kieran Culkin, Jake Gyllenhaal, Sarah Snook and Keanu Reeves were among the stars of film and TV […]
content:
Last spring, Broadway prognosticators would have been well within the boundaries of common sense to posit that the big theater story of 2025 might be the arrival of big-name Hollywood stars on Manhattan stages. George Clooney, Denzel Washington, Kieran Culkin, Jake Gyllenhaal, Sarah Snook and Keanu Reeves were among the stars of film and TV who gave Broadway one of its starriest seasons in memory.

And they brought big box office numbers (and big ticket prices) with them. For a moment there, it seemed as though Broadway, still not fully recovered from Covid, had found its saviors.

To be more specific, it seemed Broadway plays had discovered their saviors. Because the other major Broadway story of the year was the dismal reality faced by the Broadway musical. With the New York Times repeatedly shining a spotlight on the commercial failures of one highly anticipated musical after another â€” Smash, Boop!, Sunset Blvd., Cabaret, Gypsy, Redwood and, more recently, The Queen of Versailles â€” disappointing investors with multimillion-dollar losses, the future of the Broadwayâ€™s splashy, expensive stagings seemed (and seems) legitimately grim.

Watch on Deadline

And yet.

As Deadlineâ€™s theater critic, I found that a look back at Broadwayâ€™s 2025 brings a welcome reminder that there was plenty to love on those Manhattan stages. Even if we push aside the new-ish productions that opened prior to the start of the year â€” Oh, Mary!, The Outsiders, Maybe Happy Ending, to name just three â€” a threatened-though-durable Broadway didnâ€™t lose its ability to surprise, with more than a few 2025 productions boasting the wonderful performances and excellent craftsmanship that puts Broadway square in the mix of New York Cityâ€™s entertainment and cultural gifts to the world.

With that in mind, here are my choices for the 10 Best Broadway plays and musicals of 2025. Iâ€™ll also include some misses and a glance ahead to the upcoming shows Iâ€™m most anticipating.

1) Liberation

The Broadway cast of â€˜ Liberation Joan Marcus

Bess Wohlâ€™s wonderful play juxtaposes the heady, optimistic days of the Womenâ€™s Liberation Movement with the oppressive state of affairs that exists under the thumb of Donald Trump â€” even if his name is never given so much as a mention. Dreary? Not for a moment. Liberation is funny, poignant and, yes, liberating in its expression of the very human need for justice and freedom in an era when those words have been co-opted by forces who value only self-enrichment. Breathing life into the well-trod Memory Play genre, Liberation follows Lizzie (a remarkable Susannah Flood) as she approaches a middle age thatâ€™s filled with more questions than answers, particularly when it comes to her late mother, a onetime feminist firebrand who showed her daughter only her most domesticated, traditional mother-and-wife profile. In one of her direct addresses to the audience, Lizzie lays it all out: â€œThis is a play â€” a memory play, in a way â€” itâ€™s about my mother. For my mother. Who recently â€¦ Whoâ€™s not here anymore. And so itâ€™s about her, and her friends, her beautiful friends â€” and a thing â€” this is important â€”a thing they tried very hard to do. No, a thing that they did, that they unquestionably did â€” so why does it feel somehow like itâ€™s all slipping away? And how do we get it back?â€

With the cast portraying a group of women in a â€œconsciousness raisingâ€ feminist group of the 1970s as well as their 21st century selves, Liberation jumps back and forth in time, giving audiences a wide-ranging perspective on radicalism, gender roles, race, oppression and defiance. And yes, Liberation is as funny and entertaining as it is wise. Whitney White (Jajaâ€™s African Hair Braiding) directs with confidence, signaling her arrival at the forefront of Broadwayâ€™s strongest players.

Liberation is playing at the James Earl Jones Theatre through February 1

Broadwayâ€™s â€˜Ragtimeâ€™ Lincoln Center Theater

Perhaps the biggest surprise of Broadwayâ€™s current fall season, the Lincoln Center Theater revival of the 1990s musical Ragtime should be seen as no less than director Lear deBessonetâ€™s heartfelt embrace of a work that, frankly, had heretofore failed to stake its claim on the theatrical landscape. Too often lumped together with Titanic, Kiss of the Spider Woman, Miss Saigon and other bloated offerings of 1990s Broadway, Ragtime was rescued by deBessonet with a leaner, more emotionally powerful staging for City Centerâ€™s Encores! series, and like so many of Encores! better stagings Ragtime transferred to Broadway with its superb cast (led by Joshua Henry, Caissie Levy and Brandon Uranowitz) largely intact. In 2025, it finally found its proper place on Broadway.

Ragtime is playing at Lincoln Centerâ€™s Vivian Beaumont Theater through June 14

Sadie Sink (on desk) and cast of â€˜John Proctor Is the Villainâ€™ Julieta Cervantes

Few theatergoers knew what to expect with the announcement early this year that a Broadway newcomer named Kimberly Belflower had written a play that would combine elements of the Salem Witch Trials, Arthur Millerâ€™s The Crucible, the MeToo movement, sexual harassment, Lorde and Taylor Swift, with a starring role given to young Sadie Sink of Stranger Things fame. To say Belflower, director Danya Taymor, Sink and everyone else associated with this magnificent production pulled it off is an understatement. With surprises aplenty â€” and a final scene that ranks among Broadwayâ€™s most invigorating send-offs of the 21st century â€” John Proctor is the Villain cast a spell that resonates months after its too-early September 7 closing.

John Proctor is the Villain played at the Booth Theatre from March 20 to September 7, 2025

4) Dead Outlaw

Andrew Durand in â€˜Dead Outlawâ€™ Matthew Murphy

If I could pick one Broadway production of 2025 to outlast a too-brief engagement long enough to find its rightful audience, Dead Outlaw would be it. The quirky David Yazbek-Erik Della Penna-Itamar Moses musical deserved a far happier ending than it unlikely inspiration, the real-life Elmer McCurdy, a turn-of-the-century wannabe train robber whose shooting death in 1911 was only the beginning of a very strange existence: His corpse, long thought to be a prop or a mannequin, was located in 1976 at a Long Beach amusement park when crew members of The Six Million Dollar Man made the grisly discovery while shooting a location scene.

Somehow Dead Outlawâ€˜s creators made a discovery of their own: Ably assisted by a stirring (if often motionless) lead performance from Andrew Durand in the title role (check out his scorching â€œKilled a Man in Maineâ€), this musical went well beyond the macabre to find the humanity in a most unlikely place.

Dead Outlaw played at the Longacre Theatre from April 2 to June 29, 2025

5) Operation Mincemeat

â€˜Operation Mincemeatâ€™ on Broadway Julieta Cervantes

What are the chances that two musicals about corpses would wash up on the Broadway shores within a single season? And that theyâ€™d both provide such lively entertainment? Like Dead Outlaw, Operation Mincemeat is based on a real-life incident (and a real-life dead body). As resurrected by the British musical comedy troupe SplitLip, Mincemeat recounts a World War II exploit in which British intelligence officers concocted an outlandish scheme to trick the Germans: Theyâ€™d dress the corpse of a recently deceased â€” and unclaimed â€” homeless man in a British royal marine uniform, complete with phony documents in the pockets that would divert the Nazis from the Alliesâ€™ true attack plan.

Mixing outrageous slapstick comedy, a Monty Python-esque love of wordplay and one of Broadwayâ€™s most poignant new love songs in â€œDear Bill,â€ Mincemeat, like Dead Outlaw, proves all over again that in the right hands no idea is too outlandish to conquer the stage or the free world.

Operation Mincemeat is playing at the John Golden Theatre

6) Marjorie Prime

(L-R) Danny Burstein, Cynthia Nixon and June Squibb in â€˜Marjorie Primeâ€™ Joan Marcus

If Dead Outlaw and Operation Mincemeat could be theatrical cousins, Marjorie Prime and Maybe Happy Ending at the very least could be something-or-other once removed. Both envision a future in which robots, for lack of a better word (these are not your Lost in Space tin men), become all but indistinguishable from humans. Which says a lot about humans, for better and worse. While Maybe Happy Ending won 2025â€™s Best Musical Tony at least in part by infusing its tale of â€œhelper botsâ€ with genuine heart, Marjorie Prime takes an altogether more haunting approach: What if you could purchase an AI hologram â€” a â€œprime,â€ in the word of playwright Jordan Harrison â€” that resembled a dead loved one, say, the elderly mother who just passed, and that could be infused with all the memories and mannerisms for which you grieve? Directed by the irreplaceable Anne Kauffman, Marjorie Prime (flawlessly performed by June Squibb, Cynthia Nixon, Danny Burstein and Christopher Lowell) suggests that few of us could resist the unholy temptation, and that all of our technological know-how wonâ€™t save us from our longings.

Marjorie Prime is playing at the Hayes Theatre through February 15

7) Little Bear Ridge Road

Laurie Metcalf and Micah Stock in â€˜Little Bear Ridge Roadâ€™ Julieta Cervantes

Early closings are never easy, but some hit more deeply than others. That certainly was the case with Little Bear Ridge Road, Samuel D. Hunterâ€™s play about a cantankerous woman long estranged from her adult nephew and the life twists that bring them together again, however fleetingly. By turns brittle and compassionate, Little Bear Ridge Road showed us a generosity of spirit that could overcome even the most entrenched emotional barriers. The two lost souls granted a bit of grace were played by the one and only Laurie Metcalf and one of Broadwayâ€™s brightest new stars, Micah Stock, both under the unerring direction of Joe Mantello. So why didnâ€™t this fine play produced by Scott Rudin and Barry Diller last beyond a scant 11 weeks? Rudin, of course, is no stranger to controversy or hard feelings, and the playâ€™s less-than-happy ending might have dampened word-of-mouth, but the playwright, the cast and the director deserved a heartier Broadway embrace. Little Bear Ridge Road ranks right up there with Dead Outlaw in recent theaterâ€™s gone-too-soon territory.

Little Bear Ridge Road played at the Booth Theatre from October 7 to December 21, 2025

8) Purpose

The Broadway cast of â€˜Purposeâ€™ Marc J. Franklin

A Cat on a Hot Tin Roof for the 21st century, Brandon Jacobs-Jenkinsâ€™ Pulitzer- and Tony-winning Purpose examined the inner workings and emotional fine points of a Black family presided over by its civil rights hero patriarch and his tougher-than-she-would-seem wife. Seemingly based ever-so-loosely on Jesse Jackson and his sometimes errant namesake son, Purpose exposed the concept of familial legacy and obligation for the fragile deceptions they so often are. With Phylicia Rashad staking her claim as a Broadway director of high order, Purpose boasted a cast that more than met the emotional challenges laid out by Jacobs-Jenkins: LaTanya Richardson, Harry Lennix, Jon Michael Hill, Alana Arenas (in a remarkable Broadway debut), Glenn Davis Solomon and the invaluable Kara Young made for an ensemble that wonâ€™t soon be forgotten.

Purpose played at the Hayes Theatre from February 25 through August 31, 2025

9) Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York)

Christiani Pitts and Sam Tutty in â€˜Two Strangers (Carry A Cake Across New York)â€™ Matthew Murphy

Iâ€™m still not convinced that title did anything for box office, but this charming British import by Jim Barne and Kit Buchan, directed and choreographed by Tim Jackson, would seem capable of rising above just about anything. Starring Christiani Pitts and Sam Tutty (in a winning performance that gives Jasmine Amy Rogers of Boop! and Louis McCartney of Stranger Things: The First Shadow some real competition for best Broadway debut of the season), Two Strangers is that surprisingly rare creature: a romantic comedy that actually works on stage. Need proof of such rarity: Recall the boredom and the cringe of The Last Five Years and The Notebook.

Pitts and Tutty play a soon-to-be aunt and her nephew (a Broadway trend in the making? See Little Bear Ridge Road) who meet when young and puppy-dogish Englishman Dougal Todd arrives in New York to attend the wedding of his long-estranged dad to a much younger woman. The brideâ€™s New York-jaded sister Robin (the terrific Pitts) arrives at the airport to greet and schlep the wide-eyed Dougal. They meet cute (thatâ€™s where the cake comes into play), she bristles, he fawns, and pretty soon theyâ€™re ripping off that creepy dad and heading to a happy ending the audience has long seen coming. But do they? No spoilers here, but Tutty, Pitts and all concerned with the modestly staged Two Strangers are worthy of whatever good comes their way.

Two Strangers (Carry a Cake Across New York) is playing at the Longacre Theatre

10) Stranger Things: The First Shadow

Louis McCartney in â€˜Stranger Things: The First Shadowâ€™ Manuel Harlan

You donâ€™t have to follow Netflixâ€™s Stranger Things â€“ or, in my case, even particularly like it â€“ to fall under the big-spectacle spell of Broadwayâ€™s Stranger Things: The First Shadow. A prequel to the goings-on in the seriesâ€™ bedeviled Hawkins, Indiana, First Shadow brings something even scarcer on Broadway than romantic comedy (see Two Strangers, above): Honest-to-Vecna scares. Taking what struck me as a more grown-up, less Scooby Doo-ish pitch to the material than the seriesâ€™ Young Adult leanings, First Shadow, written by Kate Trefry from a story by herself, the Duffer Brothers and Jack Thorne, brings technical achievement and a thrilling panache to a medium not exactly hospitable to the horror genre. Carrie tried and failed. So did Grey House and King Kong and Dracula and Jekyll & Hyde. First Shadow, led by the impressive newcomer Louis McCartney as a pre-Vecna Henry Creel, just might open the door to a parallel universe where stage fright has a whole new meaning.

Stranger Things: The First Shadow is playing at the Marquis Theatre

Honorable Mentions

Jonathan Gross in â€˜Just In Timeâ€™ Matthew Murphy and Evan Zimmerman

Top 10 lists have to make cuts somewhere, so sincere apologies to Buena Vista Social Club, English, Just in Time, Oedipus, Waiting for Godot, The Picture Of Dorian Gray and the casts of Art (James Corden in particular), Call Me Izzy (Jean Smart, gripping), Floyd Collins (Jeremy Jordan, proving his Broadway mettle yet again) and Boop! (Jasmine Amy Rogers, rising high above the material).

Broadway 2025 Misses

Kristin Chenoweth in â€˜The Queen of Versaillesâ€ Julieta Cervantes

Some were mere almost-there disappointments, some outright flops, but a survey of Broadwayâ€™s less-than-successful 2025 offerings should include:

The Last Five Years â€” Starring Nick Jonas and a deserves-better Adrienne Warren. Five years? Nah, it only seemed that long.

Glengarry Glen Ross â€” It wasnâ€™t terrible, but with a cast that included Culkin, Bob Odenkirk, Michael McKean and Bill Burr, the David Mamet classic should have soared to the rhythms of the playwrightâ€™s language.

Good Night, and Good Luck â€” It was a monster money-maker, but câ€™mon, Clooney could have played Betty Boop and audiences would have lined up for the privilege. Imagine if Clooney had chosen to use his star power to spotlight a genuinely worthy project â€” the way, say, Sarah Paulson did with Appropriate or Keanu Reeves is doing with Waiting For Godot â€” rather than the stuffy, moribund, on-the-nose hectoring that was Good Night, and Good Luck? The same, actually, could be said of Washington, whose somber performance in the modern-dress Othello did nothing that hasnâ€™t been done in any number of Shakespeare in the Parkâ€™s lesser offerings.

The Queen of Versailles â€” Oh, please. It had nothing to do with Kristin Chenowethâ€™s kind words for a slain right-winger. The musical is just plain tedious, full of forgettable songs, muddled intentions and dumb-to-the-point-of-surreal ancien rÃ©gime flashbacks. Iâ€™m still not sure if this musical even likes Jackie Siegel, its subject-turned-investor, and I was paying attention. Thereâ€™s a lesson in there somewhere, and its not about gilded ambition or lousy parenting or money canâ€™t buy happiness. Maybe its about deep pockets and artistic compromise and wanting to be liked so intensely that you lose any chance for a Roseâ€™s Turn all your own. And maybe someone, someday, will make a musical about it.

Chess â€” While audiences seem to like it, reviews were mostly mixed. Lea Michele, Aaron Tveit and Nicholas Christopher are certainly and without a doubt very, very loud (except, oddly enough, at the exact moment you want volume â€” Tveit gets all but drowned out by the orchestra during the big, indecipherable â€œOne Night In Bangkok.â€) Mostly this revival of the 1980s flop from Benny Andersson, BjÃ¶rn Ulvaeus and Tim Rice, with Danny Strongâ€™s new book crammed with inelegant topical references, seems to exist mostly to give reviewers the chance to offer some variation of â€œclose, but no checkmate.â€

A Look Ahead To 2026

â€˜Cats: The Jellicle Ballâ€™ Off Broadway Matthew Murphy and Evan Zimmerman

Thereâ€™s some promising stuff waiting in the Broadway wings, not the least of which is Tracy Lettsâ€™ Bug (starring Carrie Coon and Namir Smallwood); Daniel Radcliffâ€™s stage return in Every Brilliant Thing; John Lithgowâ€™s turn as Roald Dahl in Giant; and Gina Gionfriddoâ€™s Becky Shaw starring Patrick Ball, Alden Ehrenreich and Linda Emond. Two revivals will boast some intriguing pairings: Arthur Millerâ€™s Death of a Salesman will team Nathan Lane with Laurie Metcalf and director Joe Mantello, and Ayo Edebiri and Don Cheadle co-star in David Auburnâ€™s Proof. Acclaimed Off Broadway treasures Cats: The Jellicle Ball and Titanique should lend some downtown elan to midtown, while Schmigadoon! hopes to tap into the cult appeal of the Apple TV series.

Roundaboutâ€™s Fallen Angels, pairing Broadway icon Kelli Oâ€™Hara with Broadway iconic to infinity NoÃ«l Coward, had me at hello, and Manhattan Theatre Clubâ€™s The Balusters, marking the Broadway returns of the great David Lindsay-Abaire (Kimberly Akimbo) and director Kenny Leon, boasts the kind of rock-solid stage cast â€” Marylouise Burke, Margaret Colin, Michael Esper, RenÃ©e Elise Goldsberry, Richard Thomas â€” that is the fever dream of every nonprofit theater company.

Then thereâ€™s the upcoming Beaches musical (no judgments), director Sam Pinkletonâ€™s Oh, Mary! follow-up a Rocky Horror Show revival, and the Broadway debut of Taraji P. Henson in Joe Turnerâ€™s Come and Gone.

But Iâ€™d be lying if I said my interest isnâ€™t perhaps most piqued by what at first glance seems an irresistibly kooky premise: a Dog Day Afternoon stage adaptation starring Jon Bernthal (respect for anyone tackling Al Pacinoâ€™s â€œAttica! Atticaâ€ chant) and The Bearâ€˜s Ebon Moss-Bachrach. And then thereâ€™s another screen-to-stage project in The Lost Boys, which has the opportunity to follow in the horror footsteps of Stranger Things: The First Shadow. Movies have a rocky history of being relocated to the stage, to be sure, but this vampire project boasts an intriguing team in director Michael Arden (Maybe Happy Ending), music and lyrics by indie rockers The Rescues, a producing team that includes actor Patrick Wilson, and a cast that features, among others, Hellâ€™s Kitchenâ€˜s Shoshana Bean, Tommyâ€˜s Ali Louis Bourzgui and young Benjamin Pajak, one of the most promising young actors to hit Broadway in years. Before starring opposite Tom Hiddleston and Mark Hamill in the Mike Flanagan film The Life of Chuck, Pajak all but stole Broadwayâ€™s The Music Man revival from adults Hugh Jackman and Sutton Foster, and wowed Encores! audiences with his powerhouse, crystal-clear vocals as the title character in 2023â€™s Oliver! revival.

title: Netflixâ€™s Lions-Vikings Leads NFL Christmas Day Audiences; Prime Video Trails With Chiefs-Broncos But Sets â€˜Thursday Night Footballâ€™ Record
summary: Netflix and Amazon jingled all the way to some big audiences on Christmas Day, thanks to the NFL. The most-watched game of the holiday proved to be the mid-afternoon Lions-Vikings match up on Netflix, which secured 27.5M live + same-day U.S. viewers according to Nielsen Big Data + Panel. This includes out-of-home viewing, CBS local […]
content:
Netflix and Amazon jingled all the way to some big audiences on Christmas Day, thanks to the NFL.

The most-watched game of the holiday proved to be the mid-afternoon Lions-Vikings match up on Netflix, which secured 27.5M live + same-day U.S. viewers according to Nielsen Big Data + Panel. This includes out-of-home viewing, CBS local market viewing, NFL+, and mobile and web viewing across Netflix.

Thatâ€™s pretty much on par with, and in fact just slightly higher than, the streamerâ€™s Ravens-Texans telecast last year. Nielsen also says that U.S. viewership for this yearâ€™s game peaked at just over 30M viewers.

Globally, Netflix says that based on first party data, the Lions-Vikings garnered an average minute audience of 30.5M in Live + 1.

Watch on Deadline

There was no BeyoncÃ© Bowl this year, but there was Snoopâ€™s Holiday Halftime Party. Snoop Doggâ€™s performance averaged 29M viewers in the U.S., per Nielsen.

Earlier in the day, the Cowboys-Commanders game averaged 19.9M U.S. viewers, Nielsen says. Netflix adds that the L+1 global average minute audience for this game came in around 22.4M. This was a bit of a slower start to the day than last year, when more than 25M U.S. viewers tuned in for Chiefs-Steelers to kick things off.

While there were only two games last year, both hosted by Netflix, the NFL threw a third game in at primetime this year, which went to Prime Videoâ€˜s .

Amazon got the Chiefs this year, although this time around the team suffered a disappointing loss to the Denver Broncos that was watched by 21.06M U.S. viewers, according to Nielsen.

That puts it in second place among the Christmas Day matchups, but it is actually the most-watched Thursday Night Football regular season game ever for Prime Video, eclipsing the previous record setter, Cowboys-Lions game earlier in the month, by about 2M viewers.

Broncos-Chiefs also attracted a record high peak audience for TNF on Prime ever with 22.9M viewers at the top of the 9 p.m. ET hour.

As with last year, all three of these matchups had U.S. audiences that were a tad lower than the usual broadcast viewership that the NFL has attracted in years past on Christmas Day. In 2023, a Chiefs-Raiders game became the most-watched Christmas Day regular-season game ever with 29.2M viewers. The Eagles-Giants also took home 29M that day, while the 49ers-Ravens managed 27.1M.

The difference maker tends to be Netflixâ€™s global audience, which helps the streamer tack on a few million additional viewers. While that helped bridge the gap for Lions-Vikings, boosting it just over these totals, it didnâ€™t do much for Cowboys-Commanders, where U.S. viewership was down quote significantly.

For Netflix, this was year two of a three-year deal with the NFL to broadcast NFL football games on Christmas Day. Under the deal, the streamer gets at least one game each year. Christmas falls on a Friday rather than a Thursday in 2026, so Prime Video is unlikely to host again. However, whether that means a game will default back to broadcast or find a home on another streamer remains to be seen.

title: Jesse Plemons Reveals What He Really Thought Of Landryâ€™s â€˜Friday Night Lightsâ€™ Murder Plotline
summary: Jesse Plemons is revealing his hesitation about a Friday Night Lights storyline in which his character Landry committed murder. It happened in the second season of the show when his character Landry Clarke and Adrianne Palicki’s Tyra Collette are seen talking at a gas station and Tyra is appoached by her stalker who attempts to […]
content:
Jesse Plemons is revealing his hesitation about a Friday Night Lights storyline in which his character Landry committed murder.

It happened in the second season of the show when his character Landry Clarke and Adrianne Palickiâ€™s Tyra Collette are seen talking at a gas station and Tyra is appoached by her stalker who attempts to assault her. Landry immediately comes to Tyraâ€™s defense and smashes the guyâ€™s head with a pipe. The stalker dies on the way to the hospital and Landry and Tyra, in a panic, then dump his body into the river.

In an appearance on Entertainment Weeklyâ€™s The Awardist podcast, Plemons said he was â€œpretty shockedâ€ when the storyline was revealed.



â€œThey didnâ€™t tell me that something bad was gonna happen or I was going to be killed off or something, so I wasnâ€™t worried about that,â€ he said. â€œBut it was kind of a double-edged sword because on the one hand, I was as shocked as everyone to read that script where the comedic relief kills for love in high school. But at the same time, I donâ€™t think I could allow myself to question it too much, because it was happening.â€

Plemons also noted that the series had a high â€œlevel of realism,â€ making it even harder to pull off a â€œreally extreme storyline that does not seem too rooted in something realisticâ€. He said he also wondered, â€œHow am I going to not sink the show with this and try and keep it as real as everything else?â€

Watch on Deadline

Plemons also said they settled on using the pipe as a murder weapon, after trying several other options.

â€œI did end up killing him multiple times with bottles and then we reshot it with a pipe or something,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s a weird, weird, weird thing we do.â€

Eventually, both Landry and Tyra were cleared of the crime and by Season 3, the plotline had been dropped.

Plemons, who can currently be seen in awards contender Bugonia, starred on all five seasons of the show, which aired from 2006-2011.

title: The Best Concerts of 2025
summary: Some pop fans might have gone into 2025 anticipating a year’s worth of the shakes, suffering from Eras Tour withdrawal. But there was no need for anyone to go cold turkey on live music these past 12 months â€” not when there were major tours from contemporary chart-toppers like BeyoncÃ©, Lady Gaga, Dua Lipa, the […]
content: Not to make this into some kind of AARP tract, but: Are there any figures in American music more inspirational than these two? It was true when they were still mere sprouts of, like, 64 and 72, but all the more so now that they are seriously defying gravity at 84 (for Dylan) and 92 (for Nelson). They played the Hollywood Bowl as a stop on their Outlaw Music Festival tour, just as they had the summer before. They may count as half of a living Mount Rushmore of music, but they are not up there just as the objects of your national-monument tourist gaze: They are embracing the spirit of each nightâ€™s moment in an accomplished and downright frisky way that most younger achievers can only aspire toward. (Although, to give credit where itâ€™s due, most of the younger acts theyâ€™ve picked as openers, like Billy Strings and Sierra Hull at the Bowl, seem like the type of kids who can and will absorb these lessons.) Dylan is still rearranging his classics, but in a fashion that seems particularly crowd-pleasing now â€” youâ€™ll enjoy that your favorite song of his suddenly sounds more like a Dire Straits or Johnny Cash classic. Willie doesnâ€™t mess with the material much, of course, but that doesnâ€™t make his ability to pull off transcendent acoustic guitar solos any less absorbing. â€”Willman

title: Media Stocks Winners & Losers In 2025: WBD Rides M&A Wave, EchoStar Jumps On SpaceX Speculation
summary: On Wall Street, speculation is often the sincerest form of flattery. That’s what the media and entertainment sector experienced in 2025, with Warner Bros Discovery shares surging 170% due to investor theorizing about the upside of the company’s acquisition by either Netflix or Paramount. EchoStar, meanwhile, started the year by merging with sister company Dish […]
content:
On Wall Street, speculation is often the sincerest form of flattery.

Thatâ€™s what the media and entertainment sector experienced in 2025, with Warner Bros Discovery shares surging 170% due to investor theorizing about the upside of the companyâ€™s acquisition by either Netflix or Paramount. EchoStar, meanwhile, started the year by merging with sister company Dish Network and ended it with its stock on a tear, up 370% for the year, due to a deal upping its stake in Elon Muskâ€™s SpaceX. (Speculation has been widespread that SpaceX could go public in 2026 in what could be the biggest IPO in history.)

Those are only the biggest winners, of course. On the other side of the coin, Comcast shares slumped 20% amid concerns about its stagnating broadband business. Angel Studios, the Sound of Freedom distributor that went public last September, saw its shares plunge 53% from that point, with other big declines registered by Trump Media & Technology Group, movie theater giant AMC Entertainment, digital publisher BuzzFeed and right-wing social media firm Rumble.

Watch on Deadline

Not quite making the chart but leaving an impression on the marketplace were Charter Communications (-39%) and Terrifier 3 distributor Cineverse, which slipped 44%. Spotify, Roku and Reddit registered gains of between 25% and 45%.

Along with Angel, other new ticker symbols joined the establishment over the past year, with Lionsgate executing a long-in-development split. The transaction created a new public entity for the companyâ€™s film and TV studio as well as a new stock for Starz. The latter had one of the best performances in the sector, rising 45% since its debut last spring.

Paramount, which is a reconstituted company with a new ticker symbol after last summerâ€™s merger with Skydance, jumped 28% as investors processed the depth of its resources amid the WBD chase. Larry Ellison, the co-founder of Oracle and one of the richest people in the world, is a key financial backer of Paramount and the proposal to acquire WBD.

Among the other comings and goings: pay-TV and broadband provider Altice USA rebranded as Optimum, changing its ticker symbol. And ad agency giant Interpublic and ad tech firm Innovid were both acquired, leading to their stocks to stop trading.

One noteworthy fact about the year in stocks is that Apple and Amazon, tech giants with significant relevance to the entertainment sector, notched only single-digit gains. That progress was far more limited than the leaps forward by Nvidia (+39%) and other players in the AI race, which drove stock markets to new records. Google and YouTube parent Alphabet was one exception, making Deadlineâ€™s ranking of top gainers (+65%), due to traction by its Gemini AI platform and continued momentum for YouTubeâ€™s ad business.

Among the other entertainment giants, Netflix and Disney also both registered single-digit gains, rising 5% and 2%, respectively. Netflix last fall set a 10-for-1 split of its shares, with the goal of making its highflying stock more affordable.

The local TV sector saw a halo effect from repeated pronouncement from government officials, industry trade groups and executives that the longtime cap on station ownership would soon be eliminated. Nexstar, which has a pending deal to acquire rival Tegna, saw its stock gain 30% on the year, with smaller competitors E.W. Scripps and Gray Media also jumping (140% and 55%, respectively). Sinclair, whose unsolicited bid for Scripps was rebuffed, gave back 5% on the year.

content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers for the series finale of â€œStranger Things,â€ now streaming on Netflix.



â€œStranger Thingsâ€ has come to an end.

The horror-fantasy sensation, which started as a modest â€™80s pastiche in 2016 and quickly became a Netflix juggernaut, has ended with a plus-sized series finale written and directed by show creators The Duffer Brothers. Below, find a breakdown of what happened during the last episode.

Eleven made it out alive!

It looked like Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown) sacrificed herself when the bomb detonated, destroying the Upside Down and effectively closing the bridge for evil to appear. She even had one last kiss with Mike (Finn Wolfhard), and all of her friends and loved ones mourned. But surprise! Her sister Kali (Linnea Berthelsen) actually cast one last spell to create a fake Eleven, so it only looked like she died. In the end, per Mikeâ€™s estimation, Eleven is safe and sound on a beautiful hike, far away from anyone looking to harvest her blood.

Popular on Variety

Both Vecna and the Mind Flayer appear to be dead.

As Eleven and Vecna (Jamie Campbell Bower) battled inside the enormous Mind Flayer, the rest of the Hawkins crew shot at and fought the big beast. Once Will (Noah Schnapp) jumped into Vecnaâ€™s mind to assist Eleven, both baddies â€” who, according to Henry (also Jamie Campbell Bower), are one and the same â€” received too many blows and were taken down. Joyce (Winona Ryder) delivered the final strike, beheading Vecna with an axe. Bonus: The little kids were saved, too!

Kali is killed.

Lt. Robert Akers (Alex Breaux) got off a shot at Kali right before Murray (Brett Gelman) caused a distraction by blowing up the helicopter. After this, Eleven killed all of the military men, and then took over Akersâ€™ mind to make him shoot himself in the head.

Henry Creelâ€™s traumatizing cave memory is revealed.

It turns out that after killing the mystery man, Henry watched his younger self open the briefcase as a piece inside leaps out into his hand. Turns out the Mind Flayer didnâ€™t want Henry to remember that he used him as a vessel to get to Hawkins â€” just as Will was a vessel for Henry. Henry disputed this, though, saying that he and the Mind Flayer were one and the same.

18 months post-Vecna, things in Hawkins are pretty much back to normal.

The catastrophic events may have been swept under the rug as an earthquake, but at least thereâ€™s a memorial! We catch up with our crew after a time jump on high school graduation day. Max (Sadie Sink) is skateboarding and making out with Lucas (Caleb McLaughlin). Hopper (David Harbour) is playing stepfather duties to Joyce and her kids, but takes time to comfort Mike, whoâ€™s still grieving El. Plus, Dustin (Gaten Matarazzo) is valedictorian, and, of course, his speech is all about â€œDungeons & Dragons.â€

Steve (Joe Keery) is now a high school sex-ed teacher and baseball coach â€” and Derek (Jake Connell) is a catcher on the team. In other news, Nancy (Natalia Dyer) dropped out of Emerson for a journalism job, Robin (Maya Hawke) is studying at Smith and Jonathan (Charlie Heaton) is working on a movie at NYU film school.

After graduation day, Hopper proposes to Joyce and suggests they move to Montauk, where he got a new job offer, and they could have a fresh start. Meanwhile, Mike, Max, Dustin, Lucas and Will skip an invite to a graduation party in order to play a D&D campaign that has a bittersweet ending which mirrors their own futures: Will heads to the big city and starts dating; Max and Lucas stay together; Dustin goes to college but still hangs out with Steve; and Mike becomes an author.

The last scene finds Mike watching as Holly (Nell Fisher), Derek and their friends start up their own D&D campaign.

Mike apologizes for not saying something earlier about Will coming out.

It was sweet to see Mike comforting Will at the top of the episode. Nothing will get between these two buds!

Steve and Jonathan make nice.

Steve and Jonathan let bygones be bygones, and both agree that neither is the right man for Nancy.

Holly finally had her heroic moment by leading the kids to the cave.

Holly felt so guilty about not helping her mother, Karen (Cara Buono), and not being brave at other points, but she made up for it in this episode.

Unlike most blockbusters these days, there is no mid- or post-credits scene.

Things are quiet in Hawkinsâ€¦for now!

title: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™: Who Lives, Who Dies In Series Finale

content:
SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from the series finale of Stranger Things.

Stranger Things has officially come to an end after an emotional two-hour finale on New Yearâ€™s Eve.

Itâ€™s been a decade in the making, and throughout the final season, creators Matt and Ross Duffer have sought to answer all the questions about the Upside Down and the supernatural horrors that have been plaguing Hawkins, Indiana, since November 6, 1983. The finale kicks off right where Episode 7, â€œThe Bridge,â€ ended on a cliffhanger with the characters set to face Vecna (Jamie Campbell Bower) for one final battle.

The plan was to attack him from all angles, inside his mind and also physically from inside the Abyss. The group runs into quite a few set backs but ultimately prevail, managing to defeat Vecna and the Mind Flayer.

Watch on Deadline

So, does everyone make it out alive?

The short answer is: We think so.

As soon as the crew leaves the Upside Down, they are confronted by the military. Hopper (David Harbour) and Murray (Brett Gelman) have already set the timers on the detonators, so the whole bridge is going to come crashing down soon.

As theyâ€™re getting apprehended, Mike (Finn Wolfhard) notices Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown) is missing. He spots her standing just inside the gate to the Upside Down and tries to run to her but is held back by a soldier. El piggybacks Mike into her mind for an emotional goodbye as she explains that she needs to sacrifice herself in order for everyone else to be safe, otherwise the government will never stop their experiments.

She forces Mike out of her void in the middle of his pleas for her to reconsider her choice, just as the bombs detonate and the Upside Down collapses.

But wait â€” months later, we see Mike, Will (Noah Schnapp), Dustin (Gaten Matarazzo), Max (Sadie Sink) and Lucas (Caleb McLaughlin) graduate from high school. After graduation, theyâ€™re finishing up a Dungeons and Dragons campaign when Mike tells his friends a theory he has about their mage (which is what he used to call Eleven), who just helped save them from defeat. He theorizes that she didnâ€™t actually sacrifice herself. As heâ€™s explaining his theory, the episode flashes back to the moment the Upside Down collapsed.

This time, it shows Eleven escape with the help of her sister Kali (Linnea Berthelsen), who uses her powers to play one last mind trick on everyone before she dies inside the Upside Down. She makes everyone think El is standing inside the gate, when in reality sheâ€™s escaped into the tunnels and gotten away. The screen then cuts to El on a hike somewhere in a mountain range as Mike says he believes their mage stumbled upon a small, faraway town to hide in.

Catching on to Mikeâ€™s implications about their friend, Max and the rest of the group are a bit skeptical, wondering how they might know if itâ€™s true. Mike says theyâ€™ll never know for sure, but they can choose to believe like he does. They take turns vowing, â€œI believeâ€ around the table.

So, if we take this at face value, then that means Eleven actually did make it out alive. It all depends on what you believe.

Oh, and thankfully the Duffers also confirmed that Ted Wheeler (Joe Chrest) is alive and well. It was up in the air after the Demogorgon took him out inside his home in Volume 1. Weâ€™d since seen Karen Wheeler (Cara Buono), but we wondered whether the weâ€™d get to lay eyes on Ted again.

Despite some close calls during their face off with Vecna and the Mind Flayer, the rest of the main characters manage to survive as well.

content:
Chinaâ€˜s theatrical market staged a robust recovery in 2025, with total box office reaching RMB51.83 billion ($7.41 billion) and admissions climbing to 1.24 billion â€“ both representing year-over-year increases exceeding 20%, according to a new report from Maoyan Entertainmentâ€™s research division.

In 2024, the China box office plummeted 23% to $5.8 billion. The 2025 rebound was fueled primarily by animated titles and IP-driven franchises, with 57 animated films generating over RMB25 billion ($3.57 billion) in revenue â€“ representing nearly half of the yearâ€™s total gross. Leading the charge were local sequel â€œNe Zha 2â€ ($2.13 billion) and Disneyâ€™s â€œZootopia 2â€ ($558.3 million), which delivered exceptional box office performance.

The Maoyan Research Instituteâ€™s â€œInsight Report on 2025 Chinaâ€™s Box Office Film Data,â€ highlighted animationâ€™s outsized impact on the marketâ€™s growth trajectory.

Popular on Variety

IP strength proved particularly potent in the animation sector, with select franchises recording significantly higher rewatch rates than market averages. â€œNe Zha 2â€ achieved the yearâ€™s highest rewatch ratio, while â€œZootopia 2â€ and other popular titles demonstrated sustained fan engagement and loyalty.

The report revealed increasing market concentration around tentpole releases. Among 2025â€™s top 10 new films, four surpassed RMB3 billion ($429 million) at the box office and eight crossed the RMB1 billion ($143 million) threshold. Local productions captured a slightly larger market share compared to 2024, though the number of local films grossing over RMB1 billion remained steady year-over-year.

However, mid-tier local releases faced challenges, with films earning between RMB100-500 million ($14.3 million-$71.5 million) and RMB500 million-1 billion ($71.5 million-$143 million) showing marked declines, underscoring the marketâ€™s growing polarization toward blockbuster projects.

Lower-tier cities emerged as crucial growth engines, with third- and fourth-tier marketsâ€™ box office contributions reaching a five-year high in 2025, marking three consecutive years of expansion. The proportion of first-time and infrequent moviegoers also increased, broadening cinemaâ€™s audience reach.

Local productions shifted away from sweeping narratives toward stories reflecting everyday life, employing diverse visual styles and genres to meet varied audience preferences. Meanwhile, imported superhero franchises experienced notable declines, suggesting these properties require fresh creative approaches to maintain market appeal.

â€œIn 2025, several key holiday release windows outperformed expectations thanks to the support of breakout hits, setting multiple new records and delivering pleasant surprises to both the industry and audiences,â€ said Maoyan Entertainment market analyst Lai Li. â€œThe traditional â€˜blockbuster model,â€™ in its classic sense, is no longer a guaranteed formula for box office success, offering new lessons for market participants.â€

Looking toward 2026, Lai emphasized the industry must continue refining its content pipeline, attracting diverse audience segments with high-quality films combining popularity, strong word-of-mouth, and freshness to unlock further growth potential.

title: Chevy Chase Was â€˜Depressedâ€™ After His Fox Late-Night Show Was Canceled After 6 Weeks: â€˜He Would Get in Bed and Not Come Outâ€™
summary: A brief chapter in Chevy Chase’s illustrious comedy career is his ill-fated late-night talk series “The Chevy Chase Show,” which ran on Fox for six weeks in 1993 and was cancelled after scathing reviews and low ratings. In the new CNN documentary “I’m Chevy Chase and You’re Not,” Chase opens up about his experience hosting […]
content:
A brief chapter in Chevy Chaseâ€˜s illustrious comedy career is his ill-fated late-night talk series â€œThe Chevy Chase Show,â€ which ran on Fox for six weeks in 1993 and was cancelled after scathing reviews and low ratings.

In the new CNN documentary â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Not,â€ Chase opens up about his experience hosting a talk show â€” and the disappointment that followed. â€œI never took anybodyâ€™s advice about how to do a talk show. I can do it, I kept thinking,â€ he said in the doc. â€œIt was hideous. I just didnâ€™t really have a sense of what you do on a talk show.â€

Chaseâ€™s representatives and collaborators explained in the documentary that the show, which debuted Sept. 7, 1993, failed because it had â€œold-timeâ€ TV producers and needed a new vision. Plus, while Chase was a gifted comedic actor and movie star, he was less skilled in stand-up comedy.

Popular on Variety

Chaseâ€™s eldest daughter, Cydney, remembered visiting her dad on set of the talk show. â€œHe felt nervous to me,â€ she said.

Andy Aaron, a writer on â€œThe Chevy Chase Show,â€ recounted, â€œThe reviews were universally terrible, and Chevy literally would come into the writers room and say, â€˜You guys are doing a great job. It is not your fault, it is my fault.'â€

â€œI donâ€™t know how people like Letterman and others do it,â€ Chase said. â€œItâ€™s beyond me. You can say, â€˜Well, itâ€™s interesting to have different peopleâ€¦â€™ Yeah right. Weâ€™re all the same, pretty much. Itâ€™s not that interesting.â€

The staff found out the show had been pulled by Fox at the end of Chevyâ€™s 50th birthday party. CAA leader Michael Ovitz, Chaseâ€™s agent at the time, asked him if he wanted to go a couple more weeks. â€œâ€˜Couple of weeks?â€˜â€ Chase recalled in mock surprise. â€œI think weâ€™re finished.â€

Chaseâ€™s daughters talked about Chaseâ€™s mental health struggles after the seriesâ€™ cancellation. â€œIt was kind of a weird environment after his talk show,â€ said Cydney Chase. â€œI know my dad has been depressed. I knew that at a young age. That was sort of hard for me because I would go in and, like, tug on his shirt and heâ€™d say, â€˜Not now, honey.'â€

Chaseâ€™s daughter Caley added, â€œOne thing that was interesting about our household is that my parents were pretty open with some of the things going on that were deeper, depending on our ages. My parents were communicating enough to say, â€˜Thereâ€™s something called depression, and it is hard for people to get out of bed.'â€

â€œHe would get in bed and not come out,â€ added Chaseâ€™s wife, Jayni. â€œI didnâ€™t understand why.â€

Chase would go on to star in a handful of films after the talk show ended, and eventually he would have a career resurgence playing Pierce Hawthorne on the sitcom â€œCommunity,â€ which ran from 2009 to 2014 on NBC.

In 1993, â€œThe Chevy Chase Showâ€ arrived in a moment of frenzy around late-night television. Johnny Carsonâ€™s retirement from â€œThe Tonight Showâ€ one year earlier opened up opportunities, and Arsenio Hall was already hosting a successful, syndicated late-night yakker, â€œArsenio,â€ which was an immediate draw with younger, multicultural viewers in big cities. Distributed by Paramount, â€œArsenioâ€ was the first competitor to go up against Carson that stuck around and made a dent in his audience.

The Fox network saw â€œArsenioâ€™sâ€ success and decided to take a swing with a late-night show. It marked Foxâ€™s second attempt to establish a foothold in late-night. In October 1986, Fox Broadcasting Co. was born when it tapped Joan Rivers to host â€œThe Late Showâ€ in the hopes of taking on Carson with one of his longtime guest hosts. But Riversâ€™ show had a rocky run and was axed by May 1987. It was replaced briefly by the offbeat, proto-â€œDaily Showâ€ newsmagazine-style â€œThe Wilton North Report.â€ That show lasted about three months. After that, Fox was out of late-night, turning its focus to primetime and finding traction with hits like â€œMarried With Childrenâ€ and â€œ21 Jump Street.â€

Five years later, Carsonâ€™s retirement set off the Leno vs. Letterman battle that ended in Leno taking â€œThe Tonight Showâ€ throne and Letterman moving on to launch a new franchise on CBS. Lettermanâ€™s â€œThe Late Showâ€ launched on CBS with great fanfare on Aug. 30, 1993, after Letterman famously had to wait out the rest of his contract as host of NBCâ€™s post-â€œTonight Showâ€ hour, â€œLate Night With David Letterman.â€ (The open slot at â€œLate Nightâ€ eventually went to Conan Oâ€™Brien, who was famously renewed in six-week increments in his first few months.)

So into this mix came Chase to do battle against Leno and Letterman, who were both revved up to prove themselves as the top-dog in the time slot. The whole fracas was quickly dubbed â€œthe late-night warsâ€ in media and pop culture.

Even though it was short-lived, the arrival of Chaseâ€™s show as a Fox network offering spelled the end for Hallâ€™s show in syndication. Thatâ€™s because a number of the stations that carried Hallâ€™s show in major markets were Fox affiliates. A new documentary from CNN offers an unvarnished look at one of the most polarizing figures in comedy: Chevy Chase. â€œIâ€™m Chevy Chase and Youâ€™re Notâ€ premieres on CNN on Thursday, Jan. 1.

Cable-cutters can stream the documentary online through a variety of Live TV streamers with access to CNN, such as DirecTV, Sling TV and Hulu + Live TV.

Directed by Marina Zenovich, the CNN Films project arrives amid renewed scrutiny of Chaseâ€™s career and conduct, including his fraught exits â€œfrom Saturday Night Liveâ€ and â€œCommunity,â€ as well as personal health-related revelations, including that he was put into a coma for eight days during the pandemic after experiencing heart failure. The film â€” which traces Chaseâ€™s rise as a foundational figure of modern TV â€” includes interviews with dozens of the 82 year-old comedianâ€™s personal and professional connections such as his daughter Caley Chase and â€œCommunityâ€ creator Jay Chandrasekhar, who reveals in the doc that he was on set the night that Chase got fired.

The documentary is highly anticipated not only because of its long-awaited Hollywood revelations but also because Chaseâ€™s infamous attitude made the idea of him collaborating with a director â€” and letting go of all editorial control â€” feel like an impossibility. Until Zenovich came along.

â€œIâ€™d never done an interview where someone was so rude to me,â€ Zenovich told Variety last month. â€œBut I was so worried going into that first interview with him about how I was going to say to him, like, â€˜Everyone thinks youâ€™re an asshole.â€™ I thought if I did, he would throw me out of his house. So the minute he said that to me, I had a way in.â€

â€œI wanted to figure out who was the real person behind the conflicted, guarded and somewhat fragile man we see on camera,â€ she continued. â€œWhat was behind the surface of his slightly intimidating superstar bravado? Was there any self-awareness there? Having interviewed Chevy at length, I have to say that yes, itâ€™s all there â€“ and a whole lot of pain and heartache too.â€

title: John Mulrooney Dies: Stand-Up Comedian, TV Host, Radio Personality & NY Cop Was 67
summary: John Mulrooney, a stand-up comedian, actor, TV host, radio personality and longtime local cop, died suddenly at his Coxsackie, New York home, according to multiple reports. He was 67. content:
John Mulrooney, a stand-up comedian, actor, TV host, radio personality and longtime local cop, died suddenly at his Coxsackie, New York home, according to multiple reports. He was 67.

Born and raised in Brooklyn, Mulrooney was best known as a stand-up comic. He made his name performing at The Improv, The Comedy Store, The Comic Strip and The Laugh Factory.

Andrew Dice Clay took to Instagram to remember what made his friend special.

â€œCrowd Work was his thing long before it became a thing,â€ wrote Clay of Mulrooneyâ€™s talent for engaging with and doing bits about the audience.

Clay recalled seeing Mulrooney at Pips Comedy Club In Brooklyn, where they both started.

â€œThe owners Marty and Seth told me to watch him. He was really amazing at it,â€ wrote Clay.

To Mulrooney, crowd work was akin to cooking a meal.

â€œI look at the audience as a spice rack,â€ Mulrooney said in 2010. â€œI know Iâ€™m gonna make a great meal; Iâ€™m just not sure of the ingredients yet.â€

Adam Sandler once told Joe Rogan that Mulrooney was one of the stand-up performers â€œyou didnâ€™t want to go after.â€

Remembered Sandler, â€œMulrooney would just destroy a room. He was so loose and could dominate the room.â€

Clay pointed out that, just because Mulrooney never achieved the same level of fame as he and Sandler did, Mulrooney was still great at what he did.

â€œHe was the last comedian to come out of that club that everybody thought would become a really really big star! Johnny was tall, good looking, An ex Boxer â€¦ he also had the ingredientsâ€¦ The discipline to get up there every night, the drive, the want and willing to go through whatever it had to be to claw his way to the top.â€

Clay continued, â€œThe thing Iâ€™m getting at is that he never gave up, he never stopped trying, which is what itâ€™s all about in my book. Not everybody climbs to the top, and not everybody becomes a superstar. John was a great, great comedian.â€

In the early â€™80s, Mulrooney did stand-up on a TV show called Comedy Tonight. He went on to write and produce original content for 165 episodes of the series. Mulrooney also competed on the Ed McMahon-fronted Star Search. He lost, but was hired as a writer.

When Joan Rivers left Foxâ€™s The Late Show in 1987, Mulrooney replaced her. The show was, however, canceled a few months later. He also guest-hosted on The Pat Sajak Show.

He got another shot as the host of Comic Strip: Live, a TV version of a comedy club show filmed in front of a live audience. It aired locally on KTTV in Los Angeles before Fox brought the show to its owned-and-operated stations. Fox took Comic Strip: Live national on Saturday nights for a year before it ended.

Mulrooney also appeared on HBO, Showtime, A&E and Comedy Central.

On the big screen, he played a talk show host opposite Dennis Quaid in Great Balls of Fire.

True to Clayâ€™s testimony, Mulrooney did all this while maintaining a talk radio career.

In the late 1990s, the comedian co-hosted an Albany-based morning show with Bob â€œThe Wolfâ€ Wohlfeld on WPYX. Mulrooney joined the Poughkeepsie-based WPDH in 2010 before moving to iHeartRadio for â€œMulrooney in the Morning.â€

At 52, Mulrooney joined the Coxsackie Police Department, where he served through 2024. That led to a pilot for a reality show called Comedy Cop, following Mulrooneyâ€™s experiences as a police officer in a small-town.

Visitation will be held at Casey Funeral Home in Staten Island on January 4 from 2-6 p.m.

His funeral will take place at the Church of the Holy Family in New York on January 5 at 10:30 am.

In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Johnâ€™s memory to St. Jude Childrenâ€™s Hospital.

Tony Dokoupil, who starts Monday as anchor of the â€œCBS Evening News,â€ spoke out on New Yearâ€™s Day about where he thinks the press has gone wrong, and vowed that starting Monday, the audience would come first â€” ahead of advertisers, politicians or corporate interests including CBS owners Paramount Skydance.

Because weâ€™ve taken into account the perspective of advocates, and not the average American. Or, we put too much weight in the analysis of academics, or elites, and not enough on you.â€

Popular on Variety

The former â€œCBS Morningsâ€ host said he has felt that â€œthe most urgent questions simply werenâ€™t being askedâ€ by current TV news journalists.

Despite his long career in the news, the incoming anchorâ€™s statement Thursday was notable in that it seemed to agree with critics of mainstream media such as President Trump, implying journalists arenâ€™t doing their jobs competently. The program, which has ties to legendary personnel like Walter Cronkite, has been mired in third place behind ABCâ€™s â€˜World News Tonightâ€™ and NBCâ€™s â€˜NBC Nightly Newsâ€™ for years.â€ Dokoupil is likely aligned with some of Weissâ€™ views, such as her pro-Israel stance, Steinberg wrote.

SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers for the series finale of â€œStranger Things,â€ now streaming on Netflix.

Matt and Ross Duffer, the creators of â€œStranger Things,â€ didnâ€™t expect the review bombing that took place after the seriesâ€™ penultimate episode dropped on Netflix on Christmas Day â€” but theyâ€™re still extremely proud.

The three episodes brought the seasonâ€™s Rotten Tomatoes score down to 56% â€” the lowest by far, with Season 4 sitting at 89%, Season 3 at 86%, Season 2 at 90% and Season 1 at 96%. â€œThe Bridge,â€ the seventh episode, during which Will (Noah Schnapp) came out as gay to his friends before battling Vecna, became the lowest-rated episode of the series with a score of 5.6 out of 10 and 96,000 reviews.

Popular on Variety

â€œThe coming out scene is something weâ€™ve been building to for nine years now. It was a really important scene for us, and a really important scene for Noah â€” not just from a thematic point of view, but also a narrative point of view,â€ Ross Duffer tells Variety on Jan. 1 during a lengthy postmortem following the series finale. â€œThis show has always been about our characters overcoming evil, and in order to overcome this evil, Vecna, in so many ways, represents all the dark thoughts and the evil of society. And for our characters to overcome that, it really becomes about embracing themselves, and then also embracing one another and coming together.â€

The scene was â€œthe final step in Willâ€™s journey, and Will is, in so many ways, the key to defeating Vecna,â€ adds Matt Duffer. â€œVolume 1 is really about self-acceptance, right? I mean, thatâ€™s sort of step one. And then step two is Will is talking to Robin â€” itâ€™s something that he wants to do. Heâ€™s trying to figure out how to come out, and he knows that he needs to do that, and that thatâ€™s the final step for him. And he finds the courage to be able to do it. And itâ€™s really the ultimate fuck you to Vecna. That was the intention.â€

COURTESY OF NETFLIX Â© 2025

While the episode was torn apart online, that doesnâ€™t change how the creators feel about it.

â€œWeâ€™re proud of the episode, and weâ€™re proud of the scene, and proud of Noah, who gave a really brave, very vulnerable performance,â€ says Ross.

The scene was extremely important for Schnapp, Matt says, and the three of them have stayed close amid the mixed reviews.

â€œI think thatâ€™s where Ross and I were most sensitive, was Noah â€” because of how close to home this hit for him,â€ he says. â€œAnd our goal was to make sure that he was comfortable and happy with the scene. And when he was, we felt good about it. Iâ€™ve been texting with him a lot, but texting with him specifically after that scene and after that episode aired. And heâ€™s in a really good place. Heâ€™s very proud of the scene, and weâ€™re proud of the scene.â€

But still, even in 2025, the online hate surprised them. â€œNo is the honest truth,â€ Matt says when asked whether heâ€™d anticipated the homophobic backlash. â€œBecause it is, as Ross said, something weâ€™ve been building for a really long time. I always say, Ross and I are many things, but subtle is not one of those things!â€

After the episode dropped, Matt also told Variety that the duo â€œspent longer writingâ€ the coming out scene than any other â€” and that it was all about collaboration.

â€œWe were so concerned about getting it right. There were a lot of things that went into it. I mean, weâ€™re definitely nervous about how itâ€™s going to go over with everyone. But not as nervous as we were handing it over to Noah. Because ultimately, it needed to resonate and be truthful for him. We really were writing it to and for Noah. He wrote us sobbing after he read it. So it really worked and resonated for him, which was great,â€ he said. â€œOn the day, frankly, there wasnâ€™t really much direction at all. Noah spent a long time â€” I mean, months â€” prepping for that scene, that moment. Luckily, that script was done well in advance. I know he did a lot of work himselfâ€¦ And most of whatâ€™s in there is the first take.â€

Kate Aurthur contributed to the reporting of this story.

title: â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Finale Spoiler Interview: Duffer Brothers on Whether Eleven Is Alive, Debating Who Got to Kill [SPOILER] and Why the Rock From the Briefcase Is Key to the Spinoff
summary: SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from the series finale of â€œStranger Things,” now streaming on Netflix.
