content:
SPOILER ALERT: This story contains spoilers from the series finale of â€œStranger Things,â€ now streaming on Netflix. And so ends the nine-and-a-half-year journey of â€œStranger Things,â€ which launched in July 2016 and concluded on Dec. 31, 2025. Creators Matt and Ross Duffer wrapped up the series in a finale that ran just over two hours, and not only premiered on Netflix, but played in select theaters as well. In a media landscape thatâ€™s splintered into a million pieces, the conclusion of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ â€” with its finale dropping precisely at 8 p.m. ET/5 p.m. PT on New Yearâ€™s Eve â€” felt like a throwback to an earlier time, and a last gasp of monoculture. â€œThe Rightside Upâ€ wrapped up the stories of all the major characters, after Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown), Will (Noah Schnapp), Nancy (Natalia Dyer), Joyce (Winona Ryder) and the rest of the Hawkins heroes went into the Abyss to defeat the Mind Flayer and kill Vecna (Jamie Campbell Bower) for once and for all. In Varietyâ€™s Oct. 15 cover story about â€œStranger Things,â€ Matt Duffer said explicitly, â€œThis is a complete story. Itâ€™s done.â€ Which doesnâ€™t mean that every single plot thread was tied up in a neat bow, as TikTok will undoubtedly be telling us for the next few months (and possibly forever). The biggest lingering question that â€œThe Rightside Upâ€ leaves ambiguous is whether Eleven is dead (did she sacrifice herself when the Upside Down was destroyed to thwart the military from weaponizing future clones of her?) or alive (was that last image just a projection of her, as aided by Linnea Berthelsenâ€™s Kali, and Eleven managed to escape?). Viewers will surely reach their own conclusions, but in the spirit of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ and its inspirations, Eleven may very well be alive. Courtesy of Netflix Mike (Finn Wolfhard) certainly seems to think so. The showâ€™s final scene â€” after an 18-month time jump to the class of â€˜89â€™s graduation â€” is set in the Wheelersâ€™ basement as the gang plays Dungeons & Dragons one last time, in a throwback to the series premiere. Itâ€™s then that Mike tells Will, Lucas (Caleb McLaughlin), Max (Sadie Sink) and Dustin (Gaten Matarazzo) how he sees their stories moving forward, as they each embark on their futures â€” and itâ€™s where he tells them that he thinks Eleven might be alive after all. As his sister Holly (Nell Fisher), her friend Derek (Jake Connelly) and their other friends come barreling down the stairs, ready to take over the D&D game, Mike closes the door. (For Varietyâ€™s full recap of the â€œStranger Thingsâ€ finale, read this.) In an interview with the Duffer brothers on the morning of Jan. 1, they delve into the uncertainty of Elevenâ€™s fate; staging the final battle with the Mind Flayer and Vecna, and debating who got to deal the death blow; the element unveiled in the finale that will be key to the spinoff â€” and being unpleasantly surprised by the review bombing of â€œThe Bridge,â€ the seriesâ€™ penulimate episode. The New Yearâ€™s Day conversation is interrupted only by Brown repeatedly trying to call Matt Duffer, which disrupts the Zoom. See, everybody? Sheâ€™s alive! Youâ€™ve been clear that youâ€™ve known for a long time that the final scene was that D&D campaign with the kids, who are now young adults. But how much of that scene did you know far in advance? Like, did you know Eleven wouldnâ€™t be there, that Max would be there â€” break it down for me, please! Matt Duffer: Initially, when we came up with it a very long time ago, it was the kids â€” the â€œkids,â€ in quotes â€” play one final game of D&D, put their books away and go upstairs. And Mike was going to shut the door, closing the door effectively on childhood. So that was the idea. Once we introduced Holly, and this is one of the reasons we were so interested in bringing Holly and her friends and Derek into the show, was to be able to have a passing of the torch moment. To be able to recapture Season 1, it allows Mike to reflect on his childhood and feel happy that his sister and her friends are going to have a magical experience, or adventures like they had â€” hopefully not as traumatic. But as Dustin said, there was so much good amongst so much bad. It changed them in so many meaningful ways. Ross Duffer: Eleven was never going to be there. It was very early on in the writing process of this season that we figured out exactly how to tell that story and landed on the â€œI believeâ€ moment. And once we landed on â€œI believe,â€ then that sort of cracked it wide open. That was in those first few weeks of the writersâ€™ room, because we started at the end, at that basement scene, and wanted to make sure that we got it to a place where we felt was the right ending for the show. And then we built the season to that moment. Matt Duffer: I also love the idea that the original ending of â€œETâ€ was them going to be them playing D&D again. So I like the idea of doing that.

Courtesy of Netflix

Speaking of the Eleven ending, and the ambiguity of whether sheâ€™s alive, can you talk about when you had that idea and why you wanted to do that?

Ross Duffer: A couple things: Eleven represents, in a lot of ways, the magic of childhood. And we knew for our kids to be able to grow up, the magic had leave Hawkins. There was never a version that we had written where it was Eleven down in that basement. It was never going to be that simple and that easy. It was finding a way to come up with an ending where it was not that simple, but also bittersweet, and that there was hope there.

Matt Duffer: Speaking of Eleven, Millie keeps Facetiming, disrupting the Zoom.

Right now? Matt Duffer: Yeah. And Millie, if you donâ€™t answer, just keeps hitting you up.



Itâ€™s two fronts. Ross is talking about it thematically, in terms of the magic of childhood. And then thereâ€™s this story element of it in Elevenâ€™s choice, ultimately. It was a huge debate â€” sheâ€™s calling again, Iâ€™m so sorry, Kate. Iâ€™m curious, actually, what sheâ€™s saying. Everybodyâ€™s very emotional.



Sheâ€™s like, â€œIâ€™m alive, guys!â€ Matt Duffer: â€œIâ€™m alive, guys,â€ yeah â€” no, sheâ€™s very emotional. Everybodyâ€™s very emotional. And no oneâ€™s here in L.A., so we havenâ€™t gotten to see anyone after it played. Iâ€™m so sorry. I know what I was gonna say: From a character point of view, not a thematic point of view, we had so many debates in the writersâ€™ room about what we were going to do with Eleven. And then we tried to actually express everything we were talking about in the room on the screen. So Hopperâ€™s speech to Eleven is vocalizing what a lot of people in the room were saying. And then what Kali was saying to her was vocalizing the other side of the argument. The question was, which of those choices is Eleven going to choose? And if you, like Mike and the others, choose to believe that she is alive somewhere, then she picked something in the middle. But either way, itâ€™s a completely selfless act and heroic act on Elevenâ€™s part. I mean, youâ€™ve seen all those pregnant women, and how many children are going to be born, potentially, using her blood, how the cycle will exist, and how many other kids will go through what she went through. And sheâ€™s making damn sure that that never happens again.

Courtesy of Netflix

One discussion online this morning is whether Mike made the whole thing up, or Eleven actually told him what her plan was. Or, that during the graduation, Mike realized that Eleven never could have gotten from the truck to the gate because of the kryptonite, so thatâ€™s not really her and was a projection. Discuss!

Matt Duffer: The only thing Iâ€™ll debunk is that Eleven does not communicate with Mike in any way. But what you just said at the end â€” yes, at graduation, heâ€™s hearing the speakers distort because the principal is so angry, and it makes him realize that there was the kryptonite. So how could she have possibly made it all the way to the gate? Not only that. How could she have possibly used her powers to bring him into the void?

Popular on Variety

But there are a lot of other questions. Could Kali have actually done that? Could she have possibly been alive? We like that itâ€™s up to the audience. Obviously, we tell you what the characters choose.

And when you decided to bring Kali back, was it in your imagination that she could possibly help Eleven with a potential fake-out at the end? And is she alive long enough to do that?

Matt Duffer: Well, thatâ€™s the question. We wanted to bring her back for a lot of reasons. We wanted that story to have existed for a reason, and weâ€™ve been looking for a way to bring Kali back and a reason to bring her back. And we found it this year.

But it wasnâ€™t just for her ability to project or create these illusions. The other part of it was Hopper and Mike are so close to Eleven. Mike is such â€” I donâ€™t want to call him naive, but a little bit. And heâ€™s such a dreamer and an optimist. I know a lot of people were frustrated with what Kali was saying to Eleven, and I get that. But what she was saying was accurate in so many ways, and we needed someone to be able to voice that â€” the dark reality of what potentially exists on the other side of that. So those were two of the main reasons we brought her back into the fold.

Letâ€™s assume Eleven is still alive, because thatâ€™s more in the spirit of â€œStranger Things.â€ Can she ever reveal herself again to her friends and family?

Ross Duffer: If she were alive, the way I would see it is no. Any contact would risk bringing her back out in the open and starting the cycle again. So, in the story that Mikeâ€™s telling, I donâ€™t think he sees a version where they reconnect.

This is a fandom that Iâ€™ve realized over the past month or two does not love ambiguity. How do you feel about the fans who are upset there isnâ€™t more clarity about Eleven?

Matt Duffer: Are a lot of people upset about that? I really donâ€™t know!

I mean, after Volume 2, people didnâ€™t understand that Jonathan and Nancy broke up. I was like, what are you watching?

Matt Duffer: This is obviously intended to be ambiguous, right? With Eleven. At the end of the day, itâ€™s being told from the point of view of Mike and his friends. And they donâ€™t know, and the audience canâ€™t know. If you knew that she was out there and you knew she existed, then sheâ€™s very much at risk. So we thought there was something really cool about not knowing for sure, and having our characters choose to believe. We just thought that was more powerful than providing a definitive answer, one way or the other. And I like that the audiences are in Mike, Max, Lucas and Dustinâ€™s shoes, in the sense that they get to choose or not choose. I mean, Iâ€™m definitely seeing the majority choosing to believe and side with the kids.

Courtesy of Netflix

I side with the kids. Can you talk about the final battle between the Mind Flayer, Vecna and our heroes, and how you specifically wanted to stage that?

Ross Duffer: We were originally going to go to New Mexico to shoot it, and logistically, that became impossible as we moved into the finale. We shot it in some, like, decrepit quarry in Atlanta. But obviously, WETA visual effects, some of the best in the world, did an incredible job.

Mainly, what we needed was a huge battlefield for this monster. I donâ€™t think we fully realized quite how large it was until once we built the interior sets. And we were like, â€œWell, if thatâ€™s the size of its interior, how big is its exterior?â€

Matt Duffer: We were thinking about D&D, and I was playing Baldurâ€™s Gate 3 at the time, and we felt it was very important that the only way for them to defeat it was for the entire party to work together. Everyone had fully realized â€” either through self-acceptance or theyâ€™ve resolved all their various issues â€” moving into that final battle, theyâ€™re absolutely primed. Theyâ€™re the ultimate team, and itâ€™s the party working all together to defeat this thing. And they each have their own individual skills, right? And thatâ€™s where I go back to Dungeons & Dragons, and something like Baldurâ€™s Gate. Because thatâ€™s how you take down these monsters that seem otherwise unstoppable. Lots of video game references were applied to that final battle.

Eleven obviously is the nuclear option, but Will really helps when sheâ€™s on her back foot. When did you figure out that part of it?

Matt Duffer: Well, we knew that Will was obviously going to play a major role in it, and it just came down to, who did we want to deliver the final blow? Was it going to be Will, or was it going to be Eleven? Then we tried to work on a way where it was actually both of them. Eleven throws him into the spike, but Will is the one who allows her to do that. He just breaks him down, rips off his left arm, allowing Eleven that final opportunity. Will was always going to be a key part in defeating Vecna. Without Will, it wouldnâ€™t have happened.

And Joyce beheads Vecna. How did you arrive at that moment?

Ross Duffer: In the writersâ€™ room, I remember we went through, â€œWho gets to do the final blow?â€ It works with all of them in a way. So, we just cycled through, what if Steve does it? What if Dustin does it? And then finally, when we landed on, what if Joyce does it? It felt right for a lot of reasons. She is sort of the mother of this group, the protector. And also, we never got to see her hit anything with that ax, so that felt like such a satisfying way to deliver the final blow to Vecna.

But it was in editorial really, where, as we were working on it, that we had the initial flashbacks to her remembering back to Bob, and building up that anger. It felt right that itâ€™s just not just a â€œfuck yeahâ€ moment. It was also, in a way, a cathartic moment for our characters, who are purging all this trauma thatâ€™s been caused here. Itâ€™s not just a stand-up and cheer moment. Itâ€™s remembering that this evil has caused them so much pain.

Matt Duffer: I remember working with our editor and our composer and just talking to them and going, â€œLetâ€™s make this the most emotional decapitation in history.â€ That was the goal.

Courtesy of Netflix

Sheâ€™s, of course, decapitating the kid whom she cast in â€œOklahoma.â€

Matt Duffer: Yeah, I guess so!

Was there ever a scene in the 18 months after Season 4 when Hopper and Joyce realized that Henry Creel, aka Vecna, was the kid they went to high school with?

Ross Duffer: Yeah, Iâ€™m sure there was. We had a walk a fine line with the play â€” we donâ€™t want to frustrate, because so much of our audience is unable to see it. To have them start talking about it would have been confusing in the context of someone who hasnâ€™t seen the play. But Iâ€™m sure they did have that conversation.

Matt Duffer: We really needed the final season to be exactly as it would have been without the play. The play is Henryâ€™s backstory after heâ€™s infected by the Mind Flayer. But this is how the season was going to play out regardless.

The Mind Flayer is the real evil, which we asked about in our Volume 1 postmortem. But if you had to define what that rock in the briefcase is, how would you describe it?

Matt Duffer: Hmm. How would we describe it?

What is it?!



Matt Duffer: Iâ€™m gonna be sketchy here, Kate, because I will say that is â€” can I say this, Ross? Because itâ€™s just hard to not say it.

Courtesy of Netflix

Spinoffy?!

Matt Duffer: Spinoffy, yeah. You pinned us down. So annoying. I do want to explain, just because peopleâ€™s expectations go in certain directions: The spinoff is going to delve into that and explain that, and youâ€™re going to understand it. But itâ€™s a completely different mythology. So itâ€™s not a deep exploration of the Mind Flayer or anything like that. Itâ€™s very fresh and very new, but yes, it will answer some of the loose threads that are remaining.



Where are you with the spinoff?

Ross Duffer: Weâ€™re going to start working on it again on Monday. Weâ€™ve been working on it on and off. Weâ€™ll take a few days off.

On Monday?!

Matt Duffer: You donâ€™t understand. My favorite part of the show is working on it. Itâ€™s not releasing it â€” thatâ€™s just stressful, no matter how it goes when you release it. Itâ€™s maybe my least favorite part of the process. I like the creative part. I like making it. So, weâ€™re actually really excited, and itâ€™s very exciting to work with a clean slate: completely new characters, new town, new world, new mythology.

And no common characters?



Matt Duffer: Right. Exactly. No common characters.

I wanted to ask you about the review bombing of â€œThe Bridge,â€ which appears to be a coordinated attack by people who didnâ€™t like Willâ€™s coming out scene. Itâ€™s now the lowest rated episode in the series. Can you talk about why it was important to you all along to have Willâ€™s queerness associated with his powers?

Ross Duffer: The coming out scene is something weâ€™ve been building to for nine years now. It was a really important scene for us, and a really important scene for Noah â€” not just from a thematic point of view, but also a narrative point of view. This show has always been about our characters overcoming evil, and in order to overcome this evil, Vecna, in so many ways, represents all the dark thoughts and the evil of society. And for our characters to overcome that, it really becomes about embracing themselves, and then also embracing one another and coming together.



Matt Duffer: Right. It was the final step in Willâ€™s journey. And Will is, in so many ways, the key to defeating Vecna. Volume 1 is really about self-acceptance, right? I mean, thatâ€™s sort of step one. And then step two is Will is talking to Robin â€” itâ€™s something that he wants to do. Heâ€™s trying to figure out how to come out, and he knows that he needs to do that, and that thatâ€™s the final step for him. And he finds the courage to be able to do it. And itâ€™s really the ultimate fuck you to Vecna. That was the intention.

Courtesy of Netflix

And were you prepared for a homophobic campaign like that?



Matt Duffer: No. I mean, no is the honest truth. Because it is, as Ross said, something weâ€™ve been building for a really long time. I always say, Ross and I are many things, but subtle is not one of those things!

Ross Duffer: Weâ€™re proud of the episode, and weâ€™re proud of the scene, and proud of Noah, who gave a really brave, very vulnerable performance.

Matt Duffer: I think thatâ€™s where Ross and I were most sensitive, was Noah â€” because of how close to home this hit for him. And our goal was to make sure that he was comfortable and happy with the scene. And when he was, we felt good about it. Iâ€™ve been texting with him a lot, but texting with him specifically after that scene and after that episode aired. And heâ€™s in a really good place. Heâ€™s very proud of the scene, and weâ€™re proud of the scene.

He should be, and so should you. I have another question along these lines. Thereâ€™s a QAnon-ish conspiracy theory going around that Volume 2 was â€” and Iâ€™m doing air quotes, in case youâ€™re not actually looking at me â€” â€œtampered with.â€ That there were scenes that were cut, including El and Mike going into Camazotz to rescue Will, and a Mike and Will one-on-one scene. Have you seen this Google Doc?

Matt Duffer: Someone sent it to us, yeah. Obviously, thatâ€™s not a real thing.

Have you seen the Change.org petition with 370,000+ signatures to release the footage?

Ross Duffer: I have not seen that! I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a single cut scene in the entire season.

Matt Duffer: The show has just grown so massive. Online, thereâ€™s just so much misinformation. Just tons of it. We would be here for hours trying to bat down the stuff that was not true. But at the end of the day, hopefully the work speaks for itself, and it is the show that Ross and I wanted to make. Netflix was, and has always been, incredible. I mean, thereâ€™s no interference or direction at all from them on us. They really trust us, and thatâ€™s been true from Season 1 on. Itâ€™s never changed, even though the show and the size of the audience have grown.

We do need to wrap, I know, but I saw you guys were at the Americana last night. Did you actually sit and watch it? And how was it?

Ross Duffer: It was awesome. We never get that experience. I mean, the premieres are one thing, but thatâ€™s generally friends and crew. So, to sit there with just true fans â€” theyâ€™re all decked out in merch, and to hear them in real-time responding, whether itâ€™s applauding or laughing or crying. It was an incredible experience. It was really special.

title: MTV Didnâ€™t Die on New Yearâ€™s Eve, Despite Social Media Posts â€” but the Music Left a Long Time Ago
summary: You’ve probably seen a variation of this news on social media over the past few days: MTV officially shut down on New Year’s Eve, ending their final broadcast the same way the network started: With the clip “Video Killed the Radio Star” by The Buggles. But those posts are misinformed. It’s New Year’s Day 2026, […]
content:
Youâ€™ve probably seen a variation of this news on social media over the past few days: MTV officially shut down on New Yearâ€™s Eve, ending their final broadcast the same way the network started: With the clip â€œVideo Killed the Radio Starâ€ by The Buggles.

But those posts are misinformed. Itâ€™s New Yearâ€™s Day 2026, and MTV is still around. Granted, today the channel is playing a marathon of â€œThe Big Bang Theoryâ€ sitcom repeats, so your interpretation of â€œMTV is still aroundâ€ may vary.

Hereâ€™s where the confusion is coming from: On New Yearâ€™s Eve, Paramount Skydance did indeed shut down several MTV-branded music channels in the U.K. According to a source, â€œMTVâ€™s specialist music channels in the UK will no longer operate as linear channels. The flagship MTV UK channel will continue to broadcastâ€¦ Paramount is reviewing and adjusting its international Pay TV portfolio, given shifts in audience behavior towards streaming and digital platforms.â€

Popular on Variety

As for the U.S., the existing MTV channels will continue to broadcast without change â€” including MTV and MTV2. MTV hasnâ€™t been â€œMusic Televisionâ€ for a long time, but the network does still program some digital music channels in the U.S., including â€œMTV Classicâ€ (playing retro music videos from the 1980s, 1990s and 2000s), â€œMTV Liveâ€ (which runs current music videos, as well as other music programming from the Paramount library) and a collection of MTV-branded FAST channels (â€œMTV Biggest Pop,â€ â€œMTV Spankinâ€™ New,â€ â€œYo! MTVâ€ and â€œMTV Flow Latinoâ€), which play contemporary music videos on Pluto TV.

Of course, fans of MTVâ€™s golden 1980s, 1990s and 2000s era still look nostalgically at when the flagship network really was about music. In those days, MTVâ€™s programming consisted of music videos and music-oriented series like â€œHeadbangerâ€™s Ball,â€ â€œ120 Minutesâ€ and â€œYo! MTV Raps.â€ Later, â€œTRLâ€ was an afternoon staple for an entire generation of kids.

But in recent years, MTV has focused on reality programming â€” which currently includes â€œThe Challengeâ€ and â€œRuPaulâ€™s Drag Race.â€ The network has also been criticized for its over-reliance on series like â€œRidiculousness,â€ which often takes up the lionâ€™s share of its programming. (As Variety wrote in 2020, at one point â€œRidiculousnessâ€ took up 113 of 168 total hours on MTV â€” 67.3% of its entire schedule.)

And thatâ€™s probably why, while inaccurate, this â€œnewsâ€ that MTV is shutting down has resonated across social media â€” especially among Gen Xers and Millennials. They still remember that music on MTV came more than just once a year on the VMAs. And theyâ€™ve also seen the recent reports of how cutbacks have eliminated the last vestiges of MTV as we know it: In 2023, the remaining shell of a once-vibrant MTV News division was shut down, and then last year the legacy MTV News website went dark, and its archives were scrubbed from the internet.

Then there was the sense in 2025 that weâ€™ve hit the tipping point when it comes to the decline in basic cable, as companies like NBCU look to shed those once-valuable assets. When Skydance acquired Paramount and started making drastic cuts, its cable networks were hit especially hard: MTV shed most of its remaining comms and talent teams, including top remaining music programming and talent execs. The idea that even a major network like MTV might shut down no longer seems so far-fetched.

According to Varietyâ€˜s 2025 tally of the most-watched linear networks in primetime, MTV rated No. 49 â€” with an average of 189,000 viewers. In adults 18-49, MTV ranked No. 25. Compare that to 10 years ago: In 2015, MTV ranked No. 36 with 606,000 viewers.

So yes, the MTV as we knew it disappeared a long time ago. But MTV as a channel still exists. For now.

title: Will Smith Sued by Tour Violinist for Sexual Harassment and Wrongful Termination
summary: Will Smith has been sued by a tour violinist who is accusing the rapper of sexual harassment, wrongful termination and retaliation. In the suit, filed yesterday and reviewed by Variety, musician Brian King Joseph names Smith and Treyball Studios Management as defendants and accuses Smith of “predatory behavior” and “deliberately grooming and priming Mr. Joseph […]
content:
Will Smith has been sued by a tour violinist who is accusing the rapper of sexual harassment, wrongful termination and retaliation.

In the suit, filed yesterday and reviewed by Variety, musician Brian King Joseph names Smith and Treyball Studios Management as defendants and accuses Smith of â€œpredatory behaviorâ€ and â€œdeliberately grooming and priming Mr. Joseph for further sexual exploitationâ€ while on his â€œBased on a True Story: 2025 Tourâ€ this past spring.

The suit alleges that Smith hired Joseph in November 2024 to perform at a show in San Diego and was subsequently invited to join his 2025 tour and play on his upcoming album. As their relationship grew closer, Smith told Joseph that â€œyou and I have such a special connection, that I donâ€™t have with anyone else,â€ among other similar expressions.

Popular on Variety

Joseph, who previously competed on â€œAmericaâ€™s Got Talent,â€ joined the first leg of Smithâ€™s tour in March 2025 for a show in Las Vegas, where hotel rooms had been booked for the band and crew members. His suit claims that his bag, which contained his hotel room key, went missing for several hours before management found and returned it to him, and that members of management were the â€œonly individuals with access to [his] room.â€

Later that night, Joseph returned to find that someone had â€œunlawfullyâ€ entered the room and left behind belongings including wipes, a bottle of HIV medication with another individualâ€™s name, and a note that read, â€œBrian, Iâ€™ll be back no later [sic] 5:30, just us (drawn heart), Stone F,â€ which Joseph interpreted as a warning that â€œan unknown individual would soon return to his room to engage in sexual actsâ€ with him.

He notified hotel security and Smithâ€™s representatives and reported the incident to a non-emergency police line. He claims that just days later, a member of the management team â€œshamedâ€ him for the incident and told him he was being terminated, suggesting that Joseph made the whole thing up.

A representative for Smith did not immediately respond to Varietyâ€˜s request for comment.

The suit claims that due to the termination, Joseph suffered from PTSD and economic loss. He is suing for retaliation, wrongful termination and sexual harassment, and that damages be determined by a jury.

title: Kennedy Center Defends Trump-Hosted Telecast After All-Time Low Nielsen Viewership, Points To $23 Million Raised
summary: The Kennedy Center is defending this year’s Kennedy Center Honors after the Donald Trump hosted telecast delivered all-time low viewership for CBS. The Dec. 23 telecast averaged 3.01 million viewers on CBS, according to Nielsen Live + Same Day Panel + Big Data. That is an all-time low audience for the annual special, down from 4.1M […]
content:
The Kennedy Center is defending this yearâ€™s Kennedy Center Honors after the Donald Trump hosted telecast delivered all-time low viewership for CBS.

The Dec. 23 telecast averaged 3.01 million viewers on CBS, according to Nielsen Live + Same Day Panel + Big Data. That is an all-time low audience for the annual special, down from 4.1M Live+Same Day viewers last year when it aired on a Sunday with a football-boosted 60 Minutes lead-in. This year, the event was broadcast on a Tuesday.

Roma Daravi, vice president of public relations for the center, said in a statement, â€œComparing this yearâ€™s broadcast ratings to prior years is a classic apples-to-oranges comparison and evidence of far-left bias. The program performed extremely well across key demographics and platforms, despite industry and timing disadvantages, including a Tuesday air date two days before Christmas.

Watch on Deadline

She added, â€œWith overall television usage down roughly 20 percent year over year, the broadcast still tied for the #1 spot among adults aged 25â€“54, alongside a live NBA doubleheader. And on social media, Honors garnered 1.5 Billion impressions in just one nightâ€”up from only 50 Million similar impressions last year. This was a successful night celebrating the outstanding achievements of our Honorees at the Trump Kennedy Center.â€

The social media data and 20% decline in usage could not immediately be corroborated (digital numbers do not have the same standard measurement that TV ratings via Nielsen does). After Trumpâ€™s takeover, the Kennedy Center has at times claimed media bias for stories that reflect negatively on the centerâ€™s operations.

The center also said that $23 million was raised from this yearâ€™s ceremony, what it said was nearly double the amount of last year.

Sylvester Stallone, Michael Crawford, KISS, George Strait, and Gloria Gaynor were honored at the Dec. 7 ceremony, taped for later broadcast. It was the first time that a sitting U.S. president had hosted the ceremony. Weeks after he took office, Trump seized control of the center, firing Joe Biden and Barack Obama appointees to the board in a move that ensured that he would be selected as the arts institutionâ€™s chairman.

Last month, after the ceremony, the board voted to add Trumpâ€™s name to the Kennedy Center, which was established by an act of Congress in 1964. Members of the Kennedy family objected to the renaming, while one ex officio member of the board, Rep. Joyce Beatty (D-OH), sued, contending that only Congress can change the name of the institution.

title: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™: Duffer Brothers Unpack Emotional Series Finale From [SPOILER]â€™s Death To That 40-Minute Epilogue, Those Needle Drops & A Spinoff Hint
summary: SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from the series finale of Netflix’s Stranger Things. Matt and Ross Duffer have officially closed the book on Stranger Things. The supernatural Netflix series rang in 2026 with an epic and emotional two-hour finale that saw the Hawkins crew finally defeat Vecna (Jamie Campbell Bower) and destroy the Upside […]
content:
SPOILER ALERT! This post contains details from the series finale of Netflixâ€˜s Stranger Things.

Matt and Ross Duffer have officially closed the book on Stranger Things.

The supernatural Netflix series rang in 2026 with an epic and emotional two-hour finale that saw the Hawkins crew finally defeat Vecna (Jamie Campbell Bower) and destroy the Upside Down for good, bringing an end once and for all to the havoc the portal to an alternate dimension has caused for the last four years of their lives.

Eleven (Millie Bobby Brown) also vanished with the collapse of the Upside Down, though the Duffers have given both their characters and the audience a powerful coping mechanism to grapple with the grief of her self-sacrifice. Earlier in the finale, it seems that Eleven has broken off from the pack to go back through the gate, ensuring sheâ€™ll go down with the wormhole and the government wonâ€™t be able to continue its experiments on other children. But, in the final moments of the episode, Mike (Finn Wolfhard) lets his friends in on a little theory he has about their mage, having realized at graduation that El was seemingly able to use her powers and enter the Void to say goodbye to him despite the fact that the military was using that piercing sound (â€œkryptonite,â€ as they call it) to debilitate her.

Watch on Deadline

He relays his hypothesis through the lens of the D&D campaign theyâ€™ve just finished playing, which Dustin (Gaten Matarazzo), Max (Sadie Sink), Will (Noah Schnapp) and Lucas (Caleb McLaughlin) win by using an eleventh hour Hail Mary to summon a mage theyâ€™d encountered earlier in their quest. As heâ€™s orating the epilogues for all of their game characters, Mike says he chooses to believe that the mage isnâ€™t actually dead. Instead, with the help of her sister, she was able to escape and start a peaceful life off the grid. As he says it, the episode flashes back to the moment the gate closes in the MAC-Z, and the audience sees Kali (Linnea Berthelsen) use her powers one last time before she dies to make everyone think they see El standing inside the gate so that she can actually slip away and escape for good.

Putting away their D&D books, the kids are an emotional wreck as they realize that the real world is knocking at the door and, in many ways, their lives are irrevocably different than they were just a few short years ago. Both for better and worse. Mikeâ€™s final moment of reverie is interrupted as Holly (Nell Fisher) and her friends come storming down the stairs to play their own D&D campaign in the basement, and Mike smiles as he closes the door, literally and figuratively, on that chapter of his life.

In the interview below, the Duffer brothers discuss crafting what they hope is a satisfying conclusion to the story that launched their careers and the careers of most of the showâ€™s young cast into the stratosphere as well as saying goodbye to the beloved current and former residents of Hawkins, Indiana.

DEADLINE: First of all, how are you both feeling now that the finale is out in the world?

ROSS DUFFER: I mean, we definitely feel emotional. I think weâ€™re still processing. We went to see it last night with fans, went to a screening in the Americana [at Brand in Glendale, California], and that was an incredible experience just being, not at a premiere, just being with fans on opening night and seeing them react in real time to whatâ€™s happening.

(L to R) Noah Schnapp as Will Byers and Winona Ryder as Joyce Byers in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5 Courtesy of Netflix

DEADLINE: You also both watched the finale with a lot of the cast just recently. What was that experience like for you?

ROSS: Oh, it was very emotional. I think for everyone, there were a lot of tears at the end, but, also, everyone was just so, so proud and just so supportive of one another. I donâ€™t know. I just felt like everything had come full circle, and just to see how much theyâ€™ve grown up over the yearsâ€¦ it was really the perfect way to end the whirlwind of press tour and filming and everything. It was quiet, but I thought it was beautiful.

RELATED LINK: â€˜Stranger Things 5â€™ Star Caleb McLaughlin On That Emotional Scene With [SPOILER], Upside Down Mythology & More From Vol. 2

MATT DUFFER: Itâ€™s sort of how we feel now. I think everybody was processing it. Everybody was crying. We all went back to my apartment in New York. Some of the cast chose to walk, even though it was 30 minutes, I think because they needed time to process everything. Just having heard from a lot of them yesterday, I havenâ€™t connected with them today, but, I think everyoneâ€™s still reeling a little bit. Everybodyâ€™s emotional.

DEADLINE: I mean, to be fair, I am feeling emotional about it, and I am only an audience member!

MATT: You have to remember, itâ€™s been 10 years, right? So for the kids, itâ€™s half their lives. I mean, Millie always says she doesnâ€™t remember life or much of it before the show, so I donâ€™t know. I think it was harder for everybody than they thought it was going to be saying farewell.

ROSS: So much of the final scenes that you see, I mean, yes, people are acting, but in a way, theyâ€™re not. Those are real emotions that theyâ€™re feeling, because those are all the last scenes that we captured with these actors. So, itâ€™s a vulnerable thing to see that projected on the big screen and then put out in front of everyone.

MATT: I donâ€™t want to say itâ€™s meta, because it wasnâ€™t, but some of it was a commentary on the experience of the show itself and what it felt like to say goodbye to it. So each of those individual scenes in the epilogue were very personal to all the cast, and I think thatâ€™s why each of those days were as emotional as they were. Everybody was crying the entire time.

The basement scene was two days, so the first day was okay. The first day it was just the fun D&D campaign. Then the second day, everyone was wrecked. I thought they were going to run out of tears, but they did not.

ROSS: They did not.

DEADLINE: You can feel a lot of that emotion very viscerally. It doesnâ€™t fully feel like theyâ€™re acting in some of those final moments.

MATT: No, thatâ€™s not acting. When theyâ€™re breakingâ€¦when you see Maya [Hawke] break, or any of them break, they were just crying.

DEADLINE: Well, thereâ€™s a lot to unpack from the finale, but letâ€™s start there. You said that the basement scene is something youâ€™ve pretty much always envisioned for the finale, but when did this idea of weaving in some ambiguity about Elevenâ€™s death crystallize for you? Why did that feel like the right way to end that story?

MATT: Itâ€™s been something on our mind for a really long time. That was the original ending of the show when it was designed as a limited series, that El has to sacrifice herself in some way. I mean, the first thing we did when we were working on Season 5 was to talk about the ending and specifically talk about Eleven and, it was hard.

This is a character weâ€™ve been with for 10 years. Weâ€™ve been with Millie for 10 years. So it was a really hard and emotional decision to make, but at the end of the day, it just felt right to us. It felt like, given the circumstances, it was the only way to actually end, permanently, everything that had been going on, and itâ€™s such a selfless act from her to protect anyone from going through what she went through, if that makes sense.

(L to R) David Harbour as Jim Hopper and Millie Bobby Brown as Eleven in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5. Courtesy of Netflix

ROSS: It was always going to end with the kids in the basement. Thatâ€™s been planned for eight years. Once we figured out this, â€˜I believe,â€™ line from Mike, thatâ€™s when everything sort of crystallized. And of course, that was very early on, like week two or three of the writers room this [season]. Once Holly became a bigger figure, sort of the passing of the torch, those were some of the first ideas we had when we were talking about what we wanted this basement scene to be, before we even started writing the season. So it was always headed towards that goal post.

MATT: At the end of the day, we see it as a big coming of age story. This scene is about one last moment of being kids before they leave that childhood behind. Them going up the stairs is them leaving it, and then Holly and her friends are the new generation who are going to live that out. So, thatâ€™s why that last shot of Mike, you see him go from feeling sad about leaving his childhood behind to feeling happy and knowing the happy memories he had with his friends are going to be with him forever.

And El, in so many ways to us, represents the magic of childhood, like when youâ€™re growing up, and anything feels possible, and that goes away in some ways as you get older, but it stays with you forever. So the memories of Eleven are always going to be with Mike, and they donâ€™t vanish, right? I mean, sheâ€™s going to be a part of Mike and her friends for the rest of time, and they choose to believe sheâ€™s still out there, which is powerful.

So, itâ€™s not saying goodbye. Sheâ€™s with them forever, and their childhood and the memories of everything they went through, as scary and traumatic as it was at times, as Dustin said, there was so much good that came out of it. Eleven and everything they went through shaped who they are today.

DEADLINE: Did you consider any other deaths?

ROSS: In the writers room, I think we talked through everything. You talk through everything, every possibility, and we knew from early on what we wanted to do with Eleven and her fate, and you talk through the other characters, but I think at the end of the day, for us, the show is an adventure story. Itâ€™s a coming of age story.

So for us, it was really talking about those last 30, 40 minutes and where we wanted our characters to be and what we wanted their growth to be and where we wanted to leave them behind. Having those discussions is how we landed on [the idea] that we want our heroes, most of them, to make it out of there.

DEADLINE: I have to say, â€˜When Doves Cryâ€™ to â€˜Purple Rainâ€™ to â€˜Landslideâ€™ is one of the craziest strings of sequential needle drops Iâ€™ve ever heard in a show. I need to know how you landed on those songs.

MATT: It was cheap, too, I can tell you. [Laughs]. We spent a long time trying to figure out what was going to be playing on the bomb vinyl. I donâ€™t think we talked more about what song we should use than we did for that particular song, because it was really, really challenging, because the first song needed to be upbeat and hopeful on the vinyl. Then the final song had to work for Elevenâ€™s farewell. So not only are you looking for an iconic song, you need the beginning song and the end song to both work and convey completely different emotions.

We asked everybody in the cast, all of our friends. Everybody weighed in. Everyone had different ideas. Eventually we landed on â€˜Purple Rain,â€™ but the concern with that was whether or not we were going to be able to get the rights. I mean, aside from Michael Jackson, itâ€™s the hardest thing to do, to get Prince rights. I donâ€™t think we would have got them had it not been for Kate Bush, to be honest. Because of the Kate Bush effect, I think that ultimately persuaded the Prince estate. I donâ€™t know how they feel about the scene, but hopefully theyâ€™re happy with it. I guess they approved it, right Ross?

ROSS: They did approve it [in the scene]. Then â€˜Landslide,â€™ we love that song, as I think everyone does, and weâ€™ve always wanted to find a place for it. Weâ€™re so glad that we finally did. Maya loves that song, and actually, for her final stint as a DJ, we had earplugs, and so she was listening to that song while delivering her last squawk.

DEADLINE: In some ways, Henry gets a redemption in the end, but he isnâ€™t let off the hook. He says he ultimately chose to align himself with the Mind Flayer and is still choosing to do so, and Joyce actually does the honors of killing him. Can you tell me about settling on that ending and why it felt satisfying to you?

ROSS: We discussed having a redemption moment for him, as we did with, say, Billy in Season 3, but ultimately, it felt like Henry has gone too far now â€” and how much of that is him in there versus how much is the Mind Flayer, how much of it is just him unwilling to admit this, we want to leave that a little bit for the audience [to decide].

Obviously, Jamie did an incredible job conveying the complexity of emotions here, but ultimately, yeah, heâ€™s gone too far to let go of this, and as a result of all this trauma that heâ€™s caused, thatâ€™s why we wanted to give that moment to Joyce. The headshot moment was always in there, but it was in editorial where we ended up putting in these flashbacks as we wanted to make that moment a cathartic moment, as opposed to a stand up and cheer moment.

Itâ€™s a little more complicated than that, in that our heroes have suffered as a result of this evil and as a result of Henry, so even if there was still good inside of him, itâ€™s almost a cleansing of all that evil that heâ€™s done.

MATT: Right. It was kind of f*ck you, and then she chops his head off. We said [in the edit], â€˜Well, letâ€™s try a more emotional route and see if we can make this the most emotional decapitation ever.â€™

(L to R) Millie Bobby Brown as Eleven, Charlie Heaton as Jonathan Byers, Noah Schnapp as Will Byers, and Finn Wolfhard as Mike Wheeler in â€˜Stranger Thingsâ€™ Season 5. Courtesy of Netflix

DEADLINE: It is pretty symbolic, since Joyce has that axe in Season 1.

MATT: Exactly. She had to use that axe.

ROSS: We went through every character going, â€˜Who gets the final blow on Vecna?â€™ Then once we landed on Joyce with that axe, us and the writers were like â€˜Sheâ€™s got to be the one.â€™ It just feels right.

DEADLINE: Itâ€™s funny, because in Season 1, I remember thinking â€˜What the hell is she going to do with an axe?â€™

MATT: [Laughs]. Well, she chopped through a wall at Season 1, but it didnâ€™t accomplish anything. She swung at a demo this year, but then she finally put it to real, proper good use.

DEADLINE: How long did it take you to get the finale to 2 hours and 8 minutes? Was there a lot you had to cut?

MATT: Actually, not that long. I donâ€™t remember how long the first draft was. I think it was pretty normal in that theyâ€™re usually, like, 10 or 15 pages too fat, and then you just trim it down. We spent so long outlining it that the structure was pretty much intact. Our goal was to keep it around two hours and avoid a two and a half hour â€˜Piggybackâ€™ [Season 4, Episode 9]. I mean, two hours is pretty luxurious for a TV episode. We didnâ€™t want there to be any filler in there. So it always landed around two hours. Thereâ€™s not footage missing.

DEADLINE: You said thereâ€™s a hint in the finale about the spinoff you guys are working on. Can you give any hints about what the hint might be?

ROSS: I know. We were just talking about this. I donâ€™t know if I want to, but I will say, though, itâ€™s not Hopper mentioning Montauk. Thereâ€™s no Montauk spinoff. That was more of a wink to the fans, deep-cut fans that know that the show started as Montauk.

Itâ€™s obviously not Holly and the kids or anything like that. Itâ€™s something much smaller than that. Weâ€™ve said this before, the spinoff idea we have, it is early days, but it is an entirely new mythology. So, it is connected, and it is going to answer some questions that people have, and thereâ€™s some lingering questions that werenâ€™t answered in the finale that will be answered in the spinoff. But at the end of the day, itâ€™s got its own story and its own mythology.

DEADLINE: My last question for you is about the end credits. Theyâ€™re awesome. Can you tell me about creating them?

MATT: I donâ€™t remember where that came in the process. I think, actually, we were editing Season 5. We were in post production when we came up with the idea. We thought about [The Lord of the Rings] Return of the King a lot, just in terms of the length of the epilogue. I always defend the Return of the King epilogue, but Iâ€™m one of those hardcore Lord of the Rings fans, to the point where Iâ€™ve watched all extended editions in a row on a single day. If you do that, the epilogue feels absolutely perfect and not long at all. In fact, if it felt shorter, it would feel absolutely distressing.

I think, Stranger Things, if you watch Season 5 all the way through, itâ€™s going to feel great. You just want to spend extra time with these characters. Anyway, that was sort of the reference for the epilogue. Then we love the credits at the end of Return of the King. So that was the initial idea, and they were these very simple illustrations.

Then we started to talk with Imaginary Forces, which is the title company that did the main title sequence for the show, who we absolutely love and adore. We pitched that maybe it was Willâ€™s notebook of drawings, and then they came back like a week later and suggested, â€˜What if it was done actually in the style of a real D&D manual?â€™

Whatâ€™s cool about these D&D manuals is thereâ€™s color images, and, also, over the years, the style of illustration changes. They brought back illustrators from the actual 1980s who drew in the manuals all the way back then. So it really came full circle, and, mainly, we wanted it to feel finite, right? I mean, that was really the key. We wanted to feel like â€˜The End.â€™

ROSS: We wanted to pay tribute, I think, to all of our actors, and even the ones where we canâ€™t list their names contractually, whether itâ€™s Joe Quinn or Shannon Purser, who passed away sadly in the show.

From left: Joe Keery, Natalia Dyer, Charlie Heaton, Maya Hawke, Finn Wolfhard, Winona Ryder, Noah Schnapp, Gaten Matarazzo and Caleb McLaughlin in â€˜ Stranger Things 5 Courtesy of Netflix

MATT: Well, Shannon didnâ€™t pass away, Ross, letâ€™s be clear. It was Barb.

ROSS: Barb, yes.

MATT: Shannonâ€™s fine.

ROSS: Shannonâ€™s fine. [Chuckles]. We wanted to be able to pay tribute to our cast and how much theyâ€™ve grown through the years. Obviously, itâ€™s not to say the whole show was a D&D campaign. It was just a way to pay tribute to everyone and also let the audience, hopefully, take in this journey that theyâ€™ve been on for nine years.

Disney+ has acquired the Irish narrative short film â€œBrown Breadâ€ following a successful festival run that began with its world premiere at the Galway Film Fleadh in 2025.

The film is now streaming across Disney+ platforms throughout Europe.

Written and directed by Shaunagh Connaire, â€œBrown Breadâ€ marks the narrative debut from writer/director Shaunagh Connaire, the two-time Emmy-nominated Irish journalist who has produced documentaries for the likes of the BBC and PBS Frontline and also served as communication director for George and Amal Clooneyâ€˜s Foundation for Justice.

The film â€” described by Connaire as a â€œmodern twist on the Irish emigration storyâ€ â€” is led by Emmy-winning actress Fionnula Flanagan (â€œLost,â€ â€œThe Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakesâ€), Katie McGrath (â€œMerlin,â€ â€œSupergirlâ€) and Dermot Crowley (â€œLuther: The Fallen Sun,â€ â€œThe Death of Stalinâ€).

Popular on Variety

Inspired by Connaireâ€™s own experience of being unable to travel to Ireland from the U.S. to attend her godmotherâ€™s funeral, the story follows Ãine (McGrath), a woman whose return to Ireland from New York to attend her godmotherâ€™s memorial mass stirs up old tensions, grief, and unspoken affection in her rural family home. Flanagan stars as Betty, a proud but emotionally restrained mother struggling with her daughterâ€™s return, while Crowley plays Ãineâ€™s father Seamus.

â€œHaving my first scripted film acquired by Disney so early in its life is so wonderful,â€ said Connaire. â€œI wanted to tell a story rooted in Irish life but expansive enough to travel. To see that belief reflected in a global acquisition like this is incredibly affirming, and a reminder that small, specific stories can resonate far beyond where they begin.â€

Produced by Julie Ryan through her production company MK1 Studios, the film was shot entirely in Connaireâ€™s hometown of Longford, Ireland. Funding was provided by Creative Ireland (Longford), with additional support from Sam and Amelia Dennigan and Anne Heraty, who served as Associate Producers. The film is distributed by Network Ireland.

â€œFrom the outset, we felt Brown Bread was a very special film, not because it was trying to be big, but because it was precise, truthful and emotionally brave,â€ said Ryan. â€œWe were always thinking globally, and Shaunagh has an extraordinary instinct for character and tone that allows stories rooted in place to travel. Seeing a film made in rural Longford now finding a home with Disney reinforces our belief that stories rooted in Irish life can resonate well beyond their place of origin.

content:
Sources are telling us this morning that the Stranger Things finale cleared well north of $25M, possibly even $30M, in concession cash to movie theaters over its New Yearâ€™s Eve and New Years Day play.

Exhibition couldnâ€™t charge for tickets to The Netflix event given the castâ€™s contractual terms for residuals, hence the streamer and circuits got around this by reserving seats with concession vouchers. At AMC theaters, such concession vouchers cost $20 per seat.

Strangers Things finale played in over 620 locations, and the series creators, the Duffer Brothers, announced two days before the finale played theaters that 1.1 million seats were sold, a number that was ahead of KPop Demon Hunters RSVPs (700M) before itâ€™s late August two-day play. (though not on a weekend) â€” but itâ€™s not box office, itâ€™s concession cash which the movies theaters get to keep, and donâ€™t have co-share ala a regular studio film rental. Exhibition wants Netflix to commit to theatrical runs more, and the streamer will have contractual obligations to filmmakers once they complete their acquisition of Warner Bros. content:
The TV series â€œTehranâ€ returns to Apple TV next week even though production wrapped back in 2023. What caused the postponement of this critically acclaimed drama depicting dueling espionage efforts between Israel and Iran was never specified by the streaming service. But sensitivities regarding the real-life battles that have ravaged the Middle East are suspected of being a factor in the delayed return of â€œTehran,â€ which is co-produced by Israeli public broadcaster Kan 11.

But thatâ€™s far from the only sign of disruption in Israelâ€™s entertainment business these days. And while the struggles currently gripping the countryâ€™s film and TV industries arenâ€™t entirely attributable to the pall the Netanyahu administration has cast over just about anything with Israeli or even Jewish connections, itâ€™s an issue to be sure.

Popular on Variety

The cloud of controversy that has enveloped Israel since Oct. 7, 2023 was a much-discussed topic at this yearâ€™s inaugural Jerusalem Sessions event, held last month in the countryâ€™s capital city. Conversation touched on a chilling effect being felt in the marketplace of an important industry export: local TV shows into other global territories.

On the latest episode of the Variety podcast â€œStrictly Business,â€ hear from some of the industry pros who came to Jerusalem Sessions from the U.S., Europe and the host country to share their insights.

The Israeli TV industry has always prided itself for punching far above its weight in its ability to sell shows beyond its borders. First there was success in formats adapted to other languages in other countries, like the HBO series â€œIn Treatmentâ€ or Showtimeâ€™s â€œHomelandâ€ and â€œYour Honor.â€ More recently, Israel demonstrated its ability to capitalize on the increasingly global market for content opened up by the explosion of streaming services. TV shows like â€œFaudaâ€ and â€œShtiselâ€ that were never intended to play outside of Hebrew-speaking market found second and third lives in other countries in subtitled versions.

But the Israelis say this business is not as strong as it used to be, Productions with an Israeli provenance are feeling the pain regardless of whether the content is remotely controversial or even pertinent to the war. Plus there are other challenges: the Israeli industry may not have any bigger problem than the one its own government represents. The Israeli broadcaster KAN faces an existential threat of its own under fire from the Netanyahu administration. And the Israeli film world is no less beleaguered, with the government threatening to withdraw crucial funding sources when movies that dare to stray from the party line are recognized.

title: French Box Office Drops by 13% to Roughly $1.17 Billion in 2025, but Year-End Rebound Signals â€˜Positive Momentumâ€™ for 2026

content:
After a bullish year bolstered by local blockbusters, the 2025 French box office dropped by 13.6% to 156.79 million admissions, according to the National Film Board (CNC) and Comscore reports. Based on the average ticket price of â‚¬7.45 ($8.75), the box office grossed an estimated $1.17 billion.

While the market share of French films rose to 37.7% â€” which is â€œunrivaled anywhere else in Europe,â€ per the CNC â€” the box office suffered from the absence of a local tentpole and was essentially dominated by Hollywood fare. Disney took the first three slots of the year with â€œZootopia 2,â€ which topped the chart with 6.18 million admissions, followed by â€œLilo & Stitchâ€ (5.10 million) and James Cameronâ€™s â€œAvatar: Fire & Ashâ€ (4.58 million). Then came Apple and Plan Bâ€™s Brad Pitt racing drama â€œF1: The Movieâ€ (3.31 million) and Universalâ€™s â€œJurassic World: Renaissanceâ€ (2.97 million).

The biggest local hit of 2025, â€œGod Save the Tucheâ€ â€” the fifth installment in PathÃ©â€™s comedy franchise â€” sold around 3 million tickets and was the only French film which made it in the top 10 (in the sixth spot). Four local films appeared in the top 30, notably Cedric Jimenezâ€™s ambitious sci-fi thriller â€œDog 51.â€ Thatâ€™s a stark contrast from 2024, when the top three French films in 2024 (â€œA Little Something Extra,â€ â€œThe Count of Monte Cristoâ€ and â€œBeating Heartsâ€) had garnered 25 million admissions combined.

Popular on Variety

Internationally, France was the market that â€œshowed the most severe year-on-year decline in 2025,â€ Comscore said in its report, noting that markets such as Germany, China and Australia recorded growth. The U.S. and Canada saw a slight increase in box office revenue, while the U.K. ended the year on the same level as in 2024. But the CNC flags that France still hosts Europeâ€™s leading nation of moviegoers. Germany closed the year at roughly 85 million admissions, followed by Italy at 67 million and Spain at 65 million, per the CNC.

The breadth of local films released throughout the year contributed to the high market share. Several French titles posted solid runs; for instance Ken Scottâ€™s â€œOnce Upon My Motherâ€ crossed 1.4 million admissions, Franck Duboscâ€™s â€œUn ours dans le Juraâ€ reached around 1.4 million and Thierry Klifaâ€™s â€œThe Richest Woman in the Worldâ€ starring Isabelle Huppert sold nearly 900,000 tickets.

As it often is in France, auteur-driven cinema remained a bright spot, delivering sleeper hits and surpassing expectations. The CNC cited the strong performance of Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œOne Battle After Another,â€ Oliver Laxeâ€™s â€œSirÃ¢t,â€ Kleber MendonÃ§a Filhoâ€™s â€œThe Secret Agent,â€ Jafar Panahiâ€™s â€œIt Was Just an Accident,â€ Joachim Trierâ€™s â€œSentimental Value,â€ Ugo Bienvenuâ€™s â€œArcoâ€ and Hafsia Herziâ€™s â€œThe Little Sister.â€

â€œ2025 was a mixed year for theatrical cinema, with a declining market due to a lack of unifying films and surprise hits like in 2024, but with a sharp rebound at the end of the year, driven by a strong offering of films, particularly American ones,â€ said GaÃ«tan Bruel, president of the CNC. â€œThis result should not obscure the relevance of our model in the long term: a network of theaters with unparalleled density that allows a wide variety of films to reach all audiences, and a market share for domestic films that makes France an exception in Europe and around the world.â€

The year ended on a rebound, powered by a cluster of U.S. pics. Besides â€œZootopia 2â€³ and â€œAvatar: Fire and Ash,â€ Sydney Sweeney and Amanda Seyfriedâ€™s erotic thriller â€œThe Housemaidâ€ (released in France by Metropolitan Filmexport) proved to be a late-year hit, released on Dec. 24 and drawing 1.1 million admissions in just a week; as well as Vincent Munierâ€™s wildlife documentary â€œLe chant des foretsâ€ with 360,000 admissions.

Bruel is optimistic about the prospects for 2026. Addressing the healthy performance of director-led films, he argued that French audiences are lured by â€œoriginal and daring offerings.â€ He added, â€œFrom this point of view, 2026 promises to be a very rich year.â€

Among the most promising 2026 releases cited by the National Exhibitors Federation (FNCF) are: Christopher Nolanâ€™s â€œThe Odyssey,â€ Steven Spielbergâ€™s â€œDisclosure Day,â€ Andrew Stantonâ€™s â€œToy Story 5,â€ Antonin Baudryâ€™s â€œDe Gaulleâ€ and Philippe Lacheauâ€™s â€œMarsupilami.â€ Thereâ€™s also Denis Villeneuveâ€™s â€œDune: Part 3,â€ Ruben Ostlundâ€™s â€œThe Entertainment System is Down,â€ James Grayâ€™s â€œPaper Tigerâ€ and Alejandro GonzÃ¡lez IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s â€œDiggerâ€ in the pipeline.

title: Stephen Colbert Says â€˜Donâ€™t Trust Billionairesâ€™ When Asked About â€˜Major Lessonâ€™ of 2025: â€˜They Donâ€™t Get Rich by Finding That Money on the Side of the Roadâ€™
summary: Stephen Colbert capped off his 2025 with a video appearance on CNNâ€™s â€œNew Yearâ€™s Eve Liveâ€ with Andy Cohen and Anderson Cooper, where the former asked the late night host to tell viewers about the “major lesson” he learned during the year. content:
Stephen Colbert capped off his 2025 with a video appearance on CNNâ€™s â€œNew Yearâ€™s Eve Liveâ€ with Andy Cohen and Anderson Cooper, where the former asked the late night host to tell viewers about the â€œmajor lessonâ€ he learned during the year. Colbertâ€™s 2025 was defined by CBS canceling â€œThe Late Show.â€

â€œSo much has happened in the last year of your life,â€ Cohen said during the telecast in a nod to Colbertâ€™s cancellation. â€œI am curious what you left last year having learnedâ€¦ what is the major lesson you learned? Itâ€™s not a controversial question.â€

â€œDonâ€™t trust billionaires,â€ Colbert said and then immediately started laughing. â€œThey donâ€™t get rich by finding that money on the side of the road, brother!â€

Popular on Variety

Colbert announced in July CBSâ€™ decision to pull â€œThe Late Showâ€ off the air. Network executives said the decision was â€œpurely a financial decision against a challenging backdrop in late night,â€ but many in the industry figured the decision had more to do with David Ellisonâ€™s Paramount takeover. The news hit right as Ellisonâ€™s Skydance was acquiring CBSâ€™ parent company Paramount Global. Ellison has been aligning the company more with Donald Trump, who Colbert often bashes on â€œThe Late Show.â€ In fact, Colbert targeted both CBS and Trump a few days before news of his showâ€™s cancellation when he called out Paramount for paying $16 million to Trumpâ€™s estate to settle a lawsuit with Trump over a â€œ60 Minutesâ€ interview with Kamala Harris.

â€œAs someone who has always been a proud employee of this network, Iâ€™m offended, and I donâ€™t know if anything will ever repair my trust in this company,â€ Colbert said on the show at the time.

David Letterman, who created â€œThe Late Showâ€ and hosted the program from 1993 to 2015, was one of many public figures who reasoned Colbert was being canceled due to political reasons involving Ellison taking over Paramount. He called CBSâ€™ decision â€œpure cowardiceâ€ and said Ellison doesnâ€™t â€œwant any trouble along the lines of freedom of the press or free speech or freedom of expression. They donâ€™t want the government going after them, because that concept of freedom of the press and freedom of speech â€” thatâ€™s so old-fashioned.â€

In a GQ cover story published in November, Colbert was asked about his CBS showâ€™s sudden axing shortly after he criticized Paramountâ€˜s $16 million â€œ60 Minutesâ€ settlement with Trump and amid Paramountâ€™s wait for FCC approval for its merger with Skydance. Colbert said it wasnâ€™t unreasonable to think he was canceled for political reasons.

â€œMy reaction as a professional in show business is to go: That is the networkâ€™s decision,â€ Colbert said. â€œI can understand why people would have that reaction because CBS or the parent corporation â€” Iâ€™m not going to say who made that decision, because I donâ€™t know; no oneâ€™s ever going to tell us â€” decided to cut a check for $16 million to the president of the United States over a lawsuit that their own lawyers, Paramountâ€™s own lawyers, said is completely without merit. And it is self-evident that that is damaging to the reputation of the network, the corporation, and the news division. So it is unclear to me why anyone would do that other than to curry favor with a single individual.â€

Colbert added: â€œIf people have theories that associate me with that, itâ€™s a reasonable thing to think, because CBS or the corporation clearly did it once. But my side of the street is clean and I have no interest in picking up a broom or adding to refuse on the other side of the street. Not my problem. So people can have their theories. I have my feelings about not doing the show anymore, but youâ€™d have to show me why thatâ€™s a fruitful relationship for me to have with my network for the next nine months, for me to engage in that speculation.â€

â€œThe Late Showâ€ will sign off the air in May.

summary: In a 2025 that generated $8.87 billion at the domestic box office, 780 million people actually went to the movies. That’s roughly two visits a year for every person living in the United States; the nation’s population factored at an estimate of 347.3 million. However, admissions were down from EntTelligence’s 2024 figure of 820 million, […]
content:
In a 2025 that generated $8.87 billion at the domestic box office, 780 million people actually went to the movies.

Thatâ€™s roughly two visits a year for every person living in the United States; the nationâ€™s population factored at an estimate of 347.3 million.

However, admissions were down from EntTelligenceâ€™s 2024 figure of 820 million, by -4.9% with the previous 12 months seeing a spike in tickets prices across the board, read general price of admission was $13.29, + 5.7% from 2024, while the price of a premium large format ticket was $17.69, +4.9%.

The latest figures come from entertainment stat org EntTelligenceâ€™s annual report, which also says that moviegoers consumed over 95 billion minutes of features on the big screen in calendar year 2025.

Watch on Deadline

Pre-Pandemic, the industry averaged well over 1B tickets sold annually during the period of 2005 to 2019.

The annual report also provides some light on attendance in regards to windows and thatâ€™s that 35.6% of all moviegoers went to see movies in the first 3 days of release. Compare that to 73.2% of all attendees watched movies in their first 14 days of release, while 90.7% of all moviegoers headed to cinemas during picsâ€™ first 30 days of release.

Disney led all motion picture studios (of course) in admissions repping close to 26% of the 780M or 202.9M; the studioâ€™s domestic figure at $2.49 billion. Warner Bros repped 20.15% of admissions or 157.1M after $1.9 billion at the North American B.O. Universal films attendance was 17.96% (140M, $1.78B), Sonyâ€™s 6.4% (49.9M, $610.5M), Paramountâ€™s 6.4% (49.9M, $554M), Lionsgateâ€™s 3.9% (30.4M, $331M) and A24â€™s 2.77% (21.6M admissions). Disneyâ€™s admissions figure doesnâ€™t include Searchlight, Sonyâ€™s doesnâ€™t include Sony Classics, and Uniâ€™s doesnâ€™t count Focus Features in the EntTelligence calculation.

Among genres, most people attended action movies at 39.2% which actually had the highest average ticket at $13.88 over horror ($13.07, 11.56% attendance), drama ($12.85, 10.3% attendance), animation ($12.67; 14.4% attendance) and comedy ($12.50, 5.6% attendance).

PG family films were very popular and pulled in the lions share of admissions at 34.4%, followed by PG-13 with 31.5% and R-rated movies at 28.3%.

Among cities, Los Angeles had the most foot traffic at 8.97%, followed by New York with 6.48%, Dallas at 3.69%, Chicago at 3.28% and Houston with 3.13%.

Blue voting zones pulled in more moviegoers than red, 56.5% to 34.6%, and thatâ€™s because most movie theaters are located in Democrat leaning zip codes (as of the 2024 presidential election).

In demos, males and females were roughly even in admissions, 50.15% to 49.85%. Kids under 13 repped 10.76% of attendance while those over 60 years old repped 11.1% of attendance.

Per industry sources, the hope is that the domestic box office gets to $9 billion in 2026. The last time the box office hit that threshold post Covid was 2023, the year of Barbie and Oppenheimer.

content:
Angelina Jolie has visited the Egyptian side of the Rafah Crossing to see up close the terrifying humanitarian crisis impacting Gaza.

An AFP video this afternoon shows the Oscar-winning star speaking with aid workers and being shown around the crossing.

According to local press, Jolie made the visit to see the condition of injured Palestinians transferred to Egypt. TRT World reported that Jolie visited the Egyptian side of the crossing, speaking with members of the Red Crossâ€™s Red Crescent and truck drivers ferrying humanitarian aid into Gaza. A Red Crescent volunteer told Jolie that â€œthere are thousands of aid trucks just waitingâ€ at the border crossing, reported the outlet.

Image: AFP via Getty

The Rafah Crossing is the only crossing point between Egypt and Palestineâ€™s Gaza Strip, playing a major role in bringing aid into Gaza since the Israeli attacks that were a response to the October 7 2023 massacre. Although a ceasefire has been reached, humanitarian aid is still desperately needed. At least 70,000 people are reported to have been killed since the Israel-Hamas War started more than two years ago, according to the Hamas-run health ministry. Much of Gaza has been destroyed.

Watch on Deadline

Jolie is an Oscar-winning star of Girl, Interrupted, Tomb Raider and Mr & Mrs. Smith, but she is also known for her humanitarian work. As Special Envoy for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, she has travelled the world visiting refugee camps and war zones.

Every year, more people are trying a Dry January â€” abstaining from alcoholic drinks for a month â€” as a way to reset health priorities after the holidays or as a test run for an alcohol-free lifestyle. And now thereâ€™s also â€œDamp January,â€ which can mean whatever you want it to but often involves cutting down to weekend-only drinking or trying lower-proof alternatives. Another new approach to alcohol consumption is â€œzebra-ingâ€ â€” following an alcoholic drink with a non-alchoholic beverage to keep consumption moderate.

Celebrity entrepreneurs are diving into the non-alcoholic market with an array of new options. This year more guys are entering the chat: Tom Holland founded BERO based on his own Dry January experience, while a sober John Mulaney helped co-found Years Beer.

Katy Perryâ€™s De Soi, a line of sparkling ready-to-drink non-alcoholic apÃ©ritifs with natural adaptogens, has NA alternatives for dozens of cocktails such as Moscow Mules and Spicy Margaritas. Meanwhile, Blake Livelyâ€™s Betty Buzz mixers work on their own or mixed with either conventional or zero-proof spirits. Meanwhile Bella Hadid is an investor in Kin Euphorics, while RuPaulâ€™s House of Love mocktails come in flavors like ginger mule and colada. Bethenny Frankel backs Mingle Mixers, versatile flavors for mixing or drinking solo.

With new choices coming on the scene every month, thereâ€™s no excuse for thinking alcohol-free means boring. Here are a few of the established and brand-new ways to nail Dry January, and the rest of the year, too.

Spirits

Seedlip Notas de Agave Seedlipâ€™s agave zero-proof spirit incorporates bright notes of lime and prickly pear, interwoven with herbal, fruity aromas of vanilla and citrus. title: Stephen Schwartz Pulls Out of Kennedy Centerâ€™s 2026 Lineup: â€˜Thereâ€™s No Way I Would Set Foot in It Nowâ€™
summary: Stephen Schwartz, the songwriter behind classic musicals from “Godspell” to “Wicked,” has revealed he will not be taking part in a program devoted to spotlighting him at the Kennedy Center on May 16. “It no longer represents the apolitical place for free artistic expression it was founded to be,” Schwartz said in an email sent […]
content:
Stephen Schwartz, the songwriter behind classic musicals from â€œGodspellâ€ to â€œWicked,â€ has revealed he will not be taking part in a program devoted to spotlighting him at the Kennedy Center on May 16.

â€œIt no longer represents the apolitical place for free artistic expression it was founded to be,â€ Schwartz said in an email sent to Newsday by his assistant. â€œThereâ€™s no way I would set foot in it now.â€

The evening is still advertised on the website of the D.C. institution, but Schwartz told Newsday he has not heard anything about it since last February, so assumed it had been canceled amid the changes with the Trump administrationâ€™s takeover of the center. Even if the show were scheduled to go on, he said, he would decline to attend on principle.

Popular on Variety

â€œLast year, way before the change of Board and name of the Kennedy Center, I was invited by (director) Francesca Zambello to be part of a Washington National Opera event on May 16, 2026,â€ Schwartz said in the email sent to Newsday. â€œBut Iâ€™ve heard nothing about it since February 2025, so I have assumed itâ€™s no longer happening. I canâ€™t imagine Francesca continuing under the current circumstances. If it is happening, of course I will not be part of it.â€

Schwartz joins a growing list of artists and performers who have pulled out of appearances scheduled for the venue, including a recent torrent who pulled out after the largely Trump-installed board voted to add the current presidentâ€™s name atop John F. Kennedyâ€™s, with no legal basis for renaming a national monument.

The pullout by Schwartz has symbolic value: He was the co-writer of the program that opened the Kennedy Center back in 1971, â€œMass,â€ a collaboration with Leonard Bernstein.

Schwartz was one of very few big-name figures left who had a performance scheduled at the Kennedy Center in 2026. Variety scanned the list of events on the ticketing page for the venue, and Renee Fleming and Tyrese are among the only celebrities on the docket. Otherwise, the programming at this point is mostly devoted to orchestral attractions and other institutional fare, along with childrenâ€™s programming, a recurring comedy show and touring musicals. A handful of jazz and Americana performances by individual artists dot the schedule, mostly by artists without a large national profile.

Among the most recent cancellations listed is a set of performances by the Asian comedy troupe â€œAsian AF,â€ listed as â€œcanceledâ€ on the Kennedy Center site although the shows still appear on the comedy groupâ€™s own website.

The Schwartz featured appearance still listed on the centerâ€™s website for May is a gala under the aegis of the Washington National Opera. â€œWitness the links between musical theater and opera come alive in this thrilling concert!â€ the promotional copy promises. â€œAcclaimed musical theater lyricist and composer Stephen Schwartz curates and hosts for one night only, bringing together an exciting lineup of soloists to perform beloved repertory.â€

UPDATE â€” Jan 2, 8:58 PT: The driver who was behind the wheel of the car that crashed on a Nigerian motorway, injuring British boxer Anthony Joshua and killing two others, has been charged.

Adeniyi Mobolaji Kayode was charged at the Sagamu Magistratesâ€™ Court in Nigeria on Friday. Local authorities have said the charges are causing death by dangerous driving, reckless and negligent driving, driving without due care, and driving without a valid driverâ€™s licence. The case has been adjourned until January 20.

Joshuaâ€™s personal trainer, Latif Ayodele, and strength coach, Sina Ghami, died in the crash. The car they were being driven in crashed into a stationary truck on a busy highway near Lagos. Joshua was taken to the hospital with minor injuries and was discharged a few days later.

ORIGINAL STORY: British boxer Anthony Joshua has been injured in a car crash in Nigeria that killed two other people.

Watch on Deadline

The accident happened on the Lagosâ€“Ibadan Expressway, Nigeriaâ€™s busiest highway, on Monday. Local police told the BBC in a statement that Joshua has been taken to the hospital and his injuries are minor.

The officials said Joshua is doing â€œfine.â€ Graphic and unverified videos of the crash and its aftermath were posted across social media sites this morning. The Nigerian Federal Road Safety Corps posted a series of snaps from the crash site across its social media accounts with the caption: FRSC OPERATIVES RESCUE ANTHONY JOSHUA AS TWO DIE FROM OGUN STATE FATAL CRASH.

https://twitter.com/FRSCNigeria/status/2005642653720068209

Joshua, a former world champion and Olympic gold medallist, was born in Watford, England, to British Nigerian parents. The fighter is coming fresh off his exhibition bout with YouTuber Jake Paul.

Joshua defeated Paul via knockout in the sixth round. Paul was hospitalized after suffering a broken jaw. The fight, organized by Paulâ€™s Most Valuable Promotions, is the former YouTuberâ€™s second live event on Netflix following his bout with Mike Tyson. Paul had been scheduled to fight Gervonta Davis next. But that fight was canceled when the latter became embroiled in a civil lawsuit where he was accused of battery, aggravated battery, false imprisonment, kidnapping, and intentional infliction of emotional distress by ex-girlfriend Courtney Rossel.

Netflix reported that the Paul and Joshua fight attracted 10.9M views. That put it in third place for the week. The figure is substantially lower than the audience for Paulâ€™s Mike Tyson matchup. That fight racked up 46.6M views. The Tyson and Paul fight was No. 1 in 78 countries and in the Top 10 in all 91 countries that Netflix tracks.
